agenda, I should like, in keeping with established practice, to draw the attention of the General Assembly to a letter addressed to me by the Secretary-General [A/S-I3/5], informing the Assembly that two Member States are in arrears in the payment of their financial contributions to the United Nations within the terms of Article 19 of the Charter.
AGENDA ITEM 4
Election of the President of the General Assembly
6.	The TEMPORARY PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I now invite the Assembly to proceed to the election of the President of the General Assembly. In this connection, it should be noted that the Preparatory Committee of the Whole for the Special Session of the General Assembly on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa recommended that the President of the General Assembly at its fortieth session, Mr. Jaime de Piniés of Spain, should serve in the same capacity at the thirteenth special session. May I take it that the General Assembly adopts that recommendation?
It was so decided (decision S-13/12).
Statement by the President
I.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I wish to take this opportunity to convey to the members of the General Assembly my profound gratitude at the honour which they have conferred upon me by entrusting to me the presidency of this special session. I am sincerely grateful for the confidence that has been placed in me.
8.	A few months ago it was my privilege, during the fortieth session, to preside over the meetings of the General Assembly held in connection with the commemoration of the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations. That was a memorable occasion. The leaders of Member States, large and small, from all over the world appeared before the Assembly to reaffirm their commitment to the fundamental principles of the Charter and their support for the United Nations. But we must also remember the words of the Secretary-General at the closing meeting on 24 October 1985, that “devotion to principles needs to express itself in concrete, workable proposals and not in rhetoric only” [see 49th meeting, para. 8].
9.	In my view, therein lies precisely the purpose of the special session on the critical economic situation in Africa. One of the purposes of the United Nations enunciated in the Charter is the achievement of international co-operation in solving international problems of an economic, social, cultural and humanitarian character. All of us have endorsed that purpose; therefore it is our task in these meetings to give practical content to it by agreeing on concrete, workable proposals to support the efforts made by our brothers in Africa fully to develop the possibilities and potential of their continent, and thus
to make a greater contribution to the prosperity and wellbeing of the world.
10.	This is no easy task. We are all aware of the great variety and complexity of the problems facing the countries of Africa. The emergency caused by the recent drought emphasized the fragile nature of the present situation. Many of the questions that have been raised have a bearing on matters which have been debated without results here in the United Nations and in other forums. If it is desired that effective progress be made in this regard, it is necessary to adopt new, imaginative and creative approaches. None the less, the time available to us at this session is extremely limited.
11.	However grave the obstacles we face, I am convinced that there are genuine grounds for optimism. In the first place, I am impressed and extremely satisfied with the level of representation at this session. Member States have thereby demonstrated the importance they attach to our efforts. In this regard, I should like to extend a special welcome to Mr. Abdou Diouf, President of Senegal and current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity.
12.	His presence at this session gives ground for optimism and demonstrates the clear and genuine commitment of the Governments of Africa to do whatever is necessary to restore and accelerate the rate of economic and social development in their countries. This is the message contained in the Declaration on the Economic Situation in Africa adopted by the Assembly of Heads' of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity at its twenty-first session, held at Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 July 1985, which was given concrete expression in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.2 
13.	The decision of the African Governments means that they have to make real sacrifices. Their will does not depend on external support, but it is clear that this support is necessary if the efforts of the African Governments are to be successful without unnecessary delay and human suffering. In this respect, I am convinced that those that have associated themselves with Africa in the task of development by adopting by consensus at the thirty-ninth session of the General Assembly the Declaration on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa [resolution 39/29, annex], and by adopting at the fortieth session the resolution whereby it was decided to convene this special session [resolution 40/40], have shown their determination to respond positively by providing the necessary assistance.
14.	Finally, I welcomed the genuine solidarity with which the international community responded recently to the emergency caused by the drought that afflicted many countries in Africa. Whatever the sceptics may say, that response has shown that human solidarity really exists and that when we all work together it is possible to do the impossible.
15.	Let me take this opportunity also to extend a welcome to the representatives of the intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations invited to attend this session. The constant contribution of those organizations to the solution of the problems of Africa should be a source of inspiration to us in our debates.
16.	For many years I have had the opportunity to take part personally in the work of the General Assembly. I am aware of our failings and weaknesses, but I am also aware of the successes of the Assembly. During the fortieth session, in my closing statement at the end of the meetings commemorating the fortieth anniversary, I said:
“For many individuals all over the world, the United Nations is primarily synonymous with the struggle against hunger, with improving communications, with giving health assistance, and so many other fields in which multilateral co-operation offers benefits in a tangible and direct fashion.” [See 49th meeting, para. 30.]
17.	In the week which is now beginning let us work together to turn this image into a reality for Africa. We must do so because the problem of Africa is our own problem. We must do so because “We the peoples of the United Nations” have solemnly resolved to unite our strength to achieve peace and security and to promote the economic and social advancement of all peoples.
18.	The Secretary-General wishes to address the General Assembly at this time; I now call on him.
Statement by the Secretary-General
19.	The SECRETARY-GENERAL (interpretation from French): This special session of the General Assembly is taking place at a crucial juncture in the economic life of Africa. The importance which Member States attach to it is indicated by the level and quality of their representation here today. The presence among us of the current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity, Mr. Diouf, President of the Republic of Senegal, further emphasizes the significance that the African countries attach to the work of this session. It is both a great honour and a privilege for us to be able to count on his experience and wisdom, which I am sure will serve as a source of inspiration in our discussions.
20.	The gravity of the economic situation in Africa is a matter of profound concern to me. My memory of the tragedy I witnessed when I visited the drought-affected regions of that continent is still vivid: thousands of men, women and children condemned to starvation and death, populations uprooted, the sick without hope of relief for their suffering because of inadequate medical facilities and supplies, and many of the survivors condemned to be handicapped for life.
21.	I concluded at the time that only through bold measures, within the framework of real co-operation based on international solidarity, would it be possible to avert economic catastrophe on that continent and revive the process of medium- and long-term development. Accordingly, I convened a series of meetings with Member States and representatives of specialized agencies to address the rapidly deteriorating situation, and as a result established an Office for Emergency Operations in Africa with the aim of saving the populations in immediate danger. 
22.	The tragedy of famine brought together the peoples of the whole world, who, in a remarkable movement of solidarity, responded generously to the appeal for assistance. This movement of solidarity, added to Africa’s own efforts, has saved millions of lives. While, with the return of the much-needed rains, the emergency situation has now become localized in only a small number of countries, the need for the international community to maintain the solidarity displayed in the face of the famine and transform it into a force for the recovery and long-term development of the continent remains. We cannot passively accept the possibility that the horrors of famine might again visit Africa in the next drought, as they surely will unless all of us here act energetically to prevent a repetition of the catastrophe.
23.	This session is an opportunity for the international community as a whole, in a joint effort with the African
countries, to adopt the measures that are so urgently needed. Africa has long recognized the need for an effective, concerted programme of action to promote social and economic growth based on self-reliance. The Lagos Plan of Action3 clearly reflects this concern.
24.	This was reaffirmed by the heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity [OAU] in July last year at their Assembly’s twenty-first session; and was given specific content in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 for the next five years. At the same time, African Governments, convinced/that the United Nations system, in particular the General Assembly is an effective forum for sensitizing and mobilizing the international community, called for the convening of this special session. By agreeing unanimously to the OAU’s call for a special session of the General Assembly, the States Members of the United Nations assumed a clear commitment to work together towards that goal. 
25.	The international community cannot stand by and allow a further deterioration in the ability of the vast majority of African countries to meet their basic needs. Many of them find themselves crippled by their inability to maintain even minimal levels of essential imports on which their economic structures largely depend. Internal and external factors have complicated the situation— among them, on the one hand, the. widespread low level of productivity and the lack of structural transformation and, on the other, steeply rising debt service payments, depressed commodity prices and flagging flows of capital and credit. Furthermore, policies pursued by African Governments have sometimes been based on assumptions which have not always proved to be appropriate, or have not materialized.
[The speaker continued in English.] 
26.	The African countries are fully aware that their economic recovery is primarily their own responsibility. Whatever the magnitude of international assistance, it can only supplement their own efforts and sacrifices. This point was clearly affirmed at the meeting of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government in July 1985 at Addis Ababa. In Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery adopted at that meeting, African countries committed themselves to restructuring their economies and to introducing the appropriate policy reforms and adjustments, The Programme places emphasis on such key areas as agriculture, human resource development and the fight against drought and desertification.
27.	The cost and the sacrifices involved in that endeavour are enormous and well beyond the means of the countries affected. Although the largest part of the resources needed to implement the Programme will be generated locally, an increase in the inflow of external resources, particularly concessional finance, commensurate with the scale of the crisis is indispensable if the effort is. to succeed in a reasonable period of time. In recent months I have been in continuous consultation with President Diouf on the situation, and there has been close co-operation between the OAU and the United Nations.
28.	The international community has extended substantial support to Africa over the years. However, it. is obvious that this assistance has not always met expectations. This also applies to the support provided by the United Nations system. The proliferation and haphazard growth of projects have often harmed the development of recipient countries and made aid as much a part of the problems as their solution. The special session therefore provides the opportunity for the international community not only to make a clear commitment to provide
the necessary resources, but also to undertake the necessary changes in aid practice and co-ordination in order to maximize the efficiency and effectiveness of the assistance provided.
29.	The special session has raised considerable hope in the hearts of millions of Africans. It is an opportunity for a new beginning in co-operation between African countries and their development partners. It is of paramount importance that the representatives of Africa who are attending it return to their respective countries with the assurance that a strong and durable partnership is emerging between Africa and the rest of the world.
30.	The special session can mark only the beginning of a fresh effort that needs to be sustained over time. It is therefore important that agreement be reached on adequate follow-up action and the monitoring of results achieved. However, it is essential that the African countries receive during the session a clear indication of their partners’ intentions, so that they may plan their own development on a realistic basis.	-
31.	African countries are embarking on a new course towards development. If they are left to pursue it alone, it will inevitably involve many great sacrifices and much delay. On the other hand, if the international community assists them in a substantial way their suffering will be reduced and delays, which in the final analysis would be detrimental to all, will be averted.
32.	I therefore appeal to all Governments represented here to make this new partnership a success. Failure to do this will not only deprive Africans of an opportunity to lay the foundation for sustainable development, but also deprive the rest of the world of the benefits that would assuredly follow for all humanity. At this special session we share the responsibility to work for a better future for the peoples of Africa, both as a matter of conscience and, above all, because we live in a world in which solidarity is the only guarantee of our survival. We must win the race against time. 
33.	I speak on behalf of all my colleagues of the United Nations system in assuring the Assembly that we are prepared to play our full role in carrying out the decisions of this important session, which must succeed through the common efforts of all.  
Address by Mr. Abdou Diouf, President of the Republic of Senegal and current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity
34.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish):The General Assembly will now hear an address by the President of the Republic of Senegal and current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity. On behalf of the Assembly, I have the honour to welcome to the United Nations Mr. Abdou Diouf and to invite him to address the Assembly. 
35.	Mr. DIOUF (interpretation from French): Our meeting here today, at the Headquarters of the United Nations, where for the first time a special session of the General Assembly is being devoted to the economic problems of a single continent”, Africa, at a time when a particularly difficult international situation is encouraging nations to concentrate on their own affairs or to defend short-term interests, in my opinion constitutes an act of faith. Jt is an act of faith by Africa in the ability of the international community to act together and in its generosity; it is also an act of faith by our continent’s international partners in Africa’s-destiny; lastly, it is an act of faith by the whole international community,in the
spirit of solidarity, interdependence and international co-operation which remains the solid foundation of the United Nations. That explains the fact that on this highly symbolic occasion I am addressing the international community, with emotion and respect, aware of the privilege afforded to Africa through me. Please believe me when I say that I am fully aware of the honour and the importance of the occasion. From the very outset I would express the fervent hope that the-results of our work will translate this act of faith into well-defined, concrete and manageable measures.
36.	Having made that preliminary comment, I wish to congratulate you most warmly, Sir, on your unanimous election to the presidency of the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly, an election which eloquently reflects the outstanding qualities you have shown in the ■past. Above all, I assure you of Africa’s spirit of cooperation and availability.
37.	We also fully appreciate the continued, discreet and effective efforts made by the Secretary-General, his staff and all the agencies and bodies of the United Nations system, as well as the high-calibre contribution made by the intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations, to ensure that this historic session takes place in the best conditions.
38.	We express our gratitude, too, to the Preparatory Committee of the Whole—and, through it, to the General Assembly—for thé positive response which has been given to the African request and which is confirmed bÿ the high-level representation of all States. We are grateful for the outstanding work done in the preparation of this session. No less could have been expected of the Preparatory Committee, headed as it was by Mr. Pisani, with whose special interest and even passionate involvement in all third-world issues we are familiar.
39.	Now that I have paid those tributes, the Assembly will no doubt be wondering what kind of language I shall be speaking here. Well, I can answer that question simply and clearly: I shall endeavour to speak the language of hope, but, above all, the language of truth, of moderation and of responsibility—the very language that I spoke here last October when I addressed the fortieth session of the General Assembly at its 42nd meeting and, on behalf of Africa, requested the convening of this session.
40.	Even though today, thanks inter alia to united and generous action by the international community, the urgent situation that prevailed in most of the African continent is not so acute, the crisis itself remains—indeed, perdures. For, having structural bases and affecting all the world’s economies, that crisis naturally poses a challenge to the social structures, the cultural norms and the values on which our civilization rests. In fact, It may be that the use of the word “crisis”, which economics has borrowed from medicine and which we know it describes as the acute phase of an illness—after which, if the ill person has not died, there is a steady return to health— has contributed to disorienting our analyses.
41.	In respect of the world economy, the idea that the. present situation is temporary and that there will then be a.return to normalcy seems, we must recognize, to be increasingly unrealistic. On the contrary, we are moving towards a new state of the world which , is difficult to describe completely, in all its facets. It is therefore not a crisis that we are experiencing but a situation of enormous change. None the less, this will have proved to be beneficial. It will have served to reveal, to project a harsh light on, our failings and on the wrong courses we have taken and to point a critical finger at our strategy. Indeed, it will have once again shed blinding light on that continent of paràdox, Africa, where—because of the
extraversion of our economies and the weakness of our production and our productivity, but also because of the rigidity and inequity of the international economic system—a vast natural and human potential coexists with famine, illiteracy and the most dire poverty.
42.	These structural deficiencies have been aggravated by natural disasters, the decline in commodity prices, the crushing burden of the debt and its servicing, stagnation—indeed, the decrease in real terms of financial flows towards Africa—and the high concentration of refugees and displaced persons.
43.	A situation as serious as that requires structural change and medium- and long-term solutions. It requires a new approach to development in Africa and the improvement of the framework of international co-operation. That is why, courageously drawing the consequences of that terrible reality, the heads of State and Government, on the basis of the Lagos Plan of Action3 and the Final Act of Lagos,4 devoted most of their twenty-first summit conference, held in July 1985 at Addis Ababa, to a thorough consideration of the African economic crisis and on that occasion adopted Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990? That Programme should make it possible -for Africa to attain food self-reliance and the objective of economic growth and self-focused and self-sustained development at the national, regional and continental levels, and thus to bring about a lasting reversal of the profound trends that have led a large number of African countries to distressing macro-economic changes and to desperate emergency situations.
44.	All the members of the Assembly are familiar with the Priority Programme. I shall not dwell on it, therefore, except to emphasize that agriculture is the core of all our work and the corner-stone of the entire conceptual edifice proposed for the Assembly’s consideration. Each and every African country is invited first of all to see its economy as one based on the rural and agricultural sector. The fundamental needs of the rural population, the supplies that they require, the mobilization of their working hours, their income, their health and appropriate training, the marketing, transport and processing of their goods: all that is the fundamental concern. .
45.	The Priority Programme proposes, in fact, an integrated approach to economic development which gives agriculture the role of the primary sector of production and the centre for intersectoral relations. Thus, agriculture becomes the priority of priorities for Africa, since it is, within the Priority Programme, the subject of specific measures gathered together in a special programme of action for the improvement of the food situation and the rehabilitation of agriculture.
46.	Thus, with the establishment of an early-warning system at the national level, co-ordinated at the regional level, measures are envisaged to handle emergency food situations. Likewise, going beyond the short term, all the member countries of the OAU have committed themselves to devoting 20 to 25 per cent of their public investment to agriculture for the rehabilitation of that sector.' Lastly, with regard to structural reform measures, the African heads of State have recognized that in order to promote agricultural development it is essential to. strengthen agriculture’s support systems. That is why, in order to support the agricultural sector, the Priority Programme attaches very special importance to giving new dynamism to transport, communications and industry, as well as to.the extension of arable land, to the development of human resources and to research on and. struggle against drought and desertification.
47.	As can be seen, the Priority Programme is the very essence of the collective and individual resolve of African countries to undertake the economic recovery of the continent, with agriculture as the central theme. It reflects the profound desire of Africa to put an end to the recurrence of famine, to improve the lot of the poorest sectors of the population, to restore agriculture and to resolve the dreadful problem posed by inexorable desertification. It reflects above all the choosing of new economic development priorities giving the restoration of agriculture and the improvement of the food situation the attention and the role they deserve. The determination and serious approach of the African leaders towards the implementation of reforms have indeed been recognized and welcomed by the World Bank in its latest report devoted to Africa.
48.	It is on the basis of the Priority Programme, and in anticipation of the holding of the present session, that the Permanent Steering Committee of the OAU, taking fully into account the suggestions and contributions made by various bodies of the United Nations system, submitted a document5 to which the Preparatory Committee of the Whole for the Special Session gave due consideration before submitting its own recommendations to the Assembly. Africa intends that document to be a contribution towards facilitating and stimulating the work of the session. It aims at providing a thorough and objective analysis of the causes of the African crisis; above all, it would demonstrate the efforts the African countries have pledged to overcome the crisis, and also what is expected of the international community. The greatest care was taken in its preparation, since the data serving as its basis was first gathered from member States and then compared with other data from competent international organizations, in particular the World Bank, the African Development Bank and EGA.
49.	As can be seen, our document has above all sought to be specific in arriving at a comprehensive and detailed assessment of the cost and the distribution of the financing for Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery. We sincerely believe that Africa is not asking for something that is impossible, for we know that in these very difficult times, those impatient souls who, like Antigone, “want everything and right away” are mistaken.
50.	In their analyses and recommendations the African proposals have broadly taken into account the emerging consensus in the international community on the causes of and the solutions to the “African ailment”. In other words, what, we have is a shared platform, an effort at reaching a compromise on decisions to be taken to meet the major challenge posed by the critical economic situation in Africa.
51.	As the members of the Assembly will have noted, Africa’s proposals are addressed, it is true, to the other members of the international community, but they are also addressed to the African countries themselves. That is why in their proposals the African countries are stressing the mobilization of internal resources for the development of priority sectors, as well as the improved use of both internal and external resources. That also explains why our countries are asking the international community for only a complementary financial contribution amounting to 30 per cent of the total cost of the Priority Programme in order that they may be in a position to implement that Programme.
52.	In that respect they particularly wish to see the Priority Programme accepted as the general framework for assistance by the international community to Africa, since we are convinced that in order to arrive at consistent
and effective assistance policies it is important that project support be placed in the priority framework of programme support. Similarly, measures aimed at improving the framework for co-operation should be taken especially through consultations between donors and recipients, in order to enhance the co-ordination of aid policies and to see to it that the assistance really does contribute to the development of the recipient country. Lastly, it is important that effective measures be taken to alter the international economic climate, especially through the stabilization of prices for raw materials at remunerative levels, an increase in concessional financing towards Africa and an easing of the debt burden and its servicing.
53.	To mention easing of the debt burden and debtservicing in our recommendations, while at the same time requesting the convening in an appropriate forum of a conference on this subject, deserves some explanation, which I shall now provide briefly. That the debt problem has been touched upon in the framework of this special session is because, in spite of all the efforts our own countries must make, it is illusory to believe that the African economies can experience growth rates that meet their real needs in the absence of adequate solutions to certain outside constraints, such as the debt and debtservicing, which are beyond our control but whose weight places a heavy burden on our development prospects. Hence, if immediate measures are not taken by the African countries and their creditors in order to ease the burden of debt-servicing, the level of payments such debt-servicing implies will constitute a serious handicap to all economic and social development efforts on the continent.
54.	Policy adjustments by the donor countries and by the recipient countries must take place in the framework of ongoing dialogue and in a spirit of equal partnership based on mutual interest. In other words, it will be a matter of arriving at the end of this session at agreements and understandings in which the contribution of each partner will be clearly defined and strictly respected in the next five years on the basis of assessment procedures and follow-up machinery such as those outlined in the African proposals.
55.	For its part, Africa pledges to mobilize all its energy and all its resources for the attainment of the objectives defined in the Priority Programme by taking significant austerity and adjustment measures at the domestic level. Africa has also sought to strengthen and broaden intraAfrican co-operation. Furthermore, the African countries are arduously working with the other developing countries for the implementation of the Caracas Programme of Action6 and the Plan of Action of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries.7 In this respect I am pleased to emphasize that the implementation of the Priority Programme must go hand in hand with the intensification of South-South co-operation. Indeed, the objective of Africa’s economic recovery fits into the framework of the North-South dialogue and is included in the efforts aimed at relaunching the process of development in the countries of the South in general. Hence it is an integral part of the consultations and negotiations under way for the establishment of a more just and equitable international economic order.
56.	This brings me to the conclusion of my statement. Forecasts have already been provided to the effect that if things continue on their present course only a few African countries will survive. This is certainly a very pessimistic prospect, even apocalyptic, but it reflects better than any speech what is really at stake at this special session. That is why I am convinced that by agreeing to
meet today to consider ways and means of helping Africa to face up to the twofold challenge of survival and development the international community has shown that it is aware of what is at stake, thereby once again demonstrating that mankind, in the diversity of its components, possesses the moral and material resources that can make it possible to meet the challenges—all the challenges—of our times. ' ■
57.	If, as Livy affirmed, ‘ ‘good faith usually engenders good faith”, then Africa is assured that the work of this session will take place in an atmosphere of total mutual trust. In that case, above and beyond the exchange of ideas, above and beyond the most relevant of analyses and indicators calling on us to mistrust ideological quarrels or confining words that only erect barriers for obscure reasons, we shall be keeping the main point uppermost in mind: the survival of a continent, the economic recovery of Africa.
58.	At a time when the United Nations has proclaimed 1986 the International Year of Peace, I assert that there will be no genuine and comprehensive peace as long as an entire continent, Africa, is threatened by famine, sickness, ignorance and an uncertain future, not to mention acts of aggression and destabilization committed against the independent countries of southern Africa by the scandalous apartheid régime installed in South Africa.
59.	Is development not the new name of peace?
60.	The peoples of Africa, crushed by the weight of the vast changes we are experiencing and torn between hope and doubt, turn to us, and since the recovery of the African economy is a problem of concern to all mankind, the world is observing what we do. All expect of us genuine, concrete and manageable decisions. I fervently hope that we shall meet those expectations fully.
61.	Then and only then will our session be more than an uncertain step forward, more than a glimmer in an approaching night: it will be a new beginning or, in terms of economic performance, a turning-point.
62.	I thank you for your kind attention and wish you every success in your task.
63.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): On behalf of the General Assembly, I wish to thank the President of the Republic of Senegal and current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government' of the Organization of African Unity for the important statement he has just made.
AGENDA ITEM 5
Adoption of the agenda and organization of work
64.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I call on the Chairman of the Preparatory Committee of the Whole for the Special Session of the General Assembly on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa,, Mr. Edgard Pisani of France.
65.	Mr. PISANI (France), Chairman of the Preparatory Committee of the Whole (interpretation from French): For lack of time, the Preparatory Committee has not been able to ensure that the special session has before it from the outset a final text. Accordingly, a whole process of negotiation will have to take place alongside the general debate and will have to be approached by everyone with the political will to bring it to a substantive outcome. This being the case, I trust members will accept that the ideas I have the honour to put before them cannot be binding on the Preparatory Committee itself. They are those of a
man who participated in its work, admittedly from a privileged vantage point.
66.	The Preparatory Committee’s task was both facilitated and made more arduous by the publication at the beginning of April of a major document5 for which the responsibility rests with the OAU, but for which part of the credit is due to ECA. This document, which stems in a direct line from the Lagos Plan of Action,3 presents an unvarnished analysis of the situation in the continent and the policies which prevail there, proposes guidelines and sets priorities. It identifies needs. It is an act of courage and clearsightedness. After reading it, we cannot plead ignorance of the essential facts, but by the same token it is impossible, once we have taken cognizance of it, to engage in a rhetorical exercise on the subject of Africa. The new and commendable rigour on the part of the Governments responsible for it must be echoed by a commitment on the part of the international community.
67.	The work of the Preparatory Committee took place over a period of weeks and in a political environment that was not conducive to reaching agreement. The emergence of the Western Sahara problem, the bombing of Tripoli and Benghazi and the commando operations against three sovereign States of southern Africa reminded us that Africa is'a continent of tension and uncertainties. Over and above the critical situation which the Assembly has chosen to discuss, there remain places of conflict in which neighbour is opposed to neighbour, but not in total isolation from outside forces. This has made us mindful that the.debate is not only economic, and not only African, in scope: it is a world-wide politico-strategic debate. 68. In the very last days of its brief existence the Preparatory Committee followed attentively the course taken around the world by the runner and the flame. The essential is, of course, not the flame itself: the flame is a symbol. The event is the extraordinary upsurge of popular support to which its passage has given rise. Millions of human beings have raised their voices in an indication of their concern and their will. Can it be that this genuine expression of international opinion, this informal but resolute will on the part of the human community, has not yet given rise to agreement on Africa’s needs and on the resources that must be made available to it? The political leaders assembled here can no longer overlook the fact that, as proclaimed by world opinion on Sunday, Africa is their problem, not just that of Africans, that Africa needs assistance and that the world needs to be better organized.
69.	Whatever the sums raised to the beat of orchestras or the champion’s stride, Africa’s problem is of such dimensions that solidarity can come to grips only with its consequences; only the will of the world’s political leaders can remedy its causes. Africa needs substantial outside support, with which only a renewed public effort in the developed countries can provide it. Thanks are due to the non-governmental organizations and to the teeming masses, but their action must be supported and their message heard by those in positions of authority.
70.	The detailed technical and financial negotiations between the African Governments and their development partners cannot take place at the General Assembly session, but no one would understand it if the end result were a text similar in all respects to texts which 10 or 100 times already have set the seal on international debates on the same subject. Neither a conference of donors nor an exercise in rhetoric—what then is the real meaning of this special session?
71.	In deciding to call for it, the African Governments made it incumbent upon themselves to put forward
proposals and enter into commitments. They have put forward these proposals and entered into these commitments. The World Bank is here to say that the African Governments have made the necessary arrangements and that all that is now missing is the external resources required to implement the policies decided upon. These resource requirements have been inventoried by African leaders, and it is time for the international community to take formal note of this and adopt them as a target for the common effort.
72.	In agreeing to the organization of this session the Governments of the North entered into implicit commitments, which to date, apparently, they have not been in a position to honour. The time has come to honour them.
73.	This session has no meaning and will have no effect unless it is the occasion for mutual political commitments and unless the procedures and the bodies to be responsible for monitoring and following up these commitments are decided upon. Africa’s programme of action for Africa must have as its mirror image a United Nations programme of action for Africa.
74.	The United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery 1986-1990 [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l, annex V] must acclaim and take into account the effort which, since 1980 and the adoption of the Lagos Plan of Action, the African countries have decided to undertake in order to bring about the recovery of their economies, promote the realization of their populations’ potential, restore their natural balances and play their part in bringing about international equilibrium. It must demonstrate the support the international community intends to give them.
75.	The Programme of Action must embody the commitments which African Governments have made to each other, to their peoples and to the rest of the world. It must take note of the fact that African Governments, measuring the immensity of their task and the dearth of immediately available resources and noting certain negative aspects of the international environment, have shown the international community the extent to which they need additional external support to make their own effort more readily effective, less risky and less severe for their people.
76.	If African Governments do not make their own effort contingent on obtaining the support they seek, the international community cannot make its contribution contingent on their persisting in that effort. African and non-African nations alike must pledge themselves to do all they can, individually and jointly, to bring the critical situation in Africa to an end. They must involve international agencies and organizations in those efforts in that spirit. .
77.	African nations and nations throughout the world must accept the targets which have been identified by the African countries and jointly agreed upon. These are: priority for food production, with all that the development of that production requires: guarantees to farmers, equipment, supporting industries, organization of producers, rural development, agronomic research, extension services; the need for an immediate commitment to a long-term effort to bring about the restoration of natural balances; the need for more effective control of demographic and population phenomena: the population explosion, urbanization, refugees; priority for the training of children and adults and recognition of the role and responsibilities of women; special attention to the needs of their populations and those segments which are most at risk, such as health and food, but also respect for human dignity, the development of democracy and community responsibility; the urgent need for a revitalization
of the structures and management methods of State machinery and the instruments that have been created around it, as well as for the improvement of public services; the importance of establishing a complex and diversified network of autonomous and independent economic actors which can by themselves produce the necessary goods and services and create and tap the savings needed for investment; the need for close collaboration between neighbouring countries—in short, the need to implement a new form of development that respects existing situations and cultures.
78.	Because it concerns the future of the world, the action undertaken by Africa and by Governments requires the support of international organizations and all countries of the world in a position to provide it. Only with their commitment and their efforts will it be possible to: correct, on a case-by-case basis, the liquidity shortages which seriously affect most African countries and prevent them from importing the goods and services needed for their development; attempt, through any measure deemed appropriate, to prevent African countries from experiencing negative financial flows resulting from their debt burden; take social and political factors as well as the special effort which the implementation of the five-year Programme of Action represents into account in carrying out. necessary debt-rescheduling operations; ensure an increase in financial resources provided on concessional terms, as well as an improvement in their quality, availability, predictability and coherence; make their assistance more appropriate; promote investment, for bank credit alone does not suffice for development; open up their markets to African products; soften the effects of the collapse in commodity prices, from which Africa has suffered the most; and provide Africa with all the available scientific and technological knowledge that can be used for its development.
79.	This commitment on the part of Governments and international organizations must be demonstrated in the support provided for the individual development strategy of each African country. It is here that reciprocal commitments will be made, their fulfilment guaranteed and their co-ordination organized so that their effectiveness can be enhanced. But it is also in this area that a genuine agreement on priority needs and on the global resources needed to meet them is called for.
80.	For the Programme of Action to become fully operative, however, African Governments must, at the national or regional level, come forward with programmes and identify both the limits of the efforts they are able to make and the amounts and modalities of the external contributions they require. To achieve this, the Government of each African country must set up a central body for programme follow-up by its administration and by the groups playing a role in its economy, as well as for co-operation with donors. Similarly, joint consultative groups for the review and implementation of the programme and commitments must be either set up or strengthened. It is at this level that specific co-ordination of the external support both promised and provided should be carried out in order to ensure effectiveness. Lastly, the reviews should take place at regular intervals on the initiative of the country concerned. The first such country evaluation should be completed within 12 months of the special session in order to ensure the launching of the programme.
81.	Once he had all these elements in his possession, the Secretary-General would submit an evaluation report and suggestions on the implementation of the Programme of Action. He should do so by a date that is early enough for
the General Assembly to be seized of the matter and consider it at its 1987 session. By the same date, the Secretary-General should submit to the Assembly suggestions on the measures to be adopted so that very longterm action may be taken. At the Secretary-General’s suggestion, the Assembly could on the same occasion establish the circumstances in which a United Nations plan of action for the period 1991-2000 would be drawn up. Thus, because international opinion will be sure that the political commitments made will be fulfilled, it will understand that the financial and technological commitments clearly needed by Africa have not been made today in this forum.
82.	When they take leave of each other in four or five days’ time, the members of the General Assembly must be in a position to say that basically the necessary conditions have been met for the implementation by each African country of rational rehabilitation, restructuring and development programmes leading, in the medium term, to a recovery that, through the economic possibilities that it opens up and the social and economic dynamics that it promotes, will set in motion the self-reliant and self-sustained process of development that the African countries set as their legitimate goal back in 1980. They must also be in a position to say that unequivocal commitments have been made in respect of the corresponding external means. The General Assembly must also reaffirm its satisfaction at the results achieved recently by Governments, international organizations, non-governmental organizations and the public at large in their efforts to help the African populations stricken by natural disasters. A permanent body to alert and mobilize the international community must be established.
83.	The United Nations must proclaim that, despite the crisis and all the hardship suffered because of the volume and variety of its resources and the potential and will of its people, Africa is and will remain a continent with a future both able and determined to participate in international efforts.
84.	It is clearly of great importance that the General Assembly should invite African Governments, Africa’s partner States, international organizations, non-governmental organizations and the media to provide the world public with an objective picture of Africa, with its droughts, disturbances, famine and disease, of course, but above all with its resources, vitality, determination, youth and importance in maintaining world equilibrium. The General Assembly can thus proclaim that the future of Africa, although first and foremost an African concern, is one of the most serious international issues— and that the efforts to ensure that future constitute one of the most promising undertakings upon which the world could embark.
85.	May I conclude by translating an unsigned text that was given to me on Sunday morning, when, like many other people, I was awaiting the runner representing life and the flame representing hope:
“We keep telling ourselves that it will never happen again—never!
“But it does!
“We keep telling ourselves that we care—that we really will do something about it!
“But we don’t!
“And still our children are dying—still our world is threatened by famine, destruction and disease.
“Surely this must be our last chance to make good on our word.” .
“Our word”, ladies and gentlemen.
