AGENDA ITEM 6
Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and medium-term and long-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures
96.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I would remind representatives that among the recommendations contained in paragraph 26 of the Preparatory Committee’s report [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l], the one concerning the general debate reads as follows:
‘‘Owing to the large number of speakers desiring to take the floor in a limited amount of time, it is recommended that statements should not exceed 15 minutes. It is also recommended that the normal requirement for a quorum to open the meeting be waived for the duration of the general debate.”
97.	The first speaker in the general debate is the representative of India, on whom I now call.
98.	Mr. NARAYANAN (India): May I at the outset, Sir, extend to you our congratulations on your election and express the pleasure of my delegation at seeing you preside over this historic session. We have every hope that your wisdom and experience will enable the session to find a way of harnessing international support for launching the continent of Africa on the path of self-sustained development.
99.	This is the first time that the General Assembly has met in special session to consider the economic situation of a particular continent. It is a recognition of the fact that in the interdependent world of today all nations and all regions are inescapably involved with one another, and that solutions to the major and fundamental problems afflicting them can be found only in the international context and through concerted supporting action by the world community. I venture to believe that this session marks the beginning of a new era in international cooperation for development, so that a tragedy such as the one that recently befell Africa will never again befall any people anywhere in the world.
100.	I consider it a particular privilege to address the Assembly on behalf of my country and the Movement of
Non-Aligned Countries. India has been bound to Africa by ties of cultural affinity and friendship almost from the dawn of history, and in modern times the leaders of our nationalist movement have gone to the extent of asserting that the independence of India would not be complete without the independence of Africa. The Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, with about half of its far-flung membership drawn from Africa and with its dedication to the objective of the development of developing nations through international co-operation and individual and collective self-reliance, has been intensely concerned with the ongoing economic and social crisis in Africa. The Ministerial Meeting of the Co-ordinating Bureau of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries held at New Delhi from 16 to 19 April 1986 welcomed the holding of this special session of the General Assembly and emphasized that “while the development of the African continent was the prime responsibility of the African Governments and peoples themselves, it was essential that their national efforts should be fully supported by the international community”.8
101.	Prime Minister Shri Rajiv Gandhi, who is the current Chairman of the Non-Aligned Movement, in the course of his recent visit to the front-line States, declared the solidarity of India and the Non-Aligned Movement with the African States and peoples in their efforts to promote economic rehabilitation and development and also in their heroic struggle against the apartheid, colonialism and destabilization represented by the Pretoria régime.
102.	The United Nations system as a whole, and the Secretary-General in particular, played a crucial role in alerting and sensitizing the world community to the African economic crisis and in mounting a massive relief effort by the international community and by the African countries themselves. Thanks to these efforts, the situation facing Africa today is not as tragically sensational as the images of starving populations and parched fields which made the front pages in newspapers until recently. But the race against time will not have been won until the gains of the relief and rehabilitation work have been consolidated and the developmental process in Africa has been revitalized and restructured in order to ensure continuous self-sustained growth.
103.	There has been considerable discussion of an appropriate policy framework for the development of Africa. It is important that, instead of trying to impose a framework from outside, the African Governments should be enabled to determine their own priorities in accordance with their own social, economic and political circumstances. In the past far too many resources have been wasted on projects conceived outside the African experience, which were inappropriate, and on efforts which were unco-ordinated. Fortunately, a general consensus now exists in the international community on the broad spectrum of the efforts required. African Governments have themselves put forward a well-thought-out priority programme for the economic recovery of Africa, a programme which would need for its successful implementation the mobilization of all the domestic resources of Africa and the active material support of the international community. In this context, the OAU and ECA deserve to be complimented on the vision and sense of realism shown by them. I also note with appreciation the very thorough work done by the Preparatory Committee for this session.
104.	Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 is a massive but minimum programme dictated by the magnitude of the problems confronting
the continent. A fundamental point in this Programme is the need to bring about a structural transformation in the respective economies of African countries suffering from problems of historical distortions and arrested economic development. Diversification of the economy, the strengthening of inter-sectoral links, increasing productivity, reducing dependence on imports and controlling the rate of growth of the population are some of the key elements in the Programme. It is noteworthy that the African countries have expressed their determination to mobilize a substantial portion—over 64 per cent—of the estimated resources required for the implementation of the Priority Programme.
105.	India is greatly impressed by the special role assigned to food and agriculture in this Programme. We believe it is an emphasis of strategic importance for the developing countries of Africa. In the developmental history of my country, where, just as in Africa, the immense majority of the people live in rural areas and are dependent on agriculture, primary emphasis has been placed on food and agriculture. In 1948 Jawaharlal Nehru, the first Prime Minister of India, said, “Everything else can wait, but not agriculture”. The green revolution that took place in India was a result of this particular priority in development. We are today in a position to share the knowledge and the technology that we have acquired in food and agricultural production with our African brethren.
106.	A number of collaborative agricultural projects are under way between India and several African countries. This is indeed a field in which South-South co-operation can be pursued constructively with maximum results, promoting collective self-reliance in the developing world in general and in Africa in particular. Only a few weeks ago the Government of India hosted a workshop in New Delhi in collaboration with the World Food Council. The workshop, which was attended by 20 top-level food policy-makers from different countries in Africa and representatives of international organizations, noted the relevance of the Indian experience in food and agriculture for African development. ‘
107,	The Co-ordinating Bureau of the Non-Aligned Movement has adopted a Plan of Action for Africa,7 focused on the food and agriculture sector, calculated to supplement other international programmes operating in the same field. The Plan of Action is a concrete expression of the principle of collective self-reliance and the promotion of economic co-operation between developing countries.
108.	While we stress the primary role of food and agriculture, the simultaneous heed to accelerate industrial development cannot be overlooked. Even to bring about stable growth in agriculture, it is essential to have a supportive industrial sector that provides agricultural implements and tools, fertilizers and pesticides and the processing of food and other agricultural products. Transfer of methods and technologies in these fields is eminently practicable. It is with this in view that India will be hosting, in collaboration with UNIDO, an Afro-Asian industrial co-operation meeting in November this year, within the framework of the Industrial Development Decade for Africa.
109.	Although a developing country, India has endeavoured to contribute to the fullest possible extent towards meeting the critical economic situation in Africa. Last year we provided 100,000 tonnes of wheat to African States affected by drought and famine; we have also announced a contribution of $10 million to the OAU Special Emergency Fund for the purchase of wheat and
cereals from India. India was the first country outside Africa to make such a contribution. Further, we have made available relief supplies and the services of teams of doctors to certain African countries. Under the Indian Economic and Technical Co-operation Programme, we provide training facilities for about 500 trainees from Africa every year. The Programme also funds more than 80 Indian experts working in various African countries. A large number of feasibility studies and consultancies have been conducted with Indian funding in the past year, and in several cases equipment and materials have been provided. India currently has 48 joint-venture enterprises in Africa in a wide range of areas, including paper, textiles, tyres, machine tools, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. 110. Education and training is another area where we have been able to be of some assistance. A large number of African students are pursuing higher studies in Indian technical and academic institutions, many of them under Indian fellowship grants. Many bilateral and multilateral donor agencies are also making use of Indian training facilities to train African nominees, particularly in fields such as forestry, soil conservation, irrigation and water management, agricultural research and extension and foreign trade.
111.	At the multilateral level, India is providing assistance to specific projects through ECA. This very year we have committed ourselves to implementing a small-scale industrial project for ECA at a cost of $400,000. India has also worked out a programme of co-operation for the next five years with the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference [SADCC], the main features of which are the offer of 300 training fellowships, the services of 100 Indian specialists, the setting up of joint pilot projects in agriculture, and a grant of Rs 15 million for the setting up of an Indo-SADCC Industrial Service Centre.
112.	I have enumerated these items of co-operation in order to emphasize India’s commitment to African development. I am aware that, in the face of the enormous needs of Africa, they may not be of major magnitude. But they are an important part of South-South co-operation and are designed to promote self-reliant development in Africa, which is also the objective of the larger international assistance for Africa.
113.	In the current as well as the medium-term and long-term crisis facing Africa, it is evident that Africa is helping itself, and the countries of the non-aligned and developing world are also extending help to Africa to the best of their ability. But the dimensions of the problem are enormous.
114.	The crisis facing Africa, just as in the case of the developing countries in general, is to a large extent the consequence of external forces beyond its control. In fact, the international economic situation has become particularly harsh and unfavourable for all developing countries, especially those in Africa. The international recession, the collapse of commodity prices to historically low levels, rising and new forms of protectionism, adverse terms of trade, high interest rates, inadequte liquidity, currency fluctuations and reductions in official development assistance and in concessional Ioans from multilateral agencies have imposed unbearable burdens and accentuated the economic crisis in Africa. .
115.	Improvement of the external environment and structural changes in the global economic system are, therefore, essential for tackling the critical economic situation in Africa. In particular, relief from the debt burden is a fundamental and urgent need. It is equally important that concessional assistance from Governments
and multilateral financial institutions be increased sufficiently to implement Africa’s Priority Programme. We hope that forward-looking statesmanship in the great developed countries of the world will rise to the occasion and find ways and means of providing the level of assistance required to overcome the present crisis and launch Africa on the path to self-sustained development, for what is at stake in Africa’s economic and social development and its consequent political stability is indeed incalculable for the world.
116.	I wish to end by reading out the following message from Shri Rajiv Gandhi to this special session devoted to the critical economic situation in Africa:
“The people of Africa are engaged in an epic struggle which compels the attention and respect of the world. It is a gigantic effort to overcome centuries of poverty, neglect and underdevelopment, while fighting to eliminate the scourge of racism in South Africa and colonialism' in Namibia.
“I have recently visited some of the front-line States in southern Africa. I have seen the reality as well as the potential of Africa. Though faced with political challenges and the disruption caused by the world economic crisis, the people and the leaders of Africa have emerged stronger and more determined.
“Much has been achieved through international cooperation to alleviate suffering caused by famine. In this task all have contributed. Much more now needs to be done. We must build on the spontaneous sympathy and fellow feeling which the crisis in Africa has evoked and lay the foundation for self-reliant and sustained development.
“The non-aligned have a keen sense of solidarity and participation with the countries of Africa in their struggle against poverty as well as their struggle against the tyranny of apartheid. Member countries of the NonAligned Movement have contributed generously, within their limited means, towards meeting'the emergency situation. They stand ready to do whatever more is possible for the rehabilitation and longer-term development of the African economies. .
“By working together in a spirit of partnership, the international community has a great opportunity and a challenge to contribute towards building a modern and prosperous Africa. An economically strong and dynamic Africa will be an important factor for world peace and stability.
“I hope that the special session of the General Assembly will be a landmark in Africa’s development and a turning point for international co-operation in general.”
117.	Mr. DIZDAREVIC (Yugoslavia): Allow me first to congratulate you, Sir, on your election to the presidency of this important special session of the General Assembly.
118.	With expressions of full solidarity with the countries of Africa, I address the General Assembly on behalf of the Group of 77, of which my country is Chairman, and at the same time on behalf of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
119.	The Group of 77 believes that the convening of this special session reflects our common concern over the worsening of the already critical economic and social situation in Africa, caused by a prolonged stagnation in its development. We have gathered here to adopt concrete decisions which would manifest a general desire by the international community to contribute to the efforts of African countries to surmount the problems threatening the very existence of millions of people and to provide lasting and accelerated development.
120.	We are all aware of the gravity, complexity and urgency of the problems facing the nations of Africa. In his inspiring statement the OAU Chairman, President Diouf of Senegal, not only set out the seriousness of the situation but also pointed to its causes and ways in which it might be overcome.
121.	The recent tragic consequences of the drought in Africa have been only partly mitigated. This year again about 19 million people will be affected by drought and hunger. Emergency relief aid is therefore still necessary. However, without the full support of the international community for the medium- and long-term development of Africa, to which this session is devoted, no substantial solution .to the problems of Africa can be found. These problems are extremely grave and challenging indeed. Today the gross national product per capita, in real terms, in Africa is at the level of 1975, whereas in 14 poorest African countries it is at the level of 1970. Food production is about 20 per cent lower than the production during the 1920s. African national economies predominantly depend on exports of only a few primary products, the prices of which, as indicated in the documents for this session, are at the level of the 1930s. The external debt of African countries amounts to approximately $170 billion, while their debt servicing exceeds 30 per cent of their foreign exchange earnings.
122.	The development crisis in Africa is not the problem of African countries alone: it is the problem of global development. The African continent is most affected by the consequences of its colonial past. Until Africa succeeds in eliminating the ensuing hardships, the entire world will be deprived of its contribution to the overall international development. In its wealth and development potential, Africa is the continent of the future. The prosperity of Africa would contribute to the progress of the whole world. The speedy development of Africa is therefore in the best interest of mankind as a whole.
123.	, African countries are fully aware that the responsibility for their own development rests primarily on themselves. They have shown this by committing themselves to providing the basis for a structural transformation of their economies in the next five years within the Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery 1986-1990 [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l, annex V]. They are also aware of their own great potential. In order to attain the goals that have been set, however, assistance and support by the wider international community, above all the developed countries, is required. Financial resources are needed to this end, but in addition to that it is indispensable to adopt solutions and measures which would pave the way for and open up prospects of an accelerated economic and social development and a better utilization of vast natural and human resources.
124.	In its quest for faster development Africa has the full understanding, solidarity and assistance of developing countries. The Group of 77 attaches great significance to mutual economic co-operation among all developing countries, believing that this would contribute to redressing the current critical economic situation in Africa. I should like to point out that the Group of 77 views Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 with full understanding and support. We believe that it is of crucial importance to ensure the necessary financial inflow fo African countries. So far that inflow has been far below the actual needs. The proposed cancellation of the debt of the poorest African countries is fully justified.
125.	We expect that this special session will reach agreement on a comprehensive and action-oriented programme
for economic recovery and for the faster development of Africa. The developed countries are rightly expected to fulfil their special responsibility by making their contribution to these endeavours.
126.	I wish to point out that Yugoslavia and the African countries are linked by bonds of traditional friendship and co-operation inspired by a common vision and the struggle of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries for just and democratic international relations. As a nonaligned and developing country, Yugoslavia has always had full understanding for the problems of African countries. Despite the fact that it is experiencing economic difficulties of its own, Yugoslavia is doing its utmost to assist African countries. During 1985, in the solidarity campaign with African countries, Yugoslavia provided, through various governmental and non-governmental institutions, aid amounting to 800 million dinars. Soft loans for the development of priority economic programmes and projects are an important form of our co-operation with and assistance to African countries. Yugoslavia also lends technical assistance, including transfer of technology and training of personnel to many African countries. Over 3,000 African students have been educated in Yugoslavia under governmental scholarship programmes, and several hundred are at present attending Yugoslav universities. Yugoslavia will continue to extend all possible support and assistance to the friendly African countries in order to help them overcome the present difficulties and to create a basis necessary for their accelerated, unhampered and independent development.
127.	In order to overcome the stagnation in the development of Africa and to achieve a faster and unimpeded economic, social and cultural development, it is necessary to create a more favourable international environment. There can be no stability or progress in Africa, nor can there be greater contribution by Africa to progress and stability in the world, without the eradication of the last remnants of colonialism, without the elimination of attempts to preserve or renew relations of neo-colonialism and exploitation, without equitable relations and cooperation with African countries and without full respect for their freedom and independence and their sovereign right to choose the ways of their internal development.
128.	Mrs. SCHOO (Netherlands): Speaking on behalf of the European Community and its member States, I should like to welcome the President of Senegal to the special session. We all recognize the highly important role President Diouf played in the preparations by the African countries.
129.	I should like to express the serious concern we feel at the critical economic situation in many African countries, particularly south of the Sahara. The crisis in those countries is seriously undermining their development prospects and is in some cases threatening the very existence of entire populations. It requires an investment of effort equal to the gravity of the problems involved, both on the part of the African countries themselves and on the part of the international community.
130.	The special session carries forward a process started in the summer of 1984. At the Economic and Social Council summer session the international community paid special attention to the short-term problems of Africa, and the subsequent session of the General Assembly adopted the Declaration on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa [resolution 39/29, annex]. In January 1985 the Office for Emergency Operations in Africa was created and hunger was tackled. The international community reacted in a most exceptional fashion.
131.	Now at this moment we need to commit ourselves to deal with the medium- and long-term problems, and ; I hope that we can come to similar effective solutions. Those will be more difficult to find and more difficult to implement. The special session should therefore pave the way for a concerted approach by the international community and by Africa and should result in a consensus on the need to redefine development priorities and on the means to be applied to that end.
132.	The negotiations on a programme of action should be finalized this week; there is no room for failure here. I should like to highlight three major parts: internal development of Africa, external environment and followup and co-ordination.
133.	Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 which finds its roots in the 1980 Lagos Plan of Action,3 contains a thorough analysis of the development problems in Africa whereby the agricultural sector gets more attention. It focuses on the transition from emergency and short-term actions to the relaunching of long-term programmes for self-sustaining economic development. It suggests a number of priorities for the African countries and the international community. It is our task to translate their points of consensus into potential specific measures to promote the rehabilitation and development of the African continent.
134.	We support fully the attention which the Priority Programme pays to the food and agricultural sector and indeed hope that African countries will never again have to go through the disastrous consequences of famine. The implementation of the Programme should form a basis for a structural transformation leading in the long term to self-reliance in food for Africa as a continent. We recognize that the African countries are making exceptional sacrifices in mobilizing domestic resources, and we are willing to back them up with appropriate policy reforms. In this context we realize that an adequate transfer of resources will contribute to the implementation of APPER’s goals in this sector. Many of the policies in the agricultural area are already supported by aid programmes. Much remains to be done, but consensus on that approach exists. I should like to point out that the European Community and its member States are making a great financial effort, bilaterally and, inter alia, in the framework of the Third Lomé Convention.
135.	In this context I should like to make some general remarks about our views on development. As regards the agricultural policy—which, we agree, is a central issue— small holders should be seen as an essential element for the foundation of agricultural policy. Steps should be taken to enable them effectively to produce both food and cash crops. Appropriate price, fiscal and land tenure policies should encourage their production, something which could also lead to mastering the growing problems of urbanization in Africa. More attention should be paid to the role of women in that sector. Appropriate food strategies should be the framework for such an approach.
136.	We fully agree that the development and efficient • utilization of Africa’s human resources is a basic concern. In our view, basic education, promotion of the role of women in development and the development and strengthening of a country’s capacity in planning and administration at all levels deserve attention.
137.	The demographic imbalance and the degradation of the natural environment, in particular that caused by drought and desertification, are threatening long-term development. The Community and its member States consider it imperative that policies to address these problems are strengthened. We are ready to support policies
directed at conservation of the natural environment and are prepared to assist Governments at their request in the implementation of appropriate demographic policies.
138.	The efforts to be made internally by the African countries need to be supplemented by measures taken by the international community to improve the general economic environment. There have been some encouraging developments recently in the world economy.
139.	As regards trade, we stress the need to encourage liberal access, both in the context of existing commitments and in the framework of the future GATT multilateral trade negotiations. The African countries should be encouraged to take an active part in those negotiations, in view of their specific interests, especially with regard to tropical and agricultural products.
140.	The situation in the raw materials markets on which Africa largely depends for its export earnings is very worrying. These problems can be tackled only as part of an overall approach embracing commodity agreements, compensatory financing and, above all, diversification and productivity measures, which should be reflected case-by-case in the sectoral restructuring programmes.
141.	While definition and estimates may differ, one thing is clear: the African debt problem is very serious. It is an obstacle to recovery. Major efforts on the part of developed countries are desirable. The African countries recognize the need to adjust and the obligation to honour foreign debt commitments. The Community considers that there will be no solution to the financial problems of many indebted African countries unless production grows and economic development is re-established. The measures to be taken should be based on the principle of a case-by-case approach because of the great variety of debt situations in Africa. This approach should be implemented in a flexible manner in support of adjustment programmes in the medium term.
142.	In this connection, we welcome the discussion by the Development Committee of the World Bank in its report Financing Adjustment with Growth in SubSaharan Africa, 1986-90, the growing commitment by African Governments to undertake policy reforms and, in this context, the appeal to the world community to exert its best efforts to meet, through additional flows of official development assistance, the supplementary financing needs of sub-Saharan Africa as estimated by the World Bank. In this context, the Community and its member States consider that for the period from 1986 to 1990 bilateral donors should not become net recipients of official capital flows from African countries undertaking adjustment programmes. Also, we support $12 billion for the eighth replenishment of IDA, a substantial increase in the capital of the World Bank, and the contribution of $2.7 billion of the trust fund within the framework of the IMF Structural Adjustment Facility.
143.	The African paper mentions a number of proposals of a general character, of which we have taken careful note. In this context I should like to draw attention to steps already taken to reschedule debts of African countries and to improve the debt conditions through retrospective terms of adjustment on a country-by-country basis.
144.	Improvement in the quality of assistance should be sought in terms and conditions, sectoral priorities and the strengthening of co-ordination. In general, we consider it important to strive for multi-year aid commitments on the part of donor countries and organizations in support of African development. Direct investment has to be promoted. In this framework, we recall the
commitments under the Lomé Convention to strengthen the role of the private sector in the African development process.
145.	Much has been said, and much will be said, on follow-up and co-ordination; negotiations are not finalized. The programme of action as proposed is a framework under which African Governments should set up their own action plans and their projects and programmes and also determine the possibilities of their own financial and managerial efforts. On this basis the African Governments will be able to assess the needed external support. Whatever form it takes, an effective co-ordination and follow-up mechanism, especially at the national level, has to fulfil a catalytic role.
146.	We support the general principles underlying the establishment of follow-up mechanisms, as set out in the African paper. The mechanism should be simple, operational and not involving substantial addition expenditure. As much emphasis as possible should be placed on strengthening existing institutions rather than on creating new ones.
147.	The Community and its member States intend to contribute to the fullest extent possible to the success of this special session. We consider this to be our duty in view of our involvement in the development of Africa and the special responsibility we have towards that continent.
148.	Having concluded my statement on behalf of the European Community, I would like to continue, speaking on behalf of my country, the Netherlands.
149.	The ideas and proposals described in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery, which was adopted by the OAU in July 1985, and contained in the working document subsequently presented by the African community to this special session, are appreciated by my Government as a bold and courageous effort by the African nations to present a diagnosis of Africa’s problems and to propose methods to cure the negative social, humanitarian and economic results of the existing crisis. We admire the openness and frankness with which the African nations are focusing on their own primary responsibility, not only for prescribing the cures but also, and mainly, for the treatment itself.
150.	My Government agrees fully with the statement in the African documents that the main source for development in Africa, in particular sub-Saharan Africa, is the rural sector. In acknowledging this we want to recognize and underline two different elements.
151.	First, in terms of mid-term development, and realizing the economic structures of the world today, actual progress can be reached, in the vast majority of African States, only by creating economically and socially acceptable living conditions in the rural area, where most African people live. This means a greater focus on integrated rural development and on productive activities, including the development of human resources and the participation of the people, in particular women, who—as in most agriculturally oriented societies—constitute an essential but, in many countries, hitherto neglected element of responsible rural development.
152.	Secondly, I want to stress that the creation of acceptable living and working conditions in the rural areas is, in our opinion, the only way to avoid or diminish the disastrous results of uncontrolled and massive urbanization.
153.	Realizing that need for work is a basic reason for people to move to urban centres, and recognizing that the creation of jobs and better working conditions in the rural area could influence the necessity to move,
another problem comes into focus—that is, population growth.
154.	In all countries of the world, family life, and for that reason family planning, is a symbol of the privacy of every citizen. Decisions in these areas are taken by the people involved based on their personal, religious, cultural, social and/or economic points of view and possibilities. Governments have to be very careful how they tread in this very private sector. Nevertheless, actual figures show that without a slower rate of population growth, the African continent already in the coming decades will have increasing problems supporting its people in a reasonable way. Governments in Africa will be forced to look at this problem and to try to find a solution: not, of course by simply promulgating decrees or enacting laws, but through information, education, the creation of public awareness and activities which generate income for women. I call upon all the States assembled here to support the African countries in this task in all the necessary ways, which will demand immense knowledge and patience.
155.	My Government appreciates very much the fact that, as stated before, the African countries have looked first to themselves and their own responsibilities, considering Africa in terms of drawing lessons from the past in designing the future. Much attention has been given in the African documents to the improvement of economic management. My Government is convinced that technical assistance is needed for the strengthening of the management system, in particular that of governmental and para-statal structures. I might mention in this respect the opening a few weeks ago of a European Centre for Development Policy Management at Maastricht. This Centre will help to create and increase institutional capacity in developing countries.
156.	But in many cases bilateral technical assistance might be less effective, mainly because of suspected possible political, cultural or other influences in the administration of a recipient country. For that and other reasons, I feel that technical assistance to central governmental organizations and important para-statal organizations on a national level, in the areas of policy preparation, policy execution and management, where needed, should in the main be given by multilateral institutions such as the World Bank and UNDP. My Government stands ready to support those institutions in implementing this duty and will make available additional funds to the amount of 12.5 million Dutch guilders, that is, approximately $5 million, to be channelled through UNDP for United Nations activities in technical co-operation for development in the field of public administration and finance. 157. The African States have asked the international community to support their efforts with extended flows of concessional money. My Government wishes to stress the obligations the international community has accepted in principle: 0.7 per cent of gross national product for official development assistance and 0.15 per cent for the least developed countries. I am sure that if all the developed countries would expedite their timing for reaching the targets a substantive flow of official development assistance to African countries could be guaranteed. The Netherlands reached both targets some years ago; our budget is geared at 1.5 per cent of our net national income, which is equivalent to approximately 1.25 per cent of our gross national product. Our aid to Africa almost doubled in the last four years. I can assure representatives that a substantial part of the growth of the Netherlands development budget will be added to the already heavily increased official development assistance flows to Africa.
158.	Substantial amounts of concessional financing have been made available to the African countries in the last 15 years. Even recognizing the immense needs, one wonders in a number of cases about the effective and efficient use of those funds. There is no reason to deny that donor countries and donor organizations bear a great responsibility with regard to the feasibility and costeffectiveness of their financial inputs in African economies. It is in recognition of that responsibility that my Government urges all donors assembled here to adhere to some guidelines which the African community has submitted. The main points are: a focus on rehabilitation of already existing economic capacities, instead of initiating all kinds of new projects; a strong shift from project aid to non-project aid to secure imports essential for development, including incentive goods; close aid coordination under the leadership of the recipient country to secure effectiveness and adherence to the priorities of the recipient country; and longer-term aid commitments through “multi-year indicative pledges”.
159.	With regard to co-ordination, the World Bank and UNDP should play a key role. We think that both those organizations, through consultative groups and roundtables, should support the African countries in their midterm planning and in the execution of their programmes. The World Bank and UNDP should co-operate closely, promoting through their actions a greater willingness and readiness in the donor community, bilateral and multilateral, to co-ordinate and co-operate, following the priorities decided by the African countries and formulated in the documents for consultative groups and roundtables.
Mr. Makekd (Lesotho), Vice-President, took the Chair. 160. No discussion on economic development in Africa is complete without touching on the African debt problem. Debt-servicing is reaching alarming proportions in many African countries and threatens to disrupt all development. Part of this debt is to multilateral institutions and commercial banks and cannot be influenced by us directly. An important part, however, is in the hands of official bilateral creditors present at this session. We have always strongly supported UNCTAD resolution 165 (S-IX) of 11 March 1978.9 In that framework the Netherlands has already converted all regular official development assistance loans to the least developed countries into grants. Today I can announce that we have decided to go further. We are prepared to cancel in principle for the coming five years—that is, the period of the Priority Programme—all debt-servicing on official development assistance loans to the African low-income countries willing to commit themselves to effective adjustment policies. That could lead to a diminution of debt-servicing for those countries of about 200 million Dutch guilders between now and 1990.
161.	We urge all donors to take similar measures. Official development assistance debts are of course only a small part of the problem. Other official debts also warrant special treatment in the appropriate forums. We for our part are prepared to consider favourably initiatives for adapting the rescheduling of those debts to the serious situation of the African countries that qualify. This includes the possibility of longer repayment periods. If possible, reschedulings should be placed in the same medium-term framework as the corresponding structural adjustment programmes.
162.	I shall conclude my statement, on behalf of the European Community and on behalf of my Government, by calling upon all countries represented here in New York to ensure that the session will clearly show the
willingness, the ability and the capacity of the.world to support Africa in its dire needs. The African countries and peoples have shown the purpose and the political will to attack those needs. The world is required to help Africa find the weapons to make the attack as forceful as possible.
163.	Mr. AURILLAC (France) (interpretation from French): With this special session of the General Assembly the moment of truth has come for Africa and, therefore, for us all: the truth about the unprecedented crisis that has stricken most countries on an entire continent and the truth about harshly realistic diagnoses, but also the moment for opportunity, so that the bold step taken by our African friends—so lucidly explained by President Diouf—will be matched by the solidarity they are entitled, to expect from a better-equipped international community, the solidarity without which all their efforts may well fail.
164.	As the prime donor of funds to sub-Saharan Africa and the second in respect of the whole of Africa, France has close, long-standing relations with many African countries north and south of the Sahara. Moreover, the new French Government has clearly shown that it intends to strengthen what it regards as a priority of its foreign policy. Hence France is particularly well placed to assess the gravity of what is at stake in this session and the importance of its results for the future of millions of men, women and children in Africa. It is therefore determined to take an active part in the session and work hard for its success.
165.	Without dwelling on an analysis of a well-known situation, I shall simply say that the sense of reality and responsibility has at last become a part of the diagnosis and is now commonly shared. On the other hand, it seems to me indispensable to determine together the major axes for concerted action to meet the African countries’ most immediate needs and their essential needs over the longer term, and also to spell out the new policies proposed by the French Government in order to meet this high-priority world-wide challenge, that is, the recovery of the African economies and their return to growth.
166.	The profound and persistent economic crisis of Africa requires a resolute attitude on the part of the international community. The whole world was struck last year by the shocking pictures of the famine that had stricken more than 20 African countries. This stark crisis has shed harsh light on the deadlock to which the fragility of development poorly adapted to population growth rates can lead. For more than 10 years individual income and agricultural output per capita have been steadily declining. The estimates for 1986 of ECA and the African Development Bank indicate that the situation will continue to get worse, notwithstanding the undeniable attempts at adjustment made by many States. Their share in international trade is going to decline, the balance of payments will continue to deteriorate, and in 1986 debt service will reach an unprecedented low point.
167.	The middle term is equally disturbing. The outlines provided by the World Bank show that even in the best scenario, per capita income will continue to decline in subSaharan Africa for many years ahead.
168.	The document elaborated by African States has analysed the internal causes of the failure of strategies and economic policies to adapt to the situation. They include: mismanagement, persistently low productivity, the burden of State structures, and practical values and social behaviour which hamper development. To these internal causes we have to add a whole series of external causes: drought, slumping demand in industrial countries
where there is stagnant growth, the high level of real interest rates, monetary disorders and, above all, accelerated deterioration of the terms of trade for most raw materials. All these situations have become precarious today, as we can see from the recent upheavals caused by the collapse of cotton, petroleum and even cacao prices. 169. The African crisis therefore is not comparable to any other. As an overall crisis affecting virtually the whole of a continent where two thirds of the least-developed countries are located, it requires a comprehensive concept of solutions. Yet it is a specific problem, affecting each African country differently. As such, it requires an individual approach tailored to the needs of each country. 170. In dealing with a stricken continent, the attitude of the international community must be resolute. All of us together—African countries, other developing countries and industrialized States—must lay the groundwork for co-ordinated action to provide solutions not only to the immediate problems but also to those which require long-term treatment.
171.	True, Africa has encountered extreme difficulties; yet it has an immense human and natural-resource potential. Hence we must all focus on two general objectives in Africa: exploitation of potential wealth and guaranteeing a lasting way out of the economic and financial crisis. .
172.	Exploitation of Africa’s potential wealth must be the goal of all co-ordinated action. In that regard, the first imperative is to preserve and develop Africa’s natural heritage. African agriculture must be revitalized on the basis of protecting and properly managing natural factors in production, such as soil, water, flora—the basis of all agricultural economies.
173.	At meetings of the Permanent Inter-State Committee on Drought Control in the Sahel, the Intergovernmental Authority for Drought and Development, the Silva Conference on tree and forest, held in Paris in February 1986, and UNDP, the international community has dwelt on the need for a common approach. Stress has thus been laid on the importance of training and research, strengthening competent African institutions, achievements in the field and the need for improving knowledge and the prediction of natural phenomena. With its SPOT satellite, France intends in this regard to make a special contribution to the understanding and forecasting of desertification phenomena. Moreover, it has undertaken to double in five years the assistance it devotes to the fight against desertification. This is particularly urgent because it is a long-term endeavour.
174.	The second imperative need in exploiting Africa’s potential wealth is to establish better management of human resources. With a population growth rate of more than 3 per cent, the highest in the world, the African continent faces a particularly grave situation: regional food production, which presently accounts for 75 per cent of consumption, is likely, by the year 2000, to meet the needs of only 60 per cent of its 850 million inhabitants. Far from being overpopulated, Africa is nevertheless suffering from demographic growth that outstrips its capacity for the generation of wealth and from severe imbalances in geographical distribution which prevent optimal exploitation of resources.
175.	However, it is not enough to control demographic growth. It is also essential to make better, wider use of Africa’s human resources, to train men and women, who are important factors in the economy. The educational system in Africa is currently in a state of crisis, as emphasized at the UNESCO Conference of Ministers of Education and those Responsible for Economic Planning in
African Member States, held at Harare from 28 June to 3 July 1982. This means a renovation and strengthening of basic education to ensure a minimum level of skills. Saturated administrations and public enterprises, often not viable themselves, must no longer be the normal outlets for an educated person. The goal should be to train people for productive activities in the crafts, in enterprises, in services or in agriculture—sectors which generate wealth and which in Africa are in need of qualified entrepreneurs and agents.
176.	The third imperative need is to improve regional co-operation. In the industrial and agricultural spheres the development of Africa will be viable only if the regional interrelationships are systematically elaborated. This is the South-South co-operation called for by President Diouf. We have seen in recent crop years that despite the drought there were surpluses here and there. But in the absence of adequate, diversified markets and a marketing system, they have gone to waste and have driven prices below the level of profitability.
177.	First of all, Africa must emerge from the economic and financial crisis in which it is now floundering. Economic growth cannot be decreed in Africa anymore than elsewhere, but it is incumbent upon the Governments of the African countries and on the international community to create conditions conducive to the generation of wealth.
178.	The first condition relates to the domestic policies of the African States themselves. Naturally, these are the sovereign choice of each country. Having become aware of the dangers over several years, most African countries have undertaken to put their public finances in order so as to maintain normal relations with the international financial community and assure external resources adequate to their investment needs. States must still make progress, especially in disengaging from activities to which they are not suited and in streamlining the administrative sector.
179.	Over and above the adoption of specific measures, conditions favourable to the producer must be created. Experience teaches that States can help in that regard by implementing pricing policies that reward the most efficient producers and credit policies that permit selection of the most profitable operations and appropriate interest rates. States should also limit public spending on unproductive activities in order to accumulate the savings needed for investment. Such policies imply that the private sector should be given broad responsibility. True “conversion” to the virtues of private initiative and commercial, craft or industrial enterprise seems to me one of the most significant developments of recent years. But the flagrant failure of pervasive State control does not of itself obviate the need to establish, with the support of external financing, public investment programmes having clearly-defined priorities.
180.	The second condition is the improvement of the international environment. Through their internal policies, the industrialized countries can do much to bring about that improvement. The French Government has been working to impart new vigour to the economy of France, and this policy should have beneficial implications for Africa, with which we are an important trading partner. International co-ordination should also be pursued in the appropriate international agencies in the monetary and commercial fields, in order to give the agents of international trade the means to do their job with security and peace of mind. Greater stability of exchange rates, the decline of real interest rates and the balance of prices on the major commodity markets should
make it possible to maximize the benefit to each partner and improve the quality of products. .
181.	The Economic Summit Meeting held at Tokyo from 4 to 6 May 1986 has made it possible to move ahead in this field. I hope that this effort will be continued and that in parallel there will be a renewal, on new bases, of international co-operation with regard to raw materials, which constitute the main source of income for the African countries.
182.	It is true that the financial context of these policies today has been described as a crisis of indebtedness, which is a major concern of African Governments. In order to cope with this problem, they have made great sacrifices and submitted themselves to rigid discipline. But that discipline should not be an end in itself; it should be a way of bringing about growth.
183.	In order to provide Africa with a real prospect of emerging from the crisis, the treatment of the difficulties of indebtedness, which should be flexible in order to take account of specific situations, will have to be associated with an appreciable growth of external transfers towards the African continent, particularly in the form of official development assistance. The support of donors must be strengthened in response to the reforms in domestic policies undertaken by the African States, for the more effective use of aid made possible by those reforms deserves to be accompanied by additional efforts on the part of the international community with regard to the co-ordination, volume and quality of aid.
184.	In the field of co-ordination, it is essential that all the general analyses, those of the multilateral agencies but also those of recipient Governments and of the biggest bilateral creditors, be comparable, in order to establish for each country concerned, under the responsibility of its Government, a single macro-economic document as a source of reference and support for the action of all those involved.
185.	When it comes to the volume of aid needed by the African countries, it is essential to avoid sterile statistical or methodological arguments. What is important is to take note of the evidence that the priority given to Africa must be strengthened and must take the form of progressive growth in Africa’s share of official development assistance.
186.	Effect should be given to this strengthening of assistance in various ways. First IDA should be reconstituted at a level of at least $12 billion to give it the mimimum means necessary for its work, and the African continent should benefit from an increasing share of those funds. Also, the commitment of each donor country to maintain a positive flow of capital to the whole of Africa would substantially improve the situation on the African continent. ••
187.	This is obviously the concern of all the industrialized countries. Is it not surprising, therefore, that the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] by itself allocates more than 90 per cent of all official development assistance. The member countries of the Development Assistance Committee of OECD could enter into a collective commitment to increase Africa’s share of their total official development assistance above the present 30 per cent. More specifically, each donor might decide on a minimum percentage of its own gross domestic product to be devoted to Africa so as to go beyond the average of 0.09 per cent now reserved for that continent. It is, or course, for each donor to set the degree of priority that it intends to accord to the African countries, but an overall response is necessary so that there can be more predictability regarding the support
accorded by the international community to the African continent.
188.	Africa can no longer afford to service its debts normally. From one rescheduling to another, time will be needed to discharge the effect of the past. For many years ahead the borrowing capacity of the African countries will be very limited, and an objective analysis of the real stakes for each African country and for each creditor makes it clear that the cancellation of debt is at best a deceptive solution and at worst a devious ploy.
189.	In order not to repeat past errors and exacerbate the debt crisis from which most African countries at present suffer, it is indispensable that the quality of aid be improved. Of course, we must first strengthen what is called concessional aid, but that is not the only way, even if it is the most sensitive with regard to the criterion of foreign debt servicing.
190.	As in the past, the diversity of situations requires a combination of aid instruments adapted to specific realities. In one case priority should be given to balance of payments assistance, while in another it might be concessional aid, and in yet another, basic sectoral action such as the rescheduling of the debt. The true value lies in a case-by-case approach. It is a matter not of breaking new ground but of persevering.
191.	The quality of financial operations is no less essential, because it conditions future growth. While it is now fashionable in certain places to ridicule what has been called the “white elephants of Africa”, people sometimes forget that the implementation of those projects was quite often based on studies which had previously been considered sound and complete. The white elephants of today result from the studies of yesterday. Those of tomorrow are perhaps being prepared today in the serious atmosphere of study and research centres. That is why it is indispensable that the capacity for the analysis and the preparation of projects be strengthened.
192.	Account should be taken also of the positive effects, in many ways, of direct consecutive investment in mutually profitable co-operation between the enterprises of the North and those of the South.
193.	This is how the Government of France views the broad aspects of concerted action to help Africa.
194.	In conclusion, ! should like to explain how the French Government has decided to reorganize its policy of co-operation in order to provide a more effective response to the urgent challenge posed by the resumption of development in Africa. For France, co-operation is an exercise in solidarity or social justice at the international level. It is also one of the most reliable ways of keeping the peace, which is the prime condition of development. It is therefore a firm obligation.
195.	France, which will have dispersed more than 25 billion francs in official development assistance in 1986, ranks high among official donors. It is determined, in fulfilling its commitments, to devote 0.7 per cent of its gross domestic product to official development assistance as soon as possible. I need not recall that its effort is already six times higher than the average among the developed countries. Essentially it has already met the other objectives that it had set itself, in particular with regard to least developed countries.
196.	However, a country such as France cannot do everything. Its limited resources as well as the constraints imposed upon it by the need to ensure the recovery of its own economy compel it to choose priorities in its policy of solidarity.
197.	While determined to concentrate its efforts to provide development assistance on Africa, France has also determined to improve the quality of that aid. In particular, the French Government has decided to increase the proportion of grants by comparison with loans in its official development assistance. This is the most realistic way for a donor country with our commitments to contribute effectively and simultaneously to reducing the indebtedness of the African countries and to restoring their financial equilibrium.
198.	This is really the moment of truth. This truth does not lie in the excessive pessimism of certain analysts, the urgings of those who would have us wait and see or the tactical manoeuvres of those who try skilfully to camouflage their indifference to the difficulties of Africa. It lies rather in bold reasoning, sincere dialogue based on equality and the expression of frank goodwill, so that each specific effort undertaken by an African country can be matched by an increase in the support granted by the international community.
199.	As members know, there are close, long-standing ties between France and Africa, a truly whole-hearted attachment. That is doubtless because we share an unswerving dedication to the capacity of man. It is this humanism which is today the best reason for hope for the future of Africa. ■
The meeting rose at 1.30 p.m.

GENERAL
ASSEMBLY
THIRTEENTH SPECIAL SESSION
Official Records
2nd
PLENARY MEETING
Tuesday, 27 May 1986, at 3.30 p.m.
N E w Y Q R K
President: Mr. Jaime de PINIES (Spain).
AGENDA ITEM 5
Adoption of the agenda and organization of work (concluded)	.
1.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): This afternoon the Assembly will first proceed to the election of the Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session, who will also be a member of the General Committee. It is my understanding that, following consultations, there is general agreement that Mr. Stephen Lewis of Canada should serve as Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session. I take it, therefore, that it is the wish of the Assembly to elect him by acclamation.
It was so decided (decision S-13/15*). .
2.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I congratulate Mr. Lewis on behalf of the General Assembly and on my own behalf. The General Committee for the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly has now been fully constituted.
AGENDA ITEM 6
Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and medium-term and long-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures (continued)
3.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I would draw the attention of members to two decisions taken by the Assembly at its 1st plenary meeting, upon the recommendation of the Preparatory Committee: first, owing to the very large number of speakers desiring to participate in the debate in a very limited amount of time, statements should not exceed 15 minutes; and secondly, the normal requirement for a quorum to open a plenary meeting is waived for the duration of the debate at this special session.
4.	Mr. AKINYEMI (Nigeria): On behalf of the Government and people of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, I congratulate you most warmly, Sir, on your well-deserved election to the presidency of this special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa. As the Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity, President Diouf, said with so much dignity and eloquence this morning, Africa—and indeed the
•For the election of the other officers of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole, see A/S-13/AC.I/SR.1, paras. 1 and 2.
whole world—expects much in terms of concrete results from this session. I wish to echo his every word.
5.	General Assembly resolution 40/40 enjoins us to focus our debate on the challenges facing African countries, with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures. In that regard, I shall focus attention extensively, though not exclusively, on the issue of the development of food and agriculture, the area in which I have been mandated to speak for Africa, 6. Permit me first of all to place on record Africa’s appreciation of Live Aid, Sports Aid and such activities. To watch these people, old and young, engaged in these selfless and soul-inspiring activities is to feel good about being part of the human race. Bob Geldof and the people he has motivated all over the world represent the acceptable face of humanity. Their activities are not necessarily condemnatory of us as Governments. However, they serve to remind us that humanity is not selfish, brutish and non-caring. Let Sports Aid remind all of us representatives of Governments of our capacity to do good and reach out to others if the will is there.
7.	I should also like to express Africa’s gratitude to the international community, including the Governments of individual countries, the United Nations system and voluntary organizations and agencies, for the generous assistance to the relief efforts during the recent drought and famine which affected many of our countries.
8.	We in Africa wish to stress the fact that to establish a prosperous future for our region there is need for our Governments, in concert with the international community, to focus in the short and medium term on specific priorities that will pave the way for the national and collective self-reliant and self-sustained growth and development of our economies. I wish, therefore, to reiterate Africa’s determination to face and overcome the twin challenges of survival and development through the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,1 adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity at its twenty-first session, held at Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 July 1985.
9.	The Priority Programme addresses itself mainly to achieving a breakthrough in structural transformation and higher productivity. It also recognizes that the reactivation of African agriculture will not take place unless structural linkages are established between agriculture and industry. This will require the provision of agricultural implements, fertilizers and pesticides, as well as the processing of food and other agricultural products. Indispensable also will be economic infrastructures, particularly feeder and access roads, storage, marketing and distribution, and facilities for research in agricultural technologies.
10.	Food and agriculture are, therefore, the centre of concern, and they have been designated the priority of priorities. No doubt, all other sectors are important in so far as they support and facilitate the structural transformation of the agricultural sector, and in so far as they assist in combating desertification and in developing human resources.
11.	A major concern to Africa has been the long-term deteriorating trend in agricultural production and per capita food production. Major factors responsible for that disappointing performance include, inter alia, overdependence on rain-fed agriculture, inadequate investment, poor incentives to farmers, inadequate application of science and technology, inefficient marketing and distribution systems and institutionalized constraints. Other major factors that are mainly exogenous include, inter alia, the international recession, collapse in commodity prices, adverse terms of trade, decline in real terms in official development assistance, increased protectionism, high interest rates, currency fluctuations and the heavy burden of debt and debt-servicing obligations of African countries. While it is true that Africa is not the only region affected by extraneous trends, the continent does not have the capacity other regions have to cushion the impact of those external shocks owing to the structural rigidities and the excessive outward orientation and dependence of the African economies.
12.	During 1971-1980, agricultural production grew by an average of merely 1.6 per cent per annum. This compares unfavourably with a rate of growth of 3 per cent for the developing countries as a whole. The deterioration is more noticeable in food production. At a time when Africa’s population was growing at an average annual rate of 2.8 per cent during the 1970s, total food production in the region as a whole was increasing by no more than 1.5 per cent. The result was that food selfsufficiency ratios dropped from 98 per cent in the 1960s to 86 per cent in 1980. In the period 1980-1984, food selfsufficiency ratios declined even further, as food production increased by a mere 1 per cent while population grew at a rate of 3 per cent. The cumulative result is that today about one out of five Africans depends for his or her survival on food imports.
13.	It is obvious, therefore, that the widespread low level of productivity of the African economies is the fundamental cause of their continued underdevelopment and persistent crisis. Thus, a substantial increase in the level of productivity in all sectors, especially in agriculture, is a sine qua non for putting the African economies on .the road to development. Together with that should be structural economic transformation, without which many African countries will not be able to attain the stage of-self-reliant and self-sustained development with the implied flexibilities that will enable them to take their place as effective partners in the international system.
14.	We in Africa are fully aware that the task of structural transformation will require, on our part, a radical change in development priority. Nowhere has this realization^ been more clearly demonstrated than in my own country, Nigeria. The Federal Government of Nigeria has consequently embarked upon major changes in the orientation of devèlopment priorities, to lessen the dependence on the monoculture of oil exports and the attendant serious economic and social' problems.
15.	The Nigerian Government, like most other African Governments, and in consonance with Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery, has embarked on a' medium-term self-reliant structural adjustment programme in order to deal with structural distortions, low productivity and a high level of unemployment in the economy. Agriculture is the main priority. Within that priority, sharp focus is placed on the productive capacity arid improvement of the quality of life of the rural community and small-scale farmers who produce over 90 per cerit-of Nigeria’s output of food and fibre and constitute thé Overwhelming majority'of the population.
16.	On the side of African countries, individually and collectively, there is an unshakeable resolve to mobilize their internal resources and capabilities for the accomplishment of all those measures that are outlined in the Priority Programme to ensure the rapid recovery of the African economies and a substantial improvement in the well-being of our peoples. This special session of the General Assembly should, therefore, address the vital issue of external resource flows for Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery.
17.	The World Bank, which has made a study of the economic crisis facing Africa, states that Africa needs up to $35.3 billion a year over the next five years for the continent to be able to effect a gross domestic product [GDP] growth rate of 3 to 4 per cent a year by 1990. There is a growing consensus that Africa needs economic growth to raise the productivity of the existing capital stock and new investment to increase the share of investment as a proportion of GDP, create new job opportunities, increase consumption and enhance its capacity to service debts. African economies will not respond to structural adjustment if they are stripped to the bone, without the injection of additional resources and without policies which stimulate growth, investment and sustained development. .
18.	In terms of external resource flows for African economic recovery, the General Assembly at this special session has a duty to call for higher targets for official development assistance for Africa. Such assistance declined by about 9 per cent from 1980 to 1984. My delegation is aware that a few countries have of their own free will set higher aid targets. The ratios of official development assistance to gross national product for some countries have already exceeded the international target of 0.7 per cent of GDP. In making this appeal for higher aid targets, I am conscious of the fact that a number of donor countries have announced their commitment to increase their aid targets. However, I should like to urge the Assembly to uphold the principle that no donor country should be a net recipient of resource flows from any African country, in order to ensure that Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery-is not starved of resources. . . ■
19.	Several African countries have already begun to restructure their economies within the framework of the Priority Programme. That commitment to structural adjustment should induce commercial banks to step up lending to productive and export-oriented sectors of African economies. In addition, commercial banks should take full advantage of the increased role given to the private sector in African '.economies to stimulate growth’and increase consumption. Africa’s investment rate fell by 14 per cent in 1984. The current level of investment in Africa is less than what is required for sustained development. African countries would like- to urge commercial banks to exhibit a greater willingness to participate in’ the longer-term development of the African continent by seeking, among other things, nonproject lending on concessionary terms to enable African countries to import raw materials, spare parts and equipment in order to rehabilitate industries and increase the capacities of their under-utilized factories. African economies are not strong enough to bear the burden of short-to medium-term credits. The burden of servicing those debts and the attendant effects are known to have thrown African economies deeper into crisis. ' 20. My delegation wishes to stress the central role that multilateral institutions can play in economic recovery in Africa. The World Bank and other multilateral
institutions have an important role to play in promoting adjustment lending to African countries. Thejndustrial nations have to take urgent political decisions^: increase the resources of these multilateral institutions to enable them to respond much more to the development needs of African countries. Resource scarcity is posing one of the greatest threats to the success of the adjustment, lending programmes of these multilateral institutions. Iri most African States, total investment has been/pn the decline as increased debt-servicing payments and reduced external inflows are accompanied by cuts in both M®| and private investment. But severe budgetary cutsxdrtail " investment and growth on which the creditworthiness of African economies depend. The dilemma of the African situation points to the urgent need to take the political decisions necessary to increase the resources of the multilateral institutions that are willing and eager to respond to the economic crisis in Africa.
21.	Debt relief constitutes an important element in the flow of resources. World Bank statistics show that, inj respect of 10 highly indebted developing nations, total debt service absorbs one third of domestic savings and almost 8 per cent of the GDP. Interest payments alone amount to 4.5 per cent of the GDP. For African countries, debt service is calculated at about $24.5 billion a year between 1986 and 1990. This will exceed by far the most optimistic expectation of resource flows to complement internationally generated resources for the implementation of the Priority Programme. It should be recalled that the expected resource gap is put at $9.1 billion annually in the African document. Therefore, unless this special session takes account of the issue of ' debt relief within the context of resource flows for Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery, I maintain that African economic recovery will not be a reality as long as African countries are expected to meet their debt obligations at the current level. The international community has the responsibility to take political decisions that will result in appropriate debt relief. My delegation appeals to creditor nations and credit institutions to agree to multi-year reschedulings with African countries. Repeated reschedulings create a climate of uncertainty that makes sustained development difficult to achieve. Foreign suppliers exploit such uncertainty by increasing the price of their products. Frequent reschedulings lead to further accumulation of arrears, which in themselves halt new loan commitments.
22.	Africa has sought within the GATT framework unrestricted free access tq the markets of its major trading partners for tropical products. That hope has not been attained. Africa’s exports continue to be buffeted by increasing protectionism, low prices and instability in the exchange rates of the world’s major trading currencies. At this special session the General Assembly should urge Africa’s trading partners to roll back protectionist measures, refrain from introducing new restrictions and improve access to exports of African countries as part of the effort by the international community to increase resource flows to Africa. Africa’s share of world trade is currently very low. African States should be enabled to expand their trade with the rest of the world so as to lay a sound foundation for growth without aid.
23.	I wish to affirm anew the determination and commitment of Africa, its peoples and Governments to the creation of a new economic environment in the region that will enable it to function more effectively in (he international trading and economic system. In turn, Nigeria calls on all States Members of the United Nations and urges the Assembly at this special session to lay the
political framework that will encourage and enable the whole international community to mobilize the necessary resources for assisting the process of the rehabilitation and restoration of Africa’s economy. We consider this the real challenge of interdependence. It is an endeavour that will be found rewarding for all, since what ...helps Africa must also contribute to a durable global '’‘prosperity. -
24.	Let us therefore work for such a world in which we ¿will ipt only be unified in words but also united in action. '■^.' §f;<XA¥OTEN (Finland): Echoing my remarks from this rostrum at the fortieth session, last September [6th meeting], I wish to begin my statement by saying how delighted I am at seeing you, Sir, presiding over our deliberations. As always you can count on the full co-operation of.my delegation.	.
26.	I< also want to thank the Preparatory Committee and its Chairman, Mr. Pisani, as well as the Secretariat, for the thorough, preparations for this special session,
27.
