The European Community is a partner for co-operation on equal terms with regional associations in the third world.
32.	The Netherlands and the Commission of the European Communities have set up a number of priorities on behalf of the European Community and have made proposals of particular importance to the medium- and longterm development of Africa. Permit me to underscore once more some of those ideas. Africa’s economic development can succeed only if Africa itself embarks on the road to economic recovery. Such reforms require bold and decisive action by the African Governments themselves. There are already positive signs of internal policy reforms in Africa. They must be systematically continued.
33.	Absolute priority must be accorded to the development of the rural sector as a whole. Basic food supplies must be ensured everywhere. Before new projects are tackled, existing production facilities and infrastructures, whose functioning has been impaired, must be restored. In this process, the requirements of the natural environment must be taken into account. Also, the gap between population and production growth must not widen. The management of African economies must be improved and the private sector stimulated. Environmental destruction must be curbed and the progressive advance of deserts halted. In this way alone will the problems of rural exodus and urbanization be solved. In this way alone can we open up to the rural population of Africa perspectives for their future. New technological developments must be used to solve the food and energy supply problems of Africa. Existing assistance must be improved and new support initiated. Assistance must be made more effective through better co-ordination among development aid donors themselves, between them and African countries, and within the recipient countries.
34.	Stability and growth of the world economy are a decisive prerequisite for the recovery of the African economies. The Federal Republic of Germany renders an important contribution to this with the economic policies it pursues. But African countries can finance their development and reduce their foreign debts only if industrial nations keep their markets open for African exports. Protectionism poses a serious strain on the development and expansion of Africa’s economies. The Federal Republic of Germany is a staunch champion of free world trade. We realize that no matter how hard the developing countries try to help themselves, their efforts are doomed to failure if their products meet the wall of protectionist measures in the industrial countries. We therefore call for a new round of negotiations in GATT to strengthen the open system of multilateral trade. We pursue our liberal foreign trade policy with determination even where this requires painful structural adjustments.
35.	Our imports from African countries—the Republic of South Africa excepted—were increased by about 9 per cent to 25,650 million marks from 1984 to 1985. In trade
with the Federal Republic of Germany those countries had a surplus of over 10 billion marks in 1985.
36.	We ratified the Agreement Establishing a Common Fund for Commodities, for we understand and share the concern especially of the African countries which derive a large share of their export revenues from their sales of commodities and which are adversely affected by the development in the international commodity markets. However, we must not expect commodity agreements to provide automatic answers to the world’s commodity problems. Our experience with the International Tin Agreement has shown that commodity prices cannot in the long term be kept artificially high irrespective of the market trend. If the situation is to be lastingly stabilized it will be necessary above all to encourage the further processing of commodities in the producer countries and thus improve their market prospects. But such a programme will work out only if the industrial countries remove the barriers to trade and terminate subsidies which hamper and distort competition.
37.	The Lomé Convention is an indication that we are serious about our offer of partnership and co-operation. The Stabex2 and Sysmin3 systems are major instruments in neutralizing the effects of price fluctuations.
38.	The debt burden weighs heavily on the nations of Africa. The necessary adjustments have a broad social and political impact. They cut deeply into the structures of the debtor countries. Adjustments demand persistence in their implementation in the debtor countries, but also comprehension of the limits of the possibilities of the creditor countries. Flexible solutions tailored to each country’s particular needs will therefore have to be worked out. The negotiations on these problems, different from country to country, will have to be continued in the competent international organizations such as IMF, the World Bank and the Paris Club. In drawing up their economic and monetary policies, the industrial countries have to be conscious of their global responsibility, and this applies all the more so the larger they are.
39.	Interest rates are so high that they can be a problem even for some industrial countries. They make it more difficult still for African countries to service their debts and to finance their development. The Federal Republic of Germany has already made sizeable contributions towards easing the pressure of indebtedness on many Africàn countries. Apart from providing non-repayable financial assistance, we have remitted within the context of our financial co-operation debts and interest payments incurred by the poorest countries. This assistance alone has exceeded 4 billion marks.
40.	In spite of all their national efforts, the African nations cannot solve their problems without assistance through development co-operation. Consequently, the Federal Republic of Germany has been co-operating with most African countries since their independence on a partnership basis. At present over 40 per cent of our total bilateral aid goes to Africa, and Africa will remain a focal point of this co-operation and benefit from increases in our development contributions. In recent years this assistance has increased at a faster rate than our national budget.
41.	We want to maintain this trend. Over and above its bilateral assistance, the Federal Government accounts for 26 per cent of the sixth European Development Fund, the biggest contribution. And we are contributing 155 million marks to the European Community’s rehabilitation programme for African countries threatened by drought. Furthermore, Chancellor Helmut Kohl, speaking at the international Silva Conference on tree and forest in Paris
from 5 to 7 February, promised 150 million marks for afforestation projects in Africa. In addition to this aid for Africa, we have also made considerable contributions within the multilateral framework.
42.	In considering how we can help Africa solve its pressing development problems, we cannot avoid the subject of disarmament and development. Colossal sums are being spent on arms. This money cannot be put to use in securing our future, either in the developing or in the developed countries. I have appealed to nations to disclose their military budgets and make them comparable. I reiterate my proposal that the United Nations keep a register of global arms exports and imports. In this way, the basis for global disarmament and arms control could be improved. In Africa, too, more money is being spent on armaments—resources that are so urgently needed in other sectors of the economy. Also in Africa, a policy of mutual understanding and co-operation would release resources that would be of great value for that continent’s development.
43.	Social justice, as well as political and social equality, is essential for the maintenance of internal and external peace. Both of the International Covenants on Human Rights must be realized also for the people of Africa— the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights [resolution 2200 A (XXI), annex].
44.	We are deeply concerend at the depressing situation in southern Africa. We reject any form of apartheid and racial discrimination as practised in the Republic of South Africa. It is utterly inhuman. We demand that the South African Government finally eliminate apartheid. The Federal Republic of Germany condemns South Africa’s continued acts of violence, carried even beyond its borders, as violations of international law.
45.	We demand for Namibia the immediate and unconditional implementation of Security Council resolution 435 (1978).
46.	The Federal Republic of Germany looks back on a long tradition of partnership with Africa. My country will continue to do all it possibly can to further Africa’s development. This special session of the General Assembly must emit a signal of hope. We owe it to the people of Africa to produce tangible, forward-looking conclusions which tackle the medium- and long-term problems of this continent. However, we can achieve results only if the African countries and the international community make their contributions. The Federal Republic of Germany is ready to do so.
47.	Mr. HE Kang (China) (interpretation from Chinese): On the initiative of the OAU and with the support of countries the world over, the special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa has successfully opened. This is the first time since the founding of the United Nations that a special session has been held exclusively to discuss the economic problems of a continent. It shows the grave concern of the whole world over the critical economic situation in Africa and the close attention it pays to this problem. The Chinese Government wishes to extend its warm congratulations on the convening of this session and sincerely hopes that it will make positive contributions to the revitalization of the African economy.
48.	The presence at this session of President Diouf, current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity, and his important statement [lit meeting] have demonstrated the strong will and common desire of the African countries and peoples to overcome their difficulties and develop
their economies. The analysis of the current economic situation and proposals made thereon by African countries have provided a sound basis for an in-depth discussion of alb items on the agenda of the present session.
49.	We should like to express our appreciation to the OAU Permanent Steering Committee, EC A, the Preparatory Committee for the special session, the United Nations Secretariat and other United Nations agencies for the great amount of work they have done for the convening of the session. The Chinese delegation stands ready to co-operate closely with representatives from Africa and other continents and will do its best to make the session a complete success,
50.	With the unprecedented upsurge of the national liberation movement in Africa after the Second World War, African countries won political independence one after another. The ascension of Africa to the world arena as a vigorous newly emerging force is a great historic event of our time.
51.	Today, most African countries have entered a new phase of history focusing on developing the national economy, consolidating their political independence and improving the people’s living standard. Proceeding from fragile economies which are a legacy of colonialism, African countries have been trudging along a rough and tortuous road of advance. In particular, the continiied deterioration of the African economic situation and the sufferings of the African people over the past few years have aroused the general concern and deep sympathy of the world. As pointed out by the OAU Assembly of Heads of State and Government at its twenty-first session, in July 1985, they are faced with a dual challenge of survival and development.
52.	The present critical economic situation in Africa has deep-rooted historical causes. It should be stressed that the prolonged colonial rule has resulted in massive plundering of Africa’s natural resources, destruction of the ecological balance, a lopsided economic structure and stagnation of economic development, bringing enormous miseries to the African people. Irrefutable historical facts have shown that Africa is the continent that has'suffered most from colonialism.
53.	Africa has not only borne the heavy burden left over from the past, but has also been tightly fettered by the existing inequitable and unjust international economic order. The economic crisis in developed countries has further aggravated Africa’s economic difficulties. The incessant drop in prices for Africa’s raw materials and primary products, the continued deterioration of its terms of trade, the increasingly harsh conditionality applied to loans and credits from international financial institutions and the gradual decrease in real terms of official development aid and the inflow of capital have resulted in a stagnation and shrinkage of production, huge deficits of international payments, heavier debt burdens, a steady fall in per capita income and worsening impoverishment in many African countries. All those unfavourable external factors, in addition to the serious natural calamities of recent years, have so far hindered the economic recovery and development of Africa.
54.	As it has not been long since the African countries won their independence, economic development and national construction are still new tasks for them. When there is no ready model for them to follow and no experience from other countries to draw on, deviations and errors of one kind or another are unavoidable in the course of their exploration and advance. By applying the experience gained in continued practice, African countries
are gradually finding a road of development suited to their domestic conditions. . .
55.	We are pleased to note that many African countries are making praiseworthy efforts in seeking the right way to rehabilitate and develop their economies. While pointing out the grave consequences of unfavourable external factors to African economies, the OAU Assembly last year made an incisive analysis of the adverse effects of mismanagement of their economic strategies and policies. Today, African countries are trying to shift the focus of their national life to economic development by giving priority to agricultural development, especially food production. They are also promoting the interdependence of diversified economic modes to bring into play the initiative of various sectors in developing production. They are carrying out extensive international co-operation and promoting regional economic.exchanges so as to enhance their ability for collective self-reliance. It is encouraging that economic reform and policy readjustment in African countries have achieved some initial results, thus promoting production and improving the people’s living standards. .
56.	In the face of the present grim international economic environment, it is an extremely arduous task for African countries to rehabilitate and develop their economies. The African countries cannot possibly accomplish this through their own efforts alone. The international community should give active support and all-out assistance so as to create the necessary external environment for them. The major task of this special session is to mobilize the international community in a concerted effort to help the African countries revitalize their economies.
57.	We have noted that the international community has rendered some support to the African countries in their economic development, and in recent years it has again-provided a considerable amount of emergency aid to the people of the African countries afflicted with drought,, which has helped to alleviate the sufferings caused by famine. At present, although the famine in Africa has been eased to some extent, the economic difficulties in Africa remain extremely serious, and new and greater efforts by the international community are needed to support the. African countries in fulfilling Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19901 and their medium- and long-term development plans. In this connection, we believe that the developed countries are all the more duty-bound to respond to the appeal of the African countries by adopting a farsighted approach and taking practical and effective steps .gradually to remove the external factors that are seriously hindering economic development in Africa.
58.	First, the development assistance to African countries should be increased and the financing of agricultural and food production in Africa should be stressed so as to help the African countries attain the goal of selfsufficiency in food supplies at an early date. The targets of development assistance specified in the. International Development. Strategy for the Third United Nations Development Decade [resolution 55/56] and the Substantial New Programme of Action for the. 1980s for the Least Developed Countries4 should be fully realized in Africa.
59.	Secondly, on the debt problem, the creditors should assume co-responsibility with the African debtor countries and help them revitalize their economies. Debt rescheduling should be carried out by the two sides through consultation. The developed countries should reduce the debt burden of the debtor countries or extend the period of repayment according to different circumstances.. And it is particularly necessary to reduce or liquidate the debts
of the least developed African countries out of consideration for their plight.
60.	Thirdly, on the issue of trade, protectionism should be eliminated so as to open more markets to African countries, and in particular the non-tariff barriers on African products should be removed. It is necessary to take measures to raise and stabilize the export prices of African primary products and reverse the trend of sharp decline in their export earnings. Efforts should be made to help the African countries enhance their capability in processing, marketing and transporting their export products.
61.	Fourthly, on the financial issue, inflow of capital to African countries should be increased. The terms of their credits should be softened and more loans on preferential terms should be provided. Interest rates should be further reduced, and consideration should be given to the African countries’ demand for increasing their quotas in IMF.
62.	We hope that the developed countries will give serious consideration to the actual difficulties and urgent demands of African countries and actively strengthen friendly co-operation with them in the interest of common progress.
63.	China and Africa shared similar historical experiences and now face common immediate tasks. The Chinese Government and people have always followed with interest the developments in Africa and deeply sympathize with the African people in their grave difficulties. China itself is a low-income developing country, but we have always regarded it as our bounden international duty to give support and assistance to African countries and peoples. The Chinese Government and people have always stood by the African countries in their struggles to win and safeguard national independence and oppose racism. We have done what we can to provide assistance to the African countries in their national construction.
64.	Africa has all along occupied an important place in China’s programme of foreign aid and economic and technical co-operation. The late Premier Zhou Enlai and Premier Zhao Ziyang both paid visits to Africa, during which they put forward the five principles guiding the relations between China and the African countries, the eight principles on China’s foreign aid and the four principles on economic and technical co-operation between China and the African countries. These principles have several main features. First, support and assistance are always mutual and not a one-way undertaking; China has helped Africa, and Africa has in turn helped China. Secondly, China sees to it that the State sovereignty and national dignity of the recipient countries are strictly respected, and China would in no way try to interfere in their internal affairs or ask for any privileges. Thirdly, the terms for aid should be favourable as far as possible. Fourthly, aid should be provided in light of the actual conditions of African countries so as to meet the needs of developing their national economies and enhancing their capability of self-reliance and not to make them dependent on China. Fifthly, while continuing to provide economic assistance, China makes efforts to explore broader.areas and diversified channels for economic and technical co-operation with the African countries on the principle of equality and mutual benefit and common progress so as to enable economic aid and economic cooperation to promote each other in concerted endeavour to push forward the South-South co-operation.
65.	Following these principles, China has established good relations of co-operation and has developed profound friendship with the African countries. China has
now signed agreements on economic and technical cooperation with more than 40 African countries and has undertaken over 460 economic aid projects, including medium-sized and small industrial, agricultural, railway, highway, marine transport, medical care and public health projects. In times of adversity when Africa was hit by sustained drought, we did our best to donate a certain amount of relief food. The seven projects under the emergency agriculture and livestock rehabilitation programme launched by FAO, to which we have contributed and which we have undertaken to implement, are now being carried out successfully. China’s Red Cross Society launched a nation-wide campaign last year to collect donations for the afflicted people in Africa. The donations are being delivered to the affected countries in the form of medicine, farm implements, food and other materials. Although the assistance we can provide is modest due to the limited strength of our country, China is sincere in rendering assistance to Africa.
66.	The Chinese Government is ready to make continued efforts to study and discuss the question of medium-and long-term development of Africa together with the African countries and the international community. With the growth of its economy and national strength, China will gradually increase its economic aid to and expand its economic co-operation with Africa. We will continue to provide long-term interest-free loans to African countries within our capabilities. If the countries concerned do find it difficult to repay the loans when they are due, the repayment can be deferred. China’s provision of loans to the African countries is a kind of mutual assistance between poor friends. Under no circumstances will China press for debt servicing.
67.	In accordance with the Priority Programme for Economic Recovery put forward by the African countries, we will give priority to our agricultural aid to Africa by increasing the proportion of aid to agriculture and to the farm produce processing industry in Africa so as to contribute to Africa’s self-sufficiency in food grains. We will increase our assistance to intellectual development in Africa, attaching special importance to the training of specialists in agriculture and other related fields. While strengthening and replenishing our work force for agricultural co-operation with Africa, we will create conditions for the establishment and good operation of training centres of Sino-African agricultural co-operation in order to train agrotechnicians and managerial personnel for Africa.
68.	In this connection, I am happy to point out that recently, at Guangzhou, China served as host to an Asian-African Workshop on Food Policy, under the sponsorship of WFC. During that Workshop experiences were exchanged in regard to solving food problems and developing agricultural production and methods, and prospects for the further strengthening of co-operation between China and African countries in the field of food and agriculture were explored. The Workshop was a complete success. ■
69.	We shall join the African countries in our continuous efforts to learn from each other. China and the African countries have both accumulated rich experience, positive and negative, in their economic development, and we both are engaged in economic reforms and policy readjustment. Exchanges of experience and learning from each other to make up for our deficiencies will help achieve our economic prosperity as well as common progress. ' 70. We are determined to work together with the African countries, other developing countries and the whole
international community and to make unremitting efforts for the establishment of the new international economic order, the strengthening of South-South co-operation and the promotion of North-South dialogue so as to seek the sound development of the world economy as a whole. 71. Africa is a developing continent with vast areas, abundant resources and a great potential for development. The rise of Africa in the political arena has had a great impact on the progress of human society and the growth of forces for peace. We are convinced that, through their unyielding efforts and with the close co-operation and energetic support of the international community, the African countries will be able to overcome the serious difficulties facing them and achieve a fundamental turn for the better in their economic situation. An economically prosperous Africa will surely make a tremendous contribution to world peace and development.
72.	Sir Geoffrey HOWE (United Kingdom): I am delighted to have the opportunity of attending this special session. My country has had a long and close association with Africa. The ties of history, language, culture and trade are strong. Personal and public links abound.
73.	When I was Chairman of the Interim Committee of IMF three years ago, the human and economic problems of Africa were already a high priority for the world community. Since then events, often tragic, have brought these problems closer to every one of us.
74.	The problem we face is the development of a whole continent: daunting but not, I think, impossible. Nor, with respect to the economists, is it a problem that can or should be reduced to abstract aggregates. It touches the lives of more than half a billion Africans. It is for those people, and for their welfare, that we at this special session should be working.
75.	Development is not Africa’s only problem. History has left many unresolved political disputes. Foreign interference did not end with the demise of colonization, and South Africa casts a long shadow. Whether or not these problems are successfully resolved, we shall still have to face up to the need for economic development.
76.	The beginning of wisdom in this as in all things is understanding. I have been greatly impressed by the African paper. It is a most perceptive document, which has formed the basis of much of our discussion. It is right that we should begin with African views.
77.	It is right too to begin with the appalling spectre of famine. Hunger in Africa has succeeded, like few other human catastrophes, in touching the consciences of the more fortunate and in releasing a tide of spontaneous generosity that knows no frontier. Millions of ordinary people have made.their contribution to help the starving in response to the challenges of Live Aid and Sport Aid. The British people gave millions of pounds to Bob Geldof’s Band Aid, and a quarter of a million of them ran for Sport Aid last Sunday. Their hearts are in the right place when it comes to Africa. It is for Governments to play their part as well.
78.	For too many years too little attention has been paid to man’s most basic need, the production of food. Africa needs adequate, reliable and cheap supplies. Africa has the capacity to feed itself. Yet in Africa hunger persists in many places. That should be an affront to our consciences. Thankfully, the short-term situation has improved. Through our programmes and through the European Community, Britain has committed <£189 million for. famine relief over the last two years. We stand ready to provide further such help, where it is necessary.
79.	But we must look beyond emergencies to the longer term. We must help Africa to help itself, I know that the policies of developed countries have sometimes aggravated its problems. Pressure from major world food producers to dispose of subsidized surpluses on world markets has discouraged those who could produce food more cheaply. Other restrictions on trade in agricultural products have not helped.
80.	While the surpluses of the developed world were being built up in the last two decades, cereal production in Africa fell. Food aid has thus been needed at times of crisis, but it is a solution neither to our own excess production nor to shortages in Africa. Last month’s Tokyo Economic Summit Meeting stressed that overproduction in the face of famine is a problem that must be tackled on a world-wide basis.
81.	In Africa itself the need for change is certainly recognized. A number of countries are taking steps to establish price and other incentives for farmers and more efficient food-marketing systems. Research capacity is being built up, and scientific methods more practically applied. Britain is already helping in many of these areas. We joined in the international activity co-ordinated by the Office for Emergency Operations in Africa, under the leadership of a great philanthropist, Bradford Morse. This was a dynamic response to a grave situation. It brought together the resources of this Organization and donor Governments. Their successful interaction may prove to be a model for the future. Britain will play its full part in further such co-operative efforts.
82.	I spoke of the need for change. There is, I believe, a growing mood of realism and an understanding that mistakes have been made. Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,1 adopted by the heads of State and Government of the OAU last July, provides convincing evidence of seriousness of approach.
83.	Intelligent long-term planning is rightly seen as a key. But a central role for government does not and must not mean huge bureaucracies. Here too there is a growing realism in the approach of many African countries to the size and role of the public sector. Leaner and more efficient administrations are being allowed to emerge. Individual talent must be given commensurate responsibility. Management efficiency must be improved, public spending brought under control, and subsidies adjusted. These are painful decisions; I know from experience the political courage required. •
84.	Development programmes too require careful scrutiny. Many African countries are now reviewing public investment plans with a sharper eye to the real future costs and benefits. They recognize the need for a climate favourable to private investment, freed of the restrictions of the past. •
85.	The development of the right mix of public and private is vital. But there are two areas where the lead has to come from government: safeguarding the environment and facing the problem, of population growth.
86,	For the sake of future generations, a more determined and practical effort is being made to introduce better farming and soil conservation, to rehabilitate forests and to develop more harvesting of timber. Individual farmers will do what they can, but they need guidance and incentives. We ourselves are involved in parts of Africa in precisely this kind of endeavour, and we propose to do more.
87.	Finally, population. It is often said that Africa is an empty continent. Not so. On present trends the population of Africa will approach 900 million by the end of
the century. How is such population growth to be reconciled with decent living standards? Africa, if it is not careful, will find itself having to run in order merely to stay where it is. I know the sensitivities, but the problem does have to be faced. We shall give any help we can.
88.	Development is a partnership. A prosperous Africa means a more prosperous world. In the industrialized countries we recognize the importance of maintaining open trading conditions. At the Tokyo Summit we made a clear declaration on this. We are fully committed to the success of the new GATT round of multilateral trade negotiations. At the special ministerial session of the Contracting Parties in September this year we shall work for early and decisive progress.
89.	Concessionary assistance will still be vital, in all forms and from both bilateral donors and multilateral institutions. We share the strong hope that an eighth replenishment of $12 billion will be achieved for IDA.
90.	I welcome the new IMF Structural Adjustment Facility and the closer co-operation between IMF and the World Bank. These developments, together with the Bank’s Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa, with which we are associating a special allocation of our bilateral aid, are a major demonstration of the concern we all feel for the needs of Africa. So was the outcome of Lomé III.
91.	I also regard as important the creation of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, of which Britain is a founder member. As I indicated earlier, overseas investment has a key role to play. Britain gives high priority to Africa in the allocation of our aid resources: over ¿550 million through bilateral and multilateral channels in 1985. We shall continue to make a substantial effort.
92.	It is not just a matter of prestige projects. Nonproject aid is increasingly important. We are providing substantial sums in this form to a number of countries undertaking programmes of economic reform. We aim, with our partners in Africa, to place more emphasis on a comprehensive approach to particular sectors. Our approach to new projects and programmes reflects the high priority we attach to the development of natural resources.
93.	One aspect of this work is the improvement of public administration and management efficiency. Britain has long helped to provide skilled manpower and training in Africa. We propose to place greater emphasis on this, concentrating in particular on helping to strengthen key institutions.
94.	Our experience in development has taught us that the difficulties, the solutions and the responses from donors need to be tackled individually, on a country-bycountry basis. The same applies to the treatment of debt. The management of a country’s debt cannot realistically be separated from the other elements in its external financial position. I see no alternative but to deal with this issue on an individual basis and through existing international structures. Already for the poorest countries our aid does not add to the burden of debt, since it is provided on a grant basis. For 13 African countries we have commuted past aid loans to grants—a total of £250 million. Britain blazed the trail on retrospective terms adjustment. We are pleased to have been followed down that trail by others.
95.	This is a time for concern but not, I think, a time for despair. I draw hope from the improvement in world trading conditions and from the positive response already made by the multilateral institutions. They have our firm
support. The international community rightly places priority on the needs of Africa. I am certain that in the years to come we shall see the rich potential of Africa and of all its peoples more and more fully realized, and I look forward to that day.
96.	Mr. MAJEWSKI (Poland): May I express our satisfaction, Sir, at working once again under your wise guidance as President of the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly. Our work will also be facilitated by the illuminating statement made yesterday [1st meeting] by Mr. Diouf, President of the Republic of Senegal and Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity. We also wish to express our satisfaction with the Secretary-General’s personal contribution to our task.
97.	In addressing this debate the Polish delegation is well aware of the extreme complexity and gravity of the problems facing us at this session, for they have a macro-economic dimension, embracing the whole of the continent and dozens of Member States of the Organization. This is a debate on the mechanisms which have generated the present situation on the African continent and a debate on what should be done in order to help Africa overcome its current difficulties.
98.	The situation under discussion has not only economic and political dimensions; it has also human and social dimensions because of the millions of Africans of, whole nations who every day are exposed to the cruel effects of this situation. Therefore, the solutions and decisions to be adopted at this session are of utmost urgency.
99.	We realize, however, that the extremely difficult and complex economic realities of Africa cannot be remedied at a special session of the General Assembly unless a change takes place at the very roots of the problem in African countries—unless a change occurs in their relationship with the outside world and they are given a due share in the international division of labour. .
100.	But, first of all, we wish strongly to emphasize our inability to solve these problems in a comprehensive manner as long as the broad context of the global political situation within which they arise remains unchanged. Nations do not develop in isolation. We are living in a world of feedback between politics and economics. Meanwhile, the course the international situation is taking causes our gravest concern.
101.	The policy of confrontation and armament imposed by the forces of imperialism has been extended to the African continent as well. Attempts are being made to divide Africa and include some areas in the strategic plans of the West, to instigate regional conflicts, to utilize economic aid as an element of political pressure and even to commit outright armed aggression, such as the act recently carried out against Libya. Those who pursue this policy are ready to sacrifice the aspirations of the peoples of South Africa and Namibia for freedom. They tolerate the aggressiveness of South Africa, which was demonstrated on the eve of our session by the absolutely unprovoked criminal assault carried out by South African troops against Botswana, Zimbabwe and Zambia. This is aimed at the destabilization of the whole southern part of the continent, forces increased spending on legitimate defence and creates obstacles to the development of Africa.
102.	By reversing this dangerous course—above all through halting the arms race and returning to détente and constructive dialogue, including dialogue on the reconstruction of international economic relations—we would be providing the world with the greatest of benefits
and creating the proper conditions for the solution of the problems of Africa.
103.	It is in this spirit, with feelings of traditional solidarity and friendship with African peoples, that Poland is participating in this session, for there exists an intimate relationship among peace, disarmament and social and economic development. In our foreign policy we have consistently attached the greatest importance to questions of the maintenance of international peace and security. Our activities and initiatives in the General Assembly have been aimed at precisely that goal.
104.	In the economic field we recently submitted a proposal on confidence-building measures in international economic relations. We did this with a view to creating an internationally approved system to protect those relations from the negative impact of political tension. We are well aware that this cannot offer a substitute for the restructuring of international economic relations in keeping with the principles of justice, equal rights and mutual benefits. At the present stage, however, the adoption of relevant confidence-building measures would considerably improve the international climate and international relations. We believe that this session offers a good opportunity to promote this idea and to include it in the final document to be adopted at the end of our deliberations.
105.	The implementation of this idea would prevent the use of the economic weapon for political ends. There will be no new international economic order unless the developed capitalist States accept the fact that the rest of the world is not a mere appendix to their system. Interference in the internal relations of other States by imposing specific patterns of development has become a permanent feature of the policy of some of those States. We reject such practices. We believe that it is brutal interference in the internal affairs of numerous developing countries to criticize their economic policies from the position of the vested interests of capitalism. This is also incompatible with the fundamental principles of the Organization, which provide for free choice of social and political system and of organizational form of economic life.
106.	Attempts to shift the blame for the ills of Africa exclusively to patterns of development, structural factors or institutional solutions are seen by us as a way of abdicating responsibility for the destructive social and economic processes in Africa, which were born of colonialism and which continued by way of neo-colonial subordination of a number of States there. We believe that the former colonial Powers cannot shirk their responsibility for the situation on the continent where colonialism has inflicted the greatest damage and where neo-colonial-ism deepens economic backwardness. Attempts by the former colonial Powers to disclaim their historical responsibility for the situation in Africa and to enforce new systems of dependence and subservience give rise to particular concern.
107.	The current massive foreign debt incurred by a number of States, including African States, is a very serious obstacle to their economic growth. The problem of the relationship between foreign debt and development and the negative impact of debt on development should become a matter for deeper study. That conviction of ours gave rise to the proposal made by Polish leader Wojciech Jaruzelski at the 12th meeting of the fortieth anniversary session of the General Assembly, that an international debt and development research centre be created under the auspices of the Secretary-General, and that its organizational meeting be held in the Polish city of Cracow. We reiterate that proposal. The debt burden,
which has created a barrier to development not only in Africa but in practically the whole world, has become today the most urgent international economic problem and is in dire need of a solution. Therefore, we believe that the African debt problem can be effectively solved only if it becomes part and parcel of a comprehensive general solution. However, we are realistic; frankly speaking, we do not expect a speedy solution of this complex problem, although we realize the urgency and immediacy of it.
108.	We approach the present economic and financial problems which so seriously affect the African continent with utmost concern. For our part, we lend permanent and consistent support to efforts to restructure international economic relations to take into consideration the interests of all developing countries. Co-operation with developing countries is a priority of Polish foreign policy. 109. The Polish delegation came to this session with a record of time-honoured close co-operation with African States stemming from our solidarity with and support for their struggle, first for political liberation and later for the consolidation of their economic sovereignty. It is worth mentioning here that it was the initiative of our country, Poland, that led the United Nations to adopt a resolution on the permanent sovereignty of States over their natural resources. We have never failed to carry out and promote a fruitful dialogue with Africa. We support the aspirations of Africa to life in peace, free from tension, under a just international economic order. We pursue stable and concrete co-operation in the fields of the economy, science and technology. We shall continue to render support and assistance where it is particularly needed: the struggle of the African National Congress of South Africa to abolish apartheid in South Africa and the struggle of the South West Africa People’s Organization to liberate the Namibian people from South African occupation. In our relations with the African continent we are open to a deepening of a mutually advantageous division of labour based on longterm programmes of economic co-operation in trade, services and joint ventures.
110.	For the discussions on the critical economic situation in Africa, many papers and documents have been prepared to acquaint us, through comprehensive statistics and facts, with the problems faced by that continent. Yet not all these documents provide a thorough analysis of the causes of the present situation and offer realistic ways and means for resolving the crisis. This applies also to some of the documents prepared for this special session of the General Assembly.
111.	The absence of a clear allocation of responsibility for the present situation, the essence of which we have tried to explain in our statement, creates a tendency to saddle all countries in equal measure with responsibility for improving the situation. In our view, that is not the right approach, and we do not consider ourselves bound by recommendations and obligations arising from it. We also think that it is a serious lapse that the documents omit the question of the interdependence of disarmament and development, especially as this is precisely the area in which the means of overcoming the economic crisis in Africa could be sought. On the other hand, we find those parts of the documentation which expand our knowledge of African countries and their pressing problems useful. Such information could be of great assistance in planning co-operation with those countries on both the bilateral and the multilateral level.
112.	In the documents prepared for this session stress is put on the development of agriculture and food production as a special measure in overcoming the present
economic crisis in Africa. In the opinion of the Polish delegation, one measure that would contribute to the attainment of that goal is the adoption of the principle of the free flow of experience, technology and organizational arrangements in the area of food production, processing and storage. Poland could share with African countries its experience in the manufacturing of farm machinery and implements and provide relevant documentation in that field, as well as make available the results of research into high-yield plants adapted to dry climates.
113.	Furthermore, we could share our experience in the area of co-operatives, the organization of rural centres for production, the training and dissemination of advanced farming techniques, the organization of veterinary services and so on. Upon request, we would be prepared to assist in the adaptation of technology and organizational arrangements to local conditions, in co-operation with United Nations specialized agencies.
114.	Thousands of top-class specialists in different fields from African countries have been trained and educated in Polish schools and universities. We shall continue and, wherever possible, expand the training of African personnel in Poland, as well as continue to send our specialists to Africa. There are thousands of Polish experts working in Africa in various sectors of agriculture, industry and construction. Polish design and consulting firms participate in many construction and industrial projects in Africa. There is growing co-operation in science and technology. We are ready to promote such forms of cooperation on terms convenient to African countries. Within the limits of our possibilities, we have been extending emergency aid to Africa; this is especially true of famine relief for Ethiopia.
115.	In a spirit of solidarity and friendship, we shall consistently develop and broaden the possibilities I have mentioned.
116.	Mr. SHULTZ (United States of America): This special session could—and we hope will—mark a historic turning point for the African continent. We meet in a year when the world is still anguished by the terrible images of famine and starvation that have scarred so much of Africa during the last two years. With an extraordinary outpouring of support, people from across the globe have rallied to Africa’s side and saved millions of lives.
117.	Today we are gathered here to address a more fundamental and enduring task: that of meeting the requirements of long-term development for Africa. The United States comes to this special session with hope. We salute the work of the OAU at the meeting of its Assembly in 1985 for the new directions which the African nations have pledged for themselves. And we welcome this session of the General Assembly as a way of translating their pledge into action.
118.	Our search for solutions to the problems of development is one of the forces that bring us together today, but it is not the only force. We are united, too, by respect and admiration for the dignity of the African peoples in the face of shared hardships. Thirty years ago the United Nations joined in support as Africans fought for freedom from colonial rule. Today we come together to seek Africa’s liberation from other ills: disease, chronic poverty and hunger.
119.	The United States has consistently sought a constructive role in Africa’s struggles. We have provided unprecedented levels of foreign assistance. During this
Administration aid to Africa has increased by over 50 per cent. Current levels of aid are four times those of the early 1970s. In the last three years alone we have provided $2.4 billion in food and emergency assistance.
120.	Effective partnership requires a shared understanding of past mistakes and present goals. This special session holds unique promise, because we seem to be closer than ever to reaching such understanding. We have learned a great deal together about what does and does not work. We have seen how now discredited orthodoxies about State-directed development gave rise to misguided policies that stifled individual initiative, policies that in practice have given inadequate incentives to African farmers and created a long-term decline in food production.
121.	Today, as a result, millions of Africa’s people depend on food imports for their very survival. The burden of foreign debt, which in sub-Saharan Africa rose by an annual average of 21 per cent throughout the 1970s, has reached crisis proportions. Measures of standard economic performance reveal that economic conditions on the continent as a whole are no better, and are perhaps worse, than they were some 25 years ago—all this despite massive injections of foreign aid.
122.	The purpose of this special session is to chart a course that will reverse those trends. According to the draft basic final document prepared by the African States for this session, our task requires that “the African countries adopt fundamental changes in their development priorities and policies” [see A/S-13/4 and Corr.l, annex V, para. 7], And I think we can agree that successful development in any nation—in Africa as anywhere else—lies fundamentally in the expansion of individual human opportunity.
123.	Even modest advances in material well-being can accelerate development. With rising income, a farmer is able to save and provide some economic insurance to his family against natural misfortunes such as drought. With rising income, a small-business owner may be able to send another child to school, increasing the promise of his family’s future. In any walk of life, people freed from dire deprivation are better able to seize the opportunities before them.
124.	The United States firmly believes that our own development experience is a useful guide to productive economic policies. What is the most fundamental lesson of that experience? It is that the talents of individual human beings are the greatest resource a society can bring to the tasks of national development. America has seen this truth at work in its agricultural era, in its industrial phase and in its post-industrial development. And we have seen our dedication to that truth translated throughout our society into better opportunities for succeeding generations.
125.	Our experience is hardly the only example of this truth. Today many countries are reawakening to the fundamental connection between individual initiative and economic process. In East Asia, the liberation of the individual talent from State-imposed economic direction has produced in recent years nothing less than an economic miracle among developing nations. Their experience confirms that there is nothing culture-bound about the creation of material well-being. Even communist nations are awakening to the fact that individual initiative, not State direction, is the source of growth. China’s unprecedented experiment with unleashing individual incentives has been remarkably successful in recent years, and we note that the Soviet Union, at its XXVIIth Party Congress, called for less emphasis on central planning and more on individual initiative.
126.	Many African nations, too, have undertaken bold reforms of economic policy. Across the continent major programmes are under way to stimulate growth. In Senegal, Zambia, Guinea, Zaire, Somalia, the Central African Republic, Mali, Rwanda, Togo and Madagascar exciting changes are taking place as leaders seek to stimulate economic growth. These leaders are recognizing, as the OAU declared last July, that the primacy accorded the State has hindered rather than furthered economic development. Agricultural pricing is being reformed to give farmers a fair and profitable return on their output. Private marketing channels are being revived to bring food to the cities and consumer goods to the countryside. Exchange systems are being revamped to reflect market value and tó permit allocation of scarce resources to the most productive sectors.
127.	These are historic changes, and they point to a new generation of African progress. The United States is supporting this trend through bilateral and multilateral programmes. This special session provides an opportunity for all of Africa to join in what is a world-wide movement by rejecting failed orthodoxies and giving greater scope to individual initiative.
128.	Our agreement on the simple truth of the critical role of the individual in development is the cornerstone of the new partnership emphasized by this session. But the tasks of economic liberation do not fall to individual Africans, their Governments or to foreign donor countries alone. We must search together for policies that will work across the full range of our partnership, as the following examples suggest.
129.	First, donor countries must design assistance programmes that increase self-reliance and discourage dependency. Some of our assistance has been counter-productive, contributing to stagnating public sectors rather than to vital private enterprise. As a result, we are starting to shift more assistance from public to private entities. Two years ago, through the Economic Policy Reform Program, we began using our foreign aid resources to give incentives and support to countries that had undertaken such internal reforms. In 1985, under this Program, we gave $75 million to five African countries: Malawi, Mali, Mauritius, Rwanda and Zambia. This year we are engaged in discussions with four other African countries which may join our Program. We can do more for Africans who are trying to reform their economies, and we will.
130.	Secondly, African and donor nations alike must work together to create conditions favourable to investment. The continent’s natural resources offer great promise. Africa has some 220 million hectares of arable land. Only half of this has ever been cultivated. Only 3 per cent of its hydroelectric power has been harnessed. And the continent is rich in the vast amounts of fresh water needed to bring growth to barren fields.
131.	But these resources cannot be put to work without investment, and investment requires confidence. Political stability creates the conditions for economic advance, not vice versa. If countries want to attract foreign and domestic capital they must begin by recognizing the imperative of creating an environment of confidence. Here, too, the United States can help, through diplomatic and other assistance aimed at securing individual rights, social justice and political stability. And I might say that a system of apartheid, and the across-border violence that seems to go with it, destroys confidence and is antithetical to the kind of investment climate we are seeking to set up, apart from being unacceptable in its own right.
132.	Thirdly, we must keep trade opportunities open. The United States has taken a series of steps to maintain
free and fair trade. In the new GATT round of multilateral trade negotiations we will be seeking to liberalize trade for the benefit of all countries. African countries should note that our Generalized System of Preferences programme emphasizes benefits for the less advantaged nations. For their part, Africans must guard against protectionist policies that discourage broader trade on the continent and elsewhere.
133.	Fourthly, assistance must come not only from individual donor States, but also from the multilateral arena, and I might say from the non-governmental organizations as well. These organizations have made and continue to make important contributions to the mobilization of private resources and to the development of essential human resources. Africa remains the neediest continent. The United States, with its own budgetary concerns, cannot meet all the African requests for assistance. So we are exploring creative alternatives.
134.	Last fall, we proposed a plan to IMF and the World Bank which would substantially increase the flow of concessional resources to Africa and other least-developed areas of the world. The IMF has adopted the Structural Adjustment Facility, which should result in an increase of $1.5 billion in low-interest loans for Africa in the next five years. We are currently engaged in negotiations with other donors on the eighth replenishment of the World Bank’s IDA. The final decision on the eighth replenishment remains open, but the United States does want to secure a substantial, increased share of IDA for Africa. Together with the new IMF Structural Adjustment Facility, the eighth replenishment will provide a major source of support for the steps that African nations have agreed to in recent OAU documents and here at the special session.
135.	Finally, we must develop production technologies appropriate to the African environment, especially in the critical area of agriculture. Agricultural production, the continent’s one-time mainstay, has regressed drastically in the last 20 years. It is now 15 years since Norman Borlaug received the Nobel Peace Prize for his pioneering research. That research helped launch the green revolutions that started India and Mexico along the road to self-sufficiency in food grains. For years many have tried to bring the same revolution to Africa, although thus far without success.
136.	The good news is that this may be changing. We seem to be standing at the threshold of an agricultural revolution adapted to African conditions. Last year an African geneticist by the name of Gebisa Ejeta—trained at Purdue University in the United States—spearheaded the successful effort to develop a new hybrid sorghum strain which is pest- and drought-resistant. This new strain has doubled the yield derived from local strains under normal weather conditions. These varieties contributed to Sudan’s surplus this year. Improved maize varieties, combined with improved agricultural policies, contributed to grain surpluses in Kenya, Zimbabwe and Malawi.
137.	The United States is committed to supporting the development of agricultural technologies suited to Africa. We plan to give some $1 billion for agricultural research over the next 15 years. With our support, international agricultural research centres and a new umbrella organization, the Program for African Agricultural Research, are also leading an international effort to bring an agricultural explosion to the continent.
138.	As is demonstrated by the example of Gebisa Ejeta, the resolution of Africa’s economic crisis lies in the liberation of its peoples from policies that have stifled
innovation and led the nations of the continent into their present difficulties.
139.	In the years since independence African and donor nations alike have learned a great deal about our respective roles in promoting development. Africans have learned that responsibility for their economic well-being rests squarely with themselves. The United States and other donor countries have had to learn another hard truth: that well-intentioned programmes can produce dependency rather than self-sufficiency, economic stagnation rather than self-sustaining growth. And we have all learned another sobering truth: flawed governmental policies can hurt economies just as surely as the natural calamities that have afflicted Africa. No amount of foreign assistance and no measure of good intentions can alleviate the hardship caused by a Government bent on misguided policies.
140.	But we know, too, that if inappropriate policies have created many of Africa’s problems, appropriate new policies will help to ameliorate them. This special session confirms our partnership in the search for workable approaches to long-term development on the continent. As our work unfolds in the coming days we can take heart not only from our converging views, but also from the fact that some global economic trends are now turning in Africa’s favour.
141.	The economic recovery of the industrialized nations over the past few years is giving much-needed expansion to markets for exports from the developing world. Africa, located close to the major markets of Europe, is well positioned to profit from that growth. Meanwhile, the decline in world oil prices—the equivalent of a tax cut for most of the world—should stimulate economic activity throughout much of the continent. Most African nations should also benefit from the drop in interest rates and the readjustment of other currencies against the United States dollar—the currency in which most African debts are denominated.
142.	African leaders and donor nations alike face many obstacles in our work to brighten the continent’s future. But we are engaged in that struggle together. Today, as leaders throughout the continent re-examine the foundations of economic growth and seek new promise for Africa, we must all ensure that our efforts will fulfil the needs of coming generations. The peoples of Africa, and their many friends throughout the world, await with hope our actions at this historic session. May our efforts be worthy of their aspirations.
143.	Mr. HORN (Hungary) (interpretation from Russian): The Hungarian People’s Republic fully shares the concern of international public opinion at the extremely grave economic situation of millions of people in Africa. The elimination of the crisis in that continent calls for effective international action, as well as the mobilization of internal energies and resources.
144.	Since the interdependence of countries and continents is a characteristic of the world of today, no problem on any continent can be addressed in isolation from the question of the well-being of other regions and of all mankind. Therefore the increasing economic and social problems of Africa threaten not only the fate of African peoples but also the balanced development of the entire world. Consequently, the expression of our sensitivity to and concern about one another’s problems is indispensable in this respect as well.
145.	The critical economic situation of Africa manifests itself in many forms. The magnitude of the economic difficulties is reflected in the very fact that 26 African
nations are among the least developed countries of the world.
146.	The unfavourable phenomena are often aggravated by natural disasters, particularly drought. The efforts of the United Nations to help cope with drought and alleviate hunger in Africa are praiseworthy. In addition to their immediate positive effect, those efforts also testify to the ability of the international community to provide considerable assistance for those in need, if the necessary political will exists. The role played by the United Nations in alleviating hunger in Africa is evidence of its ability to take effective action in pursuit of its noble objectives, provided that Member States decide to act jointly. We hope that this special session will reaffirm this ability of the world Organization.
147,	The analysis and programme of action based on the material prepared by the OAU and submitted to this session reveal that the economic problems of the continent are specific, but they also have a general character and go beyond the boundaries of Africa. Therefore, in view of the complex nature of the difficulties, concepts recommended for adoption should take into account both the local conditions and the world economic and political environment.
148.	Of the external factors responsible for the economic crisis in the African continent, mention should first be made of the tense international political situation and its most negative element—the continual growth of the arms race. The successive rounds of the arms race entail grave political and economic consequences. In such an atmosphere less attention can be devoted to the establishment of a new, more just and democratic international economic order, while the constant growth in military expenditures reduces the funds available for assistance to countries faced with economic difficulties in a period when the specifics of the crisis in the developing world require the mobilization of more funds. Here it should be noted that because of the strained international political situation the chances of solving local conflicts are lessening, which above all adversely affects a number of developing countries.
149.	Equally unfavourable to the development of the African continent are the considerable changes that have taken place in the world economic environment over the past 10 to 15 years. The most important of these is the emergence of new trends in international industrial development, which have introduced changes in supply-demand conditions and in the importance of certain factors of economic growth throughout the world. As a result of the increase in the price of the products of skilled intellectual work and the reduction in the outlay for specific raw materials and energy, there is now a lasting surplus of goods exported by the majority of developing countries. The need to adjust to new requirements in the world economy calls for significant efforts by even the highly industrialized countries, while confronting the less developed nations with problems particularly difficult to solve. This process has further aggravated problems that have existed for many years, such as the malfunctions of the international monetary and trading system, the escalation of protectionist and discriminatory measures, the application of trade sanctions, the crisis in raw material markets, the growing debt burdens of developing countries and so on.
150.	For historical reasons, and in consequence of its colonial past, Africa is an economically underdeveloped continent. After the attainment of independence the States of the region found themselves within the framework of an international order which was unfavourable
to their social and economic development. At the same time, it should not be forgotten that social progress in the young African States was also impeded by a number of negative internal factors even after the attainment of independence. The socialist countries have supported the social and economic development of these States in order to offset the negative effects of the international environment.
151.	We highly commend the objective approach in the document prepared by the OAU for this special session.5 The chapter dealing with the emergence of the crisis in Africa clearly reveals, inter alia, the internal causes of economic difficulties, thus offering lessons not only to Africa but to all of us. .
152.	I should like to make a special point of two factors specific to the African continent. First, differences occasionally lead to armed conflicts which add to economic difficulties and result in the senseless destruction of human and material resources. Secondly, the acts of aggression by the racist South African regime not only pose constant military threats to neighbouring countries, but also give rise to economic problems deriving from such threats and acts of aggression.
153.	The factors I have mentioned show that the task of alleviating the emergency situation and paving the way for development is an extraordinarily difficult and complex task. The Hungarian People’s Republic is of the opinion that the programmes to be formulated at this session must take account of all the major elements and aspects of the problem now before us.
154.	We are convinced that one of the pre-conditions for remedying the emergency situation in Africa is in the elimination of local conflicts and, in a wider context, the curbing of the arms race. The principle of disarmament for development should be given greater emphasis. Radical cuts in military expenditures could provide the most effective means of tackling on a wider scale the economic and social tasks of all countries, including developing countries.
155.	We also believe that the restructuring of international economic relations on a just and democratic basis is indispensable. Joint efforts, appropriate financial resources and vigorous liberalization of world trade are needed to enable countries faced with imbalances to embark, on the road to sustained growth.
156.	The strengthening of international economic security can likewise be ranked among the tasks of top priority. Predictable and reliable behaviour by partners in the world economy is essential if countries with national economies that are vulnerable in terms of economic adaptability are to turn to. the path of sound development without encountering serious problems.
157.	Generalizations should be avoided in determining what specific action must be taken to alleviate the economic crisis in Africa. In general, the situations of the various countries of the region show rather different patterns, and this holds also for those in emergency situations. To devise some sort of general development model would therefore be to go about it in the wrong way. It is necessary to outline development proposals which make allowances for the national characteristics of the countries concerned. The proposals formulated by the OAU reflect a duly differentiated approach and provide an appropriate groundwork for the preparation of a programme of action for the medium- and long-term development of the African economy. Better and more effective use of internal resources with a view to ensuring flexible adjustment to shifts in the world economy is a
fundamental requirement that must be taken into account in formulating economic policy proposals consistent with national characteristics.
158.	In this context we consider important the reduction of the differences in territorial and ethnic development within the separate States of the region. This is, in a sense, conditional on efforts gradually to change the mentality of the local population and increase their sense of responsibility for their own progress.
159.	At the same time, we wish to stress the need to keep in mind the primary role of economic strategies designed to stimulate export production and orientation to the world market. Inordinate striving to create an internally oriented national economy may serve to lessen its imbalances to some extent in the short run; nevertheless in the long run it will hamper attempts to catch up with developed regions.
160.	The Government of the Hungarian People’s Republic is committed to maintaining and strengthening relations of equality, dialogue and mutually advantageous economic co-operation between States with different social systems. We are in solidarity with peoples fighting for the consolidation of national independence and for social advancement. Guided by this spirit, we are ready to develop and expand wide-ranging commercial, scientific, technical, cultural and educational relations with African countries. Hungary takes an active part, within the limits of its resources, in the joint efforts to solve the economic problems of African countries and speed up their development.
161.	I conclude by emphasizing that Africa is a continent rich in unused reserves, a region which is capable of sustained and balanced growth, thus ensuring the welfare and prosperity of its peoples. To achieve this goal, not only the common efforts of the international community are required, but also necessary are regional cooperation and self-reliance. The history of the world economy is full of spectacular about-turns and proves that, given the necessary harmony between internal efforts and external circumstances, a notable improvement in the economic situation of the most diverse countries can be achieved.
162.	Mr. LOESCHNAK (Austria) (interpretation from French): Austria follows with great interest and concern the critical economic situation in Africa. The recent emergency has aroused compassion in Austria and strengthened the solidarity of its population with the peoples of Africa.
163.	Through the endeavours of the international community the worst consequences of the famine were limited. Austria contributed according to its ability to the most important multilateral humanitarian action in the history of the United Nations.
164.	All these measures contributed to reducing the most serious dangers, but they have been able to solve neither the problem of food security nor the basic economic problems. The OAU has stated with great realism and courage the need for basic structural reform, for reexamination of strategies and for setting new priorities. This need is confirmed in the documents before the special session, which analyse the causes of the negative development in the past decade.
165.	My country has therefore wholeheartedly supported the convening of this special session, which is meant to provide new political perspectives for the economic, ecological and infrastructural development of Africa and ensure a sustained process of development.
166.	Decisions on necessary policy reforms and their implementation are, however, the responsibility of the African States themselves. Africa has assumed its responsibility in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.' That Priority Programme identifies the problems in a realistic way, stipulates the objectives for future economic development and indicates approaches towards their solution. We welcome the fact that agricultural development and improvement of rural society have been recognized as top priority. That sector still accounts for the majority of Africa’s population.
167.	The problems of Africa will not be completely solved in conference rooms. Despite common features, problems and needs vary from country to country. A common effort will be needed to co-ordinate actions on the local, national and regional levels and harmonize them with economic, political and social objectives.
168.	Among the many objectives and measures the following seem of particular relevance.
169.	First, the development of agriculture must be based on a realistic, remunerative price policy for agricultural products and other productivity incentives for farmers. Moreover, co-operative mechanisms and self-help measures have to be encouraged in the framework of rural development. The role of African women in agriculture must not be underestimated. The revival of agriculture will contribute especially to improving the living standards of the poorest strata of the population.
170.	Secondly, within the framework of policy reforms the improvement of the economic environment seems to us indispensable. A realistic monetary policy is the basis for fruitful regional and international co-operation. Good management of enterprises and in public administration is also essential. An economic climate which favours saving and capital formation and stimulates national investments will in turn also attract foreign investment. Thus trade imbalances will be alleviated and employment and infrastructure created.
171.	Thirdly, additional efforts in foreign trade and better use of the advantages of the Generalized System of Preferences would be beneficial for African economies. Realistic exchange rates are essential in this context; they encourage the establishment of new industries, thus contributing to the creation of employment opportunities. A further problem to be tackled is the strong dependence on the export of raw materials.
172.	Fourthly, economic reforms which today appear to be so important should not cause us to forget the equal necessity to create a just political and social environment which includes human rights and basic freedoms. Living conditions respecting human dignity will also help prevent new flows of refugees and displaced persons.
173.	The necessary reforms and structural changes demand great efforts on the part of the African countries themselves. The fact that a number of them have already initiated this process in difficult political and social-circumstances and that all of them have the political will to undertake these efforts merits our appreciation and encouragement.
174.	The international community has to respond to the African challenge and support the process of reform in a spirit of solidarity. The industrialized nations for their part are called upon to contribute to the creation of a global economic environment which supports the African countries’ efforts. In this connection, the following points should be stressed. Strengthening of non-inflationary growth in the industrialized countries will benefit the African economies through an increased import demand
and could lead to higher levels of assistance. Structural adjustment in the industrialized countries will improve the opportunities of the African economies. The new multilateral trade round in GATT should take into account the interests of developing countries and further facilitate their access to markets in the industrialized countries. Nevertheless, African countries will also need additional flows of resources in the future.
175.	We are aware that the problem of indebtedness is a heavy burden for Africa. Although the decline of the dollar, of interest rates and of oil prices alleviates to a certain extent the situation of the majority of developing countries, the problem remains serious.
