The policy reforms and structural adjustments the African countries are planning with the aim of sustained growth are of equal importance in solving the debt problem. The present situation necessitates common efforts in the form of close co-operation between debtor countries, creditor countries, banks and international financial institutions in order to solve in a spirit of understanding the debt problems according to each country’s particular needs, on a case-by-case approach.
176.	Austria has already demonstrated its willingness to co-operate and to be forthcoming within its means, and it will continue to do so. Up to now we have been able to arrange debt reschedulings for 12 African countries, to the extent of 5.6 billion Austrian schillings, some of them for periods up to the year 2000.
177.	Austria is well aware that the achievement of growth-oriented reforms requires additional financial flows over and above debt rescheduling. We therefore welcome recent international efforts undertaken in this respect by the World Bank and IMF and the replenishment of IDA. Austria is contributing 223 million schillings to the Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa of the World Bank, which is far beyond our normal IDA share. In the negotiations on the eighth replenishment of IDA, Austria advocates replenishment at a level of at least $12 billion. ' 178. Africa is already the priority area for Austria’s development co-operation. Sixty-nine per cent of Austria’s bilateral official assistance is destined for Africa. Austria’s contributions to multilateral institutions, the activities of which to a large extent benefit Africa, were substantially increased during the past years—from 558 million schillings in 1983 to 1,553 million schillings in 1985.
179.	Austria will co-operate willingly within the framework of the programme of action, as the focus on agricultural and rural development closely matches Austria’s interest in integrated rural programmes. Austria has already undertaken such programmes in four African countries, namely, Cape Verde, Rwanda, Burundi and Zambia. I would also mention that Austria is envisaging, a substantial increase in bilateral development assistance for countries in sub-Saharan Africa. In the current year we are allocating an additional 100 million schillings for the least developed countries of that region. It is, moreover, our intention to finance mainly projects in the least developed countries of Africa within the framework of a co-financing agreement concluded with the World Bank. The Austrian contribution to this co-financing agreement amounts to 1 billion schillings.
180.	In conclusion, I should like to underline once more the importance that Austria attaches to this special session. We shall need a strong sense of responsibility in facing this immense challenge. We have the chance to fix together the priorities for a medium- and long-term development process in Africa in co-operation with African Governments, which shoulder their responsibility for the
necessary measures and reforms, and the international community, which must be aware of its responsibility for supporting Africa’s efforts.
181.	Mr. HALEFOGLU (Turkey): It is a great pleasure for me to address the General Assembly, which is for the first time devoting a special session to the economic and development needs of one region of the world. We hope that the outcome of this session will satisfy the expectations of those who are concerned about the welfare and future of the African nations and will produce a new impetus to the development process in that continent. The deliberations here should constitute a good example of international solidarity at a time when the spirit of multilateral co-operation needs strengthening.
182.	I would like to take this opportunity to express our deep appreciation to the African Governments for their invaluable efforts within the framework of the OAU, as well as to ECA for its excellent work in the preparation of comprehensive reports that bring to our attention the magnitude of the problems in Africa. My delegation also extends its appreciation to the Secretary-General, as well as to the United Nations bodies and the entire Secretariat for their sustained efforts in the preparation of this special session.
Mr. Al-Kawari (Qatar), Vice-President, took the Chair. 183. The present situation in Africa is most distressing and alarming. The deep-rooted and diverse economic problems that Africa faces today demand urgent measures and immediate action. A fundamental difficulty is the lack of adequate infrastructure in the continent. Moreover, income levels in Africa are strikingly low. The rate of population growth, on the other hand, has been above the rate of increase in per capita income, thus further aggravating the already dramatic situation. It is alarming to note from the reports that in the great majority of African countries, one half to three fourths of the population subsist in absolute poverty and that per capita food production in the 1980s has declined in comparison with the 1960s.
184.	Closely linked with these difficulties are the problems of foreign debt, deterioration in the terms of trade and the decline in the prices of commodities. These require the special attention of the international community. For many African countries, external debt constitutes a new problem, never experienced before. The roots of this problem stem from certain developments in the 1970s. The international commodity boom, increased access to sources of lending after the 1972-73 oil shock and the expansion of public sector expenditures can be emphasized as among the major factors that contributed to the outbreak of this problem in the 1970s. The problem was further aggravated in the 1980s by new external developments, such as high real interest rates, disruption in both private and public financial flows, low commodity prices and a drought, over which the Africans have no control.
185.	In these circumstances, there is no doubt that African countries are not in a position today to solve this problem oh their own. Despite the differences among the countries and the levels and composition of debt, it is absolutely above their servicing capacity. In this respect there is an imperative need for the international community to give special treatment in solving this problem, which must also be seen in the broader context of stabilizing Africa’s foreign aid requirements.
186.	Foreign trade is another area in which the African countries are experiencing serious difficulties. The value of exports in the vast majority of African countries fell by more than 40 per cent from 1981 to 1983, a decline which has led to drastic cuts in import expenditures.
Today we see a growing gap between the imports required by African countries to sustain their development process and their export earnings to pay for them. African countries generally suffer from a slow growth of demand for their exports and from declining terms of trade.
187.	Since the beginning of the 1980s, increasing protectionist practices in the industrialized countries have become a new impediment to African exports. Turkey, too, as a developing country, is negatively affected by growing protectionism. For our part, we find this an important obstacle to the successful implementation of structural adjustment policies. We see no justification for such practices, particularly at such a critical juncture, when many developing countries are making strenuous efforts at structural adjustment to increase their foreign trade capacity. We are therefore ready to support initiatives which might improve the present environment for African exports.
188.	In addition to protectionist practices, I consider it useful to focus briefly on commodity prices, because the foreign exchange earnings of the great majority of African countries depend on the export of a few raw materials and commodities. The price index of primary products is now at its lowest level. The losses of non-oil commodity exporting countries on the whole, owing to substantial declines in prices this year, are calculated to be between $40 billion and $60 billion. It is obvious that the effects of these depressed prices on the income of many African countries have been widespread. As indicated in the Secretary-General’s report, the prospects for exports by the low-income African countries, which consist mostly of non-oil commodities, are not favourable. We believe that this situation, which has created an uncertain and difficult economic future for many Africans, should be addressed effectively by the international community.
189.	The search for viable development policies in many African countries has been going on for the last three decades. The experiences in this area illustrate how difficult it is for those countries to implement successful economic policies when their basic infrastructures are inadequate. Today we see that there is a growing change in African thinking on development issues, as an increasing number of African countries are in the process of implementing new policies in order to adjust their economies to the changing conditions. Taking into account our own experiences in the area of adjustment policies, we welcome this new economic policy thrust in Africa. We believe that growth-oriented structural adjustment policies hold promise for many African countries of a healthy course for their economies, provided that they are effectively supported by major donor countries and international financial institutions.
190.	For us Africa is not a distant continent; it is just across the Mediterranean. Turkey is situated at the crossroads of Europe, Asia and Africa. Anatolia has been under the influence of the tremendous cultural and social interactions of these three major continents, and it has provided a vital link between them. We naturally have traditional and historical relationships with various African countries. We also enjoy the privilege of having special relations with the Muslim people of Africa.
191.	On this occasion I am deeply pleased to express here the great sympathy felt by the Turkish people and Government for Africa. As a developing country, Turkey is doing its utmost, within its limited resources, to contribute to the programmes related to Africa. To that end, my Government announced last year that it would donate $10 million to the countries of the Sahel. Somalia has
become the first country to receive food aid under this assistance programme, and we are in touch with the authorities of the other countries concerned in order to channel this modest aid effectively. ■
192.	In this connection, I should like to elaborate further on the efforts being made within the framework of the Organization of the Islamic Conference [O/C], That Organization’s Standing Committee for Economic and Commercial Co-operation, whose Chairman is the President of Turkey, has the economic situation in Africa as a permanent item on its agenda. During the second session of the-Standing Committee, held at Istanbul from 14 to 16 March 1986, the Economic Ministers of the member countries of QIC agreed to focus their efforts on aid packages which would have more lasting effects on the economic situation in Africa, rather than on food assistance alone, which has only a temporary alleviating effect. In keeping with that suggestion, Turkey decided to shift the emphasis of its aid programme to Africa from food aid to technical assistance.
193.	Extension of technical assistance to countries in need, and in this context to Africa, is of particular concern to my Government. Turkey is making every effort to promote that kind of co-operation. In fact, I wish to refer to a technical co-operation project which my Government signed with FAO during the eighteenth FAO Near East Regional Conference, held at Istanbul from 17 to 21 March 1986. This project envisages technical assistànce in the fields of forestry and livestock.
194.	We have been carrying out technical assistance programmes with UNIDO for about a decade now, organizing in-plant group training courses and study tours in different industrial sectors for the trainees of other developing countries. So far, the primary beneficiaries of these programmes have been'African countries.
195.	- For the realization of the. self-reliant and selfsustained development of Africa, growth-oriented structural adjustment policies are.necessary. The success of these policies depends, above all, on a favourable external economic environment, which is beyond the Africans’ control. To that end, Turkey is prepared to give full support to the concerted international actions which will be adopted at this special session.
196.	Mr. TALEB IBRAHIMI (Algeria) (interpretation from French): First, I wish to congratulate the President on his election to preside over this special session of the General Assembly. The high standards and integrity that have won him the esteem of all, as well as his wealth of experience, undoubtedly represent major guarantees that our work will be well conducted.
197.	President Diouf of the Republic of Senegal, current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, at the 1st meeting gave the Assembly a clear account of the decisions taken by the African heads of State or Government to lay the foundations for the economic recovery of the continent, and, at the same time, he spelled out the nature and types'of support expected from the international community. Thus, he set out the framework and the objectives of the present'special session. Speaking after President Diouf, Algeria endorses that message for renewed international co-operation vis-à-vis Africa.
198.	The present session is being held at a time when Africa is at a decisive turning point in its history because of the hard choices imposed on it by the very serious economic difficulties confronting it. The causes of that situation have been thoroughly analysed in terms of the colonial remnants maintained by an inequitable international economic system that affects both the coherence
and the effectiveness of development policies. Climatic and ecological factors such as drought and desertification have acted as aggravating factors whose tragic effects arise primarily from the fragility and vulnerability of the African economies.
199.	Hence, an analysis of the economic crisis in Africa necessarily leads us to the incontrovertible conclusion that the relaunching of development necessarily involves both internal and external structural changes. That is the uncompromising diagnosis'made by Africa, which has therefore decided to redefine its conduct and priorities in the light of the essential goal, which is to create the necessary conditions and means to satisy its own needs, primarily through its own resources.
200.	That Africa has also turned to the United Nations is an indication of its deep conviction that tackling these requirements presupposes, at the same time, a renewal of international co-operation. In fact, this special session can be seen as a prolongation of what Africa has started in the way of mobilizing its efforts at all levels—national, subregional, continental and international—to implement Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.1
201.	The . determination of the African countries fully to shoulder their responsibilities in the process of building their national economies must have the concomitant support of the international community, for in an interdependent world the problems of the African continent cannot be grasped in isolation from the disorders and upheavals which are a feature.of the world economic situation and to which Africa is particularly vulnerable. Also, the magnitude of the tasks of recovery and development and the burden of historical, structural and ecological handicaps to be overcome are such, in the context of the limited means of the continent, as to' constitute a challenge not only to Africa itself but also to the entire international community. ;
202.	This means that the steps to be taken and the measures to be drawn, up and the commitments to be made at the conclusion of our work must have two dimensions. First, an effort must be made to correct the external factors which make for disequilibrium, which, if it were to continue, would jeopardize Africa’s development efforts. Secondly, a direct contribution must be made to the investment efforts implied in the implementation "of the Priority Programme in order to make the social cost of its implementation tolerable.
203.	Nevertheless, it is essential that whatever support is given by the international community be in harmony with national plans and priorities as outlined in the Priority Programme as a frame of reference. Similarly, it is essential that account be taken of the specific situation which prevails in the front-line States in the light of the aggression and the efforts to bring about political and economic destabilization by the apartheid régime in South Africa. .
204.	That is the substance of Africa’s proposals, of which Algeria has been instructed to present more particularly the aspects linked with the development of agricultural support sectors.
205.	The Priority Programme assigns a dynamic role to agricultural development and the promotion of the rural environment, since it is evident that man must be relocated at the very centre of development in the dual capacity of means and end. Self-sufficiency is essential to meet this requirement. The fact that this priority has been given to the development of the agricultural sector implies an integrated approach to development. The concomitant
development of the support sectors, which initially provide the inputs and subsequently help to process and upgrade the output of agriculture, dictate the changes that must be made to increase agricultural productivity.
206.	This means that there can be no quantitive development without qualitative development. The development of support sectors such as the industries which provide capital goods and agricultural implements, the industries which provide fertilizers, plastics and pesticides, and the industries which process agricultural products are all in effect equally involved in a process of intra-sectoral and inter-sectoral integration, which has a multiplying effect both on agriculture and on the economy as a whole, while at the same time assuring balanced trade between towns and villages.
207.	Furthermore, experience has given ample proof that lasting and self-sustaining development results from the joint development of agriculture and industry to bring about the industrialization of agriculture. It must be emphasized in this context that control of the vagaries of nature so that it is, above all, at the service of man is inconceivable without the availability of the means of production and the ability to make use of them.
208.	Agro-industrial integration is likewise dependent on the development of transport and communications infrastructures. The considerable backwardness in these areas and particularly the constraints suffered by the African island or land-locked countries have an eroding effect on the development of internal and intra-African trade.
209.	Recognition of the importance of these support sectors in the development of agriculture prompted the launching a few years ago of United Nations decades devoted, respectively, to industrial development and transport and communications in Africa. Adequate international support in the implementation of the targets set for those two Decades would have undoubtedly helped to facilitate development efforts in Africa.
210.	In the light of all these considerations, we must all admit that there are grounds for re-examining the international co-operation policy in order to make it a genuine instrument of development. Africa, by boldly embarking on a thorough re-evaluation of its approach to development, is inviting all its partners to carry out an in-depth re-examination of the nature and bases of their relations with the African continent in particular and the third world in general.
211.	This, then, is the appeal of Africa, to which it expects a response from the international community. Our continent is convinced that peace and security can have no sound and lasting foundation until all men throughout the world enjoy the specific conditions which make it possible for them to enjoy their right to development.
212.	The PRESIDENT {interpretation from Arabic)’. In accordance with resolution 477 (V), of 1 November 1950, and the decision taken by the Assembly at the 1st meeting of the current session [decision A/S-13/21], I call on the observer of the League of Arab States, Mr. Adnan Omran.
213.	Mr. OMRAN (League of Arab States) {interpretation from Arabic): Mr. President, allow me at the outset to extend to you and through you to the General Assembly the great appreciation and gratitude of the secretariat of the League of Arab States for granting us this opportunity to participate in the general debate at the thirteenth special session, on the critical economic situation in Africa. This question arouses great concern in the League and the Arab States in view of the cultural and historical ties
embodied in the common destiny, indeed the single destiny, of the Arab and African peoples.
214.	The concern of the League of Arab States and its member States regarding this important question is also based on the principles of solidarity and co-operation among our States and is felt in three contexts.
215.	The first context is that of international co-operation in general, the collective responsibility for the protection of the international economic order and for making every effort to eliminate the distortions and violations which have caused imbalances in international relations and the ensuing disruption of the development process in the developing countries in particular. To this must be added the accumulated foreign debt, which has played a fundamental role in aggravating the crisis and bringing it to its critical stage. Therefore the international community has a great responsibility to remedy the situation. The States of the African continent, which is considered to be the greatest source of strategic, industrial and food raw materials, are suffering from a decline in the production of these raw materials not because of the increasing cost, of production and the weakness of the infrastructures, but because of the fall in the prices of these products on the international market as a result of unfair terms of trade on the one hand and the fluctuation in the currency market on the other. This calls for urgent treatment of the domestic causes by supporting African capacity to counter the decline in production and its means and arriving at an equitable formula that would enable these States to make the best use of their products and resources on the international market.
216.	The second context is that of co-operation among the developing States in accordance with the principle of collective self-reliance. In view of the inertia, if not outright failure, of the North-South dialogue and the frequently negative conditions which have brought that dialogue to deadlock, the developing countries have had to seek, within the limits of their abilities and possibilities, to overcome some of their problems through co-operation between third world countries. The Arab States played a major role in laying the foundations for this SouthSouth co-operation through loans, grants and joint projects and investments. Despite the difficult circumstances currently experienced by the oil-exporting Arab States and the fluctuations and instability of the oil market, our States have not abandoned their commitment to provide development aid to the developing countries, in particular African States.
217.	The third context is that of African-Arab co-operation, which is considered a pioneering experience. What binds the Arab States and the African States, in addition to proximity of civilization and geography and the bonds of history and culture, is their common fate in the face of numerous challenges. This co-operation is a true embodiment of the principle of collective self-reliance in attaining development. The documents issued by the first African-Arab summit conference, held in 1977, are considered a comprehensive common programme of action and a well-founded plan for integrated co-operation. The Arab and African groups have sought to chart a practical course for the achievement of these objectives and have succeeded in laying the proper groundwork for continuous development co-operation.
218.	In this regard, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, which is a specialized bank, has a role to play in providing financial aid to African States and also in co-ordinating the programmes of the various Arab development organizations and funds for supporting the process of African economic development, as well as
those of other funds and banks concerned with development. The priorities in the provision of Arab aid have always taken account and still take account of the characteristics of the stage of African development and the national development plans in the various States of the continent. Thus, the greater part of the aid has been focused on productive sectors and infrastructures, especially in the field of agriculture and such related vital sectors as irrigation projects and the building of dams and roads.
219.	It is important to emphasize here that Arab aid to African countries, in accordance with the principles of African-Arab co-operation, has never been subject to conditions or restrictions. Rather, it is spontaneous co-operation stemming from belief in the common responsibility for the development of our societies and consolidation of the principles of independence, freedom and dignity. It is different from the kind of aid provided or promised by some States whose philosophy and view of co-operation we have listened to today, and in whose concepts we discern the fact that aid is accompanied by conditions that infringe the sovereignty of those States and even constitute reprehensible interference in their internal affairs. This is especially true when that aid is coupled with the social and economic system such States wish to impose, directly or indirectly.
220.	The emergency measures taken by the international community for the relief operations in Africa have proved their success as a pioneering collective endeavour. This special session, which builds upon that earlier approach, is a great leap towards acceptance of the common responsibility of the international community for the future of mankind. In order to enhance these efforts and achieve complete success we should benefit from the documents and reports adopted by the fifteenth extraordinary session of the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity, held on 30 and 31 March 1986.
221.	The question of the provision of aid to Africa is among the most important questions for our Arab States collectively, through the joint structures established to make a reality of this co-operation. In this regard the Arab League Council, at its eighty-fifth regular session, adopted resolution 4550, of 27 March 1986, which emphasizes, inter alia, the following.
“First, priority must be accorded to productive development co-operation, joint Arab-African projects must take precedence over other programmes eligible for funding, and the creation of conditions favourable to investments in the African States must be speeded up, assigning a fundamental role to Arab and African private sectors. In this context, the secretariat of the Arab League, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, the Union of the Chambers of Commerce and Industry and Agriculture in the Arab States,
the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development, the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development, the Arab Organization for Industrial Development and the Arab Organization for Investment Guarantees have been assigned the task of formulating an integrated proposal to be submitted to the Arab League Council at its September 1986 session for consideration and adoption, as a subject of special importance.
“Secondly, it is necessary for joint and national Arab financial institutions to give priority, in funding economic development projects in Africa, to projects for combating drought and desertification and to quickreturn projects whose implementation has an effect on social and economic life in those African States.
“Thirdly, Arab organizations must be urged to include in their budgets provision for technical cooperation so as to give the necessary aid, each in its sphere of competence.”
222.	In conclusion, and in the light of the support by the Arab States for their sister African States, which has exceeded $9 billion over the past decade, the Arab League and its specialized organizations have affirmed their readiness, endorsed by the Standing Committee on Arab-African Co-operation at its eighth session, at Damascus in January 1986, to co-operate fully with international and regional organizations—especially the OAU, to which organization, and to its Secretary-General, we extend our warm appreciation for the great efforts in the service of African causes and of Arab-African co-operation—to contribute to the success of whatever plans, programmes and resolutions are adopted. .
223.	Finally, I reiterate on behalf of the League of Arab States the hope that the work of this special session will be crowned with success so as to effect a fundamental change in the reality of social and economic development for our sister African nations. '
The meeting rose at 1.25 p.m.

United Nations
GENERAL ASSEMBLY
THIRTEENTH SPECIAL SESSION
Official Records
4th PLENARY MEETING
Wednesday, 28 May 1986, at 3.20 p.m.
NEW YORK
President: Mr. Jaime de PINIÉS (Spain).
AGENDA ITEM 6
Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and medium-term andlong-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures (continued)
1.	Mr. LARADJANI (Islamic Republic of Iran): I should like to congratulate you, Sir, on your presiding over one of the most important and humanitarian sessions of the General Assembly in the history of the United Nations. This is the first time such a meeting has been convened in order to focus on the needs of a single continent. However, the session also demonstrates the severity of the present crisis and its threats to the future development of the African continent and the world as a whole. While appreciating the Secretary-General’s initiatives to resolve the African crisis, my delegation congratulates the current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity on his call for the holding of this special session in order to find a framework for resolving this crisis.
2.	The critical economic situation in Africa has not only jeopardized the development process of the continent but also threatened the life of millions of its inhabitants. In many African countries, the economic situation is literally a matter of life and death—indeed even more so in the sub-Saharan region. More than half of the African people subsist in absolute poverty. In some countries, over half of all rural children die by the age of five. In others, the entire population suffers from malaria, diarrhea and other chronic diseases. I do not intend to take up the time of the Assembly by citing well-known though very painful statistics on the overwhelming problems of Africa such as famine, drought, population growth, low average life expectancy, deforestation, desertification, high rates of child mortality, serious health hazards, displacement of people from their homes and high levels of malnutrition. The sad fact is that we shall be witnessing a continued increase in such statistics unless the necessary measures are taken by Africans with the full support of the international community. This session has provided an exceptionally acute opportunity for this international body to take an historic, constructive and humanitarian role in assisting large numbers of the human family residing in Africa. Let us hope that we shall not miss this chance for full co-operation, otherwise we may not be able to escape the irreparable consequences.
3.	It is noteworthy that the international community was warned years ago of the incipient economic situation in Africa through various studies done under the auspices of the United Nations and related bodies since 1975.
Effective African and international action 10 years ago could have averted the disasters of the 1980s.
4.	During the past three years Africa has gone through the most severe drought ever experienced by the people of that continent. That drought and the resulting famine and hunger have wreaked havoc on the rural economies of many African countries. Now, millions of people in those countries have pinned their hopes on our session, and they are waiting to see how we shall achieve solidarity as members of one united family.
5.	As it has been rightly mentioned in paragraph 14 of Africa’s submission to the special session,1 “The African economic crisis is due principally to insufficient structural transformation and economic diversification that are required to move the continent away from inherited colonial economic structures”.
6.	The African economy does not depend on industry and industrial products—a situation which in itself constitutes a very important shortcoming. The agricultural sector mostly depends on rainfall for irrigation. Therefore, the drought has resulted in serious destruction to the agricultural economies of many African countries. Another factor contributing to poor agricultural performance has been poor management of human resources carried out by some African Governments.
7.	My delegation fully supports the proposal for action put forward in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.2 We believe that the number one priority for Africa is the rehabilitation of agriculture, taking into account all indigenous conditions. There is a need for a sustainable agriculture that must be economically viable, ecologically sound, just, humane and culturally appropriate. Special emphasis should be given to supporting the domestic production sector with the aim of attaining food self-sufficiency in Africa. Wé also believe that the ultimate solution to the food crisis will not be achieved through receiving external hand-outs. Africa is capable of feeding itself. The people of Africa, the poor peasants, are the key to the solution of the food crisis. They have to get down to work on their land.
8.	The effects of South Africa’s systematic destabilization campaign against the States of southern Africa are also one of the disastrous factors in the African crisis. As long as the racist régime of South Africa is being supported by Western imperialism, as long as it maintains its illegal occupation of Angola, as long as UNITA3 has the comprehensive military and training support of the Pretoria régime, a great amount of human and material resources of the victimized countries of the region will inevitably be spent on defence against the racist régime. That serves as a channel for the flow of capital from those poor African countries to industrialized societies, a current which must be stopped by all means. One of the most striking examples of unreserved imperialist support for South Africa was witnessed recently when South African military forces invaded the neighbouring countries of Botswana, Zimbabwe and Zambia, and the United States vetoed the Security Council’s draft resolution condemning South Africa’s aggression. Unfortunately, United
States foreign policy against the oppressed Africans is not confined merely to South Africa. Other parts of Africa, even in the far north, such as Libya, are not immune from those destructive and aggressive policies.
9.	The Islamic Republic of Iran firmly believes that the abundant wealth and resources of the African continent should be spent on the material and spiritual well-being of the deprived and oppressed people of Africa, who have suffered so long at the hands of the colonial Powers.
10.	Another factor devastating the African economies has been the savage blows from the world economy. A survey undertaken by UNICEF on the impact of the world recession on children revealed that a multiple mechanism was at work transmitting the impact of the recession in the industrial countries to the developing countries and within the developing countries, from urban to rural areas and to different income groups and classes. At each stage, the linkage mostly served to multiply the impact rather than to diminish it as one moved further along the chain from the rich to the poor.
11.	Little attention is paid by agencies such as IMF to the conditions of many of the lesser and least developed countries. IMF has actually secured the economic interests of rich countries—a purpose for which it was originally established.
12.	The present international monetary and financial system, which has been imposed upon the third world, including African countries, is bankrupt and should be redressed towards the elimination of inequities. The crucial role of interdependence and potential mutual interest between the North and South should be fully taken into account. To challenge the current dominance of monetarism and militarism, the international community should promote a strategy for both development and disarmament in order to make more resources available for development.
13.	Most of the African countries are faced with serious balance-of-payments problems which indicate the severely unfavourable situation facing them in their conduct of trade and payments. We hope that next month’s Finance Ministers’ meeting of the African Monetary Fund at Libreville will reach tangible results so that co-operation among African countries might be increased and a solution found for the balance-of-payments problems of those countries.
14.	African countries are in a debt trap. The total interest to be paid annually during the period 1986 to 1990 by the African countries amounts to about $9.2 billion. It is evident that the interest constitutes more than 38 per cent of the total debt of African countries. Thus, under present economic conditions, there seems to be a continuous amassing of debt due to the accumulation of interest. Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery includes a special suggestion to relieve the debt burden. While my delegation strongly supports those proposals, we believe that a more basic solution could be sought in light of the Islamic banking system, which advocates interest-free loans.
15.	The fall in commodity prices is another major cause of the economic crisis in Africa. The many financially weak producing countries, mostly low-income, have limited staying-power in the international market. In the present international financial system there is no organization to provide financing to low-income countries to enable them to improve their market staying-power. We strongly support the establishment of a common fund to help producers adjust their production and deliveries and consequently avoid disastrous sales. Such a fund would enable low-income countries, many African countries
among them, to improve their bargaining position in relation to buyers in industrialized countries.
16.	Constructive efforts for international development by some donor countries, especially the United States, have deteriorated significantly in recent years; Most of the third-world proposals made in the last 10 years for a new international economic order have been rejected constantly without any justifiable reason. Net disbursements of official development assistance to developing countries and multinational agencies declined between 1960 and 1983, from 0.53 per cent to 0.24 per cent of the United States gross national product [GAT]. The seventh replenishment of IDA, a special African fund and other initiatives have been sabotaged. In general, the United States aim has been the erosion of multilateralism. It has withdrawn from UNESCO; it has stood alone in WHO against efforts to improve the use of instant milk for needy children; and it has caused a financial crisis for the United Nations by reducing its financial contribution to its budget. In the mean time, United States policy in international finance, trade, economic assistance and particularly foreign affairs is being pursued bilaterally, bypassing the United Nations and its specialized agencies. Washington has been maliciously exploiting famine and economic crisis in Africa for its imperialistic purposes by bringing pressure to bear on some vulnerable African countries to vote with it in international bodies.
17.	My delegation, while deploring the political exploitation of aid, would like to reiterate the need for the attainment of the official development assistance target of 0.7 per cent of GNP, including the established target for the least-developed countries. We also believe that the decline in IDA resources should be reversed and that reversal reflected in its eighth replenishment.
18.	Whether they want to admit it or not, the industrialized countries have a great deal of responsibility for the present critical situation, which is a direct or indirect result of their plundering actions and policies. Now they should pay their fair share for the sake of their common interest. The industrialized countries benefited by approximately $320 billion from the fall in oil prices in 1986 alone. The total foreign resources needed for implementation of the Priority Programme amount to about $45 billion, or $9 billion each year, We believe that it is only fair that these lucky profiteers make a humble donation towards the implementation of that Programme instead of showing such great hesitation in this regard.
19.	My Government’s support for the oppressed nations of Africa is a matter of principle. After the Islamic revolution our foreign policy took a completely different course. Relations with the Pretoria régime were severed and the flow of oil to it was stopped. We did not miss any chance to develop relations with African countries. Of the 17 embassies we added to our diplomatic missions after the revolution, 12 are in Africa. In spite of the heavy burden of the imposed war, we have tried to make our modest symbolic contribution to support the cause of our African fellow-sufferers in drought-stricken countries or in those countries afflicted with serious emergency situations.
20.	In our Friday congregational prayers, in which millions participate, our people feel happy to share the little they have with their African fellows by contributing modest donations to a voluntary fund that has been established without Government initiative.
21.	In the General Assembly, too, we have always tried to act in keeping with our commitment to support the cause of our African fellow sufferers. We sincerely hope that this special session will succeed in taking a major
constructive step in giving effect to the proposals put forward in the Priority Programme.
22.	Mr. KOENIG (German Democratic Republic):* There is every justification for this special session of the General Assembly focusing attention on the African continent. Indeed, the critical situation of many African countries gives rise to serious concern. Africa is facing a permanent process of destruction of its social, economic and political structures to an extent unparalleled elsewhere in the world. What is at stake here is the very survival of millions of people. Hence, the German Democratic Republic supports the adoption by this special session of a comprehensive programme designed to tackle these problems effectively. , .
23.	The search for valid answers to Africa’s questions and the initiation of. appropriate action to remedy the situation not only are matters of general concern but are particularly crucial for that continent.
24.	Africa is a continent in ascent. For decades its peoples have fought for national and economic independence. They have decisively changed the international political scene. The liberated African States play a major, active role in international politics. Their commitment to the cause of peace, disarmament and development is widely acknowledged. Almost one third of the' States Members of the United Nations are in the African continent. .
25.	However, Africa is still a continent in which the problems are colossal and are even becoming worse.. The bitter legacy of the colonial past has still not been overcome. The peoples there are still exposed to the designs of those that wish to perpetuate old dependencies in a disguised form or, as the United States aggression against Libya shows, to disrupt the independent development of African States by military force.
26.	In spite of the utmost endeavours of the African nations to ensure the consolidation and harmonious development of their economies, thè situation has not improved; rather, it has become more complex. At the recent Ministerial Meeting of the Co-ordinating Bureau of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, held from 16 to 19 April at New Delhi, the foreign ministers stated that today the situation of the developing countries is worse than it was 10 years ago. That is true in every respect of Africa.
27.	In our view, efficient assistance is required, first of all, to make the dream of an economically independent' Africa a reality. Owing to the slow pace of their economic development the African countries are falling ever further, behind. Africa, with about one tenth of the world’s population, accounts for only 1 per cent of world industrial output. Despite certain progress, agriculturè in most of those countries is incapable of producing enough food for the population. Almost all African States accrue large food import bills. Gigantic natural disasters have further exacerbated the critical situation. Backwardness is coupled with dire consequences, the most appalling of which is hunger.
28.	Against that background, it is only logical for the African States to establish a link between the exacerbation of their critical economic situation and inequality in ' international economic relations. The members of the Organization of African Unity [CM U] have stressed, with justice, that it is primarily high interest rates, currency fluctuations, unfavourable terms of trade, protectionism,
*Mr. Koenig spoke in German,.The English version of his statement was supplied by the delegation.
and net capital outflows that have compounded the disastrous consequences for economic development in Africa that I have described. It is indeed startling to note that, according to the calculations of Western experts, for every $1 invested in Africa, the big corporations pocket $3.50.
29.	As a matter of principle we support the more-than-legitimate position of the African peoples and States that demand financial and material Compensation from the former colonial overlords and those pursuing neo-colo-nialist goals. This responsibility remains, no matter how resourceful are the attempts to justify colonialism on the basis of hindsight. It is indeed worrying that sovereign States are put under pressure by demands for restriction of their public.sectors, privatization of State enterprises and access for private capital inflows in ,an attempt to make them change drastically their independent course of development.. ■ . .
30.	Is it not preposterous to blame the public sectors and centralized economic planning schemes for the critical situation in Africa? In fact, the public sector has proved to be an essential instrument. A planned economy facilitates the concentration of economic potential for the solution of priority issues. In that context, co-operatives have been vitally important in mobilizing people and ensuring more equitable distribution of what has been produced. ■ ■ .
31.	It would not be possible to discuss seriously how to mitigate the critical economic situation in Africa without ostracizing the policy of apartheid. For many African countries the racist régime of Pretoria is a formidable obstacle in the way of normal development. That régime is destabilizing the entire continent, generating as it does political tensions arid causing immense economic damage. It is specifically the front-line States that are directly exposed to terrorism sponsored by the apartheid State.
32.	The latest repugnant acts of open aggression perpetrated by the Pretoria régime against Angola, Zimbabwe, Zambia rind Botswana furnish yet further proof of that. The racists’ provocative acts must at last be checked by resolute United Nations, measures in line with Chapter VII of the Charter. The African States will not be really free and able to follow their course of independent development so long as apartheid Continues to threaten the entire continent.
33.	The continued existence and fomentation of potentially explosive situations, and regional conflicts has similarly serious consequences. Everybody knows who is to blame for this. These hotbeds of conflict are siphoning off enormous material and financial resources from economic and social development and frustrating efforts to solve the most pressing issues. . .
34.	The arms race consumes 15 to 30 per cent of the national budgets of Africa, In the light of this, the formula “disarmament for development”, coined by the socialist countries, is gaining ever-more weight. Neither economic measures nor relief actions will bring about a radical and sustained improvement for African countries if no success is achieved in halting the arms race. At present the world spends every day, within eight to nine hours, $1 billion.for the purpose of armaments. That is equivalent to 10 per cent of the yearly assistance requested for the special programme for Africa. The cessation of the arms race and the reduction of expenditure on arms would constitute the most promising and effective approach by releasing urgently needed resources. The wide range of proposals and initiatives of the socialist States on arms limitation and disarmament are aimed precisely in that direction.
35.	The Lomé Declaration of August 19854 has already shed light on the close interrelationship of the objectives of security, disarmament and development and has shown the way to the solution of economic and social problems on the African continent.
36.	A basic pre-condition of ensuring the economic rehabilitation of Africa in the long run is the existence of healthy international economic relations. The German Democratic Republic supports the developing countries in their struggle for a new international economic order, emphasizing that the principles set out in the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States [resolution 3281 (XXIX)] must at last be applied. It is essential for the development of the African countries that their economic security be ensured. The achievement of this goal is served by the Soviet Union’s proposal for the creation of a comprehensive system of international security, including international economic security. State-to-State exchanges in general must be free of arbitrary acts, unlawful embargoes, boycotts, and trade, credit and technology blockades, and economic relations must not be used as a means of exerting political pressure.
37.	The German Democratic Republic shores up its principled support for the African States with concrete assistance. Over the years we have developed co-operation of many kinds with the continent. This co-operation is free from exploitation, discrimination and overt or covert interference in internal affairs. Its purpose is to assist our African partners in the all-round and balanced development of their economic potential. .
38.	Between 1983 and 1985 alone, the German Democratic Republic provided material and financial assistance to States and national liberation movements in the region to the value of 1.5 billion marks. Its primary purpose was to assist in efforts to set up national industries, enhance efficiency in agriculture, establish efficient public and cooperative sectors and train cadres. Forty-one African countries were recipients of such aid. During the period in question, some 9,450 nationals of those countries received in the German Democratic Republic basic or advanced training in various industrial trades and in the fields of public education, health care and the planning and management of economic processes at the national level, while over 2,200 such nationals graduated in the German Democratic Republic from institutes of higher learning or technical schools after having completed courses in mechanical engineering, agricultural sciences, transport, civil engineering, economics, teaching or medicine. In the same period 960 experts from the German Democratic Republic were on assignment in Africa. The German Democratic Republic youth organization’s friendship brigades have played an important part in the training of workers.
39.	Substantial funds were made available for emergency assistance to ease the adverse consequences of natural disasters. In particular, large relief supplies of foodstuffs, medication and other urgently needed goods were shipped to drought-stricken Ethiopia. Other supplies went to Angola, Mozambique, Zambia and Tanzania.
40.	For the German Democratic Republic, the supply of complete industrial plants and the implementation of important projects in developing countries is an essential element of co-operation. It remains committed to its well-established principle that on completion factories or plants become the property of the receiving country. Any idea of transferring profits is alien to the German Democratic Republic’s policy precepts. On the contrary, my country is guided solely by the principle of mutual benefit.
It does not engage in a brain drain from African countries. It does not share in the high profits extracted from those countries by transnational corporations. It does not possess factories or natural resources in developing countries. This will continue to be our approach in the future. Our assistance is designed to help politically and economically in strengthening national economies in Africa to make them independent of foreign capital, in accordance with the wishes and interests of the African countries themselves.
41.	Given its experience and potential as a modern industrialized State with a highly developed agricultural sector, the German Democratic Republic is able to render effective assistance in implementing Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 particularly in the spheres of agriculture and food, industry and vocational training. Over the past few years more than 50 per cent of exports of agricultural machinery made in the German Democratic Republic has gone to African countries. Such deliveries will continue to expand. The German Democratic Republic will set up agricultural complexes in African countries and will give assistance in the reconstruction and modernization of industrial plants. There are good opportunities for industrial co-operation and assembly production, as well as for consulting and engineering services. ‘
42.	In the future also, the German Democratic Republic will support and promote vocational and advanced training schemes. It is a matter of principle for my country to offer rather than deny the transfer of know-how; to help train, manpower from these countries rather than practise brain drain. Thus, the German Democratic Republic provides annually 6,500 places for vocational and advanced training of African nationals and 250 scholarships at institutes of higher learning and technical schools, at a cost of 50 million marks. In addition, 150 specialists from the German Democratic Republic are assigned to work in African countries.
43.	The issues and problems under consideration do not concern Africa'alone; they present a great challenge to virtually all States, as well as to the United Nations. All of us know very well what the Organization can achieve when its Members join forces in pursuit of a lofty goal. Hence we appreciate the endeavours and the personal commitment of the Secretary-General in connection with this process. There is no doubt that the mobilization of new and existing reserves to reverse the negative development trends in Africa will remain on the agenda. In this context, the co-ordination of relief measures within the United Nations system is an important task. However, an integrated programme designed to solve the problems of the continent is now more urgently needed than ever before. The crisis afflicting many African countries cannot be overcome by shots in the arm over the long haul. Resolute action is required to eliminate the root causes, which originated either in the colonial past or in neocolonialism.
44.	In their document for the special session, the African States rightly point out that the Priority Programme cannot be implemented without a fundamental change in the international economic situation and the elimination of the aggravating external constraints on their economies. It remains a priority task also to arrest net outflows of financial resources and the brain drain from that continent.
45.	Of special importance is urgent action to speed up and support the recovery and rehabilitation of the agricultural and industrial sectors in order to boost food production. We particularly support African demands for integrated strategies towards social and economic
development, industrialization, rehabilitation of infrastructures and upgrading of educational and vocational training systems as well as for improvement of health services. It is obvious that in this regard—as has already been pointed out—the State has a major role to play. 46. There is no doubt that in view of the urgent need to solve the entire complex of issues Africa is facing, great emphasis must be placed on joint endeavours by all African countries in the quest for economic development and social progress. These endeavours are complemented by the assistance of the international community. Such assistance must, as a matter of principle, be based on respect for the sovereignty of the African States and for their choice of the way towards national development, just as it must be devoid of any attempts to interfere in internal affairs. The German Democratic Republic is prepared on that basis to participate in the drawing up of effective measures at this special session on the critical economic situation in Africa.
47.	But all efforts for economic development and social progress in Africa presuppose one thing: that there is peace, and nothing but peace, not only on that continent but in the world at large.
48.	Mr. ABULHASAN (Kuwait) (interpretation from Arabic): The special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa has convened at this time in response to many calls, the first of which came from the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity in July 1985. The convening of this session reflects a global recognition of the gravity of the economic situation in the African continent, highlights the pivotal role played by the United Nations in such significant issues and reaffirms that international peace and political security are closely associated with the economic security and stability of each people and each member of our international community. The convening of the first session of the General Assembly devoted to the needs and future of one of the regions of the world is yet another achievement that the United Nations can add to its list of achievements. This is all the more true because this special session follows the commemoration of the fortieth anniversary of the Organization. Moreover, the session is even more in the limelight because the Group of African States comes to it in full agreement on a five-year plan for economic reform. 49. To the world, this session should also serve to illustrate the international community’s continued desire to promote the goals of collective work and the principles of the United Nations, one of the principal pivots of which is the promotion of international collective endeavour, at a time of a regrettable increasing tilt towards unilateral or bilateral approaches to international problems that have obvious global dimensions and effects. We believe that it is imperative to resort to collective international efforts when our goal is to create political and economic security and stability for the world, which is very interdependent and in which malaise in one region quickly spills over to the others.
50.	We must acknowledge the significance of the popular participation in various continents in the world effort to alleviate the suffering of the inhabitants of a continent that has such importance in our world today. We wish to place on record our full appreciation of all these popular initiatives, which seek not only to provide financial resources for the current world campaign, but also to make world public opinion even more aware of the need for solidarity and interdependence among the nations of the world and of the need for participation in development and progress. I take this opportunity to state that
the people of Kuwait have played a prominent and honourable role in aiding and.providing relief to the friendly countries of the African continent, both through official and through popular channels.
51.	In order to address Africa’s economic problem, one has to tackle a wide spectrum of intertwined domestic and external issues resulting from the conditions of the continent caused by widely recognized geographic, historical, climatic and environmental factors. In addition to the problem of natural disasters, which require immediate measures, we face the problems of indebtedness, reduction in official assistance from developed countries, adverse global financial and trade conditions and a trend towards protectionism.
52.	Over and above those factors, we find that an adverse political reality continues to hang over some African areas, thus further complicating, their problems, compounding their financial burdens and distracting them from concentrating on economic development processes. The most obvious example is the policies of the racist Pretoria régime aimed at destabilizing the security and peace of the front-line States and seizing and usurping Namibia’s economic resources for the benefit of a white minority.
53,	Despite its enormous potential and resources, Africa remains the least developed continent of the world. Income rates have been declining while growth rates have been either stagnating or decreasing. Levels of food production do not match those of population growth; indeed we have even witnessed a decrease in food production in many African countries.
54.	Furthermore, we cannot overlook the African continent’s incapacitating lack of infrastructure and advanced technological abilities that are essential factors for the taking of even the first steps towards sound economic development. Hence, in addition to providing relief to victims of natural disasters, the international community has to support the medium- and long-term development efforts of the African Governments, if we wish to put an end to the stage of misfortune followed by stop-gap relief measures and to embark on a course of lasting solutions and genuine development. That is why Kuwait has given a high priority to infrastructure projects in allocating development aid to African States.
55.	Undoubtedly, the international community and the African States themselves have made great headway in identifying the continent’s economic problems and their causes and in developing a long list of solutions and remedial methods. We now have formulas and plans that can produce considerable momentum towards the continent’s achieving its economic development goals, but the results will always remain contingent upon the will of the parties concerned.
56.	We have not come here today to claim that this special session can bring about a genuine solution to Africa’s economic problem. However, we have come with the hope that the session will be a point of departure for effective, collective international effort. We believe that we need collective measures conducive to tangible results, as called for by General Assembly resolution 40/40. So let us agree on such actions and let us set out to implement at least the most important of them. We should let Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 be our model in this task. The Programme reflects strong will and complete awareness and clearly defines the goals and priorities. Therefore, we should give adequate attention to the document which represents the opinions of the continent itself about its problems and the general strategy it depicts for the solution.
57.	In this plan, the African Governments have highlighted the agricultural sector as a primary target area, with the goal of increasing productivity in general and food production in particular, in the conviction that agriculture is the cornerstone of any economic reform. The paper has proclaimed self-sufficiency, self-reliance and structural transformation of national priorities as principal objectives. It also includes strengthening incentive policies, reviewing investment policies, streamlining economic management, encouraging and mobilizing the use of local resources and ensuring the widest possible scale of popular participation in developmental efforts and in combating poverty, hunger, disease and illiteracy.
58.	We cannot address the African economic situation without pointing to the debt problem and to the imperative need to arrive at lasting and just'solutions acceptable to all parties through a prudent political dialogue taking into account the harsh conditions, substantial development needs and political stability of the African nations— a dialogue in which the creditor developed countries and the multilateral financial institutions would have to participate.
59.	Moreover, the question of basic commodity prices represents one of the major elements in the economic problem. Economic analysts have cautioned that the fall of those prices has imperiled economic development in the third world and can engender political and economic dangers, and there is obviously a growing Western recognition of the dimensions of this problem and of the conditions that the industrialized nations are required to create in order to redress the situation. These same economic analysts have asserted that the increasingly interdependent world economy necessitates a review of the fundamentals of States’ national economic policies. This is unquestionably a message meant for nations with economic structures capable of global action.
60.	Reports from the world Organization—which with its bodies and agencies has been playing a leading role in prompting, organizing and co-ordinating international endeavours aimed at assisting Africa—indicate that the drought-related crisis of Africa persists and that generous emergency aid to the people of the affected areas must continue. If the international humanitarian shake-up last year, which still continues, has managed to mitigate the crisis, the subsequent subsidence of that flood of donations and media coverage might give the impression that the crisis is over. This is utterly contrary to reality.
61.	As for development in Africa, the Secretary-General has observed, in one of his statements, that the net result of the ambitious national development plans in the continent and the foreign-aid programmes benefiting it is disappointing to both the African Governments and their partners in development. If we wish to address the crisis effectively, there must be a reorientation of policies and attitudes and a return to consultation and co-ordination instead of unilateralism, which is detrimental both to those who practise it and to those who do not in an era of increasing interdependence among the States of the world. Despite the obvious global awareness, as demonstrated by this session, the world has nevertheless failed so far to draw up and carry out an effective strategy to deal directly with the substance of the problem, a strategy for which the industrial countries will have to provide full backing and the necessary resources.
62.	For those reasons, Kuwait, as a leader among the developing nations providing assistance, has persevered in exerting utmost efforts to provide what its resources will permit, in conformity with its policies of contributing to the alleviation of the economic problem and the enhancement of the arduous developmental process in the
friendly African countries. Notwithstanding a drop of about 40 per cent in its oil revenues, Kuwait continues to adopt the same policies. Kuwait will never abandon this commitment within the maximum limits of its. means.
63.	Kuwait has been fulfilling this obligation through various national and multilateral institutions, notably the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development, with an official capital of $6 billion, whose latest annual reports indicate that about one third of its highly concessionary developmental loans were provided to African countries. Between 1975 and the end of the 1984-1985 fiscal year, the Fund extended 79 relief loans to 29 African countries non-members of the League of Arab States. This represented 20 per cent of the Fund’s aggregate allocations. Because of Kuwait’s recognition of the size of the African economic problem, the Fund has decided to exempt African States with low levels of development from some of the already moderate regulations governing the provision of its development loans. Furthermore, the Fund’s conditions for those countries are governed by various special concessional considerations resulting from the continent’s situation and its need for basic development planning. Grants too are an element in these loans, representing between 17 and 85 per cent of the value of the loans. In addition to these loans, Kuwait’s financial institutions provide various forms of technical assistance and undertake full supervision of the grants provided by the State, including, in particular, project evaluation, management and follow-up activities.
64.	Kuwait also provides assistance to Africa through the African Development Bank, the Islamic Development bank, the International Development Fund of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa and the African Development Fund and through agencies within the United Nations system, such as IFAD, WFP, IDA and UNDP. In addition there is the Joint Kuwaiti Relief Committee, which represents both the public and the private sectors in Kuwait and whose establishment in 1984 was in direct response to the situation in Africa. It was set up to mobilize the efforts of national institutions and the energies, of young Kuwaiti volunteers in relief operations. Those young volunteers travelled in Africa to supervise the granting and channelling of that assistance. The Committee was given great momentum when popular fervour and the operational and field participation of youth reached favourable levels.
65.	In conclusion, I wish to reaffirm, to the friendly African countries and to the international community at large, that Kuwait will continue to honour its commitments and to fulfil its obligations concerning the development and relief of Africa not only because of our firm national policy but also because of our conviction that this world cannot hope for security, peace and stability if Africa remains in this critical economic situation.
66.	Mr. PICHUZHKIN (Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic) (interpretation from Russian)'. This special session of the General Assembly testifies to the international community’s deeply felt awareness of the crisis in the economic and social development of African countries and of the pernicious consequences of any further deterioration. We are profoundly convinced that the economic problems of Africa are inseparable from the overall situation in that continent and from the general world political and economic climate.
67.	This session, is taking place in a complex and tense international situation. The arms race whipped up by United States militarist circles continues at an ever increasing pace, and space strike weapons are being developed. Under these circumstances the peace initiatives of the
Soviet Union and other socialist countries aimed at preventing the world from sliding to the brink of nuclear disaster are particularly significant. These include the proposal for an all-embracing system of international security put forward at the XXVIIth Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, the programme for the complete elimination of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction by the end of this millenium, the further extension of the moratorium on nuclear tests and many other initiatives. Those initiatives serve the interests of all peoples and arouse hope that the political atmosphere will change for the better. They create the conditions necessary for extensive social and economic transformations.
68.	The spiralling arms race, particularly in nuclear weapons, is diverting vast resources from social and economic development. African countries too have been drawn into the arms race imposed by imperialism. Their military budgets are growing fast. Over 20 years of independent development—from 1961 to 1980—African States increased their military spending more than twenty-fold. Ending the arms race, reducing military expenditures and implementing the principle of disarmament for development constitute the most realistic and effective source of the funds so greatly needed to meet the economic and social needs of all countries, including those of Africa. We support Africa’s position on this issue, as set forth in the Lomé Declaration4 and Programme of Action.5 69. Against the background of modern scientific and technological achievement, it is inconceivable that millions in Africa should continue to suffer from hunger, malnutrition and related illnesses and lack of housing. The long drought and other natural disasters have no doubt aggravated the difficult economic situation in Africa, but the real causes go back to the time of colonialism, when the Western metropolitan States distorted the economic and social structure of the continent and brought it into conflict with the fundamental development interests in African countries. The situation in Africa today is a consequence of the continuing neo-colonialist policies of the imperialist Powers.
70.	The difficulties faced by African countries are common to the entire developing world, but those difficulties are now manifesting themselves most vividly in that continent. As has been stated by Mikhail Gorbachev, General-Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, the 1980s are characterized by the growth of crisis trends in the economies of African States.
71.	In its document submitted to the General Assembly at this session,1 the OAU stresses the adverse influence on the African economy of external factors resulting mainly from the subordinate status of African countries in the present system of international economic relations. Protectionism, the unprecedented growth of interest rates, the artificial lowering of commodity prices, the brain drain from developing countries and attempts to destabilize the progressive Governments of some countries can all, quite rightly, be called a kind of terrorism on the part of imperialism: economic terrorism.
72.	Especially alarming is the problem of the external debt of African countries, which continues to grow and consumes almost a third of the continent’s export earnings. That means that even in a favourable economic environment the prospects for the economic recovery of these countries remain unsatisfactory. Our delegation supports the African countries’ call for a conference on the continent’s external debt for a just solution of this issue.
73.	The critical economic situation in Africa is largely the result of the predatory activities of transnational corporations in that continent, which cause significant damage to the national interests of African countries. They obstruct development, making it one-sided and oriented to the West. The task of eliminating the negative consequences of the activities of transnational corporations makes it imperative to accelerate work to finalize the code of conduct, which is being delayed because of the Western States.
74.	The delegation of the Ukrainian SSR considers that the damage done to Africa as a result of neo-colonialist policies must be fully compensated for by those who are really responsible, namely the industrialized, developed capitalist countries. However, we cannot fail to point out the activities of certain circles in the West that reject any responsibility for the current crisis in Africa and are even trying to shift the blame onto the Governments of African countries for all sorts of mistakes in their economic policy aimed at strengthening the basis of planning and the public sector. Attempts are being made under various pretexts to interfere in the economic policies of young independent States with the aim of compelling them, against their will and the interests of the African peoples, to relinquish the progressive course of development and to submit to the uncontrolled “free play” of market forces, thus rendering their future dependent on the arbitrary actions of foreign capital.
75.	We consider it essential to the long-term solution of the problems facing African countries to ensure fundamental progressive socio-economic transformations, democratization of world economic relations, stabilization of the general economic, monetary and financial situation and implementation of United Nations decisions aimed at restructuring world economic relations on an equitable and democratic basis, especially the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States [resolution 3281 (XXIX)] and the Declaration and Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order [resolutions 3201 (S-VI) and 3202 (S-VI)].
76.	Ensuring the economic security of African countries is of particular importance for overcoming the crisis and advancing development. It cannot be obtained without respect for national independence and sovereignty, equal rights, mutual benefits, non-discrimination in trade and respect for the inalienable right of every people to choose its own economic system for the development of its country. Our delegation supports the convening of a world congress on the problems of economic security to discuss the whole range of factors impeding the normal development of economic relations among all the nations of the world, including the African States.
77.	The racist régime of South Africa poses a constant threat to the political and economic security of African countries. With the connivance and very often the direct support of imperialist circles, primarily the United States, the Pretoria régime is trying to dominate southern Africa, pursuing a policy of aggression and State terrorism against independent African States.
