In spite of many decisions of the United Nations, it is impeding Namibia’s accession to independence.
78.	The act of State terrorism against Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe on 19 May this year again confirmed the aggressive nature of South Africa’s policy. The policy of the white minority Government there aimed at desta--bilizing the situation in the region has a detrimental effect on the already fragile economy of African countries. The damage sustained by the economy of countries of southern Africa as a result of Pretoria’s aggressive policy
exceeds many times over the volume of international assistance provided to those countries. The Ukrainian delegation supports the legitimate demand of African States that the racist Government of South Africa pay full compensation for the damage done. At the same time we wish to stress once again the need for all members of the international community to take effective measures to put an end to the expansionist policy of South Africa and, in particular, to impose comprehensive and mandatory sanctions under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations. This applies above all to the United States, Israel and other Western countries and to their transnational corporations, which, despite many appeals from the General Assembly, are expanding their political, economic, military and nuclear co-operation with the racists of South Africa. We also consider it inadmissible that, contrary to many resolutions, international monetary and financial organizations, primarily IMF and the World Bank, are co-operating with the Pretoria régime. 79. Consistently supporting the struggle of African countries to overcome their unequal position in the world capitalist system, the Ukrainian SSR renders them substantial assistance in creating and strengthening the basis of their national economies. Within the framework of foreign economic relations of the Soviet Union, our Republic, in so far as it can and in forms that correspond to our social system, develops with African countries relations based on the principles of complete respect for national sovereignty, non-interference in internal affairs, equality and mutual benefit.
80.	Industrial goods of the Soviet Ukraine are exported to 30 African countries. Hundreds of specialists from the Republic take part in building various industrial and agricultural projects in Africa. The Ukrainian SSR renders substantial assistance in training skilled national cadres. With our assistance, educational centres are being established in Guinea, Mali and Algeria. In co-operation with the United Nations, international courses and seminars have been organized using the facilities of major scientific establishments and enterprises in the Republic. The Ukraine has hosted seminars on such major problems as modern drilling methods, the exploitation of mineral deposits, the planning and forecasting of water-resources development and some other issues. The Ukrainian SSR will continue to do everything it can to assist African countries in resolving their urgent socio-economic problems.
81.	On the eve of the opening of the special session of the General Assembly, the international community celebrated Africa Liberation Day. Almost all of Africa is politically independent now. Many countries have chosen the road of progressive transformation and are guided by progressive social concepts. Although many difficulties still face Africa we are confident they will be overcome.
82.	The Ukrainian delegation supports the proposal made by a number of delegations that this special session elaborate an effective and complex programme to solve the economic problems of Africa. We are prepared to make our contribution towards the attainment of that objective.
83.	Mr. de ABREU SODRE (Brazil):* I wish to congratulate you, Sir, on having been elected to preside over this special session of the General Assembly. Your recognized diplomatic skills and your capabilities as a leader, which were amply demonstrated during the Assembly’s fortieth session, ensure that our work will once again be successful.
*Mr. de Abreu Sodre spoke in Portuguese. The English version of his statement was supplied by the delegation.
84.	I cannot over-emphasize the importance the Brazilian Government attributes to international efforts for the recovery of the African economies. The solidarity which Brazil has come here to put into concrete reality is not to be confused with rhetorical gestures. Within its possibilities as a developing country Brazil will seek to cooperate actively with African economic recovery. It is painful to us that Africa, at the end of the twentieth century, still suffers from dramatic poverty. The perpetuation of the factors of its critical economic and the political vulnerability should be a motive for concern and action.
85.	We are not moved solely by our feelings, however noble and warm they are. Relations between Brazil and the sister nations of Africa in the past few decades have emerged from the shadows and have acquired the greatest priority. In addition, we are now animated by enlightened common interests. Besides the evident ethnic, historical, linguistic and cultural affinities that link us so closely to the African continent, we must dwell on the fact that powerful factors clearly exist that bring Brazil closer and closer to the African nations. Today, freed from the distortions of perception imposed by colonial pacts, it can be clearly seen that our territories lie in absolute proximity. Distances from Africa, in many cases, are shorter than those that exist between places within Brazil itself, a fact that still comes as a surprise to some.
86.	Scientifically, there is evidence of obvious similarities and identities of the bio-geographical determinants of our territories and resources. Thus, new forms for cooperation are emerging in the South-South sense, based not only on criteria of complementarity but also on the awareness of the specificity of our common problems. 87. In confirmation of that rediscovery of proximities, complements and identities, the dynamism of two-way commercial trade between Brazil and Africa stands out. In the past few years that trade has had an average rate of growth larger than Brazil’s trade with any other continent. Brazil trades with Africa on levels equivalent to those with its Latin American neighbours. There is a growing, ever-firmer feeling that countries bordering on the South Atlantic ineluctably belong to the same region, one to be preserved as a zone of peace and co-operation, free from exogenous impositions, tensions and threats.
88.	Following up on the initiative of the President of Brazil, Mr. José Sarney, at the 4th meeting of the fortieth sesson of the General Assembly, I should like to inform Member States that I am addressing a letter to the Secretary-General6 to request the inclusion in the agenda of the forty-first session of an item entitled “Zone of peace and co-operation in the South Atlantic”.
89.	All those factors point to the obvious realities, potentialities and prospects for a co-operation of reciprocal interest to Brazil and Africa.
90.	The situation that affects Africa is of unquestionable gravity. Some of the most acute manifestations of the tragic calamity which in the past few years has caused incalculable human loss have been overcome, thanks to international emergency aid and recent favourable developments in climatic conditions.
91.	It is legitimate to say that hunger still threatens millions of human beings and that the process of economic deterioration in the sub-Saharan region of Africa has not been reversed. Twenty-five years after independence, the fragility of the African economy keeps the countries of the continent vulnerable to the oscillations of external factors and to adverse natural phenomena. One dramatic fact sums up the situation: Africa has the lowest indices of food self-sufficiency in the world, a
euphemism for a harsh reality, namely, hunger. The roots of that fragility are, beyond a doubt, to be found in the colonial system that favoured dependency and failed to stimulate self-sustained development on the national or regional level. To a great degree, this explains the profound distortions in the processes of modernization undertaken by the African countries and why those countries were prevented from benefiting in an adequate way from the periods of greater expansion in the international economy.
92.	In any diagnosis of the African situation, external factors acquire special relevance. It is up to the international community, therefore, to assume the portion of the responsibility that is rightfully incumbent upon it in the task of African economic recovery.
93.	The decline in international trade between 1980 and 1983 had a severe impact on the African economies, as it did on those of other regions dependent upon exports of primary goods where prices underwent severe erosion. During that period, the terms of trade of the countries of sub-Saharan Africa sharply deteriorated. The African foreign debt rose substantially, increasing sevenfold between 1974 and 1985, until today it amounts to $175 billion. Servicing that debt increased the burden on the balance of payments because of high rates of interest and fluctuations in the rates of exchange.
94.	These factors generated a serious reduction in the import capacity of the African countries, gravely affecting the agricultural sector, with disastrous effects on the production of foodstuffs, as well as on manufacturing and infrastructure, which were rendered incapable of affecting the investments that are essential for the maintenance and replacement of capital. The already weakened social sectors were equally affected, particularly in health and education.
95.	This vicious circle, which holds true for almost all developing countries, has particularly grave repercussions in Africa. Breaking it requires an integrated, overall approach to the question of trade, money and finance on the part of the international community, as well as a substantial change in the framework within which international economic relations operate.
96.	In the case of Africa, the importance of ensuring an adequate recovery of the prices of the commodities that make up the main source of income is notorious. In this connection, it must be borne in mind that the practice of agricultural subsidies adopted by some developed countries has a negative effect on international prices and on the market for these products. This problem was recently highlighted by the President of the World Bank, who said:
“Internal prices set well above world prices, especially in Europe, but also here in the United States, encourage domestic production and depress domestic consumption. The resulting surpluses, flooding the world market at depressed prices, do particular damage to those developing countries trying to raise their output of agricultural products in which they often have an absolute advantage.”
The same high official stressed that the steep rate of decline in the growth of developing countries’ exports to industrialized countries strongly suggests that protectionist measures, particularly in manufacturing and agriculture, are among the causes of the decline and increase concern about the growing use of non-tariff barriers by industrialized countries.
97.	The documents submitted for examination at this special session attest to the political will and the desire
for co-ordinated action demonstrated by the countries of Africa to resolve their economic crisis.
98.	The international community is thus faced with a challenge: to bury the past approach based on mere assistance and to inaugurate a new process of real cooperation that will make the African economy less vulnerable to external shocks. In this undertaking, the priority measures for internal economic policies are undoubtedly important proposals. With reason, great emphasis is placed on the development and modernization of the agricultural sector and its infrastructure of transportation, storage and commercialization. The increase in the production of foodstuffs and the effort to provide food security occupy a prominent place. Also being contemplated are actions to bring about administrative modernization and greater efficiency in training human resources and implementing economic policies. It therefore behoves the General Assembly at this session to assume the task of effectively supporting the effort of the African countries by eliminating the external obstacles that have beset the development of the region. In truth, it is necessary to adopt a whole range of measures that are being called for by all developing countries as indispensable to the resumption of their economic growth on a stable basis.
99.	To this end, it is important for the international community, and particularly for the developed countries, to arrive, as quickly as possible, at an agreement on the following main objectives. First, policies that favour expansion of the world economy and trade must be adopted, and protectionist measures, especially those of a non-tariff nature, which hamper the access of products of developing countries to the markets of the industrialized countries, should be eliminated. Secondly, agricultural and commercial policies that are unjustly unfavourable to the expansion of exports from developing countries must be corrected. Thirdly, measures and policies must be adopted to make it possible to guarantee remunerative and stable prices for commodities, through the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the Common Fund for Commodities and the GATT provision on special treatment for tropical products. Fourthly, the amounts of concessional financial resources earmarked for the African countries should be increased, without prejudice to the volume of concessional aid for the other developing countries. Fifthly, there must be formulas that permit relief from the developing countries’ burden of foreign debt servicing and make it possible for that debt to be paid off without adopting measures of internal readjustment prejudicial to economic development. The problem of indebtedness, although it has qualitatively diverse characteristics in Africa, is common to developing countries and affects Latin America very seriously. Brazil, together with the other countries that make up the Cartagena Consensus,7 insists upon the need for political treatment of the debt problem and reaffirms its conviction that the debt cannot continue to be paid at the cost of recession, unemployment and hunger.
100.	The conviction that it is the developed countries that are chiefly responsible for creating favourable international conditions for the economic recovery of the African countries does not lead us to assume a passive attitude. On the contrary, the solidarity of the developing countries should also be demonstrated by the strengthening of co-operation and trade between them. SouthSouth forms of co-operation are increasingly emphasized in economic relations, and Brazil attaches particular importance to them. The establishment of a global system of trade preferences among the developing countries, which was approved at the Ministerial Meeting of the
Negotiating Committee on the Global System of Trade Preferences, held at Brasilia on 22 and 23 May 1986, where African countries participated in a significant way, appears to us, in this context, to be a striking step forward.
101.	The similarities of climate, geography and social and economic levels of development frequently found among developing countries call for new technological solutions more appropriate to the environmental conditions and availability of resources in those countries than to those in the industrialized countries of the North. By diversifying means of co-operation and commerce, dependence and vulnerability are lessened. It is thus important that the programme for the economic recovery of Africa put adequate stress on measures to strengthen this aspect of South-South co-operation and provide for the necessary financial support.
102.	Aware as it is of the importance of co-operation among the developing countries, Brazil has been carrying out a promising programme of technical co-operation with Africa. At the regional and subregional levels, we would cite Brazil’s willingness to collaborate with ECA in formulating and implementing the pilot transportation plan for the continent as well as the establishment of new ties with the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCCJ in various sectors.
103.	At the bilateral level, the potential of the programmes being developed between Brazil and more than 15 African countries is also becoming increasingly promising. The goal of these programmes is to promote mutually advantageous efforts and the improvement of the institutional and managerial capacity of our partners, an essential factor in overcoming the obstacles inherent in underdevelopment.
104.	The Brazilian Government has sought to concentrate the limited resources available to it on financing integrated or support projects earmarked especially for the areas of human resources and professional training, agriculture, agro-industry, mineral resources, alternate sources of energy, transport and telecommunications— priorities which we emphasize here. In order to expand those programmes, the Brazilian Government recently signed a memorandum of understanding with UNDP to increase activities concerning technical co-operation among developing countries for the fourth programming cycle of UNDP. The memorandum envisages the concession of additional funds, and the resulting activities will get under way with a training programme for Cape Verde in the field of medicine and health. A joint mission of Brazilian and African experts will be in Africa shortly to identify and discuss other specific projects in this context.
105.	The countries of the African continent propose to undertake prodigious efforts to achieve structural reforms at the national and regional levels. Those noteworthy plans will be of no avail, however, if a comprehensive and appropriate response in the medium term is not forthcoming from the international community in the way of profound changes in the world economic and financial system, in addition to measures to be taken immediately. There is only one description for the alternative: the inhumane perpetuation of backwardness and hunger.
106.	I should like to recall here the words of the President of my country, addressed to the fortieth session of the General Assembly last September. He said:
“The world cannot enjoy peace so long as there is a single hungry mouth anywhere on the face of the earth, a single child dying for lack of milk, a single human being suffering for lack of bread. The coming century
will be the century of socialized food. The image of the mater dolorosa in the African desert is humiliating to us. Foodstuffs cannot continue to be merely speculative commodities on the exchange markets. Science and technology are here, announcing a new era of abundance through genetic engineering. Man, who has been able to break through the barriers of Earth and take off for the distant stars, cannot be incapable of eradicating hunger. What is required is á universal will to do so. That is a decision which must be taken without vetoes.” [See 4th meeting, para. 84.]
That is a challenge, a challenge that acquires particular relevance in the case of the African continent, whose critical economic situation we feel deeply.
107.	We cannot merely contemplate passively the climate of insecurity that prevails in the continent because of the crisis existing in southern Africa. Even less can we fail to acknowledge that the perpetuation of that crisis not only jeopardizes the economic future of the region, but also entails, objectively speaking, intolerable and needless bloodshed. In a recent address on the occasion of his visit to Cape Verde, the President of Brazil synthesized the position of the Brazilian Government on the subject as follows:
“I am certain that the complex problem of southern Africa can never be resolved in the context of EastWest tensions or from any strategic perception of the major Powers.
“The solution for the crisis in that region must start with the eradication of apartheid and progress to the following stage of implanting a solid structure of peaceful interaction among the countries of the region which will enable all of them to devote themselves to the struggle to implement their national development projects.”
108.	The continuing illegal occupation of Namibia by South Africa and the repeated acts of aggression and destabilization to which the countries of southern Africa have been subjected constitute a serious impediment to the economic development and recovery of that region. I should like to stress that in Cape Verde the President of my country asserted his firm conviction that:
“The cessation not only of the acts of aggression committed by the Republic of South Africa against Angola, but also of all assistance to the irregular forces destabilizing that country is indispensable and of the greatest urgency.”
In the same context, the Brazilian Government views with great concern the situation in which Mozambique finds itself.
109.	I could not address the Assembly today without failing to place on record the vehement repudiation and clear condemnation by the Government of my country of the recent attacks against other sovereign States of the region by South African forces. We extend our solidarity to the Governments and the peoples of Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe, deeply regretting the loss of life and material damages sustained as a result of yet another unjustifiable aggression.
110.	The international community was able to demonstrate by its efficient mobilization of funds for emergency aid to Africa the positive results which can be achieved when political determination and international understanding exist. The same dedication and the same efforts should now be applied to promoting ways and means for long-term structural development which will make it possible, without any sense of patronage, to shield the African peoples from the frightening spectre of the
calamities they have suffered in recent years with their sad sequel of death and destruction.
111.	Mr. KIMCHE (Israel): I should first like to congratulate the OAU on its very thorough analysis of the critical economic situation in Africa and its wide-ranging proposals submitted to the special session of the General Assembly on behalf of its member Governments in the form of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990? The causes of the crisis were identified and courageously listed and clear strategy was outlined, together with estimates of the African resources available, as well as international resource flows and economic changes required. It is also gratifying to note the unequivocal commitment to the rehabilitation and upgrading of the agricultural sector as the means not only of rural development but also as an “engine of growth” capable of attaining the necessary structural transformation of economies, improved personal income and human resources development.
112.	The State of Israel has used a similar strategy to develop its agricultural self-sufficiency and its diversified technological economy. We therefore wish to add proposals based on our own development experience and observations resulting from our own modest technical assistance and co-operation efforts in Africa over the past 28 years. At the outset, I wish to emphasize that the State of Israel is willing and able to place its considerable expertise and capabilities in this area at the disposal of interested African Governments and the international donor and development agencies in the ensuing multilateral and bilateral programmes arising out of this very important session of the General Assembly. I may add that this expertise of Israel is indeed considerable, both from the point of view of what we have achieved in our own country and in our technical assistance activities in developing countries.
113.	It is clear that the immediate and most pressing symptom of the economic crisis is the problem of negative balance of payments, debt service burdens and adverse terms of trade resulting from Africa’s dependence on primary commodities, inherited economic structure and external shocks. Clearly, international action towards increasing resource flows, reducing the debt burden and seeking a less adverse international trade framework will be necessary. '.
114.	In this respect, Israel has presented à number of well-documented proposals to various United Nations forums in the past dealing with increased capital flows to developing countries. This includes the Horowitz proposal for mass interest subsidizations, the Sanbar proposal for creating an export credit guarantee facility and the Gafney proposal for expanded co-financing.
115.	Israel supports the various domestic agricultural price policy incentive reforms as well as the economic structural adjustment and public enterprise reorganization programmes being undertaken by the African Governments with the assistance of the World Bank and other agencies. However, it is clear that the implementation of thé various policy reforms, structural transformation and absorption capacity is severely constrained by availability of not only financial, but also human resources.
116.	It is necessary to expand vocational training in the rural areas on a massive scale. It is also necessary to equip the available professionals, supervisors, managers and administrators, in both public and private sectors, with the added skills and know-how required for the structural transformation and reforms. In this respect, Israel has developed several modalities of short courses in agriculture, community development, co-operative and labour
organization management and community health services. In over 28 years of co-operation with 110 countries, Israel has welcomed over 27,000 trainees in specialized institutions for this purpose, instructed over 25,000 trainees in their respective countries and sent over 9,000 experts abroad in these fields. Israel is willing to work with African countries and the international community in assisting to relieve one of the most critical constraints to African economic development: that of know-how transfer. The emphasis in this programme should be on the conduct of courses in thé respective African countries and “training of trainers abroad” to ensure a motivating exposure to effective methods, procedures and innovations.
117.	The principal thrust of the transitional economy strategy propounded by Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery is the creation of a new bias in favour of the peripheral sector of the population, mainly in rural areas. This economic policy is based primarily on domestic consumption with primary commodity exports regarded as a means of paying for essential imports only. Economic structure transformation is, therefore, based on the multiplier effects generated primarily by agricultural diversification and intensification.
118.	The planning of a rural intervention programme; and resource allocation to implement the transitionai economy concept that I have outlined should be patterned on Israel’s “Rehovot Approach”, that is, Israel’s rural development strategy adapted to developing countries. This strategy calls for policies and programmes to enable productivity increases and utilize human potential by strengthening production incentives through upgrading the institutional structure of rural production, as well as economic and group action institutions.
119.	lam sure that representatives have all heard of the kibbutz, a communal village—and I presume it to be one of the purest forms of social communism in the world today—of the moshav, which is a co-operative village, or of Nakhal, which diverts youth doing military service to pioneering activities in the field of agriculture, especially in areas which have to be brought under the plough for the first time, such as the Negev areas in the south of our country, for example. We have succeeded in the kibbutz and the moshav in such methods. We have succeeded in developing improved community organizational forms which, together with support systems and knowledge transfer, are the basis of achieving development goals.
120.	We believe that the know-how for achievement of improvements in food and cash crop output exists in most of Africa. The problem is to ensure that this knowledge is transmitted to farmers; that the appropriate incentive environment exists to encourage its application; that farmers will co-operate willingly as output increases and production, as well as marketing, become more complex. Naturally, the local application of national programmes must meet the needs of the predominant farm types in each agro-ecological region of a country and be tailored to the local level of institutional development.
121.	Israel is well known for its achievements in ensuring agricultural productivity under semi-arid conditions. It should be remembered that over half of Israel’s area receives less than 180 millimetres of rainfall annually, and therefore we have had to make great efforts to develop agriculture with very little water—conditions which are comparable to large areas in Africa. Our history goes back over 2,000 years to utilization of flash floods and moisture conservation by rudimentary methods and communal construction of the related works. Our modern
drought management systems vary from farm-level technology to conjunctive use of surface and ground water, regional water transfer, irrigation with brackish water, conservation of flash floods and a national cloud-seeding programme of international repute. We are prepared to place our know-how at the disposal of Africa in developing suitable technologies for the reduction of drought vulnerability in improved traditional agriculture.
122.	Typical areas of applied research and implementation would be the following: genetic improvement of crops for increased yield and/or drought resistance; cultivation techniques to improve moisture conservation as a result of simple water harvesting methods; improved management of livestock herds for increased productivity and drought survival; improved organization and management for smallholder irrigation projects; identification and evaluation of ground-water resources; and improvement of land carrying capacity by wide-scale cloud-seeding operations in regions having a potential for this technique. Israel’s research institutions are prepared to collaborate with researchers in Africa and to provide major input to applied research in the areas I have enumerated, as well as to cooperate in innovative research and development.
123.	Israel wishes to share the fruits of its experience with the peoples of Africa. We are not a large country, nor do we have large budgets at our disposal. We do, however, have a great deal of experience in rural development and agriculture under difficult conditions. Also, as a people with an unparalleled history of being victims of racial persecution, we maintain a large reservoir of goodwill and sympathy for the peoples of Africa, and we are also totally opposed to racialist policies, such as that of apartheid. We are indeed earnestly seeking ways in which we can transfer the relevant aspects of our experience and know-how to Africa.
124.	My delegation has presented to this special session a document entitled “Economic Development and the Transformation of African Agriculture: An Israeli View” [A/S-13/7]. In it, suggested strategies for rural development are analysed and possible Israeli contributions to critical areas of applied research and farmer support are enumerated. Four phases of agricultural development are identified, interventions to assist.transition between phases —from traditional to improved traditional agriculture, from there further to diversified agriculture and, finally, to market-oriented and specialized agriculture—are analysed, and subjects in which Israeli expertise may be relevant are indicated. They would be in three key areas: one is the applied research within development programmes for improved agricultural technology for drought-prone and semi-arid African countries; the second would be using Israel’s international training infrastructure and experience for human resource development, including adapted extension services; and the third would be institution-building at the community and entrepreneur levels, including an approach whereby the public and private sectors join forces to accelerate development. In this respect a proposal is made to include the Institutes for Applied and Desert Research of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev and the Center for Arid and Semi-Arid Zone Development of the Hebrew University for scientific cooperation with the network of African agricultural research institutes.
125.	In this regard, I should like to inform all delegations of a special symposium hosted by my delegation discussing the Israeli experience in agriculture and aridzone research. The symposium will be held tomorrow, 29 May, from 2.30 to 6.30 p.m., in the Dag Hammarskjold
Auditorium. Experts from Israel’s Ministry of Agriculture and Ben-Gurion University will be discussing pertinent topics related to my country’s experience in agriculture with particular emphasis on arid-zone research, and, of course, all representatives are invited. .
126.	The international community has been witness to the terrible tragedy affecting so many people in the Sahel region resulting from drought and conflict. This destitution has affected mainly rural populations, and that is where a new effort must be made to alleviate human suffering. Never before have the people of Israel been so conscious of the need to face a challenge of accelerated development in Africa. This awareness is all the stronger since in the early years of our national revival we had to grapple with the problems of severely degraded lands in a hostile agricultural environment. This was our startingpoint in building an economy—first to feed the nation, then gradually to improve its income-generating opportunities and foreign-currency earnings.
Mr. Shah Nawaz (Pakistan), Vice-President, took the Chair.
127.	We adopted the Eleventh Commandment formulated so eloquently by the renowned conservationist, the late Walter Lowdermilk, in Jerusalem in 1939. We implemented it so as better to overcome desertification, land degradation and human desolation so typical of some regions of Africa today. I quote:
“Thou shalt inherit the Holy Earth as a faithful steward, conserving its resources and productivity from generation to generation. Thou shalt safeguard thy field from soil erosion, thy living waters from drying up, thy forests from desolation, and protect thy hills from overgrazing by the herds, that thy descendants may have abundance forever.”
128.	We are prepared to enter into immediate discussions with African countries and international organizations with regard to the problems of agriculture and economic development and ways in which Israel may provide the maximum contribution that its capacity may allow.
129.	Mr. SHEARER (Jamaica): Those of us who have followed with keen interest the modern history of Africa cannot but have been painfully aware of the enormous challenges facing the continent, even as we recognized Africa’s promise and immense potential. But this knowledge notwithstanding, my countrymen—and, indeed, the entire international community—were unprepared for the enormous toll in lives, the widespread loss of livelihood and the immensity of the tragedy in human suffering that occurred during the recent emergency situation in Africa. The drought that ravaged a large part of the continent focused international attention in a concerted way on the deep economic and ecological problems that faced Africa. Our gratitude goes to Governments, private organizations and especially individuals for their effective and continuing response to that crisis. As we know, the United Nations itself has played a valuable role in mobilizing and co-ordinating external assistance, particularly through the establishment and excellent work of the Office for Emergency Operations in Africa.
130.	But all these efforts were designed to relieve the emergency. The larger challenge remains before Africa and the international community. It has become unmistakably clear that a confluence of ecological and underlying structural problems has brought the economy of Africa to a critical turning-point. Against the background of the toll in lives exacted by the recent emergency situation and the frightening implications of any repetition, it is not, in our view, an exaggeration to speak of a
historical crossroads for Africa. The action we take here at this special session can help to determine the quality of life that future generations of Africans will enjoy and will help to shape the role that Africa plays in the global economy of the future. It is, therefore, with a feeling of dedication to a great cause that Jamaica participates in this effort by the international community to rise to the larger challenge of Africa’s development.
131.	The economic and social problems affecting Africa are common to many developing countries. Some are structural in nature and others have their roots in external circumstances. These problems stem mainly from the narrow range of primary commodities available for export, fluctuating world market prices for these commodities, a low level of production in the areas of manufactured goods and capital equipment, low productivity in agriculture, rapid population growth, a low level of scientific and technological development and a weak human resource base, particularly in managerial skills. ■
132.	It is axiomatic that each country bears primary responsibility for its own development, and it is evident that Governments in Africa recognize and accept this primary responsibility for Africa’s economic future. It is evident that they also recognize that special measures of an immediate and comprehensive nature have to be implemented if permanent solutions to the manifold problems are to be found. These approaches are reflected not only in the projects that make up Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 but also in the economic policy reforms which individual countries consider will facilitate the successful implementation of the Priority Programme.
133.	Policy reform is a sovereign decision of individual countries. The acknowledgement by individual countries of the need for policy reform and the acceptance by all that it is the right of individual countries to determine the nature and pace of policy reform together constitute the essential basis for international development cooperation. On that basis, international co-operation is strengthened and will yield successful results.
134.	The record shows that African Governments have long been conscious of the importance of development planning nationally, subregionally and regionally. In the last 25 years, many regional and subregional organizations have been established, integration schemes have been initiated, and bilateral and subregional technical and economic co-operation strengthened. Several plans or action programmes have been agreed for different sectors. There was the adoption of the comprehensive Lagos Plan of Action,8 a particularly significant milestone. We recall the Industrial Development Decade for Africa; the Transport and Communications Decade in Africa; the Regional Plan of Action to Combat the Impacts of Drought in Africa, adopted by the ECA Conference of Ministers in May 1984; and the Harare Declaration on the food crisis in Africa, adopted at the Thirteenth FAO Regional Conference for Africa, among others.
135.	The record also shows that bilateral and multilateral donors have recognized specific features of the African-situation and have reacted to those features through special measures consistent with the classification of many African countries as “least developed” or through aid and co-operation arrangements working through IDA, through UNDP, through the Lome Conventions and through other instruments.
136.	We must be candid, however, and say that the results achieved have not always been commensurate with the plans set forth and the efforts made, nor have the
resources provided by the international community been anywhere near commensurate with what is required.
137.	Jamaica hopes that a new chapter can be written— a new era ushered in—with Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery. The Programme is courageous. It is practical. We think it is affordable. African leaders have put together a package which is a judicious mix of State-sector and private-enterprise co-operation. The plan recognizes that genuine efforts must be made to improve the management of the African economies and to rationalize public investment policies. It points out that the positive role of the private sector is also to be encouraged through well-defined and consistent policies. The plan shows flexibility, and at the same time does not compromise the right of each country to follow its chosen development path.
138.	A study of the 17 countries most affected by the drought and famine of 1984-1985 in Africa shows that, per capita, in 1983 these countries accounted for only $107 of world imports and exports. A look at 15 Latin American and Caribbean States shows that those countries accounted for three and one-half times more world imports and exports—that is, $374 per capita. The crude inference is that by simply raising the standard of those African countries to the 1983 level of trade flow of the Latin American countries, world trade could increase by at least some $49 billion, plus a further amount resulting from multiplier effects. Taking into account the interdependence of the world economy, this increase in world trade not only would benefit millions of persons in Africa, but would also, through deliveries of machinery, equipment and services, benefit the developed countries and many other countries that produce those goods and services.
139.	But no plan, however well intentioned, however well thought out, will succeed without support. Equally, no plan can succeed unless it is started.
140.	The Priority Programme calls for overall funding of $128.1 billion between this year and 1990. Of this amount, the African countries have undertaken to provide $82.5 billion from their own resources. The additional amount needed from external sources is $45.6 billion. My delegation joins in calling upon the international community to support this effort fully and to make its commitments in a form which will leave no doubt as to its resolve to ensure a proper and effective implementation of the Programme. We are encouraged by the strong support already expressed at this session by so many Governments and the specific commitment of additional resources by some countries to the Priority Programme. 141. Other developing countries can also assist. In this regard we call on our sister developing countries to extend their programmes of South-South co-operation consistent with the needs of the African countries. We also call on non-governmental organizations, foundations and private individuals to be responsive to requests for assistance, especially to fill gaps in the range of skills that are needed.
142.	But there is another aspect of international cooperation which must be emphasized. If the tremendous national efforts which are being expended on the Priority Programme are not to be frustrated, there will need to be important changes in the international environment.
143.	First of all, the attainment of higher levels of economic activity in African countries and the assurance that Africa is able to generate the level of resources needed to meet investment targets set in the Priority Programme will require at a minimum more remunerative and more stable commodity prices, removal of protectionist measures by the industrialized countries, increased
flows of direct investment and easier access for manufactures and semi-manufactures to important markets.
144.	Equally important’ as (he measures I have just mentioned is the need to’ take steps’to deal with the pressing problem of Africa’s external debt. It is noted that while the Priority Programme calls for external resources of $9.1 billion per annum, Africa’s annual debtservicing obligations will be in the range of between $14.6 and $24.5 billion. My delegation fully agrées that urgent measures must be taken by the international community to alleviate Africa’s debt-service burden and thus enable these countries to utilize scarce resources, as far as possible, for economic recovery and development.
145.	Then, a peaceful and stable international political environment is also important to the success of development efforts. In Africa-we continue to’face the longstanding issue of racism and white-minority domination in South Africa. Namibia continues to be illegally occupied by the South African régime, and that country’s national resources are being exploited without consideration for the economic development and well-being of the indigenous population. Significant and scarce resources are being deployed by front-line States in order to secure their borders against racist aggression.
146.	The relentless campaign of military aggression and economic sabotage waged by the Pretoria régime against its neighbours forces a number of African States to spend large additional sums on armaments for their security. Resolution of the South African and Namibian issues and the consequent easing of tensions would allow for alternative use of those resources for development purposes in those countries. ' ' • ' '
147.	The international community has an obligation to ensure that a solution is forthcoming as soon as possible. We can no longer tolerate a situation in which scarce human and financial resources are diverted from development purposes. By its backward, racist policies South Africa not only holds human beings in bondage but also seriously damages the prospects for economic development in southern Africa. That régime’s recent terrorist attacks against Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe starkly reveal once again that the countries of southern Africa have no choice but to spend disproportionate sums in their effort to.secure their borders and even their cities from aggression. Jamaica joins in condemning in the strongest terms the brazen, savage banditry of the callous racists in Pretoria. . .
148.	In this special session the task is now to develop a final document which not only is action-oriented but provides a firm basis on which Africa can proceed to address its manifold structural problems, confident in the knowledge that the required levels of external supplementary financing will be forthcoming.
149.	A mammoth task lies ahead. Africa has committed itself to meeting the challenge. The international community can do no less. Let us lay the basis at this special session for a new and more fruitful period of co-operation with Africa which will create opportunities for improving the well-being of its peoples, strengthen the contribution of African countries to the health of the international economy and ensure that the recent tragedy of widespread drought and famine is never allowed to recur, though it will remain in our memories as a challenge to the will and the capabilities of all mankind. '
150.	Mr. MURIN (Czechoslovakia) (interpretation from Russian): First, of all, I wish to express our pleasure at the election of the President of this special session of the General Assembly devoted to the critical economic situation in Africa. We welcome the convening of this
session and are ready to work in order to contribute to the achievement of just and effective results.
151.	In our opinion, this session is one of the most important international political events this year. It reflects many of the acute problems and contradictions that are causing such anxiety in today’s world. The misfortune which has stricken tire entire continent of Africa cannot, in our interdependent world, fail to have an impact on. the whole range of international relations. '
152.	' The Czechoslovak delegation intends to strive at this session, together with other socialist countries, African countries and all other countries pursuing a realistic policy, for the preparation of an effective, comprehensive programme to overcome the.critical economic and social situation in Africa. Our determination to engage in such co-operation is based on the conclusions of the XVIIth Congress of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, which emphasized:
“We regard the peoples that have liberated themselves as our friends and partners in the struggle in the cause of peace and progress, and together with them we shall continue to work to eliminate the dangerous hotbeds of tension and bring about a restructuring’of international economic relations on a just, and democratic basis.” ' "
153.	The causes of the situation which has arisen in Africa are complex and multifaceted. They have been in the process of formation for several centuries, comprising both the harsh colonial past of the African countries and the neo-colonial present that is being imposed upon them now. Only the thorough analysis of these causes will make it possible to determine and agree upon reliable solutions.
154.	There is no doubt that first among the fundamental reasons for the situation in the African continent is its colonial past. The long colonial enslavement and exploitation of Africa by imperialist States led to a distortion of the social and economic structures of the African peoples and to an exceedingly disadvantageous and unnatural position for Africa in the overall structure of the inter-, national division of labour, so that its economic dependence and poverty have reached ever higher levels. One of the major problems that African countries have to . resolve, with the assistance of the international community, is that of overcoming this situation. If we talk today about Africa’s colonial past, it is because we wish to emphasize not only the historical responsibility of imperialism for creating the critical situation which has come about there, but also, and primarily, the fact that neocolonialism, that offspring of colonialism, is today both an impediment and the principal threat to the independent social and economic development of Africa and to the solution of its problems.
155.	We advocate precisely such a diagnosis and approach. We are fully aware of the gravity of the economic and social problems of the African countries. Our Government and the Czechoslovak people fully support the efforts of Africans to rid themselves of the grievous inheritance of the colonial era. However, we are against short-term solutions with strings attached, which could make the critical economic and social situation of African countries even worse and impede their independent development. .
156.	Today, Africa is a huge crucible bubbling with conflict and with internal and external contradictions. The fact that this special session is taking place in an even more tense and explosive international atmosphere is a clear reflection of the recent worrisome events affecting a number of African countries. The attack on Libya, an independent African State, is more than an outrage upon
human morality and international law; together with economic blackmail and the use of military force on the African continent, it manifests a qualitatively new form of State terrorism and the policy of armed neo-colonial-ism. That is the substance of the well-known doctrine of “neo-globalism”..
157,	The barbarous armed attack in the United States mould perpetrated last week by South Africa against three independent African States has been resolutely rejected and vigorously condemned by the Czechoslovak people and Government. That attack is further proof of South Africa’s aggressive policy, which has elevated apartheid and terrorism to the level of State policy, marking a dangerous new step towards heightened tension in southern Africa.
158.	Let us examine the policy pursued by imperialism since the collapse of the old colonial system with a view to unprecedented increases in the arms race. The goal is to use force of arms to halt further progressive change in the world and to achieve decisive supremacy over socialist and developing countries. Nor is it a secret that the military programmes of developed capitalist States are increasingly financed through the net outflow of resources from the developing countries, especially through transnational corporations. In Africa, that outflow has surpassed $9 billion. That is one of the main motivating forces of contemporary neo-colonialism.
159; That is why we stress that there can be no search for a solution to the pressing economic and social problems of African and other developing countries without due regard for the struggle to avert the threat of war, to eliminate nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction, to avoid the militarization of outer space and to reduce military expenditures substantially. In our view, the solution of the problems of Africa should be a step towards the establishment of an integrated system of international economic security, as has been advocated by the socialist countries. Such a solution could not fail to take account of the fact that the problems faced by African countries are by no means confined to their continent.
160.	We would recall that the essence of colonialism— which caused the poverty and economic backwardness of the overwhelming majority of developing countries— manifested itself in the same way everywhere: colonial military and political coercion imposing distortions of the international division of labour in order gradually to draw individual countries and whole continents into total dependence on the former metropolitan Powers. Today’s neo-colonialism essentially manifests itself in a similarly uniform way, by using the old structures of the division of labour created during the colonial period to undermine the political independence of liberated countries, turning them into appendages for raw materials and sources for financing their militaristic policies. To that end, use is made of capitalism’s entire arsenal of economic, political and even military means of coercion, especially the whole policy of granting credit, the perpetuation of debt, and the power and machinery of the mammoth transnational corporations which have deeply penetrated the economies of the developing countries.
161.	The danger of so-called pragmatism is that attempts will be made to solve Africa’s deeply rooted economic and social problems in a way that primarily favours the interests of foreign capital. Attempts to convince the Africans of a readiness to give them “needed assistance” contingent upon such things as “fundamental reforms” or the “free interplay of market forces” and so on make us wonder whether all this is not being done merely to raise the level of production in African countries to an
extent and in a manner that best meets the needs of the transnational corporations, thus tightening the noose of merciless exploitation and political diktat around those countries. Is not the aim of this to influence African countries to abandon, in exchange for illusory assistance, the results of their long struggle for political independence and national sovereignty over their own resources?
162.	We resolutely oppose this special session’s being used for the international legalization of neo-colonialist practices towards either Africa or developing countries as a whole. We feel it would be a great mistake to permit the burgeoning machinery of the transnational monopolies to get completely beyond control. We are not prepared to agree that economic assistance should be conditional upon far-reaching political demands or upon the restriction of State sovereignty. We reject attempts to instil in developing countries fatalistic ideas about the impossibility of solving their economic and social problems without outside interference.
163.	In our view, what is needed to overcome the critical economic situation in Africa is, above all, efforts by the African countries themselves to strengthen their sovereignty over their natural resources and all their economic activities. They should limit the negative impact of the activities of foreign capital—primarily the transnational corporations—and hit the net outflow of financial resources from Africa. They should increase the role of the State sector, expand economic planning and make management of sectors of the national economy more effective, bearing in mind the need to eliminate the onesidedness and monocultural orientation of the development process in most African countries and to bring about further progressive social and economic change, including democratic agrarian reform. A special role should be played by the foreign trade of the African countries. We believe this should promote the strengthening of their national economies in order to eliminate all protectionist and discriminatory obstacles to the access of the products of African countries to world markets.
164.	Czechoslovakia, like the other socialist countries, is convinced that these issues are inseparable from the task of strengthening international peace and security, curbing the arms race, bringing about a radical restructuring of international economic relations on a just and democratic basis and creating international economic security. They are equally inseparable from the task of fully eradicating those vestiges of the colonial era such as racism and the apartheid régime of South Africa.
165.	On the basis of these positions of principle we shall determine our approach to the question of the final documents of this special session in order that they not become for the African peoples a Trojan Horse.
166.	We intend also to continue actively to develop mutually advantageous economic, trade, scientific and technological co-operation with African countries on a multilateral and bilateral basis. Everyone is aware of the contribution the States members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance have made to the economic development of the African States, as well as the prospects for such co-operation in the years 1986 to 1990. To the extent of our capacity we shall provide the countries of the African continent with assistance free of charge. The volume of our assistance to Africa last year amounted to 1.2 billion Czechoslovak koruny. Our preferential scheme applies to 48 African countries, including 24 of the least developed.
167.	Our programmes of bilateral co-operation with African countries are based on equitable and democratic
principles. They are intended in particular to build productive capacity in new spheres of industry, to overcome the consequences of natural disasters and also to train African specialists. For example, last year in Africa with our assistance four major industrial facilities started operations, and seven such facilities are under construction. More than 1,500 African students are being trained in Czechoslovakia.
168.	Our programmes of economic assistance to African countries, including the provision of credits, are protected against sharp fluctuations in the market and are guaranteed by the stability of the socialist economic system.
169.	We believe that multilateral economic assistance to the African countries, inter alia through the United Nations system, should be built on a just and democratic basis commensurate with these considerations. Measures elaborated to provide the African countries with genuine assistance in overcoming their critical situation must be balanced and must assure comprehensive long-term development. It is in that spirit that we intend to act at this special session.
170.	Mr. SINCLAIR (Guyana): One of the greatest challenges to the United Nations in the 1980s is the economic and social crisis currently afflicting the African continent. As a direct result of this crisis, for many African countries development is now a goal deferred. The emphasis at present is on simple survival. It is a crisis that springs from a mix of factors both internal and external to the continent and one which, because of the diversity of the African continent, is more readily apparent in some parts than in others.
171.	Speaking at this stage of the debate there is no need for my delegation to enter into the details of that crisis; that has been so well done by the current OAU Chairman, Mr. Diouf, President of the Republic of Senegal |/si meeting]. What is more, our familiarity with its elements has already been enriched by extensive debates both in the Economic and Social Council and in this Assembly in the last two years.
172.	I would merely say, in general terms, that the African continent is afflicted in varying degrees with acute problems of poverty, hunger and economic and social dislocation often exacerbated by political and economic developments elsewhere in the world. While the expectations of its peoples are high, economic dependence or instability shackles many of them to an economic system which can fulfil neither these expectations nor the requirements of an independent world of free nations.
173.	The holding of this special session dedicated to the problems facing Africa is at once a result and a manifestation of the heightened world-wide sensitivity to that situation in Africa. Depending on its outcome, which my delegation hopes and expects will be a positive one for Africa, the Assembly will have demonstrated once again the vitality of the principle of international organization and the constructive role that the United Nations, when effectively utilized, can play in our world.
174.	Guyana’s participation, therefore, is not routine. While this participation is motivated in the first place by our solidarity with the peoples of Africa, we believe that in so doing we share the responsibility to ensure a secure economic future for Africa, which is essential for global well-being. We are also drawing critical attention, once again, to an international environment which is having crippling effects on the situation of developing countries in general.
175.	Our participation is also a contribution to strengthening the Organization’s role. The United Nations has
already played a valuable and indispensable role in forging and giving practical expression to the bonds of international solidarity, bringing life and hope to the more than 30 million people of Africa afflicted by the most devastating drought in recent history. This session provides an opportunity for us all, through the strengthening of the bonds of partnership with Africa in the critical period now before it, to advance further the spirit of global community for which the Organization is so well suited to be the working structure.
176.	Now that the excesses of drought and famine have been alleviated, there is a need to address, with the same urgency, the fundamental and longer-term problems of structural transformation and the initiation of a process of self-sustained growth and development in Africa. In this regard my delegation would like to pay a richly deserved tribute to the States of Africa, which, pursuing the initiative begun in 1980 in the Lagos Plan of Action,8 devoted most of the twenty-first session of the OAU Assembly in Addis Ababa last July to an in-depth examination of the crisis facing Africa and adopted Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 which is indeed only the latest in a series of initiatives by Africa for coming to grips with the problems facing that continent. In that Programme Africa takes a hard and frank look at itself, at its strengths no less than its weaknesses, and resolves that the task of economic recovery must begin inside Africa. It is an action-oriented document which lays the groundwork for lasting structural change. That Programme constitutes an assertion by Africa of its readiness and its determination to bear the major portions of the task of economic recovery.
177.	The Priority Programme correctly assigns priority consideration to agriculture. Inadequate food production has easily been the most serious dimension of the current crisis facing Africa. Of course, that priority attention to agriculture must necessarily include building up agricultural and industrial infrastructure and a skilled labour force. In keeping with that thrust, the expansion of education, health, electricity, transport and related facilities to meet the needs of rural populations is essential, and the commitment of African States in this regard to the Priority Programme is unequivocal.
178.	But, if the Priority Programme is a reassertion of African sovereignty and independence, it is also a summons to intensified and more meaningful international co-operation. It is difficult, indeed, to overstate the tremendous challenge posed to international co-operation by the severity of the African situation. At this critical stage, such co-operation must not falter. Ways must be found to strengthen international support for Africa’s recovery and development efforts.
179.	Neither domestic reform nor external support can, alone, guarantee a secure future for Africa. Hence there is a need for a sharing of responsibility. Those industrialized States which have recently increased their assistance to Africa in response to the present crisis, whether through rescheduling of loans, the adoption of a system of grant aid or in some other way, are to be complimented. There is need for more flexibility and innovativeness in international co-operation with Africa in accordance with the urgent demands of the current situation. There is a need to match Africa’s determination and the example of those African States which have already begun to implement major structural reforms with the assurance of increased resources on a predictable basis and of technical support. In the interdependent world in which we live, such cooperation is not an imperative of the future security of Africa alone; it could also be an imperative of that
of the developed countries in general. Since increased resources naturally mean greater problems of co-ordination not only among donors but also among recipients, there is need to give special consideration to this aspeét. 180. But even in conditions of improved international co-operation it goes without saying that an immediate improvement in the harsh external economic environment is necessary if the downward spiral in many African countries is to be reversed. Among other considerations, there is need for greater access to the markets of developed countries by African products. The sale of Africa’s raw-material exports needs to be protected against violent fluctuations in commodity prices, the imperatives of diversification notwithstanding. My delegation hopes that the new IMF Structural Adjustment Facility will operate in such a manner as to make conditionality more flexible and more responsive to the needs of African States. There is also a.need for an improvement in the levels of flows of official development assistance to those States. My delegation also sincerely hopes that the eighth replenishment of IDA will be at such a level as to allow African States in general, as, indeed, other developing countries, to derive suitable benefits.
181.	There are also other aspects of the international environment, as the Priority Programme correctly states —such as the rising tide of protectionism, exorbitant interest rates, the crushing burden of debt and debtservicing obligations—which together aggravate the crisis in Africa. This special session must take political decisions which will provide real relief to African States in these and other areas.
182.	The Priority Programme, therefore, also represents a framework for a new relationship of co-operation between Africa and the international community designed to usher in an era of economic recovery on that continent and to set its countries on a course of self-sustained development. My delegation sincerely hopes that the opportunity provided by this session will be utilized for a full-blooded commitment by all, in particular the developed countries, to shoulder their share of the responsibility to ensure a secure future for Africa. That commitment would be most appropriately expressed in a suitable programme of action, with appropriate follow-up machinery at both the national and the international levels.
183.	For Guyana’s part, we are pleased to provide, to the extent that our resources allow, technical training facilities in our specialized institutions for a number of students from African States. Guyana also has an active partnership with African members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group [ACP] of the Lomé Convention. The Group, consisting of 66 African, Caribbean and Pacific States, was formed after the signature of the first ACP/EEC Convention at Lomé and the Georgetown Agreement in 1975. Since the first Lomé Convention, and through two successive Conventions entered into with the European Community, in 1979 and 1984, the ACP Group has formulated trade, economic and cultural co-operation with the now 12-member European Community.
184.	In the light of all the foregoing, this special session needs to be marked by and to lead to decisions on concrete action by the international community, in particular the developed countries. No other response would be worthy of this Assembly. Let us not lose sight of the grave crisis in Africa to which we are called to respond, or of the seriousness and urgency with which we are summoned to make that response. The solutions are not necessarily simple ones, nor will results be produced overnight. But let us determine that at this session we will make a new beginning in a new relationship of co-operation with
Africa. Let us all determine that we shall act resolutely in this regard and that we shall not fail.
185.	Mr. ETEKI MBOUMOUA (Cameroon) (interpretation from French): I wish first to congratulate the President on his unanimous election to guide the work of this special session, which has the difficult task of adopting concrete proposals to contribute to Africa’s economic recovery and the revitalization of the authentic development process of our continent. That expression of confidence bears eloquent witness to the pleasing, responsible and competent way in which he has presided over the work of the fortieth session.
186.	The President of Senegal, Mr. Diouf, current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, was the spokesman for Africa in his moving, comprehensive and inspired statement during this debate on the critical economic situation in Africa [1st meeting]. Nevertheless, the OAU believed that in addition to hearing that general statement the General Assembly should have its attention drawn to certain particularly sensitive sectors in Africa’s determined quest for development. Hence, speaking on behalf of the African States, and in particular of the States of central Africa, I have the delicate task of addressing more specifically the human resources problem. 187. Of all the subjects emphasized in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 and in the document submitted by our continent to this special session, that of human resources is clearly one of the fundamental matters in any consideration of Africa’s economic and social development. Indeed, the management of human resources is the driving force of any economic development action. It determines a country’s ability to begin development efforts and to formulate, carry out and evaluate development projects. In other words, while being the object of development, the human being is also its essential agent. On the quality of human resources depends the development of the other available resources and the transformation of poor countries into prosperous ones.
188.	The African Governments fully recognize the role of the human factor in the development process. They also reaffirm that human resources, like other vital resources, should be carefully planned within the framework of national objectives and priorities. To that end, the African countries have made commendable efforts since their independence to develop their human resources, and important progress has been made. Comprehensive policies for planning, developing and using human resources have been adopted with the aim of integrating those resources into the national development policies and plans. Particular attention has been given to the great dependence of the African countries on foreign expertise, which is a drain on currency and a not inconsiderable component of foreign aid and assistance.
189.	The interest shown in the development of human resources has gone beyond national borders; it has been studied thoroughly and concerted action has been taken at the regional level. Our heads of State or Government stressed in the Lagos Plan of Action8 the importance of a skilled labour force as a decisive factor in economic and social development, particularly in connection with increasing revenues and creating jobs.
190.	In Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery the heads of State reaffirmed their conviction in that respect, in paragraph 31, stating that:
“The attainment of the objectives of the LPA [Lagos Plan of Action] and FAL [Final Act of Lagos] depends, in the final analysis, on the development of the wide range of human resources required for the formulation,
implementation and monitoring of programmes covering the entire spectrum and sectoral activities in the economic development process.”
191.	It must be recognized, however, that serious problems remain and that we must think of ways and means of promoting self-directed and self-sustained development.
192.	In fact, on our continent, education and training policies, planning systems, institutions, methods and services have not made it possible to strengthen as effectively as we would wish the necessary infrastructure for human resources to make their optimum contribution to the development process. In a number of cases a significant percentage of the population still does not enjoy the benefits of education. In general terms, the content of education programmes is far from meeting the increased demands of speedier growth and development. The efforts to give priority to technical education, to co-ordinate formal and informal education and to reorient the latter in order the better to meet development needs have not produced the desired results. Africa therefore has a shortage of skilled manpower and technical personnel, a high rate of unemployment, even among those who have followed a course of education, and an under-utilization of the skilled labour force at the middle and higher levels. 193. It is clear that we cannot speak of human resources in development without emphasizing certain specific aspects, such as population, education and training, women and development, health and participation. The continent’s population is now growing at an average rate of 3 per cent a year and should reach 880 million by the year 2000 and nearly 2 billion by 2025. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that there are considerable differences between population growth rates in different parts of the continent. Those differences should be recognized.
194.	Clearly, such rapid population growth has socioeconomic implications that need to be taken into account. In fact, the African countries have recognized that they will all have to give particular attention, in accordance with the Kilimanjaro Programme of Action for African Population and Self-Reliant Development,9 to a demographic policy that takes into account, inter alia, high fertility rates, morbidity and mortality rates, rapid urbanization, migration from the rural areas to the cities and from one rural area to another, the problems of children and young people and the need to protect the environment. All of those factors will have to be considered in an integrated way in order to ensure compatibility between demographic trends, the human factor and a desirable pace of growth and development.
195.	Therefore, a population policy should not be seen solely in terms of the limitation of births, but, rather, in terms of the management of the different components of a population needing to be fed and maintained in good health, making up a viable economic market and competing fully at the international level. Hence the programme “Health for All by the Year 2000”, proclaimed by WHO, should receive increased support from the international community for urgent implementation in Africa. The same applies to programmes for self-sufficiency in food, drinking water and housing—all factors that can give the African continent a better chance of more viable development.
196.	With regard to education and training, a worthwhile return from our education system requires a reassessment of programmes in order to adapt them to African sociocultural realities and the needs of the labour market. It is deplorable that our programmes are not sufficiently geared to the specific employment needs of the rural and urban sectors. Moreover, training, health and nutrition
programmes are not seen within a comprehensive framework of the development of human resources.
197.	In a context which requires the creation of a large number of jobs, we need the preparation of programmes that are action-oriented and that can foster initiative and the spirit of enterprise. Our educational systems must promote the training of skilled middle-level cadres that are properly equipped to face the technological changes of our modern day, since they are greatly lacking in our economies.
198.	As has been stressed in a UNDP study, the link between technology and employment cannot be underestimated. Since it defines the development of human resources as the use of the total potential for economic and social progress, the creation of jobs and the effective utilization of skilled manpower are necessarily important elements.
199.	Many agencies of the United Nations system have studied the relation between technology and employment. We should stress the interdependence of technological problems, the latest technology and employment problems. That multifaceted interdependence is seen in education and training which enables manpower to adapt to changes in technology and to new methods of production; in the creation of an adaptable technology in an institutional infrastructure which makes possible the identification of the potential offered by new technologies —micro-electronics and genetic engineering and research, for example; in the adaptation of technology obtained abroad; in the link between research laboratories, industry and agriculture; in the co-ordination of research and development; and in the creation of job possibilities to absorb competent local personnel and thus combat the brain drain. Along the same lines, we certainly support the contribution made by the President of the Preparatory Committee for this session, who has stressed the need better to organize research and to plan programmes that take an endogenous approach to specifically African problems.
200.
