It cannot be stressed enough that African women play an important role in the development of our continent, but it is important to point out that “women in development” is not a subject that can be reduced to a simple question of man versus woman. Quite the contrary, the primary place that women occupy in our economies is one of the key factors in our development strategy. In order to transform this recognition into concrete action, it is necessary for our Governments, the international community and development agencies to adopt policies in all sectors that make it possible to strengthen that role and to increase the participation of African women in the decision-making process.
201.	Lastly, I should like to raise the important issue of popular participation. It is increasingly clear that no action in the interest of the masses can be successful without their concrete and active participation. It is therefore essential to involve the people fully at the different stages of the development process by establishing conditions conducive to the development of creativity and the spirit of enterprise in the private sector as well as the public sector and likely to lay foundations for economic and social justice, foundations which are the leavening agent for the commitment and enthusiasm of the people and, at the same time, the goal of our development strategies.
202.	Aware of this need, Africa has pledged to take the necessary corrective measures. The Programme for Economic Recovery and the document we have submitted to this session define the objectives, guidelines and priorities
of Africa in this field. For the short and medium term, it is a matter of reorienting education and training policies and programmes, improving methods and techniques, strengthening the institutional infrastructures and minimizing the brain drain. In the long term, it will be necessary to rationalize the institutional infrastructures and to formulate and harmonize post-university manpower policies.
203.	No one would question that the development of human resources should be considered not only as a tool for economic growth or as a prerequisite for that growth, but also as the very objective of development. To develop human resources is to make the best use of human potential for economic and social progress. The concern for considering the human dimension of development as a goal as well as a means cannot be disassociated from the concern for creating employment and meeting essential needs. It has been said that however rich and fertile the soil may be, a continent is first and foremost rich through its children. Of all Africa’s assets, the one that has been developed least for the time being, or developed in the least rational way, is no doubt the human factor.
204.	The task is not an easy one. As the concept of developing human resources is worked out, the trend has been to translate the experience of the industrialized countries without always appreciating, as we should, the diversity of cultures, traditions, values and ecosystems. That is why our continent should be supported in its efforts to strengthen its endogenous capacity with respect to planning and the development of human resources.
205.	It is important for the donor countries and the international organizations to evaluate their programmes and activities in connection with the management of human resources in Africa so that they can better respond to the aspirations described in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery. It is important that measures be taken to co-ordinate and harmonize the management of regional and subregional activities for human resources; that the United Nations prepare specific programmes for planning the development and use of human resources; that donors allocate adequate resources for the implementation of these programmes; that due attention be given to the human resources factor in each sectoral project and that necessary measures be taken to ensure the availability and use of those resources; and, finally, at the national or regional level, that scientific and technical research centres be developed to promote the integration of research in the African development process, the progressive Africanization of research teams and Africa’s access to the most recent technology and know-how.
206.	In considering solutions to Africa’s current serious development problems, we must not lose sight of the fact that contemporary society has entered into the postindustrial era, which is characterized by the omnipresence of sophisticated technology, in particular the increasingly common use of computer science, which has now entered into all spheres of life. This must be taken into account by Africans because the appropriate use of this sophisticated technology can help Africa to overcome its development lag.
207.	As was so well stated by President Houphouët-Boigny of the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire, when in March 1985 he opened the conference of the intergovernmental office for computer science on the subject “Computer Technology and Sovereignty”, today the path towards economic development may take technological short-cuts within the reach of all, thanks to computer technology. He added that computer technology gives our countries
the historic possibility of meeting all the challenges of underdevelopment—technological underdevelopment, mental blocks, lack of competitiveness and so forth.
208.	In connection with management, the use of the computer makes for greater effectiveness and represents considerable progress. Furthermore, some activities can be improved through image transmission by satellite, such as work in cartography, the management of natural resources such as forests and underground water, the exploration of mineral resources, the control of erosion and desertification and so on. And at last experts seem to be giving particular attention to the application of biotechnology in resolving some of the important problems in agriculture. They can predict such things as the fixing of atmospheric nitrogen by plants, thus improving the fertility of the soil while decreasing the use of imported fertilizers. They can also stimulate the growth of trees by improving their nitrogen and phosphorous nutrients, which facilitates the reforestation of soil that is not very fertile or conducive to agriculture. Thanks to such progress, in the future it will be possible to improve significantly, by the use of biotechnology, the health of both humans and animals. The African countries should therefore be able to exploit all those possibilities.
209.	The Declaration of Yamoussoukro which was adopted at the conclusion of the conference of the intergovernmental office for computer sciences, to which I have just referred, indicates that one of the main keys to the solution of Africa’s development problem is the rational management of information in all its forms. That Declaration also stresses that the primary contribution of computer science is in the transformation of mental structures which it brings about and stimulates, thus promoting innovation and creativity, and challenging the status quo. These are the objectives, which must include also the rational development of Africa’s human resources.
210.	Because in the immediate past it has benefited from an outpouring of solidarity by the international community, because it is familiar with that community’s generous readiness for international co-operation, and because what is at stake is the fate and the destiny of man, Africa knows that it can rely today on this Assembly to give body and substance to the message of solidarity transmitted to it by Africa.
211.	Mr. BIRMINGHAM (Ireland): There is a clear and pressing need for immediate and longer-term action by the international community to help overcome the critical economic situation in Africa. The General Assembly recognized the urgency of this need when it decided by consensus last December to convene this special session. The international community now has the opportunity to concentrate on the long-term challenges facing Africa and to guard against the recurrence of the tragic famine which has so recently engaged the sympathy and the attention of the entire world.
212.	We recognize that vague declarations of good intentions are not enough; this special session must see the adoption of action-oriented and concrete measures. It is our hope that a new understanding will be reached whereby the African countries,, with the full support of the international community, can look forward to a period of sustained growth aimed at ensuring that the structural problems highlighted in recent years by drought and famine can be overcome. I see this session as not only a test of the political will of the international community to share actively in the tasks of reconstruction and rehabilitation in Africa, but also an important test of our willingness to make the world system work and of our
determination to solve substantive world problems by common action.
213.	This special session is a unique event, not least in that it was convened to address the particular problems of a single continent. The African countries themselves have prepared an analysis and programme for action. This formed the starting point of the preparatory process for the special session. Africa has accepted responsibility for its own development. Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the OAU in 1985, is a valuable survey and framework programme for future action. Many African Governments have made courageous efforts to modify their economic and social policies and to reform their administrative systems. They have sought to counter the severe problems caused by drought, desertification, unbalanced population growth and environmental degradation. They have been concerned to stress agricultural development and food self-sufficiency in order to ensure sustainable economic growth and social development. In these circumstances it is not unreasonable for Africa to request the international community to find ways to accept its responsibilities and to share in the African countries* efforts to ensure the best conditions for their advancement with new or expanded supporting measures.
214.	In my view, progress in Africa depends upon advancement in a number of interlinked areas.
21-5. Internally, political stabilization is necessary. There must be social and economic justice for all sectors of society in order that all can participate in and benefit from the development process. Economic growth must be based on the real potential of each individual country. High priority must be given to agriculture and rural development, to communications and to the maximization of human resources. Regional co-operation among African States should be pursued.
216.	Externally, there must be a greater sensitivity on the part of the industrialized countries to the needs of the developing world, especially in regard to debt and to trade. .
217.	The international community, working within existing institutions, must make every effort to help African nations resolve their liquidity crisis. While adhering to the case-by-case approach to the debt problems of individual countries in Africa, the international community should recognize the efforts of the African nations which have adopted growth-oriented policies that allow for sustained development. Ireland fully supports the principle advocated by the Development Committee of the World Bank, that no country should be the net recipient of funds from African countries which are endeavouring to implement adjustment programmes. We applaud the decision of a number of donor countries to remit all least developed countries’ official development assistance debts and to provide moratoriums for repayments by low-income African countries where suitable policy conditions can be agreed. Also, Ireland supports a generous level of replenishment of IDA, at least $12 billion, which would allow it to carry out its programme in the coming years at least at current levels. In addition, Ireland supports the proposed general capital increase of the World Bank.
218.	Again, the international community must adopt a flexible and sensitive approach to the problems of least developed countries in the forthcoming round of multilateral trade negotiations. The African countries cannot achieve their development objectives if they are denied the opportunity to increase their export earnings substantially. Official development assistance flows must be
maintained and increased in the medium term. African Governments need those flows to help execute the necessary economic and social programmes required for development. They also need, as the World Bank has pointed out, firm and unambiguous commitments by the international community in order to be able to plan over a period of years with a reasonable certainty of stability of official development assistance flows.
219.	A significant trend in the evolution of relations between North and South in recent years has been a shift of emphasis from the efforts of Governments and international organizations to the efforts of private individuals and voluntary organizations. In recent years this trend is best exemplified by the achievements of Bob Geldof, a fellow countryman of mine, in particular by his inspiration and organization of Band Aid, Live Aid and Sports Aid, which to. date have collected hundreds of millions of dollars for humanitarian relief and development projects in Africa. As was noted here yesterday by the Nigerian Foreign .Minister [2nd meeting], Bob Geldofs success brings home to us the lesson that development co-operation is so important that it should not be left to Governments alone. Historically, too, in my country, as in many others, private individuals and organizations were engaged in development work long before Governments were involved. Voluntary organizations have a number of advantages: their organizational structures are flexible, decisions are made swiftly; their practical experience and knowledge are invaluable resources; and what they lack in management structures and resources they make up for in efficiency, dedication and enthusiasm. Moreover, voluntary organizations, through their direct appeal to the general population, act as a powerful influence on public opinion: they stimulate interest in development work, often to a highly sophisticated and discriminating standard, and spur our citizens to make a concrete expression of their concern and solidarity. . .
220.	Long before my country achieved its independence —indeed, while most of Africa was still ruled by the then colonial Powers—Irish men and women travelled from their homeland to work as missionaries in Africa, many giving a lifetime of service and dedication to African people. Their vocation was primarily religious and charitable. Before Governments became involved in what we now call development co-operation, these Irish missionaries built schools and hospitals and helped the social development of the peoples among whom they lived. The starting point of their thinking was the importance of the dignity of each individual human being and the need for all to share in the benefits of social and economic progress.
221.	The work carried out by voluntary organizations, missionaries and private individuals is seen by my Government as a necessary and valuable complement to official development co-operation. We in Ireland are especially mindful of this side of our heritage in our relations with developing countries. '
222.	The Irish Development Co-operation Programme is necessarily small, but it is growing at a relatively satisfactory rate. Between 1974 and 1984, it grew from a few million pounds annually to almost 34 million pounds. Between 1984 and 1987, it is expected to expand by almost 47 per cent, to 50 million pounds. ■ :
223.	Ireland remains committed to achieving the United-Nations target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product [GAP]. We have been increasing our assistance by 0.15 per cent of GNP annually, and it is expected to reach 0.275 per cent of GNP next year. It is significant that over 10 years we have managed to move from 15 per cent
of the Development Assistance Committee’s [DAC] average rate of official development assistance as a percentage of GNP to just over 70 per cent of that rate while our relative wealth in terms of income per capita is still under half the average DAC income per capita.
224.	Our official Development Co-operation Programme, and especially our bilateral effort, has been and is intended to remain largely oriented towards subSaharan Africa. We estimate that more than 80 per cent of our bilateral aid goes to sub-Saharan Africa, while 60 per cent of our total bilateral programme goes in project aid to the four priority countries, namely, Lesotho, Sudan, Tanzania and Zambia. .
225.	The sectoral breakdown of Irish co-operation assistance to the priority countries reflects general African priorities, as listed in Africa’s Priority Programme and in regional programmes like that of SADCC, as well as Ireland’s areas of particular expertise. In 1985, these priorities were: rural development, agriculture, education and training, industry, infrastructure and health—in that order. Yesterday [1st meeting} the Netherlands Minister for Development Co-operation drew our attention to the assistance provided by the multilateral institutions to African Governments in developing their administrative capacities. Given Ireland’s commitment to helping African Governments in this vitally important area, I hope that we will be able to share in strengthening the multilateral effort to this effect.
226.	There is, I think, one last feature of Irish development co-operation which I should mention, and that is that all Irish project and programme funding is on grant terms; Ireland is not, therefore, owed any debt linked to official development assistance by any African country and is not a recipient of any reverse-flow payments.
227.	I would hope that at the conclusion of this session there will be a clearer understanding between the African countries and the international community on the priorities of development in Africa. At this stage of rehabilitation, reconstruction and growth, there should be greater sensitivity to Africa’s needs. This special session should bring agreement from the developed countries on concrete operational measures and an improvement in the quality of aid, its concentration in priority sectors and the strengthening of aid co-ordination. I believe that the outcome of this session will be beneficial, not only to the countries of Africa but to all the countries of the world. Countries cannot live in isolation. We all depend on one another. Interdependence is a fact.
228.	Mr. STANISLAUS (Grenada): I welcome this opportunity to speak for the first time from this rostrum on a subject that is near and dear to the hearts of the Government and the people of Grenada, as indeed it should be to all assembled for the special session of the General Assembly called to consider the critical economic situation in Africa. Before doing so, please allow me to join in the congratulatory remarks so eloquently made by representatives in connection with Mr. de Pinies’ dignified and able presence as President of this session.
229.	My country is not in a position to give much material help to alleviate Africa’s critical economic situation, for reasons that should be apparent to representatives. Nevertheless, since historically and ancestrally Grenada, and indeed Caribbean countries generally, have a kinship and an emotional attachment to Mother Africa, I feel compelled to crave the indulgence of the Assembly to participate in this historic debate only in a manner commensurate with the little help my country can give in material terms.
230.	Contemporary African conditions have been well researched, documented and expressed by ECA. Additionally, the OAU in its economic statement—the Lagos Plan of Action8—and more recently in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government in July 1985, has made a superb contribution to this session through the well-informed and industrious Preparatory Committee of the Whole, which worked assiduously to submit its report [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l]. This document is a timely reconsideration of previous assumptions, prescriptions, projections and strategy with respect to the African situation. It is a blueprint for action which should be adopted by consensus.
231.	“There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; Omitted, all the voyage of their life ■ Is bound in shallows and in miseries.”
So wrote Shakespeare in Julius Caesar. If this special, historic, unprecedented session stirs up and sustains the rising tide on the side of Africa, it is not too optimistic to predict that Africa, with its abundant natural resources, its most central location of all the continents, its immense size and abundant virgin soil, can, with the passage of time, become the bread-basket of the world. The cry of Africa must not be allowed to go unheeded by members of the international community, especially by those industrialized metropolitan countries with which Africa is pleading to put back into the good earth a little of what has been taken out.
232.	The race against time with regard to the African condition should dictate to the Assembly that the necessary studies and analyses have been meticulously made by eminent African leaders, scholars and pragmatists at all levels on the continent, and the time has come for action-oriented and concerted measures. To study and analyse the African problem further is to engage in a paralysis of analysis. With the type of self-reliance and self-confidence exuding from the continent, what we are hearing from Africa is simply this: give us some of the tools and we will finish the job, remembering that the future and fortune of Africa are inextricably intertwined and interwoven in the global economic structure.
233.	I shall conclude this short statement by expressing, on behalf of my Government, the hope that the ugly, heavy hand of racism, that systematized, institutionalized and barbaric practice in South Africa known as apartheid, will soon lose its grip on the States bordering on South Africa, which will then be able to share the blessing of social and economic growth and development which this special session is proclaiming for Africa. In the words of an ancient and eminent philosopher: Horam expecta veniet—Await the hour, it will come.
234.	Mr. NYAMDOO (Mongolia) (interpretation from Russian)-. For the first time in the history of the United Nations, the General Assembly is meeting in special session to consider the economic situation in Africa, which is a source of mounting concern to the world community. The Mongolian delegation, which fully shares this concern, wishes to voice its own thoughts on the far-reaching problems now under discussion.
235.	As emphasized in documents of the United Nations and of the OAU, for a long time many countries of the continent have been suffering from economic stagnation and poverty, which have been further aggravated by drought. The per capita gross national product of many African countries has been declining in the recent past, and their economies as a whole have been buffeted by
an extremely grave crisis. At present millions of Africans are still starving.
236.	It is well known that the critical situation of the economy of the continent is due primarily to the dire consequences of past colonial enslavement of the African peoples by the imperialist Powers, which over the centuries implanted in that continent their own way of doing things. It is no secret that it was precisely the imperialist and colonialist Powers that for many years mercilessly exploited the human resources and natural wealth of the African countries, thereby dooming their economies to a one-sided role in the service of the metropolitan Powers. It is also generally acknowledged that the prolonged existence of that situation has had the most grievous consequences for the economy of the continent and is now having a negative impact on the living standards of the African peoples themselves.
237.	Since the African peoples won their independence and sovereignty, the forces of imperialism have continued their exploitation of Africa in a new form—neo-colonial-ism. It is worth noting that it is precisely the neo-colonial-ist policy pursued in Africa by the United States and other Western Powers and their transnational corporations which has aggravated even further the already difficult economic situation which the countries of that continent inherited from the colonial past. High interest rates, protectionism, the artificial lowering of commodity prices and other such measures, the unlawful trade and economic embargo against African countries imposed by imperialism—as in the case of Libya this year—all constitute a specific manifestation of the neo-colonialist policy of the United States and other Western Powers, which is having an extremely negative impact on the economy of Africa as a whole.
Mr. Moushoutas (Cyprus), Vice-President, took the Chair.
238.	The world public has been particularly disturbed by the indebtedness of the developing countries, including the African countries, which has reached the astronomical total of $1,000 billion. It is readily evident that it is precisely the African countries that have the highest level of indebtedness in per capita terms. One third of the annual export revenues of those countries goes merely to pay the interest on their debts, and the annual outflow of resources from Africa to the Western Powers amounts to many billions of dollars annually.
239.	It is therefore quite evident that the grievous consequences of Africa’s colonial past, as well as the continued exploitation of Africa by imperialism, are primarily responsible for the serious crisis through which the African countries are now passing. My delegation considers that the principal responsibility for the current critical economic situation in Africa should be borne precisely by those Western Powers and their transnational corporations which have for many years been plundering the human and natural resources of the continent.
240.	But that is not all. The acts of aggression and interference which have been repeatedly undertaken by the forces of imperialism and racism have not only destabilized the economy of many countries in Africa, they also constitute a direct threat to the peace and security of the region. This fact is well illustrated by the United States act of aggression against Libya this year, South Africa’s recent aggression against three African countries —Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe—and its aggressive actions against Angola and other front-line States, which must cease if Africa’s far-reaching problems, including its economic problems, are to be resolved. The Mongolian delegation once again resolutely condemns these acts of
aggression perpetrated by the forces of imperialism, colonialism and racism against sovereign African countries and peoples.
241.	When one considers the problems on the agenda of this special session, one cannot fail to notice the very direct link between development and disarmament. The arms race, which has been stepped up by the imperialists, thereby posing a grave threat to international peace and security, diverts vast resources from being used to assist developing countries and peoples, in particular those of Africa. That is why my delegation attaches special significance to the implementation of effective measures to halt the arms race and to bring about disarmament, measures that would create the necessary conditions for the elimination of the threat of war and the solution of many acute problems of our age, including economic problems. In this connection the Mongolian People’s Republic wholeheartedly and fully supports the recent proposal of the Soviet Union for the elimination of all nuclear arsenals by the year 2000. We consider it to be an exceedingly important initiative aimed at doing away with the threat of nuclear war and normalizing international relations as a whole, including international economic relations.
242.	The normalization of international economic relations and the comprehensive solution of world economic problems, including the economic problems of Africa, would also, in our opinion, be greatly promoted by the convening of a world congress on problems of economic security, as proposed recently by the Soviet Union. Such an international forum could serve as an important mechanism to strengthen confidence in international economic relations and to exchange experience among its different participants so as to eliminate various types of difficulties in the course of development and to strengthen economic security.
243.	The Mongolian delegation also wishes to support Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 which was endorsed last year at the twenty-first session of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity.
244.	On the basis of the experience of my own country’s socio-economic development, my delegation, like many previous delegations, feels that the most effective way to overcome the economic difficulties in many African countries involves thorough socio-economic transformations, industrialization, the introduction into the economy of planned methods, the training of qualified national personnel and the implementation of other progressive measures, as well as the establishment of strict control over the activities of foreign monopolies. As the experience of my own country’s development shows, the comprehensive strengthening and development of the public sectors of the economy has a special importance and must play a key role in the mobilization of resources for development, in the elimination of backwardness and poverty and in the establishment of a strong and independent economy. By relying on the public sectors, the developing countries, including those in Africa, can put their natural resources to effective use for the purposes of development, accelerating industrialization and the solution of many other socio-economic problems.
245.	The implementation of agrarian reforms, the comprehensive encouragement of the co-operative movement and the broad introduction on that basis of modern technology into agriculture would constitute extremely important measures that would help to resolve the food problem successfully. The realization of these and other
measures would, in the opinion of my delegation, undoubtedly be conducive to a rational solution of the far-reaching problems of the economies of the African countries.
246.	In conclusion, we should like to express our hope that this special session will impart a new dynamism to the African countries and peoples in their efforts to overcome their economic crisis and in their fight against neo-colonialist exploitation and that it will thereby make an important contribution to the establishment of the new international economic order proclaimed in various United Nations documents, including the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States [resolution 3281 (XXIX)] and the Declaration and Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order [resolutions 3201 (S-VI) and 3202 (S-VI)].
247,	Mr. CHIDZERO (Zimbabwe): It is a great honour for Zimbabwe to have been mandated to speak at this special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa, in support and amplification of the statement made by President Diouf of Senegal in his capacity as current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity [7s/ meeting],
248.	Let me at the outset say that we are confident that, under the wise counsel of the President of this special session, it will be a historic success. We should also like to place on record our gratitude to the Chairman of the Preparatory Committee for the special session and, through him, to the Committee’s other officers, whose untiring efforts and sacrifices in the past few months have been invaluable investments in the cause of concerted action and international co-operation.
249.	It is not our intention to recite once again the already well-known economic and social facts about the critical situation in Africa. Rather, we shall attempt to highlight and throw into broad relief those aspects of the international economic environment which obstruct or facilitate the process of growth and adjustment or which would be conducive to comprehensive world economic recovery and sustained growth.
250.	The starting point is the recognition by the African countries themselves of the true nature of their own economic crisis, which is the product of a complex of factors, part natural, part geographical, part historical, part domestic and part international in dimension. Explicit or implicit in that recognition is the acknowledgement of the central and critical role which African Governments themselves can play in changing the course of their own economies, in reorienting their domestic economic policies in order to ensure growth and transformation.
251.	But beyond that the African countries, like other developing countries, have also clearly recognized the wider limitations within which they operate and which derive from the fact that Africa is an integral part of the international economic, trade and monetary system. There are systemic factors which impinge or impact on their domestic policies and on the specific measures they take in pursuit of the objectives of social and economic development.
252.	That, we believe, is the double message which comes out clearly from the OAU Declaration on the Economic Situation in Africa10 and, in a programmatic manner, from Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 and which is presented in Africa’s submission to this special session of the General Assembly.1
253.	Africa’s economic woes and continued crises can be traced back, broadly speaking, to the following three sets or categories of factors.
254.	First, there are the natural phenomena and hazards, over which Africa and indeed the world at large have little control. We refer to frequent or periodic droughts, desertification and, in given cases, even floods, on the other side of the spectrum of natural events or hazards. There are in general the inhospitable climatic conditions which are so typical of most of Africa and which make human endeavour and economic development that much more difficult and costly.
255.	Secondly, there are the national or domestic policies which may impede, hasten or facilitate economic development. These include a wide range of issues covering such matters as pricing, fiscal deficits, budgetary allocations relative to priorities of development, and general policies regarding income distribution and the mobilization of domestic resources for development purposes. The relative weights which are given to the various sectors of activity—education, health, agriculture, industry, mining, transport and so on—have a direct bearing on the efficient allocation and utilization of resources and the tempo with which structural changes are effected within the economy.
256.	Thirdly, there are international factors over which Africa, indeed the developing world generally, has virtually no control. These have to do with prevailing international monetary policies, particularly those pursued by some industrialized countries in respect of such matters as exchange rates, interest rates and the financing of fiscal deficits. They relate also to inflationary or deflationary policies and their consequential impact on economic activities in the developed countries, which in turn impinge, in one way or another, on economic activities in developing countries. The international environment also encompasses trade practices, in particular protectionist measures, as they affect exports of developing countries; financing measures especially in respect of liquidity; and the stance taken by a number of industrialized countries vis-à-vis the transfer of resources to developing countries, whether on a bilateral basis or through multilateral channels.
257.	The African submission to this special session clearly demonstrates the integral relationship between what Africans can do and what the international community can do or not do and thus support or undermine African efforts. It is clear, for instance, that most African countries are very vulnerable, as they depend largely for their foreign-exchange earnings, and therefore for their capital development, on the export of one or at most a few commodities whose world prices fluctuate so markedly from year to year, with generally very adverse commodity terms of trade. It is estimated that between 1980 and 1983 prices of commodities of export interest to developing countries collapsed by as much as 30 per cent, with a total loss in export earnings of $13.5 billion— equivalent to 2 per cent of the total output of that period. Protectionist measures in many industrialized countries and the general proliferation of discriminatory practices in disregard of principles and practices of GATT exacerbate the situation and retard the process of industrial transformation in developing countries. The acceleration of protectionist measures, compounded by deflationary policies in developed countries, could not but damage the future prospects of sustained growth and development.
258.	It is therefore absolutely essential that in industrialized countries structural adjustments take place which would promote similar or parallel changes in developing
countries and thus spur production and growth and facilitate trade among the two groups of countries. It should be underlined that price-stabilization arrangements, with periodic price adjustments, would enhance the capacity of African countries to achieve remunerative returns for their exports and thus alleviate their balance-of-payments problems as well as enhance their capacity to import capital goods and ensure that their development plans are not thrown into disarray or abandoned altogether.
259.	It should be pointed out that there is a growing number of countries in Africa which have effected adjustment measures, and some have achieved trade surpluses —but at the expense of contraction in essential imports rather than as a result of expansion in exports. Significantly, between 1980 and 1983, for austerity reasons and adjustment requirements, 37 African countries reduced real government expenditures per capita, but this led to deterioration in social services and had implications also for productivity and manpower development.
260.	With regard to the monetary practices of industrialized countries, we believe it is vital, if the objectives of adjustment with growth and sustained growth are to be achieved, that exchange rates in industrialized countries be maintained at levels that are not punitive to the developing world. For while over-valued currencies or high exchange rates in industrialized countries may benefit exporting developing countries in so far as their returns in terms of accruing amounts of national currencies are concerned, the loss is greater inasmuch as their imports are made the more expensive. These imports are essential as they constitute a greater bulk of inputs into the industrialization efforts of many African countries. Conversely, while lower exchange rates may benefit the import side, they depress export earnings, again in terms of domestic or local currencies in the developing countries. It follows then that extreme fluctuations render planning or any forward commitment of financial measures uncertain and indeed make adjustment virtually impossible, hence the need for some measure of stability in order to facilitate planning and efficient utilization of resources.
261.	In a similar vein, liquidity must be ensured, if need be through the creation of new special drawing rights. It is to be hoped that industrial countries will examine this whole issue constructively and provide international trade with the requisite liquidity.
262.	Turning to the flow of development resources, we think it is essential that sustained efforts be made to ensure that adequate resources, on a grant basis or on concessional terms, are available on a long-term arrangement if the critical situation in Africa is to be adequately and realistically dealt with. In this regard, it is essential that such facilities as the World Bank Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa, the IMF Structural Adjustment Facility and IDA are adequately funded or replenished on a sustained basis. Similar action is called for on a bilateral basis. The situation that obtains today, in which there is now a marginal increase in flows of resources to developing countries, in particular Africa, and a reverse flow to industrialized countries as a result primarily of debt service, must be reversed. For the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery, Africa requires, as we now know, a total of $128.1 billion, of which $45.6 billion is expected to be provided by the international community. Thus, a minimum of additional international aid of $9.1 billion annually is necessary. Clearly, supreme efforts will need to be made, especially since the situation is rendered the more difficult and challenging by the burden of debt service.
263.	On this question of international aid, I must turn for a moment to the problems of certain particularly disadvantaged countries, among which are small island African countries, which deserve special and urgent attention by the international community because of unique factors affecting their development process—factors including very small populations, limited markets and financial resources, heavy dependency on mono-crop and mono-enterprise economies, geographic remoteness and its economic consequences, the extreme nature of economic openness, and inappropriate criteria used in assessing and granting economic and technical assistance to these countries. It is important that the international community recognize the specific problems and needs of this category of countries in drawing up its financial support programmes for Africa.
264.	Similarly, special attention should be given to the problems of land-locked countries. I do not wish to restate the severe problems of these countries, but I must welcome the fact that a number of activities, particularly in the development of corridors and improvements in the infrastructural facilities, are already being undertaken or contemplated in many transit states. We can only urge that this ongoing work be speeded up by making adequate resources available for this purpose.
265.	A little while ago I referred to the African debt problem. This is indeed most crucial, as the following facts show. The dramatic increase in the volume of Africa’s external debt and the heavy debt-servicing burden are a source of profound concern, since they represent a heavy drain on Africa’s meagre foreign exchange earnings. Sub-Saharan Africa’s external debt, including short-term debt and stock of accumulated arrears, grew sevenfold to reach about $175 billion in 1984. In relation to exports and gross domestic product, Africa’s total external indebtedness more than doubled between 1974 and 1984. The gap between debt-servicing capacity and servicing obligations, including arrears, shows a ratio exceeding 100 per cent in many African countries. The average debt service as a percentage of Africa’s export earnings was 19.8 per cent in 1982 but soared to nearly 30 per cent in 1984. For many of the least developed countries the burden is even higher and more onerous. Available estimates place their current average debt-service ratio in excess of 30 per cent, with a number of individual countries experiencing ratios exceeding 100 per cent when short-term debt, IMF repurchases, arrears and associated charges are taken into account. For the majority of sub-Saharan African economies, debt-servicing problems have come close on the heels of successive economic and financial disruptions caused by external economic shocks and compounded by natural calamities and famine.
266.	It is important to draw particular attention to the fact that the burden of debt servicing increased because of the rise in interest rates, the expiration of the grace period, the decline in the net flow of resources from all sources, currency fluctuations and the sudden upsurge in the value of the United States dollar, which is the major currency of denomination.
267.	Apart from the magnitude and rate of growth in the aggregate debt and debt service, there have been sudden and far-reaching changes in the structure of Africa’s debt over the past decade. This is demonstrated by a number of factors which it is not necessary to go into at this stage. But the fact of the matter is that the ratio has shifted from 14 per cent of official development assistance to 36 per cent.
268.	For those of us in southern Africa, the uniqueness of that subregion’s situation is inescapable. We suffer
from economic and military pressures exerted by a powerful neighbour supported by great Powers afield. Those in the southern African region know this only too well. They live it. Impositions by the apartheid régime of South Africa are particularly pernicious and destructive, as exemplified by the recent unprovoked acts of aggression against the peace-loving countries of Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe.
269.	To combat this problem in the southern part of the continent, SADCC, which is fully recognized by the United Nations, was created to foster subregional cooperation among States and to provide an effective platform to respond to this threat. The South African destabilization policy, on a conservative reckoning, has cost the SADCC member States in excess of $10 billion in the past five years. This amount is greater than all the development assistance received by the region, or more than a third of the region’s total earnings.
270.	The international community has substantial political and economic leverage which can be applied to restrain South Africa from victimizing individual Member States. This calls for even closer political commitment from the international community to increase its funding of this co-operative grouping. The prospect of such a joint action will bring a new element into the situation which the South African Government must contend with, and this will also present a new focal point for concerted international action.
271.	To turn back to the general African situation, it is of critical importance that all the interlocking issues be addressed with a sense of urgency and with determination. Failure to do so would only render the situation even more critical. We take some comfort from recent statements made by industrialized countries. We were encouraged to note from the Declaration issued by the group of seven industrialized countries after their Economic Summit Meeting held at Tokyo from 4 to 6 May 1986“ that they regarded this special session of the General Assembly as being of great importance and that it was their intention to participate in it positively and constructively. The Summit attached great importance to continued co-operation through the World Bank’s Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa and early implementation of the IMF’s newly established Structural Adjustment Facility, and to increased use of IDA. We must deduce and urge that this must necessarily imply readiness on the part of these key countries to increase the resources available to those essential facilities.
272.	Likewise, we note with encouragement and qualified confidence the pointed references to the African situation contained in the communiqué issued after the April 1986 meeting of the Joint Ministerial Committee of the Boards of Governors of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund on the Transfer of Real Resources to Developing Countries. We note all this with hope and encouragement and look forward to its effective implementation—which would be in contrast to what has happened to earlier statements or “commitments”, which were followed by a dearth of full or effective action, or, in fact, by very austere programmes verging on the punitive.
273.	We recall, for instance, UNCTAD resolution 165 (S-IX), of 1978,12 on retroactive terms adjustment of the debt of developing countries. While it was implemented by a number of developed countries, action was generally inadequate. Its full implementation would greatly alleviate the debt problems of the poorest countries, in particular the least developed. Similarly, the 1981 United Nations Conference on the Least Developed Countries
adopted the Substantial New Programme of Action for the 1980s for the Least Developed Countries,13 under which industrialized countries undertook, inter alia, to increase their aid to the least developed countries to 0.15 per cent of their GNP. Here too words have largely been belied by action. History is indeed replete with lost opportunities and cases of unfulfilled promises or insufficient follow-up action. It is earnestly to be hoped, therefore, that the decisions taken at this special session will be characterized by effective follow-up action and therefore by a distinct departure from past practice.
274.	The crisis of development in Africa is not an irreversible process. True, it is a veritable challenge to the international community in general and to Africa itself in particular, but the whole process can be stopped and reversed in the interests of all. Africa has put its case succinctly before the international community in various documents, to which reference has already been made, and in the comprehensive and eloquent statement of President Diouf, current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, as well as in his supporting statements.
275.	It bears restatement that, in addition to the understandings that may be reached and the commitments that may be made at this session on support measures, it will be essential for the international economic environment to be made responsive to the cause of development generally and the rectification of the critical economic situation in Africa in particular. In saying this, we believe that this will call for imaginative and agreed action on such issues as are already on the world agenda in different forums: that is, on trade, money and finance, and on the imperative need to achieve a meaningful and sustainable measure or degree of macro-economic co-ordination or harmonization of the policies of industrialized countries in such matters as exchange rate régimes, interest rates and trade practices.
276.	It is also to be hoped that, beyond or congruent with the actions of national Governments, international institutions, in particular financial institutions, will seek to eschew the imposition of models of adjustment or growth but will endeavour to analyze and understand the actual conditions of each country and the potential factors or forces of growth which should be harnessed and supported to ensure change and development. Conditions of aid, or simple conditionality, must not be the primary aim as such; they must be instruments that promote change and must be adapted within certain limits to prevailing or actual conditions, so long as it is clear that national Governments are determined to move forward and to achieve adjustment with growth.
277.	Finally, it cannot be over-emphasized that it would be wholly inadequate to think only in terms of short-term adjustment or short-term flows of resources. Rather, emphasis should be on long-term support measures and adjustment, with a series of short-term measures, as necessary, combining programme lending with project lending: for instance, food aid with agricultural and food production programmes, soft loans with investment programmes, and so on.
278.	We have put our case before the international community, and put it squarely. We ourselves are determined to play our role and to pull ourselves up by our own bootstraps, as it were, in keeping with the imperatives of self-help and collective self-reliance, joining hands as sovereign nations with other developing countries. The positive response and affirmative action we seek in dealing with the African situation must be seen in that context. It is part and parcel of regional co-operation and
targeted action within the totality of wider, or global, cooperation. The nature of the crisis facing the African continent requires that the international community band together to devise workable and practicable solutions to the problem. We believe the need of the hour is for Africa to utilize fully the complementarities existing in the international economic system at the subregional, regional, inter-regional and international levels. In this regard, we note with appreciation the tireless efforts of the Group of 77 and the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries to enhance South-South co-operation through the implementation of the Caracas Programme of Action14 and the Action Programme for Economic Co-operation of non-aligned countries.15
279.	Africa has special problems and pressing needs which call for special attention and urgent action. But Africa is also an integral part of the international economic system, and there are limits to what we can do and cases in which progress is not possible without a hospitable and equitable international economic environment. Now is the time not for looking inward or for retreat but for renewal and rededication to the cause of internationalism and multilateralism, even through the particulars of the critical African economic situation, for what happens in Africa cannot but profoundly affect the rest of the world.
280.	Mr. TILLETT (Belize): On behalf of the Government and people of Belize, I bring to the Assembly greetings and best wishes for success in the work of this special session. At the same time I wish to affirm Belize’s solidarity with the nations and peoples of Africa.
281.	One cannot speak about the cause of the critical economic situation in Africa, for its causes are legion. And in the Assembly we shall all no doubt latch on to our favourite causes in order to propose and justify our favourite solutions. '
282.	As we continue studying the documents before us, and as we continue examining the possible solutions to this crisis, let us not overlook the obvious. All developing nations that have recently become independent after years of colonialism know how difficult it is to abandon the colonial attitude and economic structure and exercise a greater nationalistic attitude and economy. Colonialism was never intended to promote the national economy but to protect the privileged and to prosper the colonizer. This principle is a death blow to any national economy, but it worked so well for the privileged few that new Governments frequently find it self-serving to maintain colonial principles.
283.	Another school of thought would let the African drought bear the full responsibility for the critical economic situation in Africa. There is no doubt that the drought has contributed greatly to this crisis; its impact cannot be minimized. Yet the highly visible and critical effect of the drought serves more to dramatize the fragile nature of Africa’s socio-economic structure than to serve as a root cause for the critical economic situation in Africa.
284.	The causes, as I said earlier, are legion, and we can find lists of them and proponents for each list. For, although it is essential to know the causes in order better to chart the course for more effective future development, that work has already been done and is available in both documents A/AC.229/2 and A/S-13/4. And that is not the purpose for which we have come together today. Mr. Pisani, Chairman of the Preparatory Committee for this special session, stated our purpose well when he said, “What we are seeking is a mutual commitment to a more productive future for Africa”.
285.	The very fact that we have been able to come together for the sole purpose of discussing the critical economic situation in Africa is of great importance to the Belize delegation. In addition to that, it is a tribute to the flexibility of the United Nations. Just last December, at the fortieth session of the General Assembly, we were unable to reach consensus on a proclamation commemorating the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations. Only six months later we have converged here on a much greater issue with one focus: the critical economic situation in Africa. This is a compliment to the United Nations as well as to the people and the Governments of Africa.
286.	The calling of this special session is a clear manifestation of both the hope and the confidence that nations have and hold in the United Nations. The response of the international community to the call of Africa emphasizes the role of the United Nations in the amelioration of the miseries that face mankind throughout the world. As a result, this co-ordinated effort by the international community can only serve to reward the hope of the Africans, strengthen the resolve of the international community and enhance both the efficacy and the image of the United Nations. Never before has the international community had such singleness of purpose with such continental scope.
287.	To state that we have a singleness of purpose is not to disguise that there exist different approaches to this critical economic situation in Africa. It is, however, intended to express that in our diversity during this session we have only one adversary; it is the critical economic situation in Africa.
288.	The Belize delegation has noted the degree of support for Africa that has emerged so far during this session. Greater support would have been more pleasing. We observed with satisfaction the expectancy with which delegations yesterday morning awaited the address of the President of the Republic of Senegal, Mr. Diouf. We sincerely hope that during this session all Member States will be able to subdue the urge to generalize this crisis into an East-West tug-of-war or a developed-versus-developing-States controversy. Furthermore we hope that during this session all Member States will be able to focus on our one common adversary, for we believe that, as the Secretary-General said yesterday in his opening remarks [7st meeting], “Solidarity is the only guarantee of survival”. We applaud all nations contributing to this solidarity, and we are especially pleased with Canada’s contribution to it.
289.	The vitality, resourcefulness and openness with which Africa has faced this challenge must be recognized and applauded by all nations. Never before has an entire continent opened its soul for such public and international scrutiny. That is symbolic of both the severity of the situation and the determination of Africans to reverse this crisis and chart Africa’s course to development and prosperity.
290.	Nations will be well advised not to use this crisis to infringe in any way upon Article 2, paragraph 7, of the Charter of the United Nations.
291.	As has been stated here already, no one can say that Africa has been idle. Rather, Africa has set the course that will lead to its future economic development. The actions taken by Africa are far-reaching, and they demonstrate the political will necessary to overcome this crisis. Among these are, first, a commitment to resolve the economic and agricultural problems of the continent; secondly, a willingness to scrap failed policies and adopt new pragmatic approaches; and, thirdly, acceptance that
the responsibility for economic and social change rests with the Africans themselves.
292.	At Addis Ababa in March 1986 the African Ministers of Foreign Affairs and the Ministers responsible for Economic Development and Planning made this absolutely clear when they declared, in paragraph 4 of the OAU document submitted to this special session,1 “In full recognition of the potential of our region, we affirm our total commitment to the primary responsibility for the development of our continent”. The Ministers continued in a much more detailed manner in paragraph 9 of that document:
“On our side, we reaffirm our commitment to mobilize all our resources for development purposes and to undertake, individually and collectively, all measures and policy reforms necessary for the recovery of . . . our peoples. It is our collective and individual determination to make all the sacrifices required for bringing about economic rehabilitation, recovery and development. Accordingly, we will, inter alia, take measures to strengthen incentive schemes, review public investment policies, improve economic management, including greater discipline and efficiency in the use of resources, encourage domestic resources mobilization and ensure the broad participation of all our peoples in the veritable fight against poverty, famine and hunger and disease and ignorance”.
That is a sweeping commitment for which we must congratulate the African nations and peoples.
293.	In addition, Africa has analysed its situation and has drawn up a Priority Programme for'Economic Recovery 1986-1990.2 We have already heard much about this Priority Programme. Some of the plan’s main features are, first, to put emphasis on the food-and-agricultural sector to the extent of raising the level of investment in the agricultural sector to between 20 and 25 per cent of total public investment; secondly, to strengthen linkages between agriculture and other sectors; and thirdly, to develop and efficiently utilize Africa’s human resources. 294. It is clear that Africa has demonstrated the necessary political will to meet this challenge. The Belize delegation is in agreement with a statement made by Robert S. McNamara, former President of the World Bank, who said:
“The time has come to formulate a ‘compact’, an Africa Plan . . . comparable to the Marshall Plan . . . What we have here is the opportunity of a decade, if not a generation. If we miss it, history may not provide us with another.”
295.	It was only a few days ago that we witnessed Hands Across America in support of the poor in the United States of America. On that same day—and perhaps more significant for this special session of the General Assembly—we witnessed the lighting of the Sport Aid torch in front of the United Nations, signifying the start of the Race Against Time, a race in support of Africa.
296.	Africa—and, indeed, the whole world—is looking for something both concrete and symbolic from this special session onto which it can hold. The hope of millions of men, women and children is linked to the success of this session. Let us close the session with a resounding consensus of support for Africa, and let us leave the special session on the critical economic situation in Africa committed to this philosophy: No man is an island; no man stands alone. Each man is my brother; each man is my friend.
297.	Mr. FARAJ (Iraq) (interpretation from Arabic): The delegation of the Republic of Iraq wishes to express
its pleasure at seeing Mr. de Pinies presiding over the work of the Assembly again and its confidence that his wide experience and eminence in the international arena will help us to meet the challenge of this historic special session on the critical economic situation in Africa.
298.	The fact that the General Assembly has been convened in special session to study the critical economic situation in Africa reflects the international consensus on the extreme importance of confronting the threat hanging over the African continent. This session represents a mighty step forward by the peoples and Governments of the States Members of this international Organization, who have closed ranks to face the socio-economic crisis confronting a part of our world. It is an important stage in the implementation and application of the spirit and aspirations of the Charter of the United Nations in the loftiest sense. General Assembly resolution 40/40, which provides, inter alia, for the convening of a special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa, was an important aspect of what the Assembly hoped to achieve at its fortieth session to mark the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the United Nations, in reinforcing the idea of fruitful and positive international co-operation in the service of the principles of the international Organization and reaffirming its fundamental role in the midst of the great problems and difficulties confronting it.
299.	The laying of the foundations of a world in which peace truly prevails and international security is not gravely threatened depends first and foremost on the eradication of misery and despair in every part of the world. Africa is the only continent in which the standard of living has decreased in the past decade. This decrease will continue if bold and effective measures are not urgently taken.
300.	The famine ravaging Africa today is without question the worst that continent has ever faced. If immediate and effective measures are not taken, the land degradation resulting from the unexpected erosion of soil will reduce the land area available for cultivation by one sixth. The food situation in Africa has been constantly deteriorating over the past two decades. At the same time, population growth has far outstripped the increase in food production. Taking into account the extreme drought that has prevailed since 1967, the future prospects for the agricultural sector are grim, despite the arrival of emergency assistance in various parts of the continent. In more than half the African countries, the per capita share of cereals is less than 140 kilogrammes, which represents the minimum nutrition necessary to maintain health. We are deeply concerned to see that almost 70,000 square kilometres of arable land annually is transformed into desert around the vast Sahara.
301.	In Africa, the process of industrialization is fraught with serious problems. The badly needed structural adjustments have stagnated, and there is an increasing gap between investments and savings. In low-income African countries, savings have fallen from 16 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1970 to 6 per cent in 1981. In African countries the ratio of manufactured goods to total exports has fallen well below the 1970 level. All of this means that the international community must deal with the bottlenecks hindering the industrialization process in Africa.
302.	In the area of foreign trade, African countries are facing grave difficulties. According to FAO publications, African exports decreased by 20 per cent in real terms in the period 1980 to 1983. The deterioration in terms of trade in the low-income African countries has been
more than 12 per cent during the past 15 years. The decline in the prices of raw materials combined with widespread protectionist measures in developed countries has narrowed the foreign-trade prospects of African countries.
303.	The African countries’ external indebtedness is another cause of concern. ECA statistics show that in 1984 their external debts totalled $158 billion, and by the end of 1985 the figure had reached $170 billion. According to information provided by FAO, those debts constitute 40 per cent of the gross domestic product of the African countries, and more than 20 per cent of their export earnings goes to service those debts. A report of the Director-General of FAO to the General Assembly stated that Africa’s position was such that it could not finance its development. The increased debt burden is preventing development in Africa.
304.	In trade relations, African countries face an ominous return to protectionism and a decline in raw material prices. They are still the victims of exchange rate fluctuations, and the decrease in international concessional aid has greatly harmed them. The policy of structural adjustment, aimed at reducing the deficit and public expenditure, has led to a reduction of imports and to severe pressure on budgets. Therefore, it has harmed investment programmes, thus leading to the reduction of internal economic activity and increasing unemployment.
305.	There is no doubt that the crisis confronting Africa is. basically one of development. Nevertheless, climatic conditions, in the form of an unprecedented drought, led to a further worsening of the situation and to difficulty in providing food.
306.	In considering the grave conditions in the African continent we cannot overlook the repeated acts of aggression by the racist régime in South Africa, aimed primarily at the economic facilities and infrastructure of the frontline States, in order to exacerbate the situation, subjugate those countries by force and prevent them from exercising their right to choose their own independent path. The dastardly acts of aggression against the capitals of Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe at the beginning of last week were new affirmation of the racist regime’s determination to persist in its policy until its last breath.
307.	The African countries responded strongly and creatively to those grave challenges. The Declaration on the Economic Situation in Africa10 and Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the heads of State and Government of African States at Addis Ababa in July 1985, are the best proof of the bold, practical approach of the African leaders to solving the problems confronting the African continent.
308.	The Programme’s aim is to identify priorities and measures to overcome the current serious economic crisis and to reactivate the development process. Among the most important of those priorities is the development of agriculture and related industries. The full implementation of the Programme requires about $128 billion. The African countries have affirmed their intention of providing approximately $82 billion during the period 19861990, and they want the international community to provide approximately $46 billion.
309.	Thanks to both internal and external efforts and other measures, the African countries managed to reduce their balance-of-payments deficit from $25 billion in 1981 to $11 billion in 1984. That reduction, made in spite of the difficult economic conditions experienced by the African countries, particularly the sub-Saharan countries, is worthy of full support and encouragement.
310.	The whole world is profoundly concerned about the worsening of the African crisis. This necessitates— in addition to a response to the special problems of famine—concerted efforts to lay the foundations for the resumption of economic progress in Africa. Action is more than ever necessary to prevent any further deterioration in the economies of the African countries through the adoption of effective, serious measures to revive the development process and find solutions commensurate with the social, economic and development needs of each country.
311.	The economic crisis in Africa must be dealt with over both the short term and the long term, which are interrelated. In the short term, the international community must continue to be ready to support the still badly needed emergency operations in Africa, particularly in the food and agricultural sectors. In that context, we pay a tribute to the Office for Emergency Operations in Africa, which, under the leadership of Mr. Morse, has played a primary role in the co-ordination of the international community’s response. The Office has contributed to monitoring the emergency operations in Africa and to expanding United Nations assistance activities arid increasing their effectiveness. The work of the Office is an excellent example of the vital role played by the United Nations in international affairs. We also pay a tribute to the initiatives of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, the Organization of the Islamic Conference and governmental and non-governmental organizations in support of the peoples of Africa at this critical juncture.
312.	In the long term it is necessary to identify methods to increase production, restore development, increase productivity, raise standards of living, adjust economic structures and change the international economic situation.
313.	The people and Government of Iraq have always stood by the African countries and supported their aspirations to a dignified life, independence, freedom, progress and development. Iraq has supported the developing countries and their aspirations in deeds as well as in words. It has consistently provided support and assistance to developing countries in general and the African countries in particular. By 1983 Iraq had provided African countries with bilateral assistance totalling approximately $2,153 million, made up of $ 1,580 million in concessional loans and $578 million in grants. Those loans were provided on very soft terms, some being interest-free or with just token interest, and the long repayment period always began only after the passage of an adequate period of grace. .
314.	In addition to that financial assistance, Iraq has provided technical assistance, such as training, fellowships, technical expertise and other forms of assistance, through its syndicates, specialized associations and other leading institutions.
315.	Iraq also had the privilege and honour of presiding over the Islamic Committee for Solidarity with the Peoples of the Sahel when the Twelfth Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers elected Mr. Taha Moheddin Marouf, Vice-President of the Republic of Iraq, Chairman of that Committee in 1981.
316.	Iraq reaffirms once again its resolve to continue to stand by the peoples and countries of Africa and to provide every possible support and assistance as soon as current circumstances permit and the war imposed on it is over.
317.	We believe that this special session of the General Assembly devoted to the critical economic situation in Africa must adopt a rigorous, concentrated, effective and
practical approach to meeting the requirements of the African countries. This historic opportunity must serve as the basis for an international consensus on and a clear commitment to support for the development process in Africa and to action to respond to the urgent requirements clearly set forth in the reports before us. It is our profound hope that that commitment will constitute an important step towards the establishment of a new international economic order based on justice, equality, development and progress for all countries of the world, developed and developing, regardless of their different social, economic and political systems.
318.	Mr. WIJEWARDANE (Sri Lanka): My delegation recalls with pleasure the diplomatic skill and ability of Mr. de Pinies, President of the fortieth session of the General Assembly. We are indeed happy that he is presiding also over this special session, and we offer him our congratulations and best wishes.
319.	The Secretary-General has, in his usual very characteristic.manner, highlighted the concern of the international community over the human tragedy that has been enacted on the African continent. My delegation shares with him and through him recognition of the urgent need to take all such steps and measures as will prevent a recurrence of such tragic events not only in Africa but also elsewhere.
320.	At the same time, I wish to convey the thanks of my delegation to Mr. Diouf, President of Senegal and current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, whose inspiring address [1st meeting] set the tone for this special session devoted to the critical economic situation in Africa. My delegation echoes his statement that development is the new name of peace.
321.	. We wish also to place on record our appreciation of the' work done by the Chairman of the Preparatory Committee.
322.	, The current African economic crisis is not only a problem of Africa, but one that concerns all Member States as well. We must acknowledge at the outset the genuine sense, of urgency with which the .United Nations system has responded to the situation. We must also recognize that the international community has reacted with great understanding and sympathy in response to resolution 40/40, in which the General Assembly decided to convene this special session. There is no better evidence of the sense of global oneness and common concern than this spontaneous universal response to the crisis in African countries. We are all alive to the unprecedented nature of this session as a first effort by the United Nations to focus on the needs of one continent.
323.	Sri Lanka has consistently supported the cause of the African people in their struggle against apartheid, oppression and colonial domination. I take this opportunity to state unequivocally Sri Lanka’s concern about the African people in their economic and social development. 324. As is very clearly illustrated in the OAU submission to the special session on Africa’s economic and social crisis,1 a combination of external factors and domestic policies, such as inadequate resources, slow growth rate, structural weaknesses, particularly in the agricultural and industrial sectors, protectionism, world economic stagnation, indebtedness, population growth and natural factors such as drought have contributed to the present unfortunate situation. These factors have been growing in magnitude and in dimension over recent years. Inadequate transportation, population growth and migration of people following droughts have aggravated the situation. As the Assembly is aware of the diverse aspects of the present crisis, I shall not attempt to narrate them here.
Comprehensive documents relating to the crisis have been made available to us, including the report of the Preparatory Committee [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l], the OAU submission and other documentation. My delegation is inclined to believe that the international community is fully aware of the seriousness of the present economic crisis on the basis of this documentation and the wide media coverage.
325.	The OAU submission identifies the steps that African Governments and peoples are taking and are determined to take and also indicates the nature of the assistance expected from the international community. It is very pertinent that, as we learn from this document, Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 lays considerable emphasis on the food and agricultural sectors. My delegation applauds the realism with which the OAU has addressed the matter and notes that the level of investment in the agricultural sector recommended by the OAU is between 20 and 25 per cent of total public investments. This is indeed an important policy decision.
326.	Reviewing the immediate past, we note that from 1980 to 1984 food production increased by a mere 1 per cent, while population grew at a rate of 3 per cent. Thus there is clearly urgent need to pay close attention to food production. In this connection, FAO has been implementing its Agricultural Rehabilitation Programme in Africa and providing assistance, including technical and professional skills, to the OAU secretariat in formulating and implementing the special programmes of action in food and agriculture.
