WFP is also supporting the programmes of action in Africa, including research, extension and rural credit activities, which are of primary concern to African countries, in which the lack of expertise in this respect constitutes a serious constraint on their efforts to improve food crop production.
327.	It would be prudent for the Governments concerned to take steps to regulate population growth so that population does not outstrip economic growth, particularly in areas such as food production. The World Bank, in its report Financing Adjustment with Growth in SubSaharan Africa, 1986-90, has recommended that population growth be regulated as part of the search for solutions to the present economic crisis. We believe that UNFPA will continue its present programmes of action. 328. Although the food and agricultural sectors are playing a vital role in the implementation of the Priority Programme, other sectors of development, such as industry, health services, irrigation, transportation, marketing and pricing, should not be neglected.
329.	Adequate attention must also be placed on the need to give high priority to the development and management of Africa’s human resources. The future of Africa is closely tied to the managerial skills that African Governments will have at hand to manage development programmes. If the Priority Programme is to be implemented effectively within the short period of five years, adequate input of domestic effort will be necessary. We urge United Nations agencies to continue to play their role in the Priority Programme by providing technical assistance, identifying suitable emergency and short- and mediumterm programmes, providing technical data and assisting the start-up funding where necessary.
330.	As is very clearly shown in the draft United Nations Programme of Action [ibid., annex V], the African countries have an obligation to help themselves in the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery. We applaud the already proclaimed determination of the African countries to find substantial funding
from within their own resources, including mobilization of domestic savings. However, the estimated budget to see through the recovery programme runs at a figure which by any criterion is beyond the scope of national and continental endeavours. The external resource requirement is estimated at 35 per cent of the total cost of the Priority Programme. On this basis, over the period 19861990 several billion dollars have to be found annually from international resources for the successful implementation of the Priority Programme.
331.	In implementing the Programme, special attention will undoubtedly be paid to the financial and technical assistance requirements of countries most affected by drought and desertification. In all those endeavours, the countries concerned have to step up their export development programmes to find a way out of the present crisis.
332.	In examining the current situation, while it is necessary to consider ways and means by wliich the international community can assist in implementing Africa’s Priority Programme, we must also look at the long-term problems and try to find answers to them. The OAU report has attempted just that exercise.
333.	At this juncture, international support should not be limited to providing funds for the implementation of the Priority Programme. It is urgently necessary to provide relief for debt-servicing as well. Without such assistance African countries might at the end of the period be worse off than they are at the beginning. This is the more serious in that it is estimated that the debt-servicing obligation will become more than triple the 1980-1982 figure during 1986-1990, the period of the Priority Programme. Increases in net financial flows bilaterally and through multilateral institutions and from commercial lending will have to play their part in bridging that gap.
334.	Sri Lanka is a small country classified among the least advanced in terms of financial parameters. However, it has the blessing of good earth, which, with timely and seasonal rains, gives Sri Lanka a bountiful harvest. The skills and wisdom of political leadership over 50 years of self-determination and 38 years of independence, fashioned in the cross-fires of nine general elections and eight changes of Government, have resulted in the development and management of human resources. Over the past eight years Sri Lanka has maintained a steady growth rate of over 5 per cent and has progressively lowered population growth to below 2 per cent. It will therefore come as no surprise that Sri Lanka’s quality of life parameters, such as life expectancy, literacy rate and protein intake, are high, while infant mortality is low. Our achievements as regards democratic values embolden us to assure the third world that development to suit the genius of peoples within their own cultures is possible.
335.	We stand ready to share our developmental experiences with and participate in the efforts being made in Africa. Sri Lanka has considerable recent experience, particularly in the field of irrigation, water resources and management of river valley development projects, which we have successfully implemented in the recent past. We have also undertaken and successfully implemented a major land reform policy, and we could share such experience with African countries seeking expertise appropriate to their situations. Our village-awakening programme, based upon concepts of self-help and with a target of 1 million houses, is progressing happily towards the fulfilment of its proclaimed purpose of providing shelter and opportunity to the deprived in the rural countryside.
336.	Despite the financial limitations Sri Lanka is facing, my country has donated $100,000 as our modest contribution to African relief and assistance programmes. In 1984 the farmers of Sri Lanka responded to the needs of our African brothers by making a token but voluntary contribution of rice for drought-affected Africa. In 1985 the Government of Sri Lanka donated a stock of tea for distribution among the famine-stricken people. In addition, for a number of years we have provided a limited number of scholarships and training facilities to students from African countries as our effort to help build the infrastructures in their countries. Our agricultural extension services and rural credit extension schemes have been forged on the anvil of experience, and we are ready to share that experience with African States in need of such assistance.
337.	African leaders meeting at the Addis Ababa summit stated in paragraph 6 of their Declaration:10
“We reaffirm that development of our continent is the primary responsibility of our Governments and people. We are, therefore, determined to take concrete actions and measures individually and collectively for the achievement of the economic development in our continent.”
We are greatly heartened by those sentiments and affirm our willingness, within the limits of our capacity, to extend the hand of friendship to a great continent, its countries and its peoples in their hour of need.
338.	Africa can and must sow the seeds of self-sufficiency. For that purpose let us all, big and small, developed and underdeveloped Member States of this great brotherhood of humankind, assure African women and men that in their hour of crisis we affirm, with the Secretary-General of Worldview International Foundation, a non-governmental organization with headquarters in Sri Lanka, that “Solidarity with Africa is solidarity with our future”.
339.	Mr. LOPEZ (Philippines): The views expressed by previous speakers about the critical situation in Africa are widely shared and there is little that can be added to what has already been said. However, I should like to express my Government’s sentiments reflecting its sympathy and solidarity with the cause of the African peoples. The critical situation in Africa is also being experienced in varying degrees of gravity by other developing countries around the world. Hence we can identify with the problems of Africa, and we are gratified at the international concern manifested by the holding of this special session.
340.	In 1983 Africa was the focus of global attention because of the drought and famine that caused untold suffering to millions of Africans. The response of the international community was touching and impressive. Still, it is ironic to note that it was not until the situation reached a catastrophic level that the world could be spurred into action.
341.	While the immediate problem of Africa may now seem to have subsided somewhat, the overall situation remains critical. The OAU report1 affords an insight into the problem. It is now clear to us that the crisis did not begin with the famine of 1983. For centuries, history has recorded internal and external conditions that can be traced to colonial policies. Many of these conditions are common to the third world countries that now suffer under the burden of interrelated problems created by heavy foreign debt, plunging commodity prices, protectionism and high import costs. There is also the exacerbating factor of political instability, heightened by the menacing policy of apartheid. It is unfortunate that while
much of the world, including certain developing countries with a colonial heritage, has been able to achieve a degree of economic and social progress, the African continent seems to find little or no relief in coping with its problems.
342.	For moral as well as practical reasons, the world can ill afford to ignore the hapless condition of millions of Africans. The situation adversely affects the social and political stability of the international community and has a negative impact on the very foundation of present-day civilization. The problems of Africa are our collective problems. We all have a stake in ensuring that a successful effort is made to resolve the African crisis. A healthy and prosperous Africa is the essential constituent of a healthy international environment. It is with this awareness that we welcome Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.2 This is a Programme that has been developed by the Africans themselves, and they hope it will help free their peoples from the shackles of economic and social deprivation. It represents the commitment of the African States to assume primary responsibility for their own development. Thus, they have committed from domestic resources 64.4 per cent of the total cost of the Priority Programme. We warmly endorse the emphasis on self-reliance as the objective of the Programme as well as its main driving force.
343.	Unfortunately, the problems Africa faces are too enormous to be adequately met by limited domestic resources. Financial assistance, particularly from developed countries, is sorely needed to supplement these resources. We therefore endorse the efforts of the African countries to have the recovery Programme accepted. We urge that every measure be taken to reach an understanding during this session and thereby make its acceptance possible. For the Programme to succeed it is essential that there be a genuine partnership between Africa and the international community. This partnership between Africa and the international community should be characterized by a sharing of responsibilities and the presence of a clear commitment for action. Above all, it must presuppose the existence of trust and confidence in the ability of each party to fulfil its part of the arrangement. 344. Most welcome in this context was the announcement of Canada yesterday of a moratorium on the repayment of loans by African countries [2nd meeting, para. 91}. We are also heartened by the information received with regard to the efforts of other developed countries to help Africa, such as by the conversion of official development assistance into grants. This reassures us that the spirit of co-operation is very much alive. We are encouraged by these developments; they can be counted as the first positive results of the special session. We look forward to hearing similar announcements from other developed countries.
345.	The Philippines is not in a position to approximate such acts of generosity. Nevertheless, in our own modest way, we should like to convey to the African countries our readiness to extend technical assistance in the context of economic and technical co-operation among developing countries. As we have done in the past, we shall continue to make available to African and other developing countries training courses in the Philippines under the auspices of the Technical Assistance Council of the Philippines.
346.	The presence of so many world leaders at this special session and the messages of concern and support that have been expressed in their statements give us every reason for optimism. It is our hope that we shall be able to translate our good intentions into clear and firm commitments of support for Africa’s programme of recovery.
Our experience in grappling with the critical economic situation in Africa should usher in a new era in the history of the United Nations. Eagerly the world of the developing countries—indeed, the whole world—looks forward to this development. Africa has become the testing ground for the principle of international co-operation and the ultimate ideal of human brotherhood. We cannot afford to fail.
347.	Mr. ALBAN-HOLGUIN (Colombia) (interpretation from Spanish): In the history of the United Nations there has probably been no other event that has attracted such intense international concern as the critical economic situation in Africa, which has brought the States Members of the Organization together in this special session of the General Assembly devoted exclusively to this issue. Other events, such as the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations, have been solemnly commemorated, but, for reasons known to us all, none has been as comprehensive or striking as this one in which an entire continent, in concert and unity, is undertaking regional action in defence of its aspirations and legitimate interests. By the same token, this gathering demonstrates to us that never before has the world become so closely united.
348.	In this day and age we have a clear-cut awareness of the interdependence of all the nations of the world. We are familiar with the conditions of backwardness in most nations, and we know that there are places in the world where people aspire to a stage of development that will allow them to make an effective reality of more egalitarian societies, more in keeping with the dignity of the human person.
349.	Africa yearns for overall development and wishes to demonstrate its ability to guide that development to meet its needs and channel its resources. Assessment of its needs and analysis of the conclusions, backed by serious and carefully drafted documentation, have brought us to this important political forum, in which there is world-wide participation, to seek realistic and effective formulas that will make it possible to establish the indispensable structure that can provide Africa with appropriate tools, which, together with its own major human and material contributions and respecting the autonomy of its own decisions, will bring about the major reforms that are required.
350.	The disquiet felt by the international community at the worsening of the tragic situation of African countries stricken by the crisis became manifest in December 1984 with the adoption of General Assembly resolution 39/29, to which was annexed the Declaration on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa. That resolution contributed to arousing the world’s conscience to the serious problems facing Africa. The international community responded generously to the appeal addressed to it, and there was a moving manifestation of human solidarity.
351.	The emergency situation has not ended; the serious economic problems continue, and it is now indispensable that we examine in depth the fundamental problem of medium- and long-term development.
352.	It has rightly been said that there is also a crying need for external resources, which should include reduction of the debt-servicing burden, an increase in capital flows and stable prices for the continent’s basic export products. The wealthy countries must shoulder their responsibility to play their part and use their power to remedy the difficult situation facing the weak and restore their hopes. Greatness of spirit and a sense of mission are needed to ensure that the benefits enjoyed by some peoples are more widely distributed.
353.	It is for this purpose that, in the political sphere, the world has entrusted power to the United Nations, which since its inception has been committed not only to maintain international peace and security but also “to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom”. The Charter establishes, among other standards, the concept that the solidarity of peoples is not solely political but also requires each country to study, understand and help resolve the problems of others created by situations of poverty, backwardness, injustice and instability.
354.	In fulfilment of this mandate we have gathered here to advance the immense and anxious process of Africa’s struggle to achieve development—a struggle shared by the vast majority of our countries—within the framework of a rigid and unjust international economic system. Important steps have been taken at various meetings toward an understanding and analysis of the crisis facing Africa, and priority programmes designed to provide the instruments for resolving the problems have been adopted. This was the purpose of the Lagos Plan of Action8 and Final Act of Lagos.16
355.	Africa’s programme of action, which is the manifestation of the collective and individual determination of the countries of that continent, embodying as it does a serious commitment to efforts to overcome their difficulties, is an invitation to resolve a problem of common interest to all States Members of this Organization.
356.	It is clear that in this revolt against underdevelopment and backwardness, while we pinpoint many of their causes, we must focus clearly on the urgent measures to be taken in terms of population, housing, education, health, production and consumption. What future awaits Africa if no solution is found to its problems? That is why there is talk of co-operation, because it is indispensable for us to contribute to the economic development of the peoples on that continent, development that will lead to all the benefits of the most democratic societies, in which rights, respect for the dignity of the human person, social justice, independence and the selfdetermination of peoples prevail.
357.	Africa has committed itself to mobilizing all its energies and resources in the task of achieving the objectives spelled out in the Priority Programme and setting in train the necessary measures of internal adjustment. All this is a clear indication that there is an acute awareness of the gravity of the hour.
358.	Yesterday [7st meeting] the President of Senegal said that this special session of the General Assembly represents an act of faith in Africa, in its destiny and the international community as a whole. Certainly there is no lack of faith in Africa. We are all aware of the fact that the time has come for the economic development and social integration of its peoples. Representatives fully appreciate, as has been confirmed in their statements, that efforts and sacrifices must be made if the desired result is to be achieved.
359.	The principal source of Africa’s economy is trade in commodities whose prices have been worsening continuously, to the detriment of the least advanced countries. The slow increase in production, the fall in export prices, the protectionism practised by industrialized countries and the burden of the external debt are some of the structural imbalances that Africa is facing.
360.	There is a general understanding that we must focus our attention on long-term prospects and growth policies and on regional development. Obviously this requires a concerted effort on the part of the industrialized countries to provide aid and assistance towards recovery in the long run.
361.	Of overriding importance, as President Diouf put it, are effective and efficient policies in the agricultural sector, because that sector is the principal vocation of the continent. The proposals set forth in this connection reflect the priority accorded the agricultural sector in national development policies and the allocation of resources to that sector by the various countries. Indeed the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity has committed the Governments of its members to a gradual increase in the participation of the agricultural sector in the totality of national life on the order of 20 to 25 per cent by 1989.
362.	Africa aspires to a better future marked by a more egalitarian society. As the Secretary-General put it in one of his reports, “The next five years will be decisive for sub-Saharan Africa, in view of the challenges facing it”. At this gathering we must take a positive step forward in coming to the aid of our brothers in Africa so that they may successfully confront the major problems of underdevelopment. A concerted, sustained effort is indispensable if they are to emerge from the critical situation and break out of the circle in which they are foundering, employing all their energies towards better, more prosperous times with freedom and maintaining their development in the knowledge of the benefits it will bring.
363.	Colombia reiterates its faith in Africa and in genuine international co-operation and renews its steadfast solidarity with that continent, which seeks from the international community a more comprehensive appreciation of its struggles and hopes.
364.	There are those who, by historic destiny and the circumstances of their lives, embody the yearnings, the aspirations and the most profound feelings of a given people and, in exceptional cases, of an entire continent. That is indeed the case with regard to the President of the Republic of Senegal, Mr. Diouf. He spoke in eloquent terms when he addressed the Assembly, aware as he was of the privilege to do so on behalf of Africa. His words were frank, dignified, heartfelt and full of hope and faith in the spirit of solidarity and international co-operation.
365.	Colombia endorses that message, since like our brothers in Africa, we believe in the international community’s capacity for mobilization and in its generosity. At a time when multilaterialism is under fire, the important lesson we must draw, as the Secretary-General said, is that the United Nations system can play a guiding role in the mobilization of all mankind and in its capacity to achieve positive results.
366.	Mr. WOOLCOTT (Australia): Let me say how pleased the Australian delegation is at seeing Mr. de Piniés presiding over these deliberations. I am confident that under his able guidance this special session will achieve the positive results we all desire and that the critical economic situation in Africa demands.
367.	Australia welcomes this special session and the presence of so many statesmen and ministers because it provides a timely opportunity for constructive discussions about Africa’s economic problems and possible solutions to them. We believe these discussions can lead to improved co-operation between African Governments and the concerned international donors. We also believe that this session can contribute to greater understanding of the medium- and long-term strategies which will be necessary for lasting economic recovery in Africa. The Australian delegation will be working towards these ends.
368.	Australia’s strong humanitarian concern over the situation in Africa will continue to be reflected in our assistance to that region. Since January 1984, Australia has provided about 120 million Australian dollars in food
aid and emergency humanitarian assistance to Africa. This assistance is channelled mainly through international agencies, but Australian non-governmental organizations and recipient Government agencies are also important channels for us. A significant proportion of our contribution to multilateral agencies, such as IDA, is allocated to African countries. This was a major consideration in Australia’s decision last year to make a special contribution of $A 60 million to IDA. Australia also supports a substantial eighth replenishment of IDA. Australia welcomes the substantial efforts already made on Africa’s behalf by United Nations agencies and through the recent initiatives of the World Bank and IMF, in particular the Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa and the proposed Structural Adjustment Facility. We have also indicated our support for the World Bank and for a general capital increase at the appropriate time. Australia also provides technical assistance and other forms of bilateral aid to African countries.
369.	Like their counterparts around the world and reflecting the Australian community’s concern for African problems, Australian private voluntary agencies were deeply involved in 1984 and 1985 in the international public response to the humanitarian crisis in Africa. Over this period, Australian non-governmental organizations raised from public donations over $A 50 million, which has been allocated for non-government relief and development programmes throughout Africa, in particular in Sudan and Ethiopia.
370.	In deciding the allocation of our aid, Australia must continue to take into account the legitimate claims of developing countries in our own region. There are countries in the region of the world in which Australia is situated—many Asian and Pacific nations—whose needs are also pressing and to which Australia is closely linked. Nevertheless, Australia will continue to provide significant levels of assistance to African countries.
371.	For Australia, the holding of this special session is timely, because we have initiated our own review of the form and nature of our bilateral aid to African countries. We shall, of course, be able to take the results of this session into consideration in the formulation of our aid policy. The basis of the review is Australia’s commitment to a programme of aid to Africa which focuses on long-term self-sustaining development, with a particular emphasis on food security, and which draws on Australian expertise and limited resources in the most effective way possible. By focusing on long-term food security we expect to address directly Africa’s critical need for agricultural growth and improved food-management strategies. Among the Australian voluntary aid agencies there is also an increasing emphasis on assistance leading to self-sustaining development, rather than humanitarian emergency assistance. Australian official aid is in part being channelled through voluntary agencies in support of this. .
372.	Australia shares the view expressed during discussions in the Preparatory Committee for this special session that far-reaching and imaginative policies are required to avert further economic deterioration. We also welcome the recognition, in the African submission to the special session1 and in the draft basic final document submitted by the Group of African States to the Preparatory Committee [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l, annex F], that policy adjustment in many African countries is crucial to this economic recovery. We support the emphasis on food and agriculture: as I have indicated, Australia’s bilateral aid will focus on that area.
373.	Australia also supports the efforts of African countries to gain increased access for their exports to major world markets. Australia looks to the integration of African countries into the world trading system on an equitable basis. We also hope for an end to the disruptive effects of subsidies of agricultural production and exports by some other countries. Africa, having an economy dominated by agriculture, would be a net beneficiary from the strengthened and more predictable world food market which would result from the elimination of protectionist and trade-distorting measures.
374.	Australia is especially conscious of the problems faced by the African front-line States in their efforts to foster their economic development without dependence on South Africa and in the face of continuing South African acts of aggression and destabilization in the region. The most recent attacks on Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe are an outrageous breach of the Charter of the United Nations and have rightly earned the strong condemnation of the international community. These actions have also done great harm to what hopes there may be for peaceful change in South Africa. Also, they can only set back current Commonwealth efforts to foster negotiations to bring about the cessation of violence on all sides in the interest of achieving a multiracial democratic South Africa. ■
375.	Australia will continue to watch closely the economic impact of the deteriorating situation in southern Africa on the front-line States and will continue to support the commendable efforts of those States through groups such as SADCC towards economic self-reliance. 376. Australia is seriously concerned about the predicament of the African continent and the consequent hardships and suffering of so many African peoples. We look forward, therefore, to participating at this session in the discussion of the very serious issues before us. The Assembly can be assured that Australia will give these issues careful and sympathetic consideration, and we shall try to participate constructively in these deliberations.
377.	Mr. SHIHABI (Saudi Arabia) (interpretation from Arabic): I am pleased to congratulate Mr. de Pinies on his election to the presidency of the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly. I must recall here— and I am sure other participating delegations also recall— the competence and exceptional ability with which he directed the proceedings of the historic fortieth anniversary session, which was attended by the largest gathering of heads of States or their representatives in the history of nations. He played a large role in the success of that session.
378.	The heads of African States, whose countries are experiencing an increasingly exacerbated economic crisis which is exposing their political and social stability to great dangers that we all appreciate, have called upon one another and upon the world community to increase the efforts to save that continent, a continent rich in natural resources but lacking the means to exploit them and to reap the benefits of its endeavours.
379.	I should like at the outset to repeat from this rostrum that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has supported, continues to support and calls upon others to support all the efforts aimed at assisting Africa economically through international channels, regional bodies and bilateral action.
380.	The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, connected-geographically to Africa by the Red Sea, linked with its peoples by the strongest humanitarian, economic and historic ties—besides being related to it through the large group of peoples and communities whose origins go back to the ArabiatrPeninsula—supports Africa in its effort
to leave behind irrevocably the past era of colonialism for political and economic reasons. We consider that supporting its economic independence is an international responsibility, in addition to being the responsibility of its people to help it become a productive economic force, so that all of us will be able to stand together before God and history as having fulfilled the duty of brotherhood, religion, neighbourliness and humanity.
381.	The economic crisis in Africa has reached dangerous levels in recent years, threatening the social and political fabric of many of its countries, hampering economic growth and reducing production and living standards. The crisis has been exacerbated over the past years by the drought that affected a number of its countries, and by the drought and desertification affecting agriculture. The heads of African States have warned this session in the Priority Programme that the crisis has reached threatening levels and have asked for a response to their efforts to help them avoid the political and economic consequences that would have negative effects with global dimensions. The fact that the African States themselves are prepared to shoulder the largest responsibility in their own development programmes is the best indication that the problem is being addressed at its roots.
382.	The many danger signals sent by some African countries about their grave economic situation, which is accompanied by complex political and economic problems, are signals that we should read carefully. The lower production level, the imbalances in trade accounts, the fall in the prices of raw materials and the decline of economic growth are all danger signals in the life of any economic entity. Political independence loses its real content when it is not accompanied by economic independence. The genuine departure of colonialism from African States definitely requires that their economic structures become capable of standing by themselves.
383.	I should like to point out here that between 1973 and 1981 the development assistance that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia gave to the States of the developing world within the framework of its official development assistance programme amounted to $37.2 billion, including $17.7 billion in the form of grants and non-repayable assistance, which is equivalent to 47 per cent of its total official assistance. As of the end of June 1985, the share of the African countries in this exceeded 10 billion Saudi riyals, which is equivalent to about $3 billion, in the form of soft loans by the Saudi Development Fund, in addition to non-repayable monetary and food assistance and specific projects worth more than 1.3 billion riyals, equivalent to about $370 million. It is worth mentioning here also that the Kingdom has contributed more than $400 million to WFP, more than half of which was allocated to Africa. This is in addition to the Kingdom’s participation in other international efforts to assist Africa.
384.	In this context, I should like to mention that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, according to available statistics for the years 1982 and 1983, is second in the world only to the United States of America in the amount of the assistance it gives to developing countries and international agencies. Moreover, the Arab Gulf States, including Saudi Arabia, are far ahead of all the industrial States of the world which provide assistance and loans to developing States in increasing the percentage of their gross national product that is apportioned to aid in the form of bilateral and multilateral assistance. This percentage has ranged from 4 per cent to 15.9 per cent of their gross national income over the past 10 years. I am not mentioning these facts to court appreciation but to encourage others, especially the industrial States, to assume their
role in that field in which most of their contributions have not even reached 0.7 per cent of their GNP, which is the level recommended by the United Nations.
385.	I should like to conclude with a word of support and encouragement for co-operation with Africa. I reaffirm that my country, while playing an important and effective role in this field bilaterally, regionally and internationally, would be gratified to see all capable countries participate in supporting Africa at levels commensurate with the problem and will share in the discussion and evaluation of programmes, proposals and solutions emanating from the African continent.
386.	Our first duty, while we help Africa in overcoming the famine in some of its countries and economic deficit in others, is to help Africa become capable of sustaining itself and building its own society from its own resources in the long run; because a society that becomes accustomed to a style of life that depends on loans and grants is in fact conditioning itself to an impractical and unrealistic living standard that leads to problems which weaken countries and deprive societies of the foundations for vitality and growth.
387.	Africa, with its tremendous natural resources, great agricultural potential and abundant human resources, is in need of comprehensive development from a humanitarian standpoint, firstly, and from a material point of view, secondly, in all these fields, and that requires great efforts that will enable it to benefit from these potentials. I hope that we will all try to fulfil our role in this field.
388.	Mr. VONGSAY (Lao People’s Democratic Republic) (interpretation from French): I should like to convey to Mr. de Pinies the warm congratulations of the Lao delegation on his brilliant election to the presidency of this important special session of the General Assembly devoted to the critical economic situation in Africa. We are convinced that under his wise and competent leadership, already demonstrated during the fortieth session, the work of this special session will be crowned with success.
389.	We should stress the exceptional, even historic, significance of this session: this is the first time in the history of the United Nations that a special session has been devoted to the in-depth consideration of the economic and social situation of a continent. The Lao delegation welcomes this and wishes to state the position of its Government on the subject before the Assembly.
390.	My delegation wishes to thank the Secretary-General and his staff for the excellence of the documents before the Assembly. Nor can we forget to mention the remarkable work of the Preparatory Committee of the Whole in placing before us working documents of great value. We would mention Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity in July 1985, and the draft United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery, 1986-1990 [A/S-73/4 and Corr.l, annex V]. We consider the principles and purposes underlying the formulation of those five-year programmes to be well founded and to reflect eloquently the geo-political, sociological, economic, demographic and ecological reality of the continent, which boasts vast human and natural resources and whose subregional characteristics and diversity are also notable. It is remarkable that the 50 independent sovereign States of Africa have been able to transcend their political and ideological differences and rivalries to unite in a commitment to crusade against the common enemies of poverty, hunger, disease and ignorance.
391.	The Lao Government and people pay a tribute to the enormous determination now being displayed by the hard-working Governments and peoples of those African countries bravely facing and meeting the dual challenge of survival and development. We must also hail the extraordinary effort of African Governments and their peoples with a view to mobilizing the vast domestic financial resources—amounting to $82 billion—required for implementation of the five-year Priority Programme. The remaining $46 billion—$9 billion a year—ought to be provided by the international community, in particular market economy donor countries, whose special responsibility towards the African continent should be stressed.
392.	In that connection, I wish to discuss briefly the deep-rooted causes of the present economic and social crisis in Africa. As recognized by African leaders themselves, those causes are both internal and external in origin. As in the case of all developing countries, including my own, the economic and social structures of the African countries are a legacy from the colonial period, which was marked by the direct exploitation and systematic plunder of the natural and human wealth of those countries. After the restoration of their independence and freedom, these young nations were the object of the greed of imperialist and neo-colonialist Powers which, using the pretext of aid and assistance programmes for newly independent States, were in fact actively seeking to prevent them, directly or indirectly, from moving forward on the path of just, balanced and independent economic and social development. In other words, those Powers tried and are still trying to impose upon newly independent countries, including those of Africa, a development model that runs counter to the legitimate interests and aspirations of the peoples and countries in question.
393.	Natural disasters such as drought and desertification to which many African countries have fallen victim exacerbated the already precarious economic and social situation. What is more, African economies have suffered from the harmful effects of the world economic recession, as manifested in the collapse of commodity prices, the fall in real terms of official development assistance, higher interest rates, deterioration of terms of trade, the intensive use by capitalist countries of protectionist measures, the crushing burden of foreign debt and the cost of its servicing, and so on.
394.	The paradox, as stressed in the working documents before the Assembly, is that Africa is the only continent in the world where there is a reverse transfer of financial resources to the developed market economy countries, despite the abundant natural wealth and potential of that continent. As rightly pointed out by the leaders of the OAU countries, the evil must be attacked at its roots.
395.	Along with the rest of the international community, the Lao Government welcomes and supports a whole range of short-, medium- and long-term measures, including those in the draft United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery, 1986-1990. My delegation believes that those immediate and long-term measures to whose implementation the African Governments have committed themselves individually and collectively can provide lasting solutions to the economic and social crisis in Africa.
396.	It is obvious that without radical structural change in the African economies any dynamic, balanced, selfcentred, self-sustained and independent economic and social development efforts—however commendable and determined—will be in vain. It is noteworthy that the Programme of Action gives absolute priority to the
agricultural and food sector and supporting sectors; production and productivity in those sectors must increase in real terms.
397.	My country, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, was prey to the same fate as the African countries, and in addition, like the other countries of Indochina, had to wage a long, heroic struggle against foreign aggression. Our economic and social structures were devastated by that imperialist war of aggression. Our indebted subsistence economy, basically neo-colonialist in nature, was inherited from the colonial period. After our total liberation in December 1975, the new régime promulgated the first five-year plan for economic and social development. A radical structural transformation then took place, with absolute priority given to the agricultural and food sector. We are proud to be able to say now that our country has essentially achieved self-sufficiency in food. We are convinced that the African countries too will achieve satisfactory results in this vital area of the national economy.
398.	I wish to stress that our country feels particular sympathy for those African countries facing an exceptionally unfavourable economic, social and ecological situation. In practical terms, our country faces the same difficulties and challenges, for it is both a land-locked and a least-developed country. Need I recall here that the international community, and particularly the developed countries which have moral and historical obligations towards those countries, should extend full financial and other support for Africa’s Priority Programme for economic and social recovery and development. With respect to the foreign debt problem that has crippled Africa, the Declaration on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa annexed to General Assembly resolution 39/29, and in particular its paragraph 17, should be implemented.
399.	The Lao delegation holds that the international community, and particularly the developed countries and their transnational corporations, must without delay take measures vitally necessary to deter the racist Pretoria régime from committing new acts of aggression and destabilization against the front-line States in southern Africa. The Lao Government and people have staunchly condemned the recent barbaric South African raid against Zimbabwe, Zambia and Botswana. We have also expressed our solidarity with and sympathy for the peoples and Governments of those countries. It goes without saying that such acts of State terrorism seriously jeopardize any efforts of the front-line States aimed at recovery and long-term economic and social development.
400.	Equally indispensable is the imposition against the South African racist régime of mandatory comprehensive sanctions under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations if that régime persists in its refusal to implement Security Council resolution 435 (1978) concerning the granting of genuine independence to Namibia, which South Africa continues to occupy illegally, and the abolition of the criminal apartheid régime.
401.	If they are to be successful, any development efforts, be it in Africa or any other part of the world, must be carried out in a climate of peace and security. It is well known that the developing countries in general, and those of Africa in particular, have in recent years— and this continues today—allocated enormous sums to activities related to national defence, to the detriment of their economic and social development. Measures of general and complete disarmament have, as we know, been studied and decided on at two special sessions of the General Assembly, in 1978 and 1982. Unfortunately, aggressive imperialist circles have refused and continue to refuse to halt the unbridled race in boL conventional
and nuclear armaments, with the sinister goal of achieving military and strategic superiority over the Soviet Union and the other member countries of the Warsaw Pact. It is to be regretted that no tangible progress has been made in the Soviet-American negotiations at Geneva. The reason is well known. The American Administration, defying international public opinion and even the opinion of its own citizens, continues frantically following its so-called Strategic Defence Initiative—the “star wars” programme. Needless to say, a small share of the astronomical resources that could be released through measures of disarmament would be sufficient to relieve the suffering and poverty of many African women and children victims of the disastrous results of endemic droughts.
402.	Those are the thoughts my delegation wishes to submit to the Assembly for consideration with respect to the draft United Nations Programme of Action for the economic and social recovery of Africa. We are convinced that the adoption of such a programme by the international community, and particularly by the donor developed countries, would not only help to fight poverty, famine, disease and ignorance on the African continent but also open up the way to genuine international cooperation for development to the benefit of both the developing world as a whole and the developed countries themselves.
403.	My delegation expresses the hope that the work of this historic session will lead to specific concerted action. It will spare no effort to make its modest contribution. 404. Mr. AL-ATASSI (Syrian Arab Republic) (interpretation from Arabic): Allow me to echo previous speakers in congratulating Mr. de Pinies on his unanimous election to the presidency of this important special session. We are convinced that, thanks to his experience and wisdom, the work conducted at this session will attain the hoped-for results.
405.	The international community is now witnessing a major manifestation of international co-operation. Indeed the economic and social crisis in Africa, which we are meeting especially to deal with, is no longer a crisis for Africa alone but is, rather, a crisis of the entire globe. From this fact emerges the big responsibility to be shouldered by the international community, that of saving millions of our African brothers and sisters and finding appropriate solutions and measures to help that continent overcome the difficulties which it now faces. That is what we can say concerning the thirteenth special session, devoted to an examination of the critical economic situation in Africa.
406.	In our time the world has become interdependent; it is an interlocked world; and the crisis afflicting Africa affects not only the African continent. Indeed the fallout from that crisis is spreading to countries the world over, whether developed or developing, industrial or agricultural, in the North or the South. The consequences are sparing no one; rather they are engulfing the entire world without discrimination.
407.	The African continent and the countries of Africa, in solidarity, have the primary concern in this problem, and on their shoulders falls the biggest burden in making every effort and sacrifice to see their continent emerge on the shores of peace. But the international community must provide various forms of support and aid and find the solutions and measures required in the context of the Priority Programme to stem the crisis and overcome it. 408. Once the dimensions of the crisis have been established, it can be determined what the possibilities are for dealing with it or how to ease the pressure. That is why my delegation appreciates the important address by the
President of the Republic of Senegal yesterday morning [1st meeting], in which he gave the true dimensions of the crisis and its significance. He described the crisis as facing the entire international community.
409.	The problems the African continent is facing today are clearly described in the report prepared for this special session by the Preparatory Committee of the Whole [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l], in which its causes are thoroughly analysed and specific proposals for dealing with it set forth. The majority of delegations that have already spoken at this session have in turn clearly enumerated them. From all that, it is clear that those problems have been created in part by natural factors peculiar to the African continent—drought and desertification—and in part from the inherited legacy of colonialism and imperialism which for long centuries exploited the continent and bequeathed to it the ills from which it is suffering today. The African crisis also stems in part from certain imposed factors like the racist régime in South Africa, which has not ceased its actions designed to destabilize a number of African countries, particularly the front-line States.
410.	Indeed, we feel that that problem—that of ae racist South African régime—is one of the most malignant problems suffered by Africa, and any measures to deal with the current crisis and any solution to it must involve the eradication of the apartheid policy of the South African régime, a policy that flies in the face of every humanitarian value and principle and all forms of social, economic and humanitarian development.
411.	We appreciate the efforts being made by our African brothers and sisters to overcome the crisis. I should like to reiterate here that Africa’s current crisis is that of the entire international community. The Co-ordinating Bureau of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, at its April meeting at New Delhi, stated its opinion, in solidarity with the African continent, that the present crisis is one facing all the non-aligned countries and that they should lend their support and assistance to Africa to help that continent overcome its crisis.
412.	The developed industrialized countries must regard the African crisis as one of the priority crises in today’s world. By the same token, the General Assembly at this special session should examine the emergency situation in the light of requests from developing countries to achieve just economic relations and to resume the global dialogue. The developed countries must also be keenly aware of their responsibilities to treat the emergency situation, not by giving alms, but by providing scientific and economic aid that will benefit all countries throughout the world, on the basis of a principle established after decolonization, that the world is integrated, interdependent and responsible for the situation inherited by African and other countries from long centuries of servitude, colonialism and exploitation. We believe assistance should be given without preconditions and without designs, with no purpose other than to deal with the economic crisis and end it. The need for aid from the developed countries must be emphasized, and programmes, priorities and policies must be established or re-established that take into account the parameters of the North-South dialogue and the need for the establishment of a new international economic order, for if there were a just economic order, Africa would not be enduring the crisis now afflicting it. 413. A good omen for the future is that today we are awaiting the convening of the International Conference on the Relationship between Disarmament and Development. There can be no peace with increasing armaments. Peace can prevail throughout the world only through the
elimination of all conventional and nuclear arms. If that Conference can succeed in achieving positive results, its effects would obviously be felt by all developing countries, including those of Africa.
414.	The Syrian Arab Republic is also a developing country and a member of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries. In spite of its limited resources, it continues to provide aid and assistance to its African brothers. That support and assistance take many forms and can be described as falling under two broad categories. First, support is given through Arab action, which we believe in unreservedly, expressed in Arab-African co-operation. Syria has employed all its resources to establish and develop such co-operation, which now has its own institutions, structures and funds. In this connection, I must mention the latest Arab-African conference, held at Damascus, and the decisions it made with a view to developing such co-operation still further. Secondly, there is the support provided by the Syrian Arab Republic on a bilateral basis in keeping with the agreements that link us with a number of friendly States of the African continent. I must mention also that many African nationals are pursuing higher education in Syrian universities and institutions and that they return to their countries with the experience and knowledge gained.
415.	Finally, I wish to assure our African brothers that in spite of our currently limited resources, we will spare no efforts, whether through the United Nations, the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, the League of Arab States or bilaterally, in the short, medium and long term, to help the fraternal peoples of Africa pass through this difficult trial in their struggle to end the crisis. Just as the African peoples have thrown off the yoke of colonialism, they shall soon manage to eradicate the last vestiges of racism and colonialism and rid themselves of the inheritance of underdevelopment imposed upon them by colonialism in all its forms. They will certainly overcome the crisis they are now enduring.
416.	The PRESIDENT: In accordance with General Assembly resolution 3209 (XXIX) of 11 October 1974 and the decision taken by the Assembly at its 1st plenary meeting of the current session [decision S-I3/2I], I now call upon the observer of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.
417.	Mr. KUROWSKI (Council for Mutual Economic Assistance) (interpretation from Russian): First of all, I should like to thank the Assembly for the opportunity to speak at this special session devoted specifically to the critical economic situation in Africa on behalf of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance [CMEA].
418.	The world community is deeply concerned over the complexity and acuteness of economic problems in Africa. That concern is shared by the countries members of CMEA. To the extent possible, they are taking part in the effort to overcome the existing critical situation by rendering assistance to African States in various forms, as the representatives of the CMEA countries that have already addressed the Assembly have observed.
419.	Africa’s serious economic difficulties have complicated, complex causes, which are aggravated by natural disasters. The present critical situation of the African countries is mainly the result of their colonial past and current, neo-colonial exploitation, in which the uncontrolled activities of transnational corporations play a great part.
420.	We share the opinion expressed by several delegations that to overcome the critical economic situation of the African countries, it is necessary to provide assistance not only through immediate emergency supplies,
primarily foodstuffs and drugs, but also through a structural retooling of their economies, the training of skilled manpower and the establishment of an industrial base. In this connection great importance is attached to the efforts of the African countries in their struggle to achieve economic decolonization and full sovereignty over their natural and other resources and their economic activities, limit the negative effects of the domination of foreign monopolies, stop the outflow of capital and skilled workers, increase the role of the public sector and the effective management of sectors of the national economy and make other progressive social and economic changes.
421.	Africa’s economic problems are inseparable from the general world political climate and the political situation in the continent. The escalation of the arms race, especially that in nuclear weapons, draws huge resources away from social and economic development needs. The principle imposed by militarism—arms in place of development-should be replaced by the reverse—disarmament for development. The close relationship between real progress in strengthening peace, halting the arms race, disarmament and the social and economic development of all peoples is quite clear today. Disarmament is the most realistic and effective source of the means required to meet the economic and social needs of developing countries, including those of the African continent, and to deal with such global problems as overcoming economic backwardness and eliminating vast areas of poverty, illiteracy and famine. Therefore, the wide-ranging initiatives put forward by the CMEA member countries are of special importance. Their implementation would not only help strengthen peace in the future, but make possible the diversion of huge resources to improve the living conditions of the people, including the people of Africa. The latest extension by the Soviet Union of the unilateral moratorium on nuclear tests until 6 August 1986 is a new expression of goodwill and confirmation of its unswerving efforts to improve the international situation.
422.	At its 118th meeting, in January 1986, the CMEA Executive Committee supported the programme for the complete elimination of nuclear weapons throughout the world, together with the banning of space-strike weapons, the prohibition and liquidation of chemical weapons and the radical improvement of the international situation.
423.	The improvement of international economic relations and their restructuring on a just and democratic basis, the provision of international economic security and the stabilization of general economic, monetary and financial conditions are prerequisites for a long-term solution of the social and economic problems of African countries. We believe in strict observance of General Assembly resolutions on the strengthening of the United Nations system as a basis for constructive dialogue, joint action to deal with international economic and social problems, the strengthening of confidence-building measures in the economic sphere and so on. These resolutions are very important and should be fully implemented.
424.	We oppose all forms of interference in the internal affairs of sovereign States and the use of economic ties as an instrument of political pressure, which we regard as a gross violation of the universally recognized norms of international law.
425.	The economic and technological assistance rendered by the socialist community to African countries is aimed primarily at developing their productive forces and strengthening their economic self-sufficiency. The contribution of the CMEA member countries to solving the
food problem consists in strengthening the national agricultural production base and helping to establish the complex of economic branches necessary for the development of agriculture in the African countries. This includes the creation of irrigation systems, the building and equipping of machine and tractor stations and projects for processing farm produce, the provision of veterinary clinics, grain elevators and freezers, research laboratories and experimental stations and the construction of major projects for the production of farm and transport equipment. The CMEA member countries have assisted African countries in establishing over 1,800 projects, including about 380 in the agro-industrial sector. There are plans to establish about 500 other projects in the next few years, of which over 130 will be in agriculture and the food industry.
426.	The CMEA member countries provide extensive assistance in training personnel from African countries. At present, over 45,000 African nationals are studying at higher and secondary specialized educational establishments in CMEA member countries, including more than 2,000 whose studies are financed by the CMEA Fellowship Fund. The brochure published for this session, entitled “CMEA and Africa”, gives many examples of assistance provided to African countries.
427.	The CMEA Comprehensive Programme of Scientific and Technological Progress to the Year 2000, which was adopted recently, says that the CMEA member countries will continue, to the extent possible, to give economic and technical assistance to the newly free and independent States in their efforts to develop their national economies. This has been stressed once again in the statements of representatives of CMEA member countries at this session.
428.	In conclusion, I hope that the work of this special session will end with the decision to take major international action aimed at overcoming the economic difficulties experienced by the African countries. Within the area of its competence, CMEA will play its part in that action. 429. The PRESIDENT: The next speaker is the observer of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. I call on him in accordance with General Assembly resolution 36/4 of 15 October 1981 and the decision taken by the Assembly at its 1st plenary meeting of the current session [decision S-13/21].
430.	Mr. GIAMA (African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States): First of all I should like, on behalf of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States [ACP], to convey our deepest thanks to the General Assembly at this special session for the opportunity it has so kindly afforded to the Group to address this body for the first time. The ACP Group is particularly moved by this occasion and by the historic sense of timing attendant on this moment by virtue of the critical subject-matter before the Assembly. We are in this circumstance deeply appreciative and grateful to the Assembly.
431.	We wish also to extend our congratulations to Mr. de Pinies on his election to the high office of President of this historic special session. We have full confidence in his leadership, a confidence justified by his able handling of the session. We thank him in particular for assisting in our efforts to address this body, and we look forward to his steering our deliberations to a final and successful conclusion.
432.	We of the ACP Group are most intimately involved in and deeply affected by the present African economic crisis and will benefit enormously from the deliberations at this session. Established as we were by the Georgetown Agreement, which was signed on 6 June 1975 by the
countries that earlier that year had entered into the first Lomé partnership with the European Economic Community [EEC], the ACP Group of 66 developing countries includes all 45 developing African countries south of the Sahara. Therefore nearly 90 per cent of the African nations are members of the ACP Group. With their 13 Caribbean and 8 Pacific brother and sister States, they constitute the ACP Group. As 66 countries, the Group represents fully one half of the world of developing nations and approximately 40 per cent of the United Nations family of nations. We are, therefore, very much involved and very, very much affected.
433.	We are here with one overriding purpose only, that is, to support in all ways possible the critical and praiseworthy initiatives launched by the OAU and reinforced by the United Nations. To this end, we are deeply grateful and extend our sincere thanks to President Diouf of Senegal, current Chairman of the Organization of African States, for his clear, profound and insightful address to the Assembly conveying Africa’s vision of the problem —its diagnosis, its prescriptions, its indigenous undertakings and commitments and its external requirements. None of the many statements we have heard has departed in their analyses in any major way from that of President Diouf.
434.	We of the ACP fully share the fundamental analysis of the African situation undertaken by the OAU. We do not intend to repeat it here. After two days and scores of speakers, we do not think that necessary. We recommend, therefore, concentration on the identification of and undertakings by all participants in regard to the supporting measures to be provided to assist the African peoples at this crucial juncture. .
435.	We of the ACP have but one important asset— our unity. And we intend to make full use of it in support of our African brothers and sisters. Our presence here today is a demonstration of that support. Even the composition of our delegation is symbolically representative. But important as it is, symbolism is not all. We are at present working towards the development and implementation of an intra-ACP co-operative programme of action in a number of sectors, including co-operation in air and maritime transportation and trade and. trade financing. Success in this regard would bring some small benefits to the African situation, as indeed to the general ACP condition.
436.	In our North-South relations, we have improved the quality of our co-operation with our EEC partners to the benefit of both sides. We consider this co-operation to be of critical importance at this stage of our development, and we look forward to the EEC being among those playing a substantial leadership role in this quest for additional support for the critical African situation. In this regard, yesterday’s undertakings by the EEC have, like many others, been encouraging in many respects. However, further and more courageous undertakings would almost surely have been even more deeply appreciated and encouraging.
437.	The ACP Group appreciates the positive response by the international community. The ACP Group, having established a special relationship with the EEC through the Lomé Convention, would like to ensure that this relationship focuses adequately on the critical economic situation in Africa and contributes to the urgent measures necessary for bringing about economic rehabilitation, recovery and development in Africa. The ACP Group is cognizant of the Lomé provisions, including financing and technical assistance, which might be duly applied to the economic situation facing Africa. These provisions
are, we know, already being put into operation. However, the gravity of the economic situation in Africa calls for specific commitments by the EEC beyond those of the Convention so as to give even greater support to agricultural development and food production in particular, and to the supporting sectors and the infrastructure.
438.	The ACP Group specifically urges the donor countries to make substantial financial contributions towards facilitating the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery.
439.	We further call on the international donor community to consider favourably, among other measures, converting Africa’s debts and debt-service obligations into grants. In this regard, we salute the Canadian, Dutch and other delegations which have undertaken to take positive steps in this direction.
440.	Finally, we appeal to all industrial countries to adopt policies that are conducive to economic recovery and growth, such as increasing the participation of African countries in the processing, marketing, distribution and transportation of their domestic and export commodities. We urge them especially to take immediate steps to ensure that all protectionist measures on African exports to their markets are eliminated. We also look forward with great expectation to the forthcoming multilateral negotiations in addressing fully the problems of Africa.
441.	In all those steps we reiterate our appeal to the European Economic Community to play a leading role in the spirit of special co-operation existing between them and the African countries as acknowledged by the EEC itself in its statement to this special session [2nd meeting].
442.	The struggle facing Africa today is a struggle ultimately facing mankind. Not merely the implications of economic interdependence are relevant in this situation; the wider questions of world peace and stability, world social and political order and man’s relation to man are at stake. No country and no man’s conscience shall truly escape from our failure to rise to the challenge which Africa’s situation represents today. We therefore join the OAU in supporting Africa’s commitment to internal changes and in calling on the international community to respond courageously in removing the obstacles and in providing the resources sought from it which, in the wider sphere of the use of the world’s resources, is really
a modest investment in the world’s—and every country’s —future development.
The meeting rose at 10.35 p.m.

United Nations
GENERAL ASSEMBLY
THIRTEENTH SPECIAL SESSION
Official Records
5th
PLENARY MEETING
Thursday, 29 May 1986, at 10.35 a.m.
NEW YORK
President: Mr. Jaime de PINIES (Spain).
AGENDA ITEM 6
Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and medium-term and long-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures (continued)
1.	Mr. IGLESIAS (Uruguay) (interpretation from Spanish): We are attending this special session of the General Assembly to convey to the Governments and peoples of Africa a message of solidarity and fellowship from the people and Government of Uruguay. We wish thus to tell the African nations that Uruguay is fully aware of the magnitude and complexity of the grave crisis that besets them.
2.	In its analysis of the continent’s economic and social situation and prospects, EC A dramatically points out the threats that hover over those countries if present trends continue with no awareness of change, noting that with their weak and fragile socio-political systems, the sovereignty of the African States is thus endangered. In these conditions, Uruguay believes that what is at stake is not only economic and social development or political stability, but Africa’s very survival.
3.	It is this understanding of the present African phenomenon that moves us all to express our full and steadfast solidarity, as manifested by the presence of so many and such distinguished delegations. We must now give tangible effect to our solidarity by taking practical and effective measures based on agreed collective aims , and efforts.
4.	Uruguay, like all of Latin America, has embarked on the arduous task of promoting its economic and social development in freedom and within its regained traditional democracy. For this reason, we know how difficult an undertaking it is and we have a clear awareness of the pitfalls, many of which are similar to those facing Africa, arising for the most part from unjust and regressive international trade and financial relationships. This may place us in a privileged position to understand the dimensions of the problem that besets Africa, the legitimacy and justice of its claims and the urgency with which all the members of the international community, to the extent possible, must respond to that call.
5.	Because of its origins, its history, the fact that it belongs to the Latin American family of nations, within which it shares common problems and ideals, and because of its traditional conviction that there are political and legal principles of universal value, Uruguay, which throughout all its history has developed a sharp sense and clear vision of the interdependence that governs the world, wishes on this occasion to reiterate its firm belief
that the problems which today beset Africa concern us all and that, acting together, we can all help solve them. 6. It would be superfluous to dwell here on the harsh data set forth in the valuable documents resulting from the technical work of the Organization of African Unity [OAU] and ECA and from the discussions of the Preparatory Committee for this special session.
7.	Africa has emerged from the decolonization process with disjointed economies incapable of laying the foundations of dynamic, self-sustained development, as a direct result of the various forms of colonial exploitation. Compounding the traumas and maladjustments that tend to accompany national independence processes, recent years have brought dramatically persistent natural events, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, where famine, death and destruction have spread across the entire continent—not to mention the alarming desertification process, which not only imposes a heavy burden on the present but also undermines the foundations of any future development. 8. Within this complex of problems, the continent, like all of us, has felt the effects of an unjust international economic order which thwarts all development efforts. We all know the signs: high interest rates applied to debts, often incurred to service other debts; spectacular drops in the prices of raw materials, the African countries’ main source of foreign earnings; unfair competition in the international markets, as a consequence of agricultural policies in the industrialized countries which undermine— if not paralyze—all our efforts to expand agricultural exports; shrinking capital investment and the international community’s inability to provide the region with the resources required for accelerated development.
9.	But Africa’s problems are not just economic and social; they are more than natural disasters: we wish to stress again that they are also the unjust and inhuman effects of apartheid imposed by racist policies which not only slow death and destruction, but further inhibit the economic and social development of countries suffering the effects of the legitimate struggles against racial discrimination in the region. Uruguay takes this occasion to reiterate its strongest condemnation and repudiation of these policies, as well as its solidarity with Botswana, Zaire and Zimbabwe, recent victims of attacks against the most elementary norms of international law, morality and civilized coexistence.
10.	In keeping with our repudiation of racism, Uruguay has just signed the International Convention against Apartheid in Sports [resolution 40/64 G, annex].
11.	We reiterate our call for compliance with United Nations mandates designed to ensure the independence and sovereignty of Namibia within the framework of the norms approved by the overwhelming majority of the international community.
12.	In this respect, we must be very clear: as long as these problems persist it will be very difficult to generate on the African continent an authentic relationship of cooperation among African States which will allow the advancement of effective development policies. Without peace, without respect for human rights in the region,
113
A/S-13/PV.5
it will be impossible for Africa to devote its energies to promoting truly just and balanced development. That is the contradiction most African countries find themselves in today.
13.	On the basis of the record only too well known, the competent bodies of the OAU, with the co-operation of each of the African States, have provided us with a valuable document.1 It is based on factual information encompassing the national, subregional and regional aspects of the problem. It analyses frankly, maturely—I would say even courageously—the nature of the African development crisis, as well as that rich, vast continent’s development potential, with all its immense untapped spiritual, material, human and cultural and other resources.
14.	Taking these clear and precise diagnoses as their starting point, the African countries have come to these deliberations committed to doing all they can to attack the root causes of the crisis, which demands the adoption of difficult and painful internal measures for structural transformation, modernization and improved efficiency in the management of their economic policies. The developing countries have been accused more than once of evading their own responsibilities by blaming all their problems on the operation of the international economic order. That is certainly an over-simplification. Such criticism, though often an oblique way in which the rich countries evade their own responsibilities, is not well-founded.
15.	The Africans have come up with ideas and programmes; they have evinced the political will to embark upon their own domestic tasks, implicitly acknowledging failings or errors of policy that might have existed in the past. We fully share the priority given to agriculture, the basis for sound development plans. Nothing can be of greater priority in Africa today than food production. Yet there must also be a bold campaign against the agonizing processes of desertification. Moreover, only through active preparation and training of human resources will it be possible to defend policies of structural change in the region to achieve dynamic and self-sustained development.
16.	We know, from our own experience, how frustrating and restricted one’s own effort is when circumstances are not propitious or when they are openly adverse to the ripening of such efforts.
