The African countries’ acceptance of their responsibility for the development of their continent and their declared will to attack the root causes of poverty and backwardness will not achieve the desired results without a simultaneous change in external factors inconsistent with the will of the countries affected, so as to create an international climate in which the national and regional efforts of the developing countries may bear fruit. The unjust prices paid to developing countries for their commodities, the deterioration in the terms of trade, high interest rates, the foreign debt burden, which increased more than sevenfold in Africa between 1974 and 1985, protectionism and trade restrictions are all factors outside the will of our countries and that of Africa and represent a critical dimension of the crisis, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Senegal, Mr. Fall, has said.
17.	Within that perspective, the duties of the international community are clearly defined. The African economies, as studies have shown, are at the mercy of the vicissitudes generated by those numerous external factors; they are tremendously dependent on them and cannot attain self-sufficient, self-sustained development by their own efforts alone.
18.	The words of President Sanguinetti at the 6th meeting of the fortieth session of the General Assembly are particularly relevant. He said:
“It is short-sighted and insensitive to believe that the only factors which have placed the debtor developing countries in this vertiginous spiral of debt that generates further debt are lack of responsibility on the part of those countries, their poor administration and their lack of foresight . . .
“If the industrialized countries persist in denying the real origin and nature of these problems, if they do not shoulder their share of responsibility for the situation that prevails in the developing world, if they do not become less inflexible with regard to just demands for more equitable treatment, all our sacrifice will be a forlorn, wasted effort and there will be no reason for optimism regarding the survival of democracy.’’
The international community must therefore help Africa to find specific, concrete solutions for the external factors beyond its control.
19.	Some initiatives have already been taken in the realm of international financial institutions such as the World Bank, IMF and IDA, but, given the magnitude of the problem, we believe that those initiatives are not enough. Important complementary financial resources on preferential, soft terms are required urgently. It is necessary to liberalize the harsh conditions imposed by the present economic and financial order, thus relieving the debt burden. The co-operation and assistance of the international community should complete the great efforts that the African countries have shown they are determined to make, and its contribution must be adjusted to their needs.
20.	We must also be very clear in this respect: the international community is assuming a responsibility that is its duty and that cannot be fulfilled at the price of extranational forms of guidance or tutelage regarding the development of each country or any type of interference in the sovereign decisions of States, which alone must guide their own destiny, and the focus which—without prejudice to the assistance they deem pertinent—they wish to give to their development process. The international community must shoulder its share of responsibility in this new state of international relations characterized by interdependence and the need for co-operation, taking the measures that it should to maintain peace and stability in international relations and strengthen justice, the source of peace.
21.	We, the developing countries, must also recognize our responsibility. Uruguay gives high priority to trade and relations of co-operation between developing countries. Much of its external trade is guided by this. We believe that in the present circumstances South-South cooperation, including such co-operation in the field of technology, must be a valuable instrument, repeatedly called for at this special session, in the recovery and development of Africa. We are prepared to collaborate in these initiatives.
22.	The contribution and assistance of the international community is inspired, naturally, by an ideal of human solidarity, but solidarity is not a gift but a duty. The basis of that contribution is a reciprocal commitment based on the principle of the legal equality of States and mutual interest. It is in this spirit that we are here, knowing that this is one more challenge that the United Nations must face in carrying out its mission to preserve and maintain international peace and security; to foster friendly relations among nations based on mutual respect; to promote the development of peoples, which, as Pope Paul VI said, is the new name of peace; and to achieve international co-operation.
23.	This session provides us with an opportunity to respond effectively and efficiently to that challenge and to demonstrate concretely, as was said by the Foreign Minister of Senegal in a statement in the Preparatory Committee for this special session, “our common will to live in common”.
24.	I wish to close my statement with a final thought. This session should be something more in the life of the United Nations. It should be a challenge to the very existence of the United Nations as a forum for solidarity and co-operation. At a time when there is widespread weariness and disbelief regarding its virtues and potential, when interests of all kinds assail the principles of sound multilateralism that it has been so hard to build over the 40 years of the Organization’s existence, when the upheavals in the world economy are particularly evident as it lavishes progress and well-being on a few while incapable of generating equality of opportunities for a developing world, in these difficult times arises this opportunity, precisely for a continent that harbours the most dramatic areas of poverty and misery in the world. 25. The success of this special session will be a breath of fresh air in the atmosphere of disbelief in which we move today in this Organization. We hope that it will bring forth concrete and effective decisions and truly rise to this challenge.
26.	Uruguay, a developing country, unassuming and beset by severe problems of its own, feels united with the African peoples by common interests and aspirations. Within the limits of its possibilities and in the spirit of South-South co-operation, in which it has always believed, it is prepared to add its effort to make this special session the beginning of a new, fruitful stage in the era of international co-operation.
27.	Mr. NOORANI (Pakistan): The convening of this five-day special session of the General Assembly is an important step towards redressing the serious economic problems of Africa, which came into sharp focus as a result of the persistent drought and famine conditions obtaining in many parts of that continent. The grave conditions in the famine-stricken areas evoked an extraordinary response all over the world and galvanized the international community to provide emergency assistance on an unprecedented scale to ameliorate the hardship and suffering of the afflicted people.
28.	The most important response to the crisis has come from the African countries themselves. It is they that have resolved to take concerted action to improve the wellbeing of the people of Africa and to initiate processes which will promote self-reliance and ensure the sustained growth of their economy. They are to be congratulated on drawing up a bold and comprehensive plan, embodied in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 which was adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity in July 1985.
29.	This Priority Programme provides a comprehensive framework for structural as well as medium- and longterm solutions. It is predicated on a new development approach for Africa and an improved framework for international co-operation. Full implementation of this Programme can bring about the necessary economic development, ensuring the well-being, prosperity and future progress of the African people.
30.	While delivering the keynote address at this special session on behalf of the OAU at the 1st meeting, President Diouf of Senegal presented a detailed account of the difficulties which have seriously undermined every effort to break the vicious circle of underdevelopment in the
African continent. Africa remains in the grip of a persistent economic crisis which forces tens of millions of its inhabitants to live on the edge of hunger and starvation. The President of Senegal courageously acknowledged mistakes in the past economic policies pursued in Africa which contributed to the present predicament and the chronic economic difficulties of the continent. At the same time he lifted our spirits with a note of optimism based on the determination of the African States to launch a programme for economic recovery and rehabilitation and to mobilize all their resources to ensure its successful achievement.
31.	Being a developing country ourselves, we have studied the African development programme with great care. In this regard we have noted the important emphasis which the Priority Programme places on agriculture and food production. Indeed, this sector is vital for a self-reliant economy and for ensuring the well-being of the people. A gigantic and sustained effort and great sacrifices are required on the part of the African States, to achieve the goals and objectives that they have set for themselves. Africa’s laudable undertaking to help itself creates a corresponding obligation on the part of the international community to supplement this massive indigenous effort, since the world as a whole has a stake in its success.
32.	The nature and magnitude of the efforts necessary to reverse the crisis in Africa and the extent to which international co-operation is required to achieve this aim have been outlined in the OAU documentation and the draft basic final document, entitled “United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery, 1986-1990” [A/S-13/4 and Corr.l, annex V]. According to this documentation, the total financial requirement for the successful implementation of the Priority Programme is $128 billion over the five-year period. The African States have indicated that they will themselves raise $82 billion, or nearly 64 per cent of the total resources required, from the mobilization and more effective use of their own domestic resources. The remaining $46 billion will have to be generated from outside by way of contributions from the international community. The present special session provides an opportunity to extend the necessary assurances to the African countries in regard to the availability of external resources consistent with the international community’s determination to rid the world of the scourge of poverty and hunger.
33.	In addition to the specific financial requirements stipulated in the Priority Programme, Africa needs international assistance to enable it to implement existing development programmes and policies. In this context it is self-evident that the African States need action on the part of the international community to provide relief from their heavy debt-servicing burden. If the. problem of African debt and its heavy servicing is not redressed urgently, the success of the Priority Programme will be in serious jeopardy.
34.	In an inspiring response to Africa’s needs, people all over the world have joined in spontaneous rallies to express support for and solidarity with Africa and to raise funds to help the people in the afflicted areas. This great effort calls for a matching commitment on the part of Governments all over the world. The decisions at this session must reflect the same concern and resolve. Timely and effective action at this session to help our African brothers to overcome their current economic difficulties can substantially reduce the burden of hard-pressed Governments in Africa and set an unprecedented example of international co-operation and collective willingness to
employ all available resources to combat adversity in any part of the world and thus ensure a life of dignity for all mankind. Relying on their own talent and resources, the African States are making a determined bid to overcome the many problems which they have inherited from their colonial past. In this undertaking they feel justified in expecting the international community to come forward with unstinted support.
35.	The concepts of universal brotherhood and the unity of mankind are deeply ingrained in the belief of the people of Pakistan. We respond easily to suffering in any part of the world. The persistent drought and famine in Africa, which have claimed hundreds of thousands of precious lives, move us deeply. Within our very limited resources, we have extended substantial assistance to African countries in the form of emergency relief and long-term technical assistance.
36.	In 1985 Pakistan extended humanitarian food assistance, with an estimated value of $4 million, to a number of African countries. Under its technical assistance programme, Pakistan provides training facilities to African nations on a regular basis in the fields of civil aviation, banking, railways, medicine, energy, engineering and agriculture. We hope soon to be able to establish an African technical assistance programme especially designed to provide more systematic and long-term assistance to the African countries, especially in the agriculture, irrigation and livestock sectors. I take this opportunity to reassure our African brethren that the Government and people of Pakistan stand ready to do everything within their means to assist them in their courageous efforts to achieve economic recovery and development.
37.	Before concluding, I should like to emphasize the role that the international organizations within the United Nations system can play in mobilizing and channelling both emergency and long-term developmental assistance to the African countries. During the past two years efforts concentrated on emergency requirements for Africa have led to the development of a new alliance between peoples, Governments and the United Nations system, bringing into being a process of practical consultations and collaboration which has saved the lives of millions. It is essential that we maintain this alliance in the future as we deal with both the continuing emergency situation and the equally urgent problem of rehabilitation and development.
38.	The fundamental problem of long-term development can be addressed most effectively by an integrated approach and a sense of collective urgency on the part of the international community as a whole. Experience shows that situations of economic crisis in the past have been overcome by such an approach. Emergency aid, recovery and development programmes must be viewed as a continuum. To fail to recognize that is to condemn millions of our fellow human beings to a vicious cycle of poverty and deprivation.
39.	An effective response by the international community to the current economic crisis in Africa is no less important than the endeavours of the African countries themselves to achieve self-sustained economic development. It is, therefore, imperative that this special session extend its full support to the initiative taken by the African States themselves and evolve a set of international measures and financial commitments vitally needed to supplement their efforts to implement the Priority Programme designed to overcome the critical economic situation in Africa.
40.	Mr. IACOVOU (Cyprus): May I, Mr. President, at the outset echo the sentiments of those delegations that have preceded me in expressing satisfaction at seeing you
presiding over this special session. Your experience and wisdom will once again guide this body towards fruitful and concrete discussion and action. Both are essential if Africa is at last to embark on the road to self-sustained development.
41.	Our meeting here this week is historic. It is clear evidence that the economic and social crisis that has had a stranglehold on the continent of Africa is cause for grave concern to us all. It is also a clear signal of solidarity with the people of Africa.
42.	The interdependent nature of the world today inescapably dictates that when one nation or region is affected by events, we are all in some way affected. Today the continent of Africa is in the midst of a severe crisis . This was acutely manifested during the height of the drought-induced emergency of 1983-1985 that plagued the continent. The spontaneous expressions of solidarity by the international community, though much needed, were but a temporary respite in the crisis. This year again, about 19 million African people will be affected by drought and hunger. Emergency relief is therefore still absolutely essential.
43.	The situation existing today has strengthened the resolve of African countries, both individually and collectively, to take into their own hands the economic recovery of the continent. No clearer resolve has been shown than in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the African Heads of State and Government at Addis Ababa last year. However, Africa’s long road to development needs the support, solidarity and commitment of the international community. Without constructive interdependent action there can be no solution to Africa’s needs for its medium-and long-term development.
44.	As many African delegations have stated, the Priority Programme is what Africa needs to lead it from the burden of structural inequalities towards long-term structural transformation. The potential for human advancement in Africa is abundant; yet it has thus far been stifled. This is indeed a sad reflection of the world we live in, where a continent with great natural and human capabilities coexists with famine, illiteracy and destitution, as eloquently stated by the President of the Republic of Senegal and current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, Mr. Diouf, in his inspiring opening address.
45.	African countries themselves have recognized that there exist internal constraints which have produced major social and economic distortions in Africa’s development. These have been recognized, and through the Priority Programme action will be taken to rectify them. These efforts have our full support. However, these internal constraints cannot be looked at in isolation. The finger of responsibility cannot be pointed solely at the Governments and peoples of Africa. Factors outside the control of those Governments and peoples have had a catastrophic effect on the magnitude of the critical economic situation. The international recession, the collapse in commodity prices, which in real terms are at the lowest level since 1940, the adverse terms of trade, the decline in real terms in official development assistance, increased protectionism, high interest rates, currency fluctuations and the heavy burden of debt—as well as debt servicing, which has had a debilitating effect on African economies —have all aggravated the crisis.
46.	Much discussion has been devoted to the question of an appropriate policy framework for the development of Africa. It is my delegation’s firm belief that the African countries should be enabled to determine their own
priorities, in accordance with the specific nuances of their own social, economic and political circumstances. We believe that there is a consensus emerging internationally that the problems of Africa must be addressed in a spirit of compromise and interdependence. The Priority Programme, we feel, has emerged as a well-thought-out, coordinated programme that will guide Africa towards economic recovery.
47.	We are greatly impressed and encouraged by the special place given to food and agriculture in the Priority Programme. It is primarily agriculture that is the lifeline of many millions of African people. This crucial element has led the African Governments to commit themselves to 'allocating 20 to 25 per cent of public investment to agriculture and to strengthen the support sectors of agriculture. Parallel to this is the simultaneous need to accelerate industrial development.
48.	We have seen that in the fight both for mediumterm and for long-term alleviation of the crisis, Africans are helping themselves. However, it must also be clear to us all that they will not be able to see their development dreams fulfilled without our concrete support. A new partnership must emerge that will lead Africa towards self-sustained development. It is imperative that there be an immediate improvement of the external environment and structural changes in the global economic system. It is of central importance that there be relief from that crushing debt burden that has weighed' and is weighing so heavily on the shoulders of African countries and their economies. Relief should be coupled with an essential increase in concessional assistance from both Governments and multilateral financial institutions so that the Priority Programme may be implemented. .
49.	The Government of the Republic of Cyprus expresses its full solidarity with the peoples of Africa. They have shown us individually and collectively their unshakeable resolve to undertake urgently measures that will lead to a substantial improvement in the well-being of their people. The question that we must all ask is: are we, the international community, ready to join them in their commitment? The time has come for the brotherly support heard in this Hall to be echoed throughout the continent of Africa.
50.	Mr. GOTSEV (Bulgaria) (interpretation from Russian): It is with profound and sincere concern for the fate of millions of people on the African continent that the delegation of the People’s Republic of Bulgaria has come here to participate in this special session of the General Assembly. We are guided by our understanding of the seriousness of the matter and our desire to help, within our means, to resolve Africa’s medium- and long-term development issues.
51.	To achieve those goals it will be necessary, first, to tackle and eliminate the root causes of the difficulties that have brought the majority of the population of the African countries to the brink of a sub-human existence. Analysis of those causes demonstrates objectively that they are complex and intricate.
52.	The countries of the African continent are among the youngest independent States. The majority have been developing in conditions of political independence for no more than 20 to 25 years. They continue to suffer the heavy legacy of colonialism in all areas of life. For long years, in pursuit of their selfish interests, the former metropolitan countries imposed on Africa the development of a stunted, single-crop economy, based on raw materials or agricultural produce, and turned the colonies into their raw-material appendages.
53.	After the collapse of the colonial system imperialism succeeded in establishing a new system of neo-colonial exploitation through various political manoeuvres, blackmail and frequent direct interference in the internal affairs of other countries, including the use of various economic levers. A system of unequal international economic relations was imposed on the developing countries. That system is characterized by growing protectionism and discrimination in trade policy and practice, refusal to introduce overdue structural reforms in the world capitalist economy, large-scale use of economic measures as instruments of political and economic pressure and so on. At the same time, the developed capitalist countries continue their efforts to transfer the burden resulting from the crisis of the capitalist economy to the developing countries.
54.	More covert methods of economic burglary have been introduced in the guise of good intentions and concern for the plight of the developing countries. For example, world statistics show that a substantial part of the national income of the United States and some other imperialist countries is derived from neo-colonialist exploitation, the main conduits of which are the transnational corporations, which each year extract enormous wealth from Africa. Neo-colonialist exploitation, which is particularly acute in the field of monetary and financial relations, has aggravated the debt problem of the developing countries, whose indebtedness has now grown to over $1,000 billion. For the African countries alone it is nearly $200 billion. The debt problem of the African countries is demonstrated by the fact that it has adversely affected the already low rate of growth of their social and economic development. For some countries the foreign debt has surpassed the volume of their gross national product.
55.	Analysis has shown that if the present inequitable relations in the world capitalist economy are maintained, the developing countries will be unable to resolve the debt problem without sacrificing their economic development for an indefinite period. This has created a real threat of political and economic tension in the developing countries, which could have serious social, economic and political implications for international relations. There is now no doubt that the debt problem is no longer a purely economic matter and that its solution will require political efforts.
56.	The international community is well aware that the critical economic situation in the African countries has been further aggravated by the aggressive and expansionist policy of imperialism. Imperialist forces have been attempting to prolong the existing armed conflicts in Africa and to foment new ones. They do not even stop at direct military intervention. We were shocked by the armed aggression against sovereign Libya. Nor is it any secret that imperialism has been supporting forces whose aim is to overthrow the legitimate Governments of certain countries.
57.	Another important reason for the critical economic situation in a number of African countries is the policy and practice of apartheid of the racist régime of the Republic of South Africa. As is emphasized in the Declaration on the Economic Situation in Africa,3 adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity at its twenty-first session, South Africa has been carrying out a policy of economic and military destabilization of the States of southern Africa. A recent brazen demonstration of that, and a serious challenge to all mankind, was the criminal raids by South Africa on Zimbabwe, Zambia and
Botswana. There is no end to the racists’ acts of aggression against Angola or to their support for the bandit groups in Mozambique.
58.	Influenced by world imperialism’s policy of blackmail, conspiracy and open armed intervention, many African countries have been drawn into an arms race which has forced them to squander enormous material and financial resources.
59.	The problem of the critical economic situation in Africa has been discussed in many international forums. Recently, for example, it was discussed at Sofia, where, at an international meeting with representatives of 126 political parties and organizations, including 32 from African countries, the President of the Council of State of the People’s Republic of Bulgaria, Todor Zhivkov, said, “Responsibility for economic underdevelopment, poverty and the existing acute social problems in the majority of developing countries rests, above all, with imperialism.” 60. The Declaration on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa adopted by the General Assembly states that “the maintenance of peace and security and the strengthening of international co-operation are important for meeting the challenge of development” [resolution 39/29, annex, para. 8]. We share that position and would even go further by saying that it is crucial for development in general and for overcoming many problems throughout the world.
61.	The realistic approach to the maintenance of peace is to end the arms race, prevent its extension to outer space and gradually deliver mankind first from nuclear weapons and then from all other means of destruction. The member States of the Warsaw Treaty Organization have put forward a number of initiatives to that end.
62.	Of particular importance is the programme for the elimination of nuclear weapons by the year 2000, which was set forth by Mikhail Gorbachev on 15 January this year. The implementation of that programme would lay a solid foundation for the solution of many economic problems and furnish new and truly great opportunities for increasing the level and improving the terms of financial and economic assistance to the developing countries. Herein lies the overriding significance of the principle of disarmament with regard to development. Proceeding on that basis, the People’s Republic of Bulgaria is in favour of holding the International Conference on the Relationship between Disarmament and Development at the time already agreed.
63.	Of primary importance in resolving the problems of the African countries are the restructuring of international economic relations on a just, democratic basis, stabilization of the general economic, monetary and financial situation and implementation of United Nations decisions, in particular the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States [resolution 3281 (XXIX)] and the Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order [resolution 3201 (S-VI)]. In that connection, we support the idea of establishing a system of international security, including economic security, which would ensure conditions for the normal development of all peoples. We also support the convening of a world congress on the problems of economic security, which could give thorough consideration to the factors that have been hindering international economic ties.
64.	The press release circulated at this session by the Bulgarian delegation attests to the principled approach taken by the People’s Republic of Bulgaria in developing its relations with the African countries. Our co-operation will continue to be aimed at the over-all development of their national economies by means of setting up projects
in agriculture, industry, energy production, expansion of the transportation infrastructure and training. More than 7,000 African specialists have been trained in my country’s educational establishments, while over 2,000 young people from the African continent are now studying there. More than 10,000 Bulgarian experts are sharing their experience in various areas of the economic life of African countries.
65.	For a country with its economic potential, the People’s Republic of Bulgaria has provided substantial assistance to developing countries. Approximately two thirds of that assistance is channelled to Africa. The volume of such assistance in 1985 alone was 0.88 per cent of the country’s gross national product [GNP]. Also, since 1984 Bulgaria has deferred payment on the credits and other financial obligations of a number of African countries amounting to more than $100 million.
66.	The People’s Republic of Bulgaria is convinced that the total mobilization of national resources on the basis of long-term development planning and strengthening the public sector of the economy are crucial for achieving progress in the socio-economic area. In this context we support the basic positions taken by the OAU in the Lagos Plan of Action4 and in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.1
67.	The People’s Republic of Bulgaria consistently upholds the principle of solidarity and will continue to support, in so far as it is able, the aspirations of the African countries for independent and progressive socioeconomic development.
68.	Mr. ELHINDI (Sudan) (interpretation from Arabic): I am honoured to speak before the General Assembly on behalf of the African continent on a question that is foremost among our concerns, namely, drought and desertification. Before briefly reviewing the reasons for and consequences of that drought and desertification, as well as the solutions proposed to combat them, I should like to express to you, Mr. President, and to Mr. Lewis, representative of Canada, our congratulations on your unanimous elections to lead our work at this important special session.
69.	It might be appropriate to begin by answering a basic question: Why, indeed, does Africa attach such importance to the question of drought and desertification, and why has it made the combating of those conditions one of its most urgent priorities and brought it before the international community as represented here in the General Assembly? Drought and desertification are two phenomena that are not unique to Africa, as their destructive consequences extend to every continent of the world and affect a very large number of countries, both rich and poor, to varying degrees.
70.	The answer to the question includes a number of factors, foremost among which undoubtedly is the fact that over the past few years the consequences of drought and desertification have been the final straw that has broken the back of African economies, causing great upheavals in the lives of most of the continent’s population. Consecutive years of drought and its spread to include the countries of the east and south of the continent, in addition to the countries of the Sudano-Sahelian belt, which extend from the Red Sea to the Atlantic Ocean and which have been experiencing drought since the late 1960s, have had a profound effect on livestock and food production and have turned the situation into a catastrophe afflicting the entire continent and created a famine threatening the lives of half of its population, uprooting millions from their homes and forcing them to migrate to the fringes of the cities in search of food. They have
seriously crippled the economies of the rural areas, probably for years to come. The drought has spread to many areas of the continent, accompanied by spreading desertification which annually advances nearly 10 kilometres over land suitable for agriculture and grazing. Land is the basic asset of the rural population, who are the majority of Africa’s population and the producers of its food and the pillars of its economies.
71.	It was thus only natural that the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity last year listed the questions of drought and desertification as among the most pressing priorities, since they are vitally linked to the productive sectors, foremost among which are food, agriculture and rural development, and have a direct effect on the lives and economies of the population of rural areas and intensify the degradation of the environment in the region. Drought and desertification also drain the land of its fertility and destroy the vegetation cover, threatening rural energy sources, ground and surface water and thus the lives of both people and livestock.
72.	The OAU Assembly, by setting the issues of drought and desertification among Africa’s highest priorities, affirmed a basic fact which can usefully be reaffirmed here. There is no way for Africa to get out of its current economic crisis other than by assigning prime importance to the food and agriculture sector, and the food sector, which is foremost among African priorities, cannot stand unless there is development in rural areas and concern for their population. That, in turn, cannot be accomplished in most African countries unless the consequences of drought and desertification are combated, desert encroachment stopped and the overall ecological balance preserved.
73.	I wish to mention briefly some of the causes of desertification and degradation of the environment, because finding the sources of the problem will help us to find appropriate solutions. The basic cause of desertification can be traced to the irrational use of natural resources, in particular on the margins of the Sahara and in the poor savannah area. Excessive agriculture exhausts the soil, overgrazing eliminates the vegetation cover and cutting down trees to provide fuel for both the rural areas and the cities loosens the soil. Poor use of water resources in rural areas, burning off the pastures after prolonged drought and other irrational human activities lead to an ecological imbalance and breakdown, as seen in the impoverishment of the soil, reduction of its productivity, loss of its cohesion and its desertification. All this can be linked to social and economic roots, including persistent negligence of the rural areas, mismanagement, the population explosion, a change in consumption patterns due to different and increased requirements, the irrational increase in livestock, and the fact that the afflicted regions are included in the economic, monetary and trade cycle.
74.	From this brief review of the causes and roots of desertification and ecological imbalance resulting from human activity and linked to the scarcity of rain, it is clear that comprehensive action on a broad front is necessary to combat drought and desertification and maintain the ecological balance, including legal, social, economic and political measures that take into account all the elements and causes I have mentioned. The ideal way to deal with the consequences of drought and to combat desertification in Africa requires the following basic guidelines.
75.	First, a scientific approach must take into account the comprehensive character of the problem and the need to persevere and avoid partial solutions.
76.	Secondly, the question of desertification and drought must be dealt with within a clear strategy based on integrated development of the areas affected.
77.	Thirdly, solutions must include preventive measures by the enactment of the necessary laws prohibiting the cutting down of trees and agricultural expansion in marginal areas, protecting pastures and forests and providing remedial measures, such as planting tree belts, sowing grass and stabilizing sand dunes.
78.	Fourthly, popular participation must be encouraged as much as possible in both remedial and preventive measures and in finding solutions compatible with the environment and social and economic conditions of each area, thus guaranteeing the continuing participation, understanding and co-operation of the population of the affected areas, without which protecting the environment and maintaining ecological balance is impossible.
79.	Fifthly, scientific research must be intensified and its results applied, in particular, to developing droughtresistant trees, plants and crops suitable for regions where there is little rain, and to the most effective use of new and renewable sources of energy, in finding substitutes for firewood or in increasing the efficiency of firewood and other traditional sources of energy, so as to reduce the pressure on natural resources in the marginal areas concerned and the poverty and physical exertion of the rural population, especially women.
80.	Sixthly, efforts must be made to increase awareness of and training in environmental matters, particularly among women, who constitute the majority of the farmers in Africa and are responsible for the provision of water, housing and fuel and for tending the herds.
81.	Seventhly, regional and subregional co-operation is necessary in Africa to combat desertification and drought through the establishment of regional facilities to coordinate the efforts of African States, particularly since these two phenomena have no geographical limits, and also to co-ordinate the implementation of joint projects and establish regional research institutions to rationalize the use of resources, profit from experiences acquired and facilitate the exchange of experiences and information.
82.	Eighthly, international co-operation must be harnessed to support African national and regional efforts to combat drought and desertification, in particular, and protect the environment in general. This co-operation must be used to mobilize the necessary financial resources, exchange information and experiences, transfer appropriate technology and the results of scientific research and participate in the creation of the trained cadres needed to set up and implement the programmes to combat drought and desertification. In that context it is necessary to support the efforts of the African States to set up early warning systems in Africa to enable the continent to face the dangers of drought and desertification in a scientific manner.
83.	Ninthly, since projects and programmes to combat drought and desertification are medium-term and longterm, the necessary financial resources must be made available for their implementation in a predictable, dependable manner, to facilitate planning. These financial resources can be mobilized on two levels: first, on the local and national level, as a reaffirmation of the principle of popular participation and local concern; and secondly, on the international level, to provide the resources necessary to implement the programmes and projects to combat desertification. ,
84.	Here, we must pay a tribute to the statements ar.d positive initiatives presented by some delegations duris?
this debate to help Africa avoid the effects of drought and desertification. The welcome efforts made by the non-governmental organizations in this regard deserve support, thanks and appreciation.
85.	This is the analysis of the causes, roots and consequences of drought and desertification and of the basic tenets on which any radical solution must depend. Africa attaches great importance to this problem, which directly threatens not only its chances of overcoming its current economic crisis and remedying the ecological imbalance in very large parts of the continent, but also the lives of millions of African people, as has been made clear by the experience of the 1970s in West Africa and the 1980s in most parts of the continent. That is why the twenty-first session of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity made drought and desertification one of the basic priorities in its Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 19861990.2 Despite the fact that the struggle against drought and desertification requires long-term plans, the African summit conference and ministerial meetings convened to prepare for this special session decided that it is essential to take action immediately on the national, regional and continental levels to implement a comprehensive programme to combat drought and desertification, encompassing definite preventive and remedial measures in protection of the environment, the rational use of natural resources, especially water sources, pastures and forests, afforestation and reforestation to stabilize the soil and the development of alternative sources of energy, in particular in the rural areas.
86.	Africa is fully aware that the implementation of such an urgent programme demands an enormous national effort, as well as close co-operation on the regional level and continuing support by the international community for those national and regional efforts. The African Governments have adopted national plans to combat drought and desertification. They have established or support facilities that co-ordinate efforts in this area and have committed themselves to providing the local resources to implement existing plans.
87.	On the regional level, in recognition of the role of regional co-operation in combating drought and desertification, last year saw the establishment of the Intergovernmental Authority for Drought and Development, which includes the East African States and is headquartered in Djibouti. It is based on the example of the Permanent Inter-State Committee on Drought Control in the Sahel, based in Ouagadougou. Further, there is a large number of regional organizations concerned with more comprehensive matters, including the struggle against drought, such as the Southern African Development Coordination Conference and other institutions created to protect African lakes and river basins, in whose activities the environmental aspect is an important element. I also wish to note the importance of the African Ministerial Conference on the Environment, convened last December at Cairo by UNEP, and of its resolutions. We look forward to the donor countries providing the necessary assistance to implement that important programme.
88.	On the international level, the African estimates made it clear that the implementation of the urgent regional and national programme needs almost $3.5 billion for the next five years, of which the African States have committed themselves to providing $1.5 billion. That leaves some $2 billion to be provided by external sources. It must be mentioned here that the comprehensive plan of action to combat drought and desertification in Africa needs enormous financial resources that go far beyond
the estimated funds and that the figures mentioned in the African document represent the minimum needed for the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990.
89.	Despite the fact that Africa’s implementation of programmes to combat drought and desertification is not conditional on international support, everyone knows that those programmes are less likely to succeed in the absence of continuing financial support from the international community. Hence, in the light of the international consensus on the gravity of the African economic crisis in general, and the gravity of drought and desertification in particular, Africa expects that the international community will—at the bilateral and multilateral levels— exert special efforts to provide the external financial resources necessary for the success of the programmes to combat drought and desertification. Africa also expects that the various United Nations organizations and programmes will contribute effectively in supporting the efforts of African States to combat drought and desertification and that the number of such organizations will grow and enhance the contribution of the United Nations in Africa instead of weakening and impeding the effectiveness of the common efforts. .
90.	Finally, I wish to borrow a phrase heard repeatedly throughout the past week: “Africa is in a race against time, a feverish race to survive and to develop”. Those words are applicable to the problem of drought and desertification in particular, since Africa is in a real race against the constantly creeping desert and against drought that is killing the vegetation and desertification that is transforming fertile land into a wasteland. Africa is resolved to win that race; it has harnessed its energies and resources to achieve that goal. The duty of the international community, as represented in the Assembly, is to provide all the necessary support for Africa to win that race.
91.	Mr. FLORES OLEA (Mexico) (interpretation from Spanish): Mr. President, the delegation of Mexico would like to join those who have already congratulated you on your assumption of the task entrusted to you by the General Assembly at this special session. Your able guidance and diplomatic experience will help us attain results that will permit the mitigation of the present critical situation in the continent of Africa.
92.	Our solidarity with Africa is profound. For years we have struggled together for peace, and we continue to strive to preserve our political and economic independence. We have faced similar problems and promoted common aspirations. We have joined forces in the quest for a more just and equitable system of international relations, a system that can provide our people with a better hope for development and well-being.
93.	We are strong supporters of the African countries in their struggle against apartheid, a system that is contrary to the most elementary human rights and the principles of civilized coexistence. Unfortunately, in spite of the efforts of the United Nations, apartheid continues to be an odious system that oppresses our South African brothers and shames the community of nations. At the end of the twentieth century we cannot tolerate that outrageous abuse which still persists through force in southern Africa.
94.	Mexico recently condemned South Africa’s attacks against the territories of Zimbabwe, Botswana and Zambia.
95.	Mexico takes pride in taking part in this decisive session on Africa. For the first time the General Assembly has met in a special session to examine the economic
situation of a whole continent. We are witness to a major event in international life and an historic milestone in multilateral diplomacy. The political will of the world community now has the opportunity to turn this meeting into a victory for economic development co-operation and peace in accordance with the principles of the Charter. 96. Africa has felt the impact of the crisis in a serious way. Falling commodity prices have been accompanied by growing protectionism in the developed countries, by international financial and monetary disorder and by the burden of foreign debt. But Africa has also suffered in recent times unprecedented drought and desertification. 97. We the Member States are fully conscious of the stakes: the economic and political future of an enormous continent which accounts for one fourth of the world’s land surface and, above all, the lives of a great number of human beings, who by the end of the century will number close to 900 million. A universe of men, women and children that has seen its existence challenged by natural disasters, drought, desertification, the terrible aftermath of colonialism, and, recently, by an international economic recession.
98.	Confronted with the greatest economic crisis ever faced by any region of the planet, Africa today has turned to the United Nations in search of solidarity and action. Although the most urgent needs of the situation that prevailed from 1982 to 1985 have been partially alleviated, the profound crisis of the continent requires concerted world action to rehabilitate and restore as soon as possible its capacity for growth and development.
99.	Twenty-five years after the independence of the majority of the African countries, and in spite of the great efforts made, the basic structure of the continent’s economic relations has not yet been substantially transformed. National economies have become more vulnerable to changing external factors. We still find 60 to 80 per cent of GNP in the subsistence sector, and the result is that today one in five Africans depends on imported food. Africa’s foreign debt appears small compared to that of Latin America. However, in terms of income and exports, it is actually the highest among the developing countries. For the debtor countries of sub-Saharan Africa, debt represents about 50 per cent of their GNP.
100.	Between 1974 and 1985, the accumulated foreign debt of the region grew more than sevenfold, to $175 billion. Altogether, African Governments have rescheduled their debt more than 32 times over the past three years, and yet they still face a critical situation. The restructurings that have taken place, while they may have lightened the immediate burden, have increased the debt payments from approximately $4.3 billion per year between 1980 and 1982 to over $15 billion over the next five years. This situation, as explicitly recognized by the OAU, totally surpasses the means and repayment capacity of the African countries.
101.	Problems of underdevelopment cannot be solved exclusively from abroad. It is necessary to make enormous domestic efforts and to adopt the necessary internal measures to make economic headway. Nevertheless, the international community cannot elude its responsibilities and must assume its share of the costs.
102.	First of all, we must achieve better living conditions for all peoples and more just and equitable economic relations. Domestic efforts cannot sustain growth in debtor countries under adverse international conditions. Debt-servicing must be linked to the real capacity of each country to pay. No people can renounce its development and resign itself to recession. It is now time for the international community as a whole to recognize that the
payment of debt requires, as an indispensable condition, adequate growth and development and that this is impossible without opening the markets of the industrialized countries to our products. Those goals will not be reached without the adoption of concerted measures in the areas of money, finance and trade. The more we delay these necessary steps, the greater the suffering of our peoples will be and the greater the risk of seriously endangering the democratic structures established through the enormous efforts of our peoples.
103.	At stake is the harmony and stability of the world community. Without equitable economic and social development, without a just solution to national and regional problems, peace will be increasingly precarious, increasingly fragile.
104.	We vigorously support Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted at the twenty-first session of the OAU Assembly. The Programme encompasses the immediate recovery needs indispensable for attaining the long-term development goals and sustained development of the African nations.
105.	Africa’s Priority Programme is the j oint response of the Governments of Africa to the challenges of their countries’ immediate future. It reflects a political will at the highest level, flowing from the sovereign decision of States and their free will to undertake national actions with a specifically continental vocation. Its adoption clearly reveals the unquestionable decision of the peoples and Governments of Africa to exercise their own responsibility in the promotion and conduct of their development process: a free, autonomous and firm development in solidarity with the world community, which should respond with broad understanding to such unquestionable demands for justice.
106.	The Programme will require $128 billion for its implementation. The African nations have undertaken to provide, through enormous effort, 65 per cent of the funds needed. However, it is imperative that the international community fully activate the machinery for institutional and multilateral solidarity in order to channel $9.1 billion annually over the next five years towards underwriting the remaining 35 per cent.
107.	We have stressed that, given the extreme gravity of the situation, the proposals contained in the Priority Programme are but the first “common point of reference” of a broader series of international actions, to be taken together in order to redirect the economic life of the continent towards a renewal of its development process. That is how Mexico understands the unequivocal meaning of the African proposal to the General Assembly.
108.	Member States should now undertake the task of examining in depth and with a sense of respect, understanding and solidarity towards the nations of Africa the possibilities and machinery the world can and should implement in order to co-operate with them for the most successful outcome of their historic commitment to development. The Government of Mexico, as the representative of a sovereign State Member of the Organization, fully understands that the international community— by developing this draft United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery, 1986-1990 [A/S-13/4 andCorr.l, annex F], and, most certainly, in the process of its implementation, follow-up and review— is committing its best efforts to strengthening the independence, autonomy and sovereignty of the nations of the continent without new attempts to impose tutelage. This independence and autonomy have been won as a result of centuries of struggle against political oppression and natural adversity.
109.	We wish to point out that at the annual academic seminar of Latin American and African students, which is now taking place in the capital of my country, it has been proposed—yesterday, in fact—that the General Assembly should proclaim 1987 as the Year for International Co-operation with Africa. We very much hope that this suggestion will elicit a favourable response from the international community.
110.	We should make full use of the opportunity offered by this special session and make the necessary political commitments. We must make use of our collective political will to identify the measures that will make it possible to overcome the critical situation in Africa.
111.	Mutual respect and the conviction that only when we are united will we be able to build a new system of international relations based on justice and equity should provide the framework for our deliberations. Each country, on the basis of its own historical experience, defines its own path. That path should be respected by others and should receive the necessary support, especially when it coincides and identifies completely with the purposes and goals of the San Francisco Charter.
112.	My delegation reiterates that Mexico is ready to serve this noble cause, within the limits of its possibilities, in order to ensure the success of this session, the result of which should be a better future option for Africa and the developing world.
113.	Mr. HOANG BICH SON (Viet Nam) (interpretation from French): First, on behalf of the delegation of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, I wish to convey to the President and the members of the General Committee my warmest congratulations on their election to the leadership of this special session of the General Assembly. I am confident that under their expert and talented guidance this session will prove fruitful.
114.	This special session is of crucial importance, because it is the first time that the General Assembly has held a session to discuss medium-term and long-term measures to put an end to the economic crisis of an entire continent. 115. Mankind is preparing to enter the twenty-first century. With the transformation of economic structures oriented towards in-depth development going hand in hand with the most recent progress in the scientific and technological revolution, profound changes are occurring in production and people’s lives. At the same time, the economic and social situation in Africa is worsening every day. Underdevelopment, backward material and technical infrastructures, serious economic dependency on the outside world, the ever-present dearth of food and the everincreasing debt burden are the salient features of the present state of the economy in Africa, a situation which is a source of serious concern for the international community. 116. The delegation of Viet Nam believes that the state of poverty, backwardness and dependency of the African economy stems first and foremost from centuries of domination and exploitation by colonialism. By means of a difficult, determined struggle, the African countries have by turns regained their political independence, but imperialist forces are doing their utmost to continue to plunder Africa’s natural and human resources and to keep the African countries dependent on the imperialist States by means of neo-colonialism. The policy of the imperialist countries, which consists in shifting the burden of the crisis on to the developing countries and implementing measures of economic terrorism, has done serious damage to the African countries. What is more, those countries do not enjoy a situation of peace and stability in which to bring about their economic development. The racist régime of South Africa and other reactionary forces,
assisted by a certain number of Western countries, indulge in destabilizing activities which merely exacerbate the critical economic situation of the African countries at the present time. The United States armed attack against Libya, its assistance to UNITA5 against Angola and the recent attacks by the Pretoria régime against Zimbabwe, Zambia and Botswana not only endanger the independence and sovereignty of those nations but undermine their economic development efforts. For southern Africa alone, the economic damage caused by the racist régime of South Africa over the past five years amounts to more than $10 billion—more than four times the assistance received by the affected countries.
117.	In addition to those basic causes, natural factors— natural disasters, drought and desertification—as well as economic management shortcomings, have helped to exacerbate the crisis.
118.	In the circumstances, the search for a comprehensive solution combining emergency measures with longterm ones is vital. First, it is necessary to eliminate the causes of the critical economic situation in Africa, that is, the capitalist developed countries and the racist régime of South Africa must end their neo-colonialist policies and acts of aggression, intervention and destabilization. At the same time, the African countries must carry out progressive economic and social reforms internally. Confidence must be established in international economic relations. Recourse to economic measures to exert political pressure on the developing countries must cease and disarmament must be effected in order to release resources for development investment, including increased assistance to the African countries.
119.	My delegation supports the measures advocated in Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the OAU Assembly at its July 1985 session and submitted by the OAU to this special session of the General Assembly. In the opinion of the delegation of Viet Nam, the most important sector on which to concentrate efforts is agricultural production, which must be stepped up if food self-sufficiency is to be achieved by the end of the century.
Mr. Pop (Romania), Vice-President, took the Chair. 120. The establishment of a solid economic infrastructure is decisive for the success of the recovery programme. In my delegation’s view, to achieve that goal the African Governments alone are capable of strengthening their social and economic institutions in order to meet the development challenges by improving their management systems, rationalizing their activities and eliminating overlapping.
121.	Given the gravity of the economic crisis besetting Africa and the limited means available to the African countries, the assistance of the international community is particularly vital. However, we must stress that the responsibility lies first with those States that more or less participated in exploiting the African nations. We believe that in lending assistance to the African countries, other countries must respect their independence, sovereignty and development options.
122.	My delegation endorses the proposals of the African countries, supplemented by the measures put forward by the Secretary-General and the Chairman of the Preparatory Committee concerning the position of the international community on Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery. They are as follows. First, the developed capitalist countries must be more flexible in regard to loan conditions and administrative procedures, increase their assistance budgets and depoliticize such assistance. Secondly, the international community must enter into
viable practical commitments with the African countries so as to alleviate the debt burden and debt-servicing for the African countries, including the conversion of the public debt and interest into grants. Thirdly, the developed capitalist countries must assume responsibility for guaranteeing terms of trade for commodities by instituting income-stabilization plans. Fourthly, the economic destabilization policies of the racist regime of South Africa must be neutralized by the imposition of an economic embargo against South Africa. Fifthly, SouthSouth co-operation must be stepped up in the spirit of collective self-reliance of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries and the Caracas Programme of Action.6
123.	Viet Nam, a developing country, spent a hundred years under colonial domination and more than 30 years resisting a war of aggression and sabotage waged by enemy external forces. It therefore well understands the economic difficulties that beset Africa. Despite the geographical distance and the many economic difficulties Viet Nam faces, it has sought and will continue to seek as far as it can to increase co-operation with the African countries by sending specialists and sharing our experience in various fields such as culture, education, health, hydraulics, transport and communications, and so forth.
124.	The urgent question facing African countries and this special session is that of defining effective comprehensive measures to overcome Africa’s present economic situation. Viet Nam has experienced similar circumstances and has special relations with the African countries in their struggle to win and defend their political independence and economic development. The delegation of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam pledges close co-operation with the President and the other delegations, in particular those of Africa, to make this session a success.
125.	Mr. CAVE (Barbados): The delegation of Barbados welcomes this opportunity to address the special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa. This is an historic occasion, since it is the first time that the representatives of nearly all mankind have come together to focus attention on the problems besetting a whole continent and its people. Moreover, the convening of this session, following a call by the twenty-first session of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity, is a positive indication of the responsiveness of this body to the evolving needs of the African States.
126.	The situation in Africa holds many lessons for the international community. It is ironic that on the very threshold of the twenty-first century, with the stars within our reach, famine and premature death still stalk the land believed to be the cradle of human life. It is equally paradoxical that Africa, despite its vast size and abundance of resources, remains the least developed of all the continents. Africa is a lesson in the consequences of neglect by the international community. At the same time, Africa presents a unique opportunity to redress past mistakes.
127.	Much has already been done to meet the basic needs of the millions that suffer in Africa, and so far the providing of emergency relief assistance to Africa has been emphasized. Indeed, the international response has been admirable and without doubt has helped to relieve some of the suffering of countless men, women and children. The global outpouring of concern and generosity has reaffirmed faith in the essential goodness of mankind.
128.	Short-term, stop-gap measures have their place. However, a much greater task lies ahead: that of ensuring
that a recurrence of the African crisis is humanly preventable. The challenge facing the international community is to extend the humanitarian response to the drought-aggravated emergency in Africa into a commitment to finding solutions to Africa’s more entrenched economic problems.
129.	Today there is growing appreciation that drought, desertification and famine are but symptoms, albeit of catastrophic proportions, of deeper problems besetting Africa. The delegation of Barbados wishes to remind all here that the problems Africa now faces are not uniquely African. They are the classic and traditional problems of development: those of finding institutions that will address the idiosyncracies of environment, the prejudices of culture and the legacies of history. The drought has merely accentuated the more pervasive structural problems of the African economy. Taking this into account, it seems to us that no amount of relief assistance will prevent a recurrence of the ecological and human disaster in Africa. A major shift in emphasis to rehabilitation and long-term development is therefore required.
130.	The delegation of Barbados will not dwell on an analysis of the origins and causes of Africa’s economic crisis. These have already been discussed by our colleagues from Africa. However, differences in perception of the nature of Africa’s problems are important in so far as they predicate the type of response which is supported or endorsed. Regrettably, ad.hoc short-term treatments have now become prevalent features of international economic relations. These do nothing to cure the deep-rooted illness afflicting the patient but merely assuage the more obvious symptoms.
131.	The delegation of Barbados suggests that the longterm solution of Africa’s economic problems is possible only if economic struggles are adjusted to accommodate the dynamics of African development. Africa remains largely dependent on primary production, while many other parts of the developing world have embarked on programmes of industrialization. Weak linkages between productive sectors at the domestic level and a relative absence of interdependence between the national economies of Africa also combine to prevent the continent from realizing its full potential.
132.	A major step would be taken if this special session were to give effect to the concept of a partnership between African States and the rest of the international community. Regrettably, there have been some disconcerting signs that, while the developed countries have been quite magnanimous in providing emergency aid to Africa, the commitment of some States to the long-term recovery and economic development of Africa has not been readily apparent. The delegation of Barbados wishes, however, to take public note of the marked commitment of the Government of Canada to the future development of Africa.
133.	There is nothing to be gained and much to be lost by Africa remaining economically disadvantaged. There can be no true international economic recovery while the threat of economic disaster hangs over Africa’s millions. International peace and security will be fragile if the international community continues to turn a blind eye to the long-term development needs of Africa.
134.	At the same time, we recognize that no solution to Africa’s economic problems can be achieved without the African States themselves becoming the driving force behind their economic development. The African States have acknowledged that they have the primary responsibility for revitalizing their economies, and we note with
satisfaction that they have taken the initiative in formulating strategies geared towards the rehabilitation and economic recovery of Africa.
135.	The adoption by the OAU Assembly in July 1985 of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 is the most recent indication that African States are not satisfied to look only to the international community for the solution to their problems. In the Priority Programme they have adopted a package of measures intended to achieve self-reliant and self-sustained development at the national and continental levels. The Government of Barbados whole-heartedly supports this effort which places due emphasis on self-help programmes. In the long run, whatever positive results are achieved will be better integrated into the national and regional economic milieu of Africa.
136.	However, there are certain realities which must be recognized. One is that the African States will not be able by themselves to mobilize all the resources necessary to relaunch their economic development process. The other is that there are many obstacles to this process in the international environment, obstacles which, we suggest, are beyond the control of African States: obstacles in the form of protectionist policies by developed countries, shrinking prices for commodities, declining terms of trade, massive debt and crippling terms of debt repayment. All these are factors which highlight the need for urgent action by the international community in support of the Priority Programme. .
137.	The crisis in Africa can in years to come be regarded as just another symptom of global catastrophe, or Africa can be remembered as the continent in which the downward spiral was checked and reversed. The scenario depends in large part on the decisions which will be taken here. The major developing countries can build upon their outstanding record of humanitarian assistance by supporting the economic recovery programmes of the African States, or they can allow the efforts of the last few years to be wasted. There should be no illusions: unless a significant effort is made to address the fundamental structural problems of Africa, another crisis of even greater proportions is entirely possible.
138.	For a few days last week, while discussions proceeded in the Preparatory Committee, another issue of critical importance to peace and security in Africa seized our attention. I refer, of course, to the raids by the racist régime in Pretoria against Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Barbados, which only yesterday had its fourth general election since independence in 1966, understands all too well the correlation between genuine self-determination and the process of economic development. The Government of Barbados views the continued existence of the illegal Pretoria régime as a major obstacle to the economic recovery and development of the front-line States, and indeed the true development of all of southern Africa. How can these States devote their full energies to solving their economic problems in the face of attack and the threat of attack by South Africa? How can they make maximum use of their scarce financial resources when they must attempt to defend themselves against the military might of Pretoria?
139.	Nature and history have not always been kind to Africa and its peoples. The delegation of Barbados understands in intimate terms the pillage that was slavery, the tragedy that was colonialism and the scars they have left on the African psyche. Today, the remnant of these vicissitudes survives, shamelessly and brazenly displayed in the politics of Pretoria.
140.	Harsh climatic conditions have frequently made life for millions of Africans a monumental challenge in survival. Now, as the stricken continent frees itself from the ravages of famine and drought, we are informed by FAO that a plague of locusts stands poised' to do more damage to African lands. This new menace can only underscore the urgency with which wé must bestir ourselves.
141.	Mysterious are the powers that govern the destinies of man. Perhaps the locusts, an old and relentless enemy of the welfare of mankind, have come to us as a timely signal, a reminder that we should not, must not, turn our backs upon our neighbours.
142.	We end our remarks with a resolute pledge of solidarity with the States of Africa and with the solemn hope that this special session shall not have been summoned in vain. ■
143.	Mr. GYI (Burma): My delegation welcomes and appreciates the President’s able direction of this special session and takes this opportunity to extend our felicitations to him.
144.	As we pursue our deliberations on the critical economic situation in Africa, it is indeed noteworthy that, through their will and determination and with the cooperation of the international community, the African States have managed to overcome the immediate crisis. Despite this situation, there remains a continuing need to maintain the momentum for relief and rehabilitation, and beyond that the imperative need to find longer-term measures for the building of viable economies. That calls for further co-operation at the international level which is more comprehensive in scope and character.
145.	In his report to the fortieth session of the General Assembly, the Secretary-General mentioned that African countries had been adversely affected by various demographic and political pressures, desertification, structural problems, agricultural difficulties and an unfavourable international economic climate. Hence, it would only be appropriate that the international community should perceive the need for concerted action to assist African nations in overcoming their difficulties; that would require co-operation in accordance with the principles and purposes of the Charter of the United Nations and, accordingly, on the basis of the principles of equal rights and self-determination for the peoples of Africa.
146.	It is in that spirit that we welcome the convening of the special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa. This session will enable the international community to continue its concerted efforts to search for appropriate measures for the recovery and development of Africa—an issue that has been of vital importance in debates in the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council for the past two years.
147.	Acting in accordance with the wishes of the African States, the General Assembly last December adopted without a vote resolution 40/40, providing for the convening of a special session of the Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa. The primary objective of this session is to focus discussion on the medium-and long-term problems and challenges facing African countries, with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures. Among the most important issues to be deliberated and acted upon at present are issues of food and agriculture, debt and the related issues of resource flows and export earnings, the infrastructure and other supporting sectors.
148.	The countries of Africa no doubt look to this session to focus on the restoration of their economies and
on medium- and long-term development problems and to achieve results in programmes aimed at the economic recovery of their continent. It remains the task of the world community to assist in this endeavour with an integrated approach toward the effective mobilization of financial and material resources for the rehabilitation of the economies of Africa.
149.	Here, it would be pertinent to mention that the OAU has been appropriately in the forefront of mobilizing support to alleviate the multitude of difficulties afflicting their continent. The holding of this special session and the results it could achieve testify to their will and courage and their determination to overcome the difficulties they face. Indeed, it was the African leaders and Governments themselves who showed the vision and will to deal with the situation and to initiate action for the convening of this session. It may be recalled that at the twenty-first session of the OAU Assembly in July 1985 at Addis Ababa, the African Heads of State and Government proposed this special session. The decision of the African leaders was that it should address the root causes of the critical economic situation in Africa, to prevent such emergencies in the future and to enable Africa once again to take the path of self-sustained development. Moreover, the African leaders have reaffirmed that the primary responsibility for the development of their continent lies with the peoples themselves. Accordingly, they have dedicated themselves to all efforts towards the achievement of that end.
150.
