8th PLENARY MEETING
Sunday, 1 June 1986, at 8.30 p.m.
NEW YORK
President: Mr. Jaime de PINIES (Spain).
AGENDA ITEM 6
Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and medium-term and long-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures (concluded)
AGENDA ITEM 7
Adoption, in an appropriate format, of the document or documents of the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly
1.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): As members are aware, all delegations have been working extremely hard during the past few days both in formal and informal meetings to finalize the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990. Unfortunately, this indispensable process of consultations and meetings took longer than origiTially envisaged. Therefore, the closure of the thirteenth special session had to be delayed. I assume that the Assembly realizes that the postponement was essential and that it agrees that the delay in the closure of the special session was necessary.
2.	I remind representatives that the debate on item 6 was concluded in the morning of Friday, 30 May.
3.	The Assembly will now consider the report of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session of the General Assembly [A/S-13/15], For the time being, the text of this report may be found in document A/S-13/AC.1/L.3 and Corr.l in French only, as orally revised by the Rapporteur.
4.	Mr. NGAIZA (United Republic of Tanzania), Rapporteur of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session: I have the honour to present to the General Assembly the report of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session, on the critical economic situation in Africa.
5.	I regret that owing to time constraints the Committee’s report could not be submitted to the plenary meeting in final form. That is why it is necessary to refer to the text of the draft report [A/S-I3/AC.I/L.3], However, I shall give an oral account of the action taken by the Ad Hoc Committee at its last meeting, which has just concluded.
6.	I am happy to inform you, Mr. President, that the Ad Hoc Committee adopted without a vote the draft resolution entitled “United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 19861990”, the text of which appears in paragraph 8 of the draft report.
7.	I wish to make the following revision to the draft resolution recommended to the Assembly for adoption. A new operative paragraph should be inserted before the present paragraph 2. The new paragraph 2 reads as follows:
“2. Emphasizes the need to intensify economic and technical co-operation with African countries during and beyond the period of the Programme of Action;”. The remaining paragraphs will be renumbered accordingly.
Pursuant to rule 66 of the rules of procedure, it was decided not to discuss the report of the Ad Hoc Committee.
8.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): Statements will be limited to explanations of vote or position.
9.	The positions of delegations regarding the recommendation of the Ad Hoc Committee have been made clear in the Committee and are reflected in the relevant official records. May I remind members that in paragraph 7 of its decision 34/401, the General Assembly decided that when the same draft resolution is considered in a Main Committee and in plenary meeting, a delegation should, as far as possible, explain its vote only once, that is, either in the Committee or in plenary meeting, unless that delegation’s vote in plenary meeting is different from its vote in the Committee.
10.	May I also remind members that, also in accordance with decision 34/401, explanations of votes should be limited to 10 minutes and be made by delegations from their seats.
11.	In this connection, may I suggest that the Assembly proceed immediately to the report of the Ad Hoc Committee and the recommendation contained therein, on the understanding that any delegation wishing to do so would be free to explain its vote or make statements of position on the subject after its approval.
12.	I take it that it is the wish of the General Assembly to follow that procedure.
It was so decided.
13.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I invite representatives to turn to paragraph 8 of the draft report of the Ad Hoc Committee, as orally revised by the Rapporteur, which contains a draft resolution entitled “United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990”, which the Ad Hoc Committee adopted without a vote. May I take it that the Assembly also wishes to adopt this draft resolution, as orally revised?
The draft resolution, as orally revised, was adopted (resolution S-I3/2).
14.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I should like to thank Mr. Lewis and all the officers, the Secretariat staff and all those who have tirelessly worked and contributed to ensuring the success of this special session. It is indeed a milestone, as this is the first time that the General Assembly has considered an item of the magnitude and importance of economic aid to Africa. The achievement of such an important consensus augurs well
for the future of the United Nations and of the African continent.
15.	I call upon the Secretary-General, who wishes to make a statement.
16.	The SECRETARY-GENERAL: It is a great source of satisfaction that this special session is concluding on such a positive note. In my opening statement, I described the session as an opportunity for a new beginning in cooperation between African countries and their development partners. This opportunity has been seized. It is clear from the statements in the plenary meetings, from the parallel activities of non-governmental organizations and, most important, from the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990, just adopted, that the international community has joined together in a common effort to provide the basis for self-reliant and selfsustained growth in Africa.
17.	We could do no less, for we are gathered here as representatives of the peoples of the world, and they have clearly expressed their human solidarity with their brothers and sisters in Africa. In lighting the pillar of flame at United Nations Headquarters a week ago, Omar Khalifa indeed launched a “Race Against Time” in which peoples all over the world have joined.
18.	But the race has just begun. If we are to succeed, it will take a determined and continued effort over time. The presence at this session of Abdou Diouf, President of Senegal and current Chairman of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity, and other senior representatives from all regions, is evidence of the seriousness of purpose with which Governments approach this challenge. I speak for all my colleagues in the United Nations system in assuring members of our commitment to play our part.
19.	The image of Africa as a dependent continent must disappear. Africa is a continent rich in physical and human resources. The realization of its potential will not only fulfil the hopes and aspirations of the peoples of Africa, but will also contribute immeasurably to the economic and social well-being of all the world.
20.	The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I shall now call on those representatives who have placed their names on the list to speak in explanation of vote or to make statements in explanation of their positions.
21. Mr. McPHERSON (United States of America): Mr. President, Mr. Secretary-General, this has been a successful week. You and your colleagues deserve special congratulations. We particularly would like to thank President Diouf and Foreign Minister Fall of Senegal, and Mr. Pisani, Chairman of the Preparatory Committee. We have been able to come together here and reaffirm those priorities necessary for stimulating economic recovery and renewed growth in Africa. We have accomplished this knowing that Africa’s problems are complex and that there are no easy solutions.
22.	We are now at a crossroads. We shall leave this Hall having charted a new course this week, one that concentrates resources on high priorities and is based on a partnership of mutual understanding.
23.	During the past few days a lot of good will has been generated. Obviously, some problems have been encountered, but that was inevitable, given the importance of this subject. Nevertheless, we come out of this with the political will to implement the United Nations Programme of Action adopted here.
24.	I would like to outline how the United States will support economic recovery of Africa. We will focus our
assistance on four of the highest priorities: economic restructuring, agricultural growth, human resources development and, finally, famine preparation. To do so, we will concentrate our efforts on finding the most effective and efficient ways to implement these priorities with the resources at hand. Let us take them one at a time.
25.	Economic restructuring is the number-one priority for Africa. Nothing short of this will spark renewed growth. The United States strongly supports the bold steps for policy reform called for in the Programme of Action. We know that austerity alone is not enough. Economic stabilization, yes, is absolutely necessary, but it must be accompanied by reforms which produce jobs and growth. Each country will employ different means to achieve these goals, but an increased role for prices, markets and individual initiative clearly is fundamental.
26.	The results of policy changes are already being felt throughout Africa. Dramatic increases in food production have occurred in a number of countries as the result of the increased prices paid to farmers and the greater reliance on the free market. For example, in Malawi an 85 per cent increase in maize prices to farmers resulted in more than a 200 per cent increase in market output.
27.	Donors can support the innovative and courageous efforts of committed countries in a number of ways. For example, the United States has developed the African Economic Policy Reform Program which, along with the Baker initiative, is directed at accelerating policy reforms. We are also supporting the World Bank Special Facility for sub-Saharan Africa.
28.	However, as our African colleagues have said, growth will not come from foreign assistance alone. Leadership by African nations is critical to manage the resources and to carry out the essential reform programmes.
29.	Our second priority for Africa is agriculture, a principal engine of growth. The United Nations Programme of Action and previous documents of the Organization of African Unity [O^U] and ECA should be commended for their renewed commitment to agriculture. 30. Progress in key areas is vital for agricultural growth. The most important area is a favourable policy framework to support production and marketing by small-scale farmers. Next, farmers need appropriate technologies. Much progress has been made. However, to bring about a breakthrough in research, to bring a green revolution to Africa, will require a long-term effort and very substantial funding. As Secretary Shultz stated on Wednesday [3rd meeting], the United States plans to give $1 billion for agricultural research for Africa over the next 15 years. The fact is that there simply has not been enough spent on research on crops grown and consumed by the people of Africa. We plan to make a major contribution. Also, we believe that a system of agricultural universities to support research extension and education will be needed. Here too we shall contribute to that effort.
31.	Another area needing support is agricultural marketing. The surplus of grains—and I stress “surplus”— in many areas of Africa this year underlines the necessity of expanding trade among African neighbours. There is an enormous need to develop closer rural and urban ties for the marketing of agricultural goods. We need to find the best means for processing and marketing local foods and to move away from reliance on food aid.
32.	Finally, for agricultural growth we are supporting better management of the natural resources of Africa. The advance of the desert, the destruction of the forests and the depletion of soils undermine agricultural production and increase the chances of famine. Desertification
is real. I remember last year, when I was in Niger with Vice-President Bush, when we could not take an incountry plane trip because there was too much sand in the air.
33.	Environmental degradation is increasing due to misuse and over-use of land by people and livestock. Population pressure is pushing people into marginal lands, often causing further loss of productive land and forests.
34.	These conditions, made worse by man, can also be changed by man. In this regard, tree planting works best when local families and communities are given the responsibility for trees that protect their own land. It is human nature that people protect their own trees and chop down other trees, especially if no one clearly owns those trees. I have seen this time after time, all over the world. We try to build on this concept of human nature. For example, in Niger, working with the CARE organization, the United States has helped local people plant over 500 kilometres of windbreaks, which now produce fuelwood and valuable wood products and which have increased millet yields by 20 per cent in the area protected.
35.	This type of community-based forestry activity can be promoted and organized by non-governmental organizations and can serve as a model for other parts of Africa. In fact, four new forestry projects of the Agency for International Development with United States nongovernmental organizations are now under way in Senegal, Mali, Sudan and Somalia. We applaud the Canadian forestry initiative, which builds on the concept of working with the non-governmental organizations in local communities, and we shall follow that initiative very closely.
36.	Development of Africa’s human resources is our third priority. To make economic policy reforms and agricultural development really work, we must never lose sight of the most important resource of any country: its people. Accordingly, the United States is putting substantial resources into training African men and women, and we think this will pay off.
37.	Also, child survival is a key area for us. Here we have seen great success in the development and distribution of appropriate low-cost technologies such as immunization and oral rehydration therapy. We are already saving thousands of African babies, and the job has only begun. For example, oral rehydration therapy is almost magical in the way it can bring a child back from near death from diarrhoea and dehydration in a matter of a few hours. It is a simple mixture of a pinch of salt, a handful of sugar and water fed spoonful by spoonful to a child. I have seen this all over Africa, and I can tell those who have not seen it that it is really something.
38.	Working in partnership with non-governmental organizations has been a very effective approach in implementing our child survival programmes, and we shall continue this work. We are not working only with international non-governmental organizations, but with local ones as well. For example, local churches in Zaire have developed a primary health care system which has resulted in healthier children and adults in many villages.
39.	Of course, population growth rates are a factor in the African development equation. Many leaders of African countries are heeding the Kilimanjaro Programme of Action1 in its call for increased attention to this issue, including strong Government support for the provision of family planning services. I have watched this question of family planning closely over the almost six years I have headed the Agency for International Development, and I can say that there is a much deeper commitment to family planning in Africa than ever before. Accordingly,
the United States will continue to support and encourage the availability of family planning services in Africa and elsewhere.
40.	Also, the development of women’s capabilities is essential in Africa. We must recognize that attention to women’s roles in development is critical, particularly in agriculture. In addition to their daily domestic tasks, women farmers in many parts of Africa produce as much as 80 or 90 per cent of the food. I think all of us have seen the sign to that effect in the lobby. Therefore, as we allocate our scarce resources, women must be integrated into economic assistance activities through training and development programmes.
41.	Finally, a fourth priority is an African drought early-warning capacity. Famine is a slow-moving disaster which, I firmly believe, can be detected by monitoring various physical and social factors. We learned a great deal from last year’s drought, and we must build upon that experience. The monitoring capability must be put in place on a continuous-effort basis. It should combine first-hand knowledge of local conditions with high technology, such as remote sensing data from satellites.
42.	Such a system will have to be inexpensive and relatively simple to operate and maintain. If it is not inexpensive, if it is not simple, it will not be kept in place for the next time we need it. It should be fully professional and should be demonstrably free of political manipulation. We have such a professional, apolitical system to determine when there is an epidemic. That system produces conclusions upon which decision-makers the world over rely. We need such a system for famine determinations.
43.	The report of the Economic Summit Meeting held at Bonn in May 1985 recognized that an early-warning system cannot be successful without the development of national and regional capabilities. Organizations such as the Permanent Inter-State Committee on Drought Control in the Sahel, the Intergovernmental Authority for Drought and Development, and the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference should strengthen their co-ordination with FAO and donors with early-warning systems. The regional remote sensing centres in East and West Africa and the Regional Training Centre for Agrometeorology and Operational Hydrology and their Applications in Niamey are key organizations in the development of early-warning systems.
44.	We are not proposing a new bureaucracy, but the United States wants to work with African countries and other donors to draw upon our combined experience, which has been very considerable in the last year or so, and technical strength to support this effort. We know that there will be another drought. The question we must ask is whether we will take the steps to avoid another widespread famine. I firmly believe that such famines can be avoided in the future. We have the technology. The question is whether we will work together to put in place an effective professional, apolitical early-warning system.
45.	To carry out the four priorities I have outlined, we must mobilize all available resources. For example, the potential for unleashing the energies and resources of the African private sector is enormous. Clearly, they have not yet been fully marshalled. Also, support from nongovernmental organizations the world over has been massive. They continue to be extremely important as a source of direct assistance, and they can mobilize additional financial aid from public and private sources. We believe the African people have the energies and the desires to realize the promise of a productive, self-reliant life—if the African people can get the tools; if the African
people are given the chance; and if the African people and Governments take the lead.
46.	African Governments are working to create the environment in which their citizens can prosper. The United States and the international community are pledging here to deepen and broaden the partnership we have with you—the Governments, the people of Africa—to help make these goals a reality.
47.	This special session has aroused public interest in the development problems of Africa. It has focused the attention of donor decision-makers. We must now move forward with a determination to tailor development programmes which focus on the priorities of individual countries. We have confidence that the people of Africa will make it a success.
48.	Mr. GOLOB (Yugoslavia): I have asked to speak on behalf of the Group of 77. First of all, I should like to express our deep appreciation to all those who contributed to the elaboration and adoption of the United Nations Programme of Action for Africa’s Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990.
49.	Let me recall here that a few years ago the SecretaryGeneral drew the attention of the world to the emerging crisis in Africa and induced the international community to start immediate supportive action.
50.	I have to refer here with respect, and indeed with awe, to the inspiring statement made by the President of Senegal, Mr. Diouf [1st meeting], who inspired us all with his words of sagacity and with his insight into the problems of the continent and into their possible solutions.
51.	We have been deeply impressed by Mr. Fall, the Foreign Minister of Senegal. He has invested his enormous wisdom and energy in this project. In the best tradition of Africa, he and his team have done this with dignity, commanding nothing but respect and support. They have effectively displayed the dedication of the developing countries to self-determination, to the inalienable right of every country to choose its own way of development and the modalities of its social system.
52.	Our appreciation goes as well to Mr. Pisani of France, Chairman of the Preparatory Committee, for his hard work and widely acknowledged dedication to the cause of Africa. We maintain high esteem for Mr. Lewis of Canada and for the knowledge and competence that he so amply displayed and used while he guided the proceedings of the Ad Hoc Committee. In his work he was ably and most impressively assisted by Mr. Qazi Shaukat Fareed of Pakistan, who is known here for his diplomatic skill and for his really deep knowledge of the issues involved. .
53.	The international community now has a comprehensive instrument. It has now strongly, politically committed itself to assist countries of Africa to help themselves to overcome the present hardships and to move towards a steady and speedy economic and social development. The document just adopted is above all a realistic step forward. Therefore, there is every reason to expect that it will be fully and timely implemented.
54.	The African countries have once again demonstrated their political wisdom and their dignity. Throughout the negotiating process they affirmed the readiness of their peoples and their Governments to shoulder all tasks and to spare no effort to pull their countries out of the present malaise, and they made it clear that they intended to make full use of their own vast potential, both human and material.
55.	The General Assembly has acknowledged this commitment with high esteem and has responded positively
to the expectations for co-operation and for assistance. We believe that in the course of the past five days, the case of Africa has become better known and better understood, and we expect that this will be adequately reflected. This session of the General Assembly should bring about assistance to and support for Africa, thereby allowing it to play the role the world expects and needs.
56.	The Group of 77 has supported African efforts throughout the preparatory stage and will continue to do so in a spirit of full solidarity in the process that will follow this special session of the General Assembly. Let me state as well that Africa’s measure of success and achievement at this General Assembly is our own measure, The value of global multilateralism as expressed and reflected in the General Assembly has been confirmed again this past week. This is particularly valuable since these are times of adversity for the Organization.
57.	Finally, permit me to state again that the progress and stability of Africa and its contribution to the progress and stability of the world require the eradication of apartheid and the remnants of colonialism. They require the independence of Namibia, and they require full respect for freedom, independence and self-determination.
58.	Mr. NOWORYTA (Poland) (interpretation from Russian): I have the honour to speak on behalf of the delegations of the People’s Republic of Bulgaria, the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic, the German Democratic Republic, the Hungarian People’s Republic, the Mongolian People’s Republic, the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the Polish People’s Republic.
59.	The position of the socialist countries on the problem of the critical economic situation in Africa was stated in detail during the special session. That position was reaffirmed in the joint statement of the socialist countries [A/S-J3/14]. The socialist countries took an active and constructive part in the session in an attempt to promote the elaboration of an effective and integrated programme to resolve the economic problems of the continent and to eliminate the real reasons for the crisis and to improve the political and economic situation in Africa and in the world as a whole. Based on the foregoing positions, we should like to make some remarks with regard to the final document adopted by the Assembly.
60.	The socialist countries have great sympathy for the aspirations of the African countries to ensure the implementation of Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 adopted by the OAU. A sine qua non for the implementation of that Programme is the central role of the State in overall administration of the economy and in ensuring a balanced development of its basic areas. In the document adopted at the special session the important role of the public sector is correctly noted.
61.	We also understand the particular attention the African countries give to the task of raising agricultural and food production. However, a genuine solution to the problem of overcoming backwardness requires an integrated approach to socio-economic development, including the promotion of industrialization as the basis for an independent national economy. That is the approach approved by the African countries in the Lagos Plan of Action3 and in the Industrial Development Decade for Africa. One serious omission is the fact that the framework for economic development established in the document has turned out to be separate from the continent’s social problems, and the aggravation of those problems
has had an adverse impact on the living conditions of millions of Africans.
62.	The document has not analysed with sufficient clarity the external factors hindering African development, nor does it provide for the working out of recommendations for effectively overcoming the continent’s unequal status in the world economy as a result of imperialist and neo-colonialist exploitation.
63.	In our view, because of those and a number of other weaknesses the document is, on the whole, one-sided and fails to take into account many extremely important United Nations decisions regarding the establishment of a new international economic order or the objectives and tasks of the socio-economic development of developing countries. Hence it can hardly be said that the special session was fully equal to its assigned task, which was, as set out in the agenda, to examine, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, the medium-term and long-term development problems of Africa.
64.	Everyone understands that the African countries and peoples are not to blame for their plight. The outcome of the session is first of all the result of the position of the leading Western States, which continue to block the economic liberation of Africa, and not only of Africa, to thwart balanced international economic co-operation and to split the unity of African and other developing countries. That policy was also manifested in some of the statements made at plenary meetings in the form of proposals for the final document which the West attempted to impose on the rest of the United Nations membership.
65.	The socialist countries condemn attempts to take advantage of the critical economic situation of the African countries in order to interfere in their domestic and foreign policies. The United Nations should not and will not be an accomplice to that policy.
66.	The approach of the socialist countries to relations with the African countries is based on various principles: genuine equality, full respect for national sovereignty, non-interference in internal affairs and mutual benefit. We shall continue to develop trade and economic, scientific and technical co-operation with the African States and to render them multilateral assistance aimed at achieving a genuine solution to their problems, taking into account the fundamental, long-term interests of the African peoples.
67.	In developing such co-operation, we shall take into account the development goals of the African countries and the objectives set forth in the Lagos Plan of Action and Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990. The socialist countries believe that a solution to the economic problems of Africa requires radical measures to eradicate their causes, inherited from colonialism and neo-colonialism. Such measures must be closely linked to the problem of disarmament, which would lead to the release of resources to overcome backwardness in African and other countries.
68.	The resolution of Africa’s complex economic problems requires the participation of all States, regardless of ideological differences, economic potential, the size of their territory or the size of their population. Therefore, all countries, without exception, must fully abide by the progressive provisions of the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States [resolution 3281 (XXIX)], the Declaration and Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order [resolutions 3201 (S-VI) and 3202 (S-VI)], the International Development Strategy for the Third United Nations Development Decade [resolution 35/56, annex] and other United Nations decisions dealing with the restructuring
of international economic relations on a just and equal basis. Obviously, in carrying out its part in the solution of the problems of the African continent the international community must pay full respect to the sovereignty of the African States and the paths of national development chosen by their peoples. This must be assured by the future activities of the United Nations in promoting the solution of the critical economic situation in Africa.
69.	Mr. HE KANG (China) (interpretation from Chinese)-. We are most happy that the special session has adopted its final document on the basis of the African submission, following the concerted efforts and friendly consultations among the participating delegations, and has achieved positive results. The Chinese delegation wishes to express its warm congratulations on all this.
70.	The convening of the special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa is in itself an achievement of great significance, a reflection of the attention and concern of the whole world to African economic problems. Now the session has been crowned with postive results, thus opening new prospects for African countries and the international community in their joint endeavours for revitalizing the African economy.
71.	The session’s proceedings have shown that economic problems of Africa should ultimately be decided by African Governments and peoples themselves, and all other countries should respect the choice made by the African countries through full consultations.
72.	In order to facilitate the implementation of the Programme of Action, I wish to reiterate what I said in my statement during the general debate [3rd meeting]— that is, the Chinese Government will contribute to the best of its ability to Africa in such aspects as increasing its economic assistance—agricultural aid in particular. —continuing to provide long-term preferential loans, strengthening personnel training and exchanging experience in policy making.
73.	I wish to take this opportunity to express our appreciation to you, Mr. President, to the Preparatory Committee and the Ad Hoc Committee of the Special Session and to the Secretariat and the related organs of the United Nations for the great amount of work they have done for this session. I sincerely wish the United Nations continuous and new successes in its efforts for the maintenance of peace and the promotion of development.
74.	Mrs. SCHOO (Netherlands): Mr. President, speaking on behalf of the European Community and its member States, let me state at the outset that I shall not take too much of your time and of this session at this late stage. We have all worked very hard and with great dedication. Nevertheless, I should like to make a few remarks before you formally close the session.
75.	The resolution we have just adopted was arrived at after long and strenuous negotiations. The process of negotiations started a few months ago and reached its peak during the special session itself. Achieving consensus was not an easy process. It required a substantial amount of energy, flexibility and willingness to take into account the views of all parties concerned. The reason the negotiating process took time lies, in my opinion, in the complexity of the issue under consideration, the critical economic situation in Africa. Trying to devise ways to deal with the medium- and long-term problems those countries are facing is an extremely arduous task, involving numerous and different interests.
76.	But we were heartened to note that at every stage of the debate, all parties involved showed a clear readiness to find a solution, to end the session with a consensus
document that will provide guidance for our further work. We have a right to be satisfied with the results. Of course, we did not manage to insert in this text all the views of our respective Governments; texts could have been phrased in a different and perhaps a more effective manner here and there. Nevertheless, we have adopted a text that is clear proof of our firm determination, African countries and the international community alike, to do our utmost to give a new impetus to the development process in Africa. Both actors have their role to play in the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990 that we just approved. The African countries have reiterated their willingness to take concrete measures to enhance their economic prospects. The international community will, for its part, contribute to this endeavour with strong supportive measures. This common course of action will, we all hope, stimulate the African continent towards selfsustaining development and economic growth. But the adoption itself of this Programme of Action is only a first step. It is clear that the next step, the implementation of the Programme, will be even more important.
77.	The positive result we achieved today would not have been possible without the strong input of the African countries themselves. Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery I986-19902 provided us with an effective basis for our work. I already had an opportunity, speaking in the general debate on behalf of the European Community and its member States [1st meeting], to highlight the important role President Diouf of Senegal played in the African preparations. I should like to repeat this at the closure of this session; his very presence here gave an inspiration to the conference. When the President left, his Foreign Minister, Mr. Fall, stayed with us. I should like to take this occasion to express my sincere gratitude for his actions and interventions; his presence in discussions and in negotiations proved to be a crucial element for reaching solutions.
78.	Mr. President, I will not take up more of your time by expressing my appreciation for all those involved in the success of this special session: delegations, individuals and the Secretariat services which deserve a special mention in this respect. But I should like to make three exceptions: first, a special word of thanks is appropriate for Mr. Lewis, whose dedicated leadership proved to be very important in reaching the result we have on the table; secondly, to Mr. Fareed for his untiring work in the Committee. Finally, a special salute goes to you, Mr. President. The way you presided over our proceedings contributed substantially to creating the right atmosphere that made it possible to conclude our work in such a positive way.
79.	Mr. YOSHINO (Japan): I wish wholeheartedly to welcome the adoption by consensus of the resolution to which the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990 is attached. Its adoption is the outcome of the sincere efforts of all those present after long hours of laborious work extending over several months. I believe that such strenuous efforts and hard work have been fully rewarded with the agreement on the well-balanced document that certainly establishes an important common point of reference for the joint actions and measures to be taken by the African countries and the international community for. years to come.
80.	Let me take this opportunity to express my delegation’s deep appreciation to Mr. Lewis of Canada, Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole, for his tireless efforts to reach a consensus on the resolution. It was only with the able and dynamic leadership he showed
during the difficult negotiations that we have succeeded in adopting this resolution. We have also been very much impressed by the statesmanship and leadership of the Foreign Minister of Senegal, who acted as the principal negotiator of the Group of African States. His dedication, integrity and determination have contributed enormously to the success of these difficult but fruitful negotiations. I also wish to thank the other officers of the Committee for their valuable contributions to the successful conduct of the meetings. Special appreciation goes to Mr. Fareed, Vice-Chairman of the Committee and chairman of the drafting group of the Preparatory Committee. When the Ad Hoc Committee started its work it benefited greatly from his contributions to the paper on which we initiated negotiations.
81.	I should like to make a few observations on some of the basic points.
82.	First, as far as Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-19902 is concerned, Japan appreciates the general thrust of the document, particularly its emphasis on the self-reliant efforts of the African people themselves and on the importance of agriculture and food production. These are precisely the areas the Japanese people themselves have emphasized as they work for the economic and social development of their own country. I strongly believe that it is incumbent upon the developed and donor countries to support this new orientation, and I wish to assure the Assembly that Japan, for its part, is resolved to respond positively.
83.	Secondly, on Japan’s relations with African countries, I am glad to state that on our part there is a growing awareness of the need for increased co-operation with and assistance to Africa. In recent years, my Government has strengthened its assistance to Africa. I especially wish to refer to the medium-term plan to double official development assistance within seven years that my Government recently adopted. I am glad to say that Japan stands prepared to increase substantially its co-operation in the form of grant aid, technical assistance and loans to Africa. Japan is deeply aware of its responsibilities in this regard.
84.	Lastly, Africa has undeniable economic potential. With the newly agreed United Nations Programme of Action for Africa, we are on the threshold of the long process of solving the problems with which the African people are faced. In other words, transforming their continent into a place of hope, and prosperity is an enterprise for which the international community should jointly exert every effort.
85.	Japan regards this special session as an excellent opportunity not only to commit both the African countries and the international community to the cause of the economic recovery and development of Africa, but also to impart fresh momentum and prospects for further realistic and constructive North-South dialogue.
86.	Mr. LABERGE (Canada) (interpretation from French): I do not intend to revert here today to the statement made by Ms. Vezina, Minister for External Relations of Canada, when she addressed the Assembly ¡2nd meeting] on my country’s bilateral response to Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery 1986-1990,2 but rather to take note of the important step which the General Assembly’s adoption of document A/S-13/AC. 1/L.3 represents.
87.	The United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990 marks an historic watershed by setting up a new pattern for co-operation between Africa and the international community as a whole. This Programme bears the seeds
of a new take-off for Africa in its quest for self-sustaining development, especially development that is genuinely African. The countries of Africa have reaffirmed their determination and commitment individually and collectively to adopt measures and to take steps that are essential, indeed even painful, to attain that goal. For its part, the international community commits itself to support the will and determination of the Africans.
88.	Although the Programme is innovative, it is of cqurse no more than a starting-point. The results will be commensurate with the perseverance, determination and resoluteness of the commitments undertaken by the two partners in this Herculean enterprise. We in the international community have not only met the hopes and aspirations of the African peoples, but have carried out the duty of the United Nations to promote the economic and social advancement of all peoples.
89< Mr. PAPAJORGJI (Albania): The Albanian delegation has already made dear its position on the critical economic situation in Africa in its statement [6th meeting] and, hence, there is no need to repeat it now. We join in the consensus in keeping with the position of the Albanian. Government and. people, in support of the brother peoples of Africa. At the same times our delegation would like to point, out that it has reservations on the resolution.
90.	Mr. FALL (Senegal) (interpretation from French): Following upon the statement delivered at the opening of this special session by Mr. Diouf, current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity, my country has once again the signal honour of addressing the Assembly bn behalf of our continent. However, before I discharge that pleasant duty I should like, with your permission, personally to thank all the speakers who have kindly paid tribute to the Senegalese head of State, as well as to the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Senegal for his contributions during the preparations for and the holding of this special session, which is now drawing to a close. On their behalf, and on my own behalf and that of the entire delegation of my country, I wish simply but from the bottom of my heart, to thank one and all.
91.	As spokesman for Africa, I should like first to voice its profound gratitude to the Preparatory Committee of the Whole and its Chairman, Mr. Pisani, for the quality of their contribution, and, in respect of Mr. Pisani personally, for his commitment and dedication to the cause of the session; to the drafting group and its co-ordinator, Mr. Fareed, for their dedication and efficiency; to the international governmental and non-governmental organizations, for their noteworthy contributions, of which we have indeed taken note; and, finally, to the States and regional groups for their goodwill, open-mindedness and support, all of which have contributed greatly to making a success of this special session—a session from which we should like to see emerge a resumed North-South dialogue and strengthened South-South co-operation.
92.	Allow me also once again, on behalf of the continent, to express our deep appreciation for the dedication, competence and commitment of Mr. Lewis, Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee, and all those who assisted him in helping us to achieve in our work something satisfactory and realistic, in a spirit of solidarity, understanding and interdependence.
93.	The positive results of our work—with which we Africans are very pleased—have been possible thanks to the discreet efficacy and high calibre of the contribution of the Secretary-General and all the staff members of the United Nations system, who deserve our tribute. .
94.	Last but not least, I wish to pay a tribute to all persons of goodwill: sportsmen, musicians, artists of all kinds, persons of culture, policy-makers, leaders of nongovernmental organizations, journalists of the written press and of radio and television from around the world, but especially journalists of the United Nations press and information services, who spared neither their time nor their energy to sensitize public opinion everywhere, nationally and internationally, to the critical economic situation in Africa, with sympathy and eommitment that does honour to all of mankind.
95.	To Africa’s language of truth, moderation and responsibility throughout the preparations for and holding of this special session, the international community has given a positive response by committing itself with our continent to a new era of co-operation based on a spirit of genuine partnership. The international community’s decision to lend us its support and backing by translating into reality Africa’s Priority Programme for Economic Recovery is even now taking shape in commitments regarding a tangible increase in the level of official development assistance to Africa, notably for the five-year period 1986-1990; commitments regarding the priority given to ¡grants rather than to loans and the cancellation or suspension of debts in favour of some or all African countries; and commitments regarding the replenishment of the funds of assistance organizations such as IDA, IFAD, the African Development Fund, UNDP, the World Bank and others, raising their funds to levels equal to the importance and orientation of their development actions favouring African States and intra-African development organizations. .
96.	Similarly, many States, of the North as well as of the South, have announced their determination to establish special programmes for various sectors of the Priority Programme. The struggle against drought and desertifica-1 tion has especially attracted the attention of several States, which have decided to earmark significant funds to that end. The same applies to utilization of human resources and, in particular, to increasing the role of women and education. Agriculture and food have marshalled the attention of many countries which have decided to Channel aid in those areas to Africa during the period of the Priority Programme to bring about food self-sufficiency.
97.	Africa, which is grateful to the international community for having rallied to its side in response to its appeal, places great hope in the implementation of the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990 just adopted. The realistic, tangible and specifically oriented decisions we have just taken in an exemplary atmosphere of mutual confidence can and will be carried out by both Africa and the international community. In so far as it is concerned, Africa has no choice but to act in accordance with its commitments, since its very survival and that of its peo-pies is at stake.
98.	The most daunting challenge has thus been posed to the international community. It must successfully carry out the joint commitments it has undertaken with Africa so that when the time comes to take stock we shall all be able to respond positively to the expectations of the African peoples torn between doubt and hope. In this connection, Africa attaches the highest priority to the . follow-up and evaluation machinery just adopted; it hopes that that framework will enable us to translate into concrete action the determination shown on all sides to co-operate for a genuine partnership.
99. Although I have spoken at length, I am convinced	Closure of the thirteenth special session
that I have given but partial expression to the message
of satisfaction, friendship and hope of the Group of African States. I have had the honour to voice that message on behalf of our whole continent. But the hour is late and duty calls us to action. AGENDA ITEM 2 Minute of silent prayer or meditation	. 100. The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I now invite representatives to stand and observe one minute of silent prayer or meditation. The representatives observed a minute of silence.	101. The PRESIDENT (interpretation from Spanish): I declare closed the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly. The meeting rose at 9.55 p.m. Notes ,	1 Kilimanjaro Programme of Action for African Population and Self-Reliant Development, adopted by the Second African Population Conference, held at Arusha, United Republic of Tanzania, from 9 to 13 January 1984. 2A/40/666, annex I, declaration AHG/Decl. 1 (XXI), annex. 3 Lagos Plan of Action for the Implementation of the Monrovia Strategy for the Economic Development of Africa, adopted by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government of the Organization of African Unity at its second extraordinary session, held at Lagos on 28 and 29 April 1980.

DOCUMENT A/S-13/12
Report of the Credentials Committee
[Original: EnglisM [29 May 198^
1.	At its 1st plenary meeting, on 27 May 1986, the General Assembly, in accordance with rule 28 of its rules of procedure, appointed a Credentials Committee for its thirteenth special session with the same composition as that of the Credentials Committee at the fortieth session, namely: Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Canada, China, Papua New Guinea, Suriname, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and United States of America.
2.	The Credentials Committee held one meeting, on 29 May 1986.
3.	On the proposal of the representative of Brazil, Mr. Henri A. M. Guda (Suriname) was unanimously elected Chairman.
4.	The Committee had before it a memorandum by the Secretary-General, dated 28 May 1986, on the status of credentials of representatives to the thirteenth special session. The Deputy to the Legal Counsel updated the information contained in the memorandum. The memorandum as updated during the meeting indicated that as at 29 May 1986:
(a)	Formal credentials issued by head of State or Government or by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, as provided for in rule 27 of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly, had been submitted by the following 77 Member States: Afghanistan, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Botswana, Brazil, Bulgaria, Bukina Faso, Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic, Canada, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, China, Côte d’Ivoire, Cuba, Cyprus, Czechoslovakia, Democratic Kampuchea, Democratic Yemen, Denmark, Ecuador, El Salvador, Equatorial Guinea, Finland, Gabon, German Democratic Republic, Germany, Federal Republic of, Ghana, Greece, Guinea, Hungary, Iceland, Indonesia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Ireland, Israel, Italy, Jamaica, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Luxembourg, Maldives, Mali, Malta, Mauritius, Mexico, Mongolia, Morocco, Nepal, Netherlands, Niger, Nigeria, Norway, Oman, Pakistan, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Sao Tome and Principe, Seychelles, Somalia, Spain, Suriname, Sweden, Togo, Uganda, Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Northern Ireland, United Republic of Tanzania, Uruguay, Viet Nam, Yugoslavia, Zaire and Zimbabwe.
(b)	The appointment of the representatives of the following 19 Member States had been communicated to the Secretary-General in the form of a cable from the head of State or Government or Minister for Foreign Affairs concerned: Albania, Burundi, Chad, Chiles Colombia, Comoros, Congo, Costa Rica, India, Malaysia, Mauritania, Panama, Papua New Guinea, Paraguay, Peru, Rwanda, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Senegal and Venezuela.
(c)	The appointment of the representatives of the following 27 Member States had been communicated to the Secretary-General by letters or notes verbales from the Permanent Representatives or Permanent Missions concerned: Bahamas, Bangladesh, Benin, Bhutan, Burma, Dominican Republic, Egypt, Ethiopia, Fiji, France, Gambia, Grenada, Guinea-Bissau, Iraq, Japan, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Madagascar, Malawi, Nicaragua, Qatar, Sierra Leone, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Syrian Arab Republic, Turkey, United States of America and Zambia.
(d)	Of the Member States participating in the session not already mentioned, the following 31 had empowered their Permanent Representatives to represent their respective States in the General Assembly without limitation as to session: Algeria, Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Bahrain, Barbados, Belize, Bolivia, Brunei Darussalam, Cameroon, Djibouti, Dominica, Guatemala, Guyana, Haiti, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Mozambique, New Zealand, Saint Lucia, Samoa, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Swaziland, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Vanuatu and Yemen.
(e)	Four Member States had not yet communicated to the Secretary-General any information regarding their representatives to the thirteenth special session: Honduras, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, Philippines and Saint Christopher and Nevis. .
5.	Statements concerning the credentials of the representatives of Member States referred to the Committee for its consideration were made by the representatives of
the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, the United States of America, Canada and Brazil.
6.	The representative of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics stated that the Soviet delegation strongly -opposed the acceptance of the credentials of the representatives of the so-called “Democratic Kampuchea”. It was an irrefutable fact that “Democratic Kampuchea” was only a political ghost, which certain circles were attempting to help to acquire some semblance of material existence through representation at the United Nations. The representatives of the so-called “Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea” acted only on behalf of a small group of renegades driven out of their country, including representatives of the Pol Pot clique, which had committed bloody crimes against the Kampuchean people. Since 1979, a State existed on the political map of the world—the People’s Republic of Kampuchea—reflecting the interests of the Kampuchean people. The Government of the People’s Republic of Kampuchea, formed as a result of general elections, was exercising effective control over the whole territory of the country, enjoyed the support of friendly States, was rapidly rehabilitating the national economy which had been brought to a state of collapse by the Pol Pot clique and was striving to strengthen the democratic system. In the international arena, the People’s Republic of Kampuchea consistently conducted a policy of peace and co-operation and actively advocated the normalization of the situation in South-East Asia. The Soviet delegation was in favour of the immediate restoration of the legitimate rights of the People’s Republic of Kampuchea in the United Nations. The only just decision, in keeping with the spirit and letter of the Charter of the United Nations, would be to grant the delegates of the People’s Republic of Kampuchea the legitimate right tó represent their country and the Kampuchean people in the Organization.
7.	The same representative added that the Soviet delegation wished to reaffirm its non-acceptance of the credentials of the delegation of the Fascist regime in Chile and also of the representatives of the puppet regime established by the Americans in Grenada.
8.	The representative of China stated that the General Assembly at previous sessions had taken correct decisions on the legitimacy of the credentials of the delegation of Democratic Kampuchea. The validity of the credentials of the delegation of Democratic Kampuchea should naturally be reaffirmed by the General Assembly at the current special session. However, in view of the reservations expressed on this matter by a certain delegation, the Chinese delegation had to state its position once again. The Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea with Prince Norodom Sihanouk as its President was the sole legitimate Government of Kampuchea. It was gaining ever broader support in the world as evidenced by the result of the vote on the resolution on the situation in Kampuchea at the fortieth session of the General Assembly. According to the Charter of the United Nations and the norms of international law, foreign aggression against Kampuchea should in no way change the legal status of that country. The puppet régime headed by Heng Samrin was installed through Vietnamese aggression and was therefore illegal. It in no way represented the Kampuchean people. In view of these facts the Chinese delegation reaffirmed its acceptance of the credentials of the representatives of Democratic Kampuchea.
9.	The same representative reiterated the Chinese delegation’s position with regard to the credentials of the representatives of Afghanistan. The fact that the representatives of Afghanistan had been allowed to participate
in the current special session should not in any way be interpreted as an acquiescence in the situation created by the foreign armed invasion and occupation of Afghanistan.
10.	The representative of the United States of America stated that his delegation wished to associate itself with the statement made by the representative of China regarding the credentials of the representatives of Democratic Kampuchea. Those credentials were in order,'they fulfilled the requirements of the rules of procedure, they had been accepted at previous sessions of the General Assembly and should be accepted at the current special session. The substance of the situation in the country would be debated at a later stage in an appropriate forum.
11.	The same representative stated that it was regrettable that the Soviet delegation had felt compelled to challenge the credentials of the delegation of Chile. Those credentials were obviously in order and there was no basis whatsoever for questioning their validity. The statement made by the representative of the Soviet Union merely reflected the Soviet Union’s dislike of the Government of Chile. That was not a responsible approach to the conduct of international relations. The same representative added that as in the past the United States delegation had not raised any objection to the credentials of the representatives of Afghanistan but that in order not to delay the work of the Committee was not to be interpreted as acquiescence in the situation that existed as a result of the foreign aggression from the Soviet Union.
12.	The representative of the United States stated further that the credentials of the delegation of Grenada were completely in order and there was no basis in fact or in law for the objection raised by the Soviet delegation regarding those credentials.
13.	The representative of Canada stated that his delegation’s guiding principle was that the Credentials Committee should concern itself with the technical aspects of the credentials referred to the Committee. On the basis of information provided to the Committee the credentials of the representatives of Democratic Kampuchea appeared to be in order. Canada accepted the credentials of delegations for technical reasons and not for foreign policy considerations. The credentials of the representatives of Democratic Kampuchea had been accepted at previous sessions of the General Assembly and there was no basis for a departure from past practice. The same representative added that the credentials of the delegations of Chile and Grenada also appeared to be in order and there were thus no grounds for adopting a different approach at the current special session than at previous sessions. The Canadian delegation also had no objection to the credentials of the delegation of Afghanistan for the same reason. Acceptance of these credentials and of others before the Committee by the Canadian delegation was not intended to imply any foreign policy position.
14.	The representative of Brazil stated that in the view of his delegation all credentials submitted by delegations and referred to the Committee were in order and should be accepted.
15.	The representative of the Soviet Union stated that the statements made by certain representatives regarding Afghanistan was an attempt to distort historical and political reality. Those assertions could not alter the fact that the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan existed, acted in the international arena as a sovereign, non-aligned State and was a full and equal Member of the United Nations. The ill-intentioned remarks made in the Committee represented an inadmissible attempt to interfere in the internal affairs of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan. Such action was contrary to the Charter
of the United Nations and to the interests of normalizing the situation in South-West Asia and to ensuring favourable conditions for the talks being held through the intermediary of the personal representative of the Secretary-General.
16.	The Chairman proposed that, taking into account the statements that had been made by members of the Committee which would be reflected in the Committee’s report, the Committee should adopt the following draft resolution: >
“The Credentials Committee, .
“Having examined the credentials of the representatives to the thirteenth special session of the General Assembly of the Member States referred to in paragraph ,4 (a) to (d) of its report,
“Taking into account the reservations expressed by delegations during the debate,
“Accepts these credentials, it being understood that credentials in proper form for representatives of all Member States participating in the special session and for whom formal credentials have not been submitted
will be communicated to the Secretary-General as soon as possible.” ■
17.	The draft resolution proposed by the Chairman was adopted without a vote.
18.	The Chairman then proposed that the Committee recommend to the General Assembly the adoption of a draft resolution (see para. 20 below). The proposal was adopted without a vote.
19.	In the light of the foregoing, the present report is submitted to the General Assembly. '	' ;
Recommendation of the Credentials Committee
20.	The Credentials Committee recommends to the General Assembly the adoption of the following draft resolution:
Credentials of representatives to the thirteenth

Report of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session
1.	The General Assembly, at its 1st plenary meeting, on 27 May 1986, allocated to the Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole of the Thirteenth Special Session the consideration of item 6, entitled “Consideration of the critical economic situation in Africa to focus, in a comprehensive and integrated manner, on the rehabilitation and mediumterm and long-term development problems and challenges facing African countries with a view to promoting and adopting action-oriented and concerted measures”.
2.	The Ad Hoc Committee held three meetings, on 27 and 29 May and 1 June 1986. An account of the Ad Hoc Committee’s discussions is contained in the relevant summary records (A/S-13/AC.1/SR.1-3). A number of informal meetings were also held.

(b)	A letter dated 9 May 1986 from the representative of Morocco to the Secretary-General transmitting a monograph submitted by the Government of Morocco to the special session of the General Assembly on the critical economic situation in Africa (A/AC.229/3).
